events.title: Darcy's Observation and Elizabeth's Confrontation at Lucas Lodge
detailed_summary: Darcy desired to know Elizabeth better and started listening intently to her conversations with others as a preliminary step to engaging her directly.
His focused attention did not go unnoticed by Elizabeth during a large party at Sir William Lucas's home.
Elizabeth questioned Charlotte Lucas about Darcy's behavior, wondering why he was eavesdropping on her talk with Colonel Forster.
Charlotte deflected, saying only Darcy knew his own motives.
Elizabeth declared her intention to confront Darcy if he continued, noting his satirical gaze and her own inclination towards impertinence to preempt feeling intimidated.
Shortly after, Darcy approached their group, though seemingly without intending to speak.
Miss Lucas dared Elizabeth to address Darcy about his listening.
Prompted by the challenge, Elizabeth turned directly to Darcy.
She teasingly asked if he didn't think she had expressed herself well when joking with Colonel Forster about a ball.
Darcy acknowledged her energy but remarked coolly that the subject typically energizes ladies.
Elizabeth retorted that his comment was severe.
Miss Lucas interjected, suggesting it would soon be Elizabeth's turn to be teased and moved towards the piano, signaling Elizabeth should perform.
Elizabeth playfully scolded Charlotte for constantly pushing her to perform publicly, stating she'd rather not, especially for an audience accustomed to expert musicians.
Yielding to Charlotte's persistence, Elizabeth agreed, adding with a pointed look at Darcy a proverb about minding one's own business, implying she would focus on her singing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He began to wish to know more of her; and, as a step towards conversing with her himself, attended to her conversation with others.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And gravely glancing at Mr. Darcy, “There is a very fine old saying, which everybody here is of course familiar with—‘Keep your breath to cool your porridge,’—and I shall keep mine to swell my song.”

events.text_segment:
He began to wish to know more of her; and, as a step towards conversing with her himself, attended to her conversation with others. His doing so drew her notice. It was at Sir William Lucas’s, where a large party were assembled.
“What does Mr. Darcy mean,” said she to Charlotte, “by listening to my conversation with Colonel Forster?”
“That is a question which Mr. Darcy only can answer.”
“But if he does it any more, I shall certainly let him know that I see what he is about. He has a very satirical eye, and if I do not begin by being impertinent myself, I shall soon grow afraid of him.”
On his approaching them soon afterwards, though without seeming to have any intention of speaking, Miss Lucas defied her friend to mention such a subject to him, which immediately provoking Elizabeth to do it, she turned to him and said,—
“Did not you think, Mr. Darcy, that I expressed myself uncommonly well just now, when I was teasing Colonel Forster to give us a ball at Meryton?”
“With great energy; but it is a subject which always makes a lady energetic.”
“You are severe on us.”
“It will be her turn soon to be teased,” said Miss Lucas. “I am going to open the instrument, Eliza, and you know what follows.”
“You are a very strange creature by way of a friend!—always wanting me to play and sing before anybody and everybody! If my vanity had taken a musical turn, you would have been invaluable; but as it is, I would really rather not sit down before those who must be in the habit of hearing the very best performers.” On Miss Lucas’s persevering, however, she added, “Very well; if it must be so, it must.” And gravely glancing at Mr. Darcy, “There is a very fine old saying, which everybody here is of course familiar with—‘Keep your breath to cool your porridge,’—and I shall keep mine to swell my song.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
His observation of her revealed a quick wit and pleasing manner that surprised him. Miss Elizabeth Bennet possessed an ease of conversation he had not expected from someone of her station. Her lively mind and intelligent remarks stood in contrast to the affected airs of many ladies of his acquaintance.

At the next gathering, he positioned himself closer to her circle, catching fragments of her discussions on books and local affairs. Her opinions were delivered with confidence yet without pretension. When she laughed, it was with genuine amusement rather than the practiced titters he had grown weary of in London society.

Darcy found himself drawn to her expressive eyes, which seemed to reflect both intelligence and mischief. Though he maintained his reserved demeanor, he began formulating topics that might engage her interest should an opportunity arise.

When Sir William Lucas attempted to bring them together for a dance, Darcy was momentarily tempted. Yet his pride intervened, reminding him of the impropriety of showing particular attention to someone whose connections were so decidedly beneath his own.

Still, he could not prevent his gaze from following her movements across the room. Her indifference to his status intrigued him; most young ladies were eager to secure his attention, yet she seemed perfectly content without it.

As the evening progressed, Darcy realized with some discomfort that he was developing a genuine interest in Elizabeth Bennet. This unexpected attraction troubled him, for it conflicted with all his notions of suitable connections. Nevertheless, he resolved to speak with her directly when next they met, if only to confirm that his fascination was merely a passing fancy born of provincial boredom.

events.title: Contrasting Musical Performances and Lively Dancing
detailed_summary: Elizabeth's musical performance was well-received for its pleasantness, although not technically outstanding.
Before she could respond to requests for more songs, her sister Mary eagerly replaced her at the instrument.
Mary, being the least physically attractive sister, had dedicated herself to acquiring knowledge and accomplishments and was always anxious to showcase them.
Lacking natural genius or taste, Mary's diligent practice was marred by vanity, resulting in a pedantic demeanor and conceited manner that undermined her efforts.
Elizabeth's unaffected ease had been more genuinely enjoyed by the listeners, despite her lesser skill.
After performing a lengthy concerto, Mary eventually played simpler Scottish and Irish tunes requested by her younger sisters, earning some gratitude.
The younger Bennet sisters, along with some Lucases and officers, enthusiastically started dancing jigs and reels at one end of the room.
Nearby, Mr. Darcy watched this impromptu dancing with quiet disapproval, feeling it was a poor way to spend an evening that stifled conversation.
He was lost in his critical thoughts, unaware that Sir William Lucas had approached him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Her performance was pleasing, though by no means capital.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Darcy stood near them in silent indignation at such a mode of passing the evening, to the exclusion of all conversation, and was too much engrossed by his own thoughts to perceive that Sir William Lucas was his neighbour, till Sir William thus began:—

events.text_segment:
Her performance was pleasing, though by no means capital. After a song or two, and before she could reply to the entreaties of several that she would sing again, she was eagerly succeeded at the instrument by her sister Mary, who having, in consequence of being the only plain one in the family, worked hard for knowledge and accomplishments, was always impatient for display.
Mary had neither genius nor taste; and though vanity had given her application, it had given her likewise a pedantic air and conceited manner, which would have injured a higher degree of excellence than she had reached. Elizabeth, easy and unaffected, had been listened to with much more pleasure, though not playing half so well; and Mary, at the end of a long concerto, was glad to purchase praise and gratitude by Scotch and Irish airs, at the request of her younger sisters, who with some of the Lucases, and two or three officers, joined eagerly in dancing at one end of the room.
Mr. Darcy stood near them in silent indignation at such a mode of passing the evening, to the exclusion of all conversation, and was too much engrossed by his own thoughts to perceive that Sir William Lucas was his neighbour, till Sir William thus began:—

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
After a short interval, another young lady was prevailed upon to play. Elizabeth, having observed Mr. Darcy's attention to her sister's performance, found herself drawn to watch his reaction to this new musician. 

His countenance remained composed, yet she detected a slight shift in his posture—a subtle indication of his critical assessment. When the young lady concluded, polite applause followed, though noticeably less enthusiastic than what had greeted her predecessor.

Elizabeth wondered what standards Mr. Darcy applied to such performances. Did he judge harshly based on comparison to professional musicians, or did he appreciate the earnest efforts of country ladies with varying degrees of training? His sister, she had heard, was accomplished at the pianoforte—perhaps this colored his expectations.

As conversation resumed around her, Elizabeth considered how musical ability seemed to be among the many accomplishments expected of genteel women. Yet she preferred genuine enjoyment of music over technical perfection without passion. She glanced again at Mr. Darcy, curious whether a man so apparently concerned with propriety might share such a view, or if his standards remained as rigid as his demeanor often suggested.

events.title: Awkward Exchange, Failed Matchmaking, and Darcy's Surprising Admission
detailed_summary: Sir William Lucas initiated conversation with Darcy, praising dancing as a refined amusement.
Darcy responded curtly, noting dancing's popularity extends even to 'uncivilized' societies.
Sir William, after a pause, complimented Mr. Bingley's dancing and assumed Darcy was also proficient.
Darcy confirmed Sir William saw him dance at Meryton but stated he never dances at St. James's (a fashionable London venue).
Sir William's attempts at further conversation about London society were met with minimal response, a bow being Darcy's only reply to a question about having a town house.
As Sir William paused hoping for a reply, he noticed Elizabeth approaching and decided on a 'gallant' gesture.
He called out to Elizabeth, asking why she wasn't dancing, and attempted to present her to Darcy as a partner, insisting Darcy couldn't refuse such beauty.
Sir William took Elizabeth's hand to give to Darcy, who, though surprised, seemed willing.
Elizabeth immediately pulled her hand back, firmly telling Sir William she had no intention of dancing and hadn't approached to find a partner.
Darcy politely requested the honour of her hand, but Elizabeth remained resolute, unmoved by Sir William's persuasive attempts.
Elizabeth deflected Sir William's flattery about her dancing skill and Darcy's politeness with a smile and turned away.
Her refusal didn't negatively impact Darcy's opinion; he was contemplating her with some satisfaction when Miss Bingley interrupted.
Miss Bingley assumed Darcy was reflecting on the 'insupportable' nature of the party and its guests, expressing her own annoyance.
Darcy corrected her, stating his thoughts were more pleasant: he was meditating on the pleasure afforded by a pretty woman's fine eyes.
Miss Bingley pressed him to identify the woman who inspired such thoughts.
Darcy boldly named Miss Elizabeth Bennet.
Astonished, Miss Bingley questioned how long Elizabeth had been his favourite and sarcastically asked when she should congratulate him on an engagement.
Darcy dryly remarked on the rapidity of a lady's imagination, jumping from admiration to marriage.
Miss Bingley continued her sarcastic teasing about Elizabeth's family becoming his relations.
Darcy remained perfectly indifferent to her barbs, his composure reassuring Miss Bingley that he wasn't serious, allowing her to continue her witty remarks.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What a charming amusement for young people this is, Mr. Darcy! There is nothing like dancing, after all. I consider it as one of the first refinements of polished societies.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He listened to her with perfect indifference, while she chose to entertain herself in this manner; and as his composure convinced her that all was safe, her wit flowed along.

events.text_segment:
“What a charming amusement for young people this is, Mr. Darcy! There is nothing like dancing, after all. I consider it as one of the first refinements of polished societies.”
“Certainly, sir; and it has the advantage also of being in vogue amongst the less polished societies of the world: every savage can dance.”
Sir William only smiled. “Your friend performs delightfully,” he continued, after a pause, on seeing Bingley join the group; “and I doubt not that you are an adept in the science yourself, Mr. Darcy.”
“You saw me dance at Meryton, I believe, sir.”
“Yes, indeed, and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight. Do you often dance at St. James’s?”
“Never, sir.”
“Do you not think it would be a proper compliment to the place?”
“It is a compliment which I never pay to any place if I can avoid it.”
“You have a house in town, I conclude?”
Mr. Darcy bowed.
“I had once some thoughts of fixing in town myself, for I am fond of superior society; but I did not feel quite certain that the air of London would agree with Lady Lucas.”
He paused in hopes of an answer: but his companion was not disposed to make any; and Elizabeth at that instant moving towards them, he was struck with the notion of doing a very gallant thing, and called out to her,—
“My dear Miss Eliza, why are not you dancing? Mr. Darcy, you must allow me to present this young lady to you as a very desirable partner. You cannot refuse to dance, I am sure, when so much beauty is before you.” And, taking her hand, he would have given it to Mr. Darcy, who, though extremely surprised, was not unwilling to receive it, when she instantly drew back, and said with some discomposure to Sir William,—
“Indeed, sir, I have not the least intention of dancing. I entreat you not to suppose that I moved this way in order to beg for a partner.”
Mr. Darcy, with grave propriety, requested to be allowed the honour of her hand, but in vain. Elizabeth was determined; nor did Sir William at all shake her purpose by his attempt at persuasion.
“You excel so much in the dance, Miss Eliza, that it is cruel to deny me the happiness of seeing you; and though this gentleman dislikes the amusement in general, he can have no objection, I am sure, to oblige us for one half hour.”
“Mr. Darcy is all politeness,” said Elizabeth, smiling.
“He is, indeed: but considering the inducement, my dear Miss Eliza, we cannot wonder at his complaisance; for who would object to such a partner?”
Elizabeth looked archly, and turned away. Her resistance had not injured her with the gentleman, and he was thinking of her with some complacency, when thus accosted by Miss Bingley,—
“I can guess the subject of your reverie.”
“I should imagine not.”
“You are considering how insupportable it would be to pass many evenings in this manner,—in such society; and, indeed, I am quite of your opinion. I was never more annoyed! The insipidity, and yet the noise—the nothingness, and yet the self-importance, of all these people! What would I give to hear your strictures on them!”
“Your conjecture is totally wrong, I assure you. My mind was more agreeably engaged. I have been meditating on the very great pleasure which a pair of fine eyes in the face of a pretty woman can bestow.”
Miss Bingley immediately fixed her eyes on his face, and desired he would tell her what lady had the credit of inspiring such reflections. Mr. Darcy replied, with great intrepidity,—
“Miss Elizabeth Bennet.”
“Miss Elizabeth Bennet!” repeated Miss Bingley. “I am all astonishment. How long has she been such a favourite? and pray when am I to wish you joy?”
“That is exactly the question which I expected you to ask. A lady’s imagination is very rapid; it jumps from admiration to love, from love to matrimony, in a moment. I knew you would be wishing me joy.”
“Nay, if you are so serious about it, I shall consider the matter as absolutely settled. You will have a charming mother-in-law, indeed, and of course she will be always at Pemberley with you.”
He listened to her with perfect indifference, while she chose to entertain herself in this manner; and as his composure convinced her that all was safe, her wit flowed along.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: "What a charming amusement for young people this is, Mr. Darcy! There is nothing like dancing, after all. I consider it as one of the first refinements of polished societies."

"Certainly, sir; and it has the advantage also of being in vogue amongst the less polished societies of the world. Every savage can dance."

Sir William only smiled. "Your friend performs delightfully," he continued after a pause, on seeing Bingley join the group; "and I doubt not that you are an adept in the science yourself, Mr. Darcy."

"You saw me dance at Meryton, I believe, sir."

"Yes, indeed, and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight. Do you often dance at St. James's?"

"Never, sir."

"Do you not think it would be a proper compliment to the place?"

"It is a compliment which I never pay to any place if I can avoid it."

"You have a house in town, I conclude?"

Mr. Darcy bowed.

"I had once had some thought of fixing in town myself—for I am fond of superior society; but I did not feel quite certain that the air of London would agree with Lady Lucas."

He paused in hopes of an answer; but his companion was not disposed to make any; and Elizabeth at that instant moving towards them, he was struck with the action of doing a very gallant thing, and called out to her:

"My dear Miss Eliza, why are you not dancing? Mr. Darcy, you must allow me to present this young lady to you as a very desirable partner. You cannot refuse to dance, I am sure, when so much beauty is before you." And, taking her hand, he would have given it to Mr. Darcy who, though extremely surprised, was not unwilling to receive it, when she instantly drew back, and said with some discomposure to Sir William:

"Indeed, sir, I have not the least intention of dancing. I entreat you not to suppose that I moved this way in order to beg for a partner."

Mr. Darcy, with grave propriety, requested to be allowed the honour of her hand, but in vain. Elizabeth was determined; nor did Sir William at all shake her purpose by his attempt at persuasion.

"You excel so much in the dance, Miss Eliza, that it is cruel to deny me the happiness of seeing you; and though this gentleman dislikes the amusement in general, he can have no objection, I am sure, to oblige us for one half-hour."

"Mr. Darcy is all politeness," said Elizabeth, smiling.

"He is, indeed; but, considering the inducement, my dear Miss Eliza, we cannot wonder at his complaisance—for who would object to such a partner?"

Elizabeth looked archly, and turned away. Her resistance had not injured her with the gentleman, and he was thinking of her with some complacency, when thus accosted by Miss Bingley:

"I can guess the subject of your reverie."

"I should imagine not."

"You are considering how insupportable it would be to pass many evenings in this manner—in such society; and indeed I am quite of your opinion. I was never more annoyed! The insipidity, and yet the noise—the nothingness, and yet the self-importance of all those people! What would I give to hear your strictures on them!"

"Your conjecture is totally wrong, I assure you. My mind was more agreeably engaged. I have been meditating on the very great pleasure which a pair of fine eyes in the face of a pretty woman can bestow."

Miss Bingley immediately fixed her eyes on his face, and desired he would tell her what lady had the credit of inspiring such reflections. Mr. Darcy replied with great intrepidity:

"Miss Elizabeth Bennet."

"Miss Elizabeth Bennet!" repeated Miss Bingley. "I am all astonishment. How long has she been such a favourite?—and pray, when am I to wish you joy?"

"That is exactly the question which I expected you to ask. A lady's imagination is very rapid; it jumps from admiration to love, from love to matrimony, in a moment. I knew you would be wishing me joy."

"Nay, if you are serious about it, I shall consider the matter is absolutely settled. You will be having a charming mother-in-law, indeed; and, of course, she will always be at Pemberley with you."

He listened to her with perfect indifference while she chose to entertain herself in this manner; and as his composure convinced her that all was safe, her wit flowed long.

events.title: Bennet Family Finances and the Meryton Distraction
characters: Bennet daughters (Jane, Elizabeth, Mary, Catherine, Lydia)
detailed_summary: The Bennet family's financial situation is outlined, highlighting the entailment of Mr. Bennet's estate away from his daughters and the relative insufficiency of Mrs. Bennet's inheritance.
Mrs. Bennet's family background is mentioned, including her sister married to Mr. Philips (who took over their father's attorney business) and a brother in trade in London.
The close proximity of Longbourn to Meryton makes it a frequent destination for the Bennet sisters, particularly the youngest two, Catherine and Lydia.
Catherine and Lydia's visits to their Aunt Philips and a local milliner are described as a way to fill their vacant time and gather news.
The recent arrival of a militia regiment in Meryton for the winter has become the primary source of excitement and news for Catherine and Lydia.
Their visits to Mrs. Philips yield much information about the officers, including names, connections, and lodging locations.
Mr. Philips' acquaintance with the officers provides his nieces unprecedented access and happiness.
Catherine and Lydia become completely preoccupied with the officers, finding even Mr. Bingley's wealth insignificant compared to a military uniform.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Bennet's property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two thousand a year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was entailed, in default of heirs male, on a distant relation; and their mother’s fortune, though ample for her situation in life, could but ill supply the deficiency of his.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They could talk of nothing but officers; and Mr. Bingley’s large fortune, the mention of which gave animation to their mother, was worthless in their eyes when opposed to the regimentals of an ensign.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Bennet's property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two thousand a year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was entailed, in default of heirs male, on a distant relation; and their mother’s fortune, though ample for her situation in life, could but ill supply the deficiency of his. Her father had been an attorney in Meryton, and had left her four thousand pounds.
She had a sister married to a Mr. Philips, who had been a clerk to their father and succeeded him in the business, and a brother settled in London in a respectable line of trade.
The village of Longbourn was only one mile from Meryton; a most convenient distance for the young ladies, who were usually tempted thither three or four times a week, to pay their duty to their aunt, and to a milliner’s shop just over the way. The two youngest of the family, Catherine and Lydia, were particularly frequent in these attentions: their minds were more vacant than their sisters’, and when nothing better offered, a walk to Meryton was necessary to amuse their morning hours and furnish conversation for the evening; and, however bare of news the country in general might be, they always contrived to learn some from their aunt. At present, indeed, they were well supplied both with news and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in the neighbourhood; it was to remain the whole winter, and Meryton was the head-quarters.
Their visits to Mrs. Philips were now productive of the most interesting intelligence. Every day added something to their knowledge of the officers’ names and connections. Their lodgings were not long a secret, and at length they began to know the officers themselves. Mr. Philips visited them all, and this opened to his nieces a source of felicity unknown before. They could talk of nothing but officers; and Mr. Bingley’s large fortune, the mention of which gave animation to their mother, was worthless in their eyes when opposed to the regimentals of an ensign.

At present, indeed, they were well supplied both with news and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in the neighbourhood; it was to remain the whole winter, and Meryton was the headquarters.

events.title: Parental Disagreement Over Daughters' Silliness
detailed_summary: Mr. Bennet overhears his youngest daughters' enthusiastic talk about officers and declares them to be two of the silliest girls in the country.
Catherine is visibly upset by his remark and falls silent.
Lydia, however, remains unfazed and continues discussing Captain Carter, whom she hopes to see before he leaves for London.
Mrs. Bennet expresses shock at Mr. Bennet's willingness to criticize their own children.
Mr. Bennet retorts that if his children are silly, he should acknowledge it.
Mrs. Bennet insists all their daughters are very clever.
Mr. Bennet states this is the only point on which they disagree, firmly believing their two youngest are exceptionally foolish.
Mrs. Bennet argues that young girls cannot be expected to have their parents' sense yet, recalling her own past fondness for soldiers.
She adds that she would happily approve if a wealthy colonel wanted to marry one of her daughters, mentioning Colonel Forster favorably.
Lydia interjects with gossip from her aunt about Colonel Forster and Captain Carter spending less time with Miss Watson and more time at Clarke's library.
A footman interrupts with a note for Jane from Netherfield, halting Mrs. Bennet's reply.
Mrs. Bennet excitedly urges Jane to read the note quickly.
Jane identifies the sender as Miss Bingley and proceeds to read the contents aloud.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After listening one morning to their effusions on this subject, Mr. Bennet coolly observed,—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Caroline Bingley.”

events.text_segment:
After listening one morning to their effusions on this subject, Mr. Bennet coolly observed,—
“From all that I can collect by your manner of talking, you must be two of the silliest girls in the country. I have suspected it some time, but I am now convinced.”
Catherine was disconcerted, and made no answer; but Lydia, with perfect indifference, continued to express her admiration of Captain Carter, and her hope of seeing him in the course of the day, as he was going the next morning to London.
“I am astonished, my dear,” said Mrs. Bennet, “that you should be so ready to think your own children silly. If I wished to think slightingly of anybody’s children, it should not be of my own, however.”
“If my children are silly, I must hope to be always sensible of it.”
“Yes; but as it happens, they are all of them very clever.”
“This is the only point, I flatter myself, on which we do not agree. I had hoped that our sentiments coincided in every particular, but I must so far differ from you as to think our two youngest daughters uncommonly foolish.”
“My dear Mr. Bennet, you must not expect such girls to have the sense of their father and mother. When they get to our age, I dare say they will not think about officers any more than we do. I remember the time when I liked a red coat myself very well—and, indeed, so I do still at my heart; and if a smart young colonel, with five or six thousand a year, should want one of my girls, I shall not say nay to him; and I thought Colonel Forster looked very becoming the other night at Sir William’s in his regimentals.”
“Mamma,” cried Lydia, “my aunt says that Colonel Forster and Captain Carter do not go so often to Miss Watson’s as they did when they first came; she sees them now very often standing in Clarke’s library.”
Mrs. Bennet was prevented replying by the entrance of the footman with a note for Miss Bennet; it came from Netherfield, and the servant waited for an answer. Mrs. Bennet’s eyes sparkled with pleasure, and she was eagerly calling out, while her daughter read,—
“Well, Jane, who is it from? What is it about? What does he say? Well, Jane, make haste and tell us; make haste, my love.”
“It is from Miss Bingley,” said Jane, and then read it aloud.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
After listening one morning to their effusions on this subject, Mr. Bennet coolly observed,—

"From all that I can collect by your manner of talking, you must be two of the silliest girls in the country. I have suspected it some time, but I am now convinced."

Mrs. Bennet was indignant at this characterization of her daughters and quickly came to their defense, insisting that they were merely showing proper enthusiasm for the prospects of good society.

"My dear Mr. Bennet," she replied, "how can you speak so of your own children? You take delight in vexing me. You have no compassion for my poor nerves."

"You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for your nerves. They are my old friends. I have heard you mention them with consideration these last twenty years at least."

"Ah, you do not know what I suffer," said Mrs. Bennet with a dramatic sigh.

Mr. Bennet returned to his book with a slight smile, while Kitty and Lydia continued their animated discussion of officers' uniforms, undeterred by their father's criticism. Elizabeth, observing this familiar scene, exchanged a knowing glance with Jane, both sisters accustomed to the particular dynamics of their household.

Later that day, as Elizabeth walked in the garden, she reflected on her father's words. Though delivered with his characteristic dry wit, there was truth in his assessment. Her younger sisters' preoccupation with officers and balls did indeed border on the ridiculous at times. Yet she wondered if her father's detached amusement was the proper response to guide them toward more sensible behavior.

The sound of approaching footsteps interrupted her thoughts. It was Jane, coming to join her with news that their aunt Phillips had sent an invitation for them to dine the following evening.

"And you can be certain," Jane added with a gentle smile, "that Lydia has already confirmed that several officers will be present."

Elizabeth laughed. "Then we shall have peace at home for at least a day, as they plan their conquest of the militia."

The sisters continued their walk, discussing the upcoming dinner and the likelihood that their mother would use the occasion to further her matchmaking schemes.

events.title: Jane Invited to Netherfield; Mrs. Bennet Devises a Plan
detailed_summary: Miss Bingley's note playfully invites Jane to dine at Netherfield to prevent boredom between herself and Louisa Hurst.
The note specifies that Mr. Bingley and the other gentlemen will be dining out with the officers.
Lydia exclaims surprise that her aunt hadn't shared this detail about the officers dining out.
Mrs. Bennet laments that the gentlemen are dining out, seeing it as unfortunate for Jane's visit.
Jane asks if she can use the carriage to go to Netherfield.
Mrs. Bennet advises Jane to go on horseback instead, citing the likelihood of rain, which would necessitate her staying overnight.
Elizabeth remarks that this plan only works if the Bingleys don't offer to send Jane home.
Mrs. Bennet counters that Mr. Bingley's chaise will be used by the gentlemen going to Meryton, and the Hursts lack their own horses.
Jane expresses a preference for the coach.
Mrs. Bennet insists Mr. Bennet needs the horses for the farm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “My dear friend,
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They are wanted in the farm, Mr. Bennet, are not they?”

events.text_segment:
“My dear friend,
“If you are not so compassionate as to dine to-day with Louisa and me, we shall be in danger of hating each other for the rest of our lives; for a whole day’s tête-à-tête between two women can never end without a quarrel. Come as soon as you can on the receipt of this. My brother and the gentlemen are to dine with the officers. Yours ever,
“Caroline Bingley.”
“With the officers!” cried Lydia: “I wonder my aunt did not tell us of that.”
“Dining out,” said Mrs. Bennet; “that is very unlucky.”
“Can I have the carriage?” said Jane.
“No, my dear, you had better go on horseback, because it seems likely to rain; and then you must stay all night.”
“That would be a good scheme,” said Elizabeth, “if you were sure that they would not offer to send her home.”
“Oh, but the gentlemen will have Mr. Bingley’s chaise to go to Meryton; and the Hursts have no horses to theirs.”
“I had much rather go in the coach.”
“But, my dear, your father cannot spare the horses, I am sure. They are wanted in the farm, Mr. Bennet, are not they?”

events.title: Jane Departs on Horseback Amidst Rain
detailed_summary: Mr. Bennet confirms the horses are frequently needed on the farm.
Elizabeth points out that if the horses *are* available today, her mother's plan (sending Jane on horseback) will succeed.
Elizabeth eventually gets her father to admit the horses are indeed engaged elsewhere.
Consequently, Jane must travel on horseback.
Mrs. Bennet sees Jane off, cheerfully predicting bad weather.
Her prediction comes true; it begins to rain heavily shortly after Jane leaves.
Jane's sisters worry about her, but Mrs. Bennet is pleased.
The rain persists throughout the evening, making Jane's return impossible.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “They are wanted in the farm much oftener than I can get them.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Jane certainly could not come back.

events.text_segment:
“They are wanted in the farm much oftener than I can get them.”
“But if you have got them to-day,” said Elizabeth, “my mother’s purpose will be answered.”
She did at last extort from her father an acknowledgment that the horses were engaged; Jane was therefore obliged to go on horseback, and her mother attended her to the door with many cheerful prognostics of a bad day. Her hopes were answered; Jane had not been gone long before it rained hard. Her sisters were uneasy for her, but her mother was delighted. The rain continued the whole evening without intermission; Jane certainly could not come back.

events.title: News Arrives: Jane is Unwell at Netherfield
detailed_summary: Mrs. Bennet repeatedly congratulates herself on her scheme, taking credit for the rain.
She remains unaware of the full consequences until the following morning.
Shortly after breakfast, a servant from Netherfield arrives with a note for Elizabeth.
The note is from Jane, explaining she feels very unwell, likely due to getting soaked the previous day.
Jane writes that her hosts insist she stay until she recovers and that they will have Mr. Jones, the apothecary, see her.
She reassures Elizabeth not to worry, stating she only has a sore throat and headache.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “This was a lucky idea of mine, indeed!” said Mrs. Bennet, more than once, as if the credit of making it rain were all her own.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Yours, etc.”

events.text_segment:
“This was a lucky idea of mine, indeed!” said Mrs. Bennet, more than once, as if the credit of making it rain were all her own. Till the next morning, however, she was not aware of all the felicity of her contrivance. Breakfast was scarcely over when a servant from Netherfield brought the following note for Elizabeth:—
“My dearest Lizzie,
“I find myself very unwell this morning, which, I suppose, is to be imputed to my getting wet through yesterday. My kind friends will not hear of my returning home till I am better. They insist also on my seeing Mr. Jones—therefore do not be alarmed if you should hear of his having been to me—and, excepting a sore throat and a headache, there is not much the matter with me.
“Yours, etc.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: "This was a lucky idea of mine, indeed!" said Mrs. Bennet, more than once, as if the credit of making it rain were all her own. Till the next morning, however, she was not aware of all the felicity of her contrivance. Breakfast was scarcely over when a servant from Netherfield brought the following note for Elizabeth:

"MY DEAREST LIZZY,—
"I find myself very unwell this morning, which, I suppose, is to be imputed to my getting wet through yesterday. My kind friends will not hear of my returning till I am better. They insist also on my seeing Mr. Jones—therefore do not be alarmed if you should hear of his having been to me—and, excepting a sore throat and headache, there is not much the matter with me.
"Yours, etc."

"Well, my dear," said Mr. Bennet, when Elizabeth had read the note aloud, "if your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness—if she should die, it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of Mr. Bingley, and under your directions."

"Oh! I am not afraid of her dying. People do not die of little trifling colds. She will be taken good care of. As long as she stays there, it is all very well. I would go and see her if I could have the carriage."

Elizabeth, feeling really anxious, was determined to go to her, though the carriage was not to be had; and as she was no horsewoman, walking was her only alternative. She declared her resolution.

"How can you be so silly," cried her mother, "as to think of such a thing, in all this dirt! You will not be fit to be seen when you get there."

"I shall be very fit to see Jane—which is all I want."

"Is this a hint to me, Lizzy," said her father, "to send for the horses?"

"No, indeed, I do not wish to avoid the walk. The distance is nothing when one has a motive; only three miles. I shall be back by dinner."

events.title: Elizabeth Resolves to Walk to Netherfield
detailed_summary: After Elizabeth reads Jane's note, Mr. Bennet sarcastically remarks to his wife that it would be comforting to know Jane's potential death was due to her scheme to catch Mr. Bingley.
Mrs. Bennet dismisses his concern, asserting that people don't die from minor colds and that Jane will receive good care at Netherfield.
She expresses a wish to visit Jane herself if only the carriage were available.
Elizabeth, feeling genuine anxiety for Jane, decides to go to Netherfield immediately.
Since the carriage is unavailable and she isn't a skilled rider, walking is her only option.
Mrs. Bennet objects, calling the idea silly due to the muddy conditions and worrying how Elizabeth will appear upon arrival.
Elizabeth retorts that her appearance doesn't matter; seeing Jane is her only goal.
Mr. Bennet asks if this is a hint for him to arrange for the horses.
Elizabeth confirms it is not, stating the three-mile distance is manageable given her motivation, and she plans to return by dinner.
Mary offers a pedantic observation about tempering emotional impulses with reason and proportioning exertion to the need.
Catherine and Lydia offer to walk with Elizabeth as far as Meryton.
Elizabeth agrees, and the three sisters depart.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet, when Elizabeth had read the note aloud, “if your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness—if she should die—it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of Mr. Bingley, and under your orders.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth accepted their company, and the three young ladies set off together.

events.text_segment:
“Well, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet, when Elizabeth had read the note aloud, “if your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness—if she should die—it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of Mr. Bingley, and under your orders.”
“Oh, I am not at all afraid of her dying. People do not die of little trifling colds. She will be taken good care of. As long as she stays there, it is all very well. I would go and see her if I could have the carriage.”
Elizabeth, feeling really anxious, determined to go to her, though the carriage was not to be had: and as she was no horsewoman, walking was her only alternative. She declared her resolution.
“How can you be so silly,” cried her mother, “as to think of such a thing, in all this dirt! You will not be fit to be seen when you get there.”
“I shall be very fit to see Jane—which is all I want.”
“Is this a hint to me, Lizzy,” said her father, “to send for the horses?”
“No, indeed. I do not wish to avoid the walk. The distance is nothing, when one has a motive; only three miles. I shall be back by dinner.”
“I admire the activity of your benevolence,” observed Mary, “but every impulse of feeling should be guided by reason; and, in my opinion, exertion should always be in proportion to what is required.”
“We will go as far as Meryton with you,” said Catherine and Lydia. Elizabeth accepted their company, and the three young ladies set off together.

events.title: Elizabeth's Muddy Arrival and Reception at Netherfield
detailed_summary: During the walk, Lydia hopes they might encounter Captain Carter before his departure.
The sisters part ways in Meryton; Catherine and Lydia go to visit an officer's wife, while Elizabeth continues alone towards Netherfield.
Elizabeth walks briskly across fields, navigating obstacles with determined energy.
She arrives at Netherfield feeling tired, with dirty stockings and ankles, and flushed from the exertion.
Elizabeth is shown into the breakfast room where everyone except Jane is gathered.
Her appearance causes considerable surprise, especially to Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley, who are incredulous that she walked three miles alone in bad weather.
Elizabeth senses their disapproval and contempt regarding her state.
Despite this, the Bingley sisters receive her politely.
Mr. Bingley greets her with genuine warmth and kindness, exceeding mere politeness.
Mr. Darcy remains quiet, internally conflicted between admiration for her healthy glow and doubt about the propriety of her solitary journey.
Mr. Hurst says nothing, preoccupied with his meal.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “If we make haste,” said Lydia, as they walked along, “perhaps we may see something of Captain Carter, before he goes.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The latter was thinking only of his breakfast.

events.text_segment:
“If we make haste,” said Lydia, as they walked along, “perhaps we may see something of Captain Carter, before he goes.”
In Meryton they parted: the two youngest repaired to the lodgings of one of the officers’ wives, and Elizabeth continued her walk alone, crossing field after field at a quick pace, jumping over stiles and springing over puddles, with impatient activity, and finding herself at last within view of the house, with weary ancles, dirty stockings, and a face glowing with the warmth of exercise.
She was shown into the breakfast parlour, where all but Jane were assembled, and where her appearance created a great deal of surprise. That she should have walked three miles so early in the day in such dirty weather, and by herself, was almost incredible to Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley; and Elizabeth was convinced that they held her in contempt for it. She was received, however, very politely by them; and in their brother’s manners there was something better than politeness—there was good-humour and kindness. Mr. Darcy said very little, and Mr. Hurst nothing at all. The former was divided between admiration of the brilliancy which exercise had given to her complexion and doubt as to the occasion’s justifying her coming so far alone. The latter was thinking only of his breakfast.

events.title: Jane's Condition Worsens; Elizabeth Stays at Netherfield
detailed_summary: Elizabeth learns that Jane slept poorly, is feverish, and remains confined to her room.
She is taken to Jane immediately.
Jane is overjoyed to see Elizabeth, admitting she had wanted her there but hadn't expressed it fully in her note for fear of causing alarm.
Jane is too unwell for much conversation and mainly expresses gratitude for the kindness she's receiving.
Elizabeth tends to her sister quietly after Miss Bingley leaves them.
Later, the Bingley sisters join them, and their evident affection and concern for Jane somewhat softens Elizabeth's initial impression of them.
The apothecary arrives, diagnoses Jane with a severe cold, advises bed rest, and prescribes medication.
Jane's fever and headache intensify, and she follows the apothecary's advice.
Elizabeth remains constantly by Jane's side.
The Bingley sisters also spend considerable time in the room, as the gentlemen are out, leaving them with little else to do.
At three o'clock, Elizabeth feels she should leave and reluctantly says so.
Miss Bingley offers the use of the carriage.
Before Elizabeth can fully accept, Jane expresses such distress at the thought of her sister leaving that Miss Bingley changes her offer to an invitation for Elizabeth to stay at Netherfield.
Elizabeth gratefully accepts, and a servant is sent to Longbourn to inform the Bennets and retrieve clothing for Elizabeth.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Her inquiries after her sister were not very favourably answered.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth most thankfully consented, and a servant was despatched to Longbourn, to acquaint the family with her stay, and bring back a supply of clothes.

events.text_segment:
Her inquiries after her sister were not very favourably answered. Miss Bennet had slept ill, and though up, was very feverish, and not well enough to leave her room. Elizabeth was glad to be taken to her immediately; and Jane, who had only been withheld by the fear of giving alarm or inconvenience, from expressing in her note how much she longed for such a visit, was delighted at her entrance. She was not equal, however, to much conversation; and when Miss Bingley left them together, could attempt little beside expressions of gratitude for the extraordinary kindness she was treated with. Elizabeth silently attended her.
When breakfast was over, they were joined by the sisters; and Elizabeth began to like them herself, when she saw how much affection and solicitude they showed for Jane. The apothecary came; and having examined his patient, said, as might be supposed, that she had caught a violent cold, and that they must endeavour to get the better of it; advised her to return to bed, and promised her some draughts. The advice was followed readily, for the feverish symptoms increased, and her head ached acutely. Elizabeth did not quit her room for a moment, nor were the other ladies often absent; the gentlemen being out, they had in fact nothing to do elsewhere.
When the clock struck three, Elizabeth felt that she must go, and very unwillingly said so. Miss Bingley offered her the carriage, and she only wanted a little pressing to accept it, when Jane testified such concern at parting with her that Miss Bingley was obliged to convert the offer of the chaise into an invitation to remain at Netherfield for the present. Elizabeth most thankfully consented, and a servant was despatched to Longbourn, to acquaint the family with her stay, and bring back a supply of clothes.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Miss Bingley replied that Jane had slept poorly, and though risen, was feverish and not well enough to leave her room. Elizabeth was glad to be taken to her sister immediately, and Jane, who had only restrained her feelings of illness out of consideration for her hosts, was delighted to see her. She was not, however, inclined to much conversation, and when Miss Bingley left them together, could scarcely speak at all.

When the apothecary came, he confirmed that Jane had caught a violent cold and should remain in bed. This news surprised no one, least of all Elizabeth, who attended her sister diligently throughout the evening. When the ladies retired after dinner, she returned to Jane's room, leaving the gathered party to discuss her.

"She has nothing, in short, to recommend her, but being an excellent walker," said Miss Bingley sharply. "I shall never forget her appearance this morning. She really looked almost wild."

"She did, indeed," agreed Mrs. Hurst. "To walk three miles, or four miles, or five miles, or whatever it was, above her ankles in dirt, and alone, quite alone! What could she mean by it?"

"It shows an affection for her sister that is very pleasing," said Bingley.

"I am afraid, Mr. Darcy," observed Miss Bingley in a half whisper, "that this adventure has rather affected your admiration of her fine eyes."

"Not at all," he replied. "They were brightened by the exercise."

A short silence followed this speech, and Mrs. Hurst began again: "I have an excessive regard for Miss Jane Bennet, she is really a very sweet girl, and I wish with all my heart she were well settled. But with such a father and mother, and such low connections, I am afraid there is no chance of it."

events.title: Dinner Observations and Renewed Disdain
detailed_summary: Before dinner, Elizabeth updates the party on Jane's lack of improvement.
Mr. Bingley shows genuine concern, which Elizabeth appreciates.
The Bingley sisters offer superficial condolences before dismissing the matter, renewing Elizabeth's negative opinion of them.
Elizabeth observes that Mr. Bingley is the only one whose company she finds agreeable due to his evident anxiety for Jane and pleasing attentions to herself.
She notes that Miss Bingley and Mrs. Hurst are preoccupied with Mr. Darcy.
Mr. Hurst, positioned next to Elizabeth, proves to be solely interested in food, drink, and cards, losing all interest in conversing with her upon learning she prefers simple food.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At five o’clock the two ladies retired to dress, and at half-past six Elizabeth was summoned to dinner.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She had very little notice from any but him. Miss Bingley was engrossed by Mr. Darcy, her sister scarcely less so; and as for Mr. Hurst, by whom Elizabeth sat, he was an indolent man, who lived only to eat, drink, and play at cards, who, when he found her prefer a plain dish to a ragout, had nothing to say to her.

events.text_segment:
At five o’clock the two ladies retired to dress, and at half-past six Elizabeth was summoned to dinner. To the civil inquiries which then poured in, and amongst which she had the pleasure of distinguishing the much superior solicitude of Mr. Bingley, she could not make a very favourable answer. Jane was by no means better. The sisters, on hearing this, repeated three or four times how much they were grieved, how shocking it was to have a bad cold, and how excessively they disliked being ill themselves; and then thought no more of the matter: and their indifference towards Jane, when not immediately before them, restored Elizabeth to the enjoyment of all her original dislike.
Their brother, indeed, was the only one of the party whom she could regard with any complacency. His anxiety for Jane was evident, and his attentions to herself most pleasing; and they prevented her feeling herself so much an intruder as she believed she was considered by the others. She had very little notice from any but him. Miss Bingley was engrossed by Mr. Darcy, her sister scarcely less so; and as for Mr. Hurst, by whom Elizabeth sat, he was an indolent man, who lived only to eat, drink, and play at cards, who, when he found her prefer a plain dish to a ragout, had nothing to say to her.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
As Elizabeth entered the dining room, she was greeted by the elegant setting that characterized Rosings Park. Lady Catherine de Bourgh sat at the head of the table with an air of superiority, while her daughter Anne, pale and sickly, sat quietly beside her. Mr. Collins hovered nearby, ready to shower his patroness with excessive compliments.

The dinner was elaborate, with numerous courses served by livered servants. Lady Catherine dominated the conversation, offering her opinions on everything from music to household management. She frequently questioned Elizabeth about her family, education, and accomplishments, seeming surprised at the Bennet sisters' upbringing without a governess.

Elizabeth answered with composure, occasionally allowing her wit to surface despite Mr. Collins's nervous glances whenever she spoke too freely. Charlotte attempted to direct the conversation to more neutral topics, while Mr. Darcy remained mostly silent, though Elizabeth noticed his eyes following her responses with interest.

The evening proceeded with Lady Catherine instructing Elizabeth on proper piano practice, criticizing her technique without having heard her play. Throughout the meal, Elizabeth observed the dynamics between these characters, storing away impressions that would later inform her understanding of Mr. Darcy and his connection to this imposing family.

events.title: Post-Dinner Criticism and Social Commentary
detailed_summary: After Elizabeth leaves the dining room post-dinner to tend to Jane, Miss Bingley immediately criticizes her.
Miss Bingley condemns Elizabeth's manners as a blend of pride and impertinence, lacking conversation, style, taste, and beauty.
Mrs. Hurst concurs, adding Elizabeth's only positive attribute is being a good walker, and recalls her disheveled appearance that morning.
Miss Bingley elaborates on Elizabeth's untidy hair and mud-splattered petticoat from her walk.
Mr. Bingley defends Elizabeth, stating he found her appearance agreeable and hadn't noticed the mud.
Miss Bingley appeals to Mr. Darcy, implying he wouldn't want his own sister appearing in such a state.
Darcy curtly agrees he would not.
Miss Bingley further criticizes the solitary, muddy walk as showing unbecoming independence and lack of decorum.
Bingley interprets the walk as a sign of commendable sisterly affection.
Miss Bingley subtly suggests to Darcy that the sight must have diminished his admiration for Elizabeth's eyes.
Darcy contradicts her, stating the exercise actually made her eyes brighter.

Following a pause, Mrs. Hurst voices concern for Jane's prospects, attributing the difficulty to her parents and low family connections, mentioning an attorney uncle in Meryton and another near Cheapside.
The Bingley sisters laugh derisively at the mention of Cheapside.
Bingley protests that family connections do not lessen the Bennet sisters' agreeableness.
Darcy counters that such connections significantly harm their chances of marrying well.
Bingley offers no reply, while his sisters endorse Darcy's view and mock the Bennets' relations.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When dinner was over, she returned directly to Jane, and Miss Bingley began abusing her as soon as she was out of the room.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: To this speech Bingley made no answer; but his sisters gave it their hearty assent, and indulged their mirth for some time at the expense of their dear friend’s vulgar relations.

events.text_segment:
When dinner was over, she returned directly to Jane, and Miss Bingley began abusing her as soon as she was out of the room. Her manners were pronounced to be very bad indeed,—a mixture of pride and impertinence: she had no conversation, no style, no taste, no beauty. Mrs. Hurst thought the same, and added,—
“She has nothing, in short, to recommend her, but being an excellent walker. I shall never forget her appearance this morning. She really looked almost wild.”
“She did indeed, Louisa. I could hardly keep my countenance. Very nonsensical to come at all! Why must she be scampering about the country, because her sister had a cold? Her hair so untidy, so blowzy!”
“Yes, and her petticoat; I hope you saw her petticoat, six inches deep in mud, I am absolutely certain, and the gown which had been let down to hide it not doing its office.”
“Your picture may be very exact, Louisa,” said Bingley; “but this was all lost upon me. I thought Miss Elizabeth Bennet looked remarkably well when she came into the room this morning. Her dirty petticoat quite escaped my notice.”
“You observed it, Mr. Darcy, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley; “and I am inclined to think that you would not wish to see your sister make such an exhibition.”
“Certainly not.”
“To walk three miles, or four miles, or five miles, or whatever it is, above her ancles in dirt, and alone, quite alone! what could she mean by it? It seems to me to show an abominable sort of conceited independence, a most country-town indifference to decorum.”
“It shows an affection for her sister that is very pleasing,” said Bingley.
“I am afraid, Mr. Darcy,” observed Miss Bingley, in a half whisper, “that this adventure has rather affected your admiration of her fine eyes.”
“Not at all,” he replied: “they were brightened by the exercise.” A short pause followed this speech, and Mrs. Hurst began again,—
“I have an excessive regard for Jane Bennet,—she is really a very sweet girl,—and I wish with all my heart she were well settled. But with such a father and mother, and such low connections, I am afraid there is no chance of it.”
“I think I have heard you say that their uncle is an attorney in Meryton?”
“Yes; and they have another, who lives somewhere near Cheapside.”
“That is capital,” added her sister; and they both laughed heartily.
“If they had uncles enough to fill all Cheapside,” cried Bingley, “it would not make them one jot less agreeable.”
“But it must very materially lessen their chance of marrying men of any consideration in the world,” replied Darcy.
To this speech Bingley made no answer; but his sisters gave it their hearty assent, and indulged their mirth for some time at the expense of their dear friend’s vulgar relations.

"She has nothing, in short, to recommend her, but being an excellent walker. I shall never forget her appearance this morning. She really looked almost wild."

"She did, indeed, Louisa. I could hardly keep my countenance. Very nonsensical to come at all! Why must she be scampering about the country, because her sister had a cold? Her hair, so untidy, so blowsy!"

events.title: Declining Cards for Books and Talk of Pemberley
detailed_summary: The Bingley sisters pay a brief visit to Jane's room after dinner.
Elizabeth stays with Jane until she is asleep, then feels obliged to rejoin the party downstairs.
She finds the others playing the card game loo and is invited to participate.
Suspecting high stakes and citing her need to return to Jane soon, Elizabeth declines, choosing to read a book instead.
Mr. Hurst expresses astonishment at her preferring reading to cards.
Miss Bingley mockingly remarks that Elizabeth despises cards and enjoys nothing but reading.
Elizabeth refutes this, asserting she enjoys many things besides reading.
Mr. Bingley kindly suggests she finds pleasure in nursing her sister and expresses hope for Jane's recovery.
Elizabeth thanks him sincerely and moves towards a table with books.
Bingley offers to retrieve more books from his library, lamenting its modest size.
Elizabeth assures him she can find something suitable among the available books.
Miss Bingley expresses surprise at her father's small collection and pivots to praising Mr. Darcy's impressive library at Pemberley.
Darcy attributes its quality to the efforts of past generations.
Miss Bingley flatters Darcy on his continuous additions to the library.
Darcy states he finds neglecting a family library incomprehensible.
Miss Bingley continues her flattery, praising Pemberley and advising her brother to use it as a model for his own future estate, also complimenting Derbyshire.
Bingley jokingly offers to buy Pemberley if Darcy were selling.
Miss Bingley clarifies she speaks of plausible scenarios.
Bingley retorts that purchasing Pemberley seems more plausible than successfully imitating it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: With a renewal of tenderness, however, they repaired to her room on leaving the dining-parlour, and sat with her till summoned to coffee.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Upon my word, Caroline, I should think it more possible to get Pemberley by purchase than by imitation.”

events.text_segment:
With a renewal of tenderness, however, they repaired to her room on leaving the dining-parlour, and sat with her till summoned to coffee. She was still very poorly, and Elizabeth would not quit her at all, till late in the evening, when she had the comfort of seeing her asleep, and when it appeared to her rather right than pleasant that she should go down stairs herself. On entering the drawing-room, she found the whole party at loo, and was immediately invited to join them; but suspecting them to be playing high, she declined it, and making her sister the excuse, said she would amuse herself, for the short time she could stay below, with a book. Mr. Hurst looked at her with astonishment.
“Do you prefer reading to cards?” said he; “that is rather singular.”
“Miss Eliza Bennet,” said Miss Bingley, “despises cards. She is a great reader, and has no pleasure in anything else.”
“I deserve neither such praise nor such censure,” cried Elizabeth; “I am not a great reader, and I have pleasure in many things.”
“In nursing your sister I am sure you have pleasure,” said Bingley; “and I hope it will soon be increased by seeing her quite well.”
Elizabeth thanked him from her heart, and then walked towards a table where a few books were lying. He immediately offered to fetch her others; all that his library afforded.
“And I wish my collection were larger for your benefit and my own credit; but I am an idle fellow; and though I have not many, I have more than I ever looked into.”
Elizabeth assured him that she could suit herself perfectly with those in the room.
“I am astonished,” said Miss Bingley, “that my father should have left so small a collection of books. What a delightful library you have at Pemberley, Mr. Darcy!”
“It ought to be good,” he replied: “it has been the work of many generations.”
“And then you have added so much to it yourself—you are always buying books.”
“I cannot comprehend the neglect of a family library in such days as these.”
“Neglect! I am sure you neglect nothing that can add to the beauties of that noble place. Charles, when you build your house, I wish it may be half as delightful as Pemberley.”
“I wish it may.”
“But I would really advise you to make your purchase in that neighbourhood, and take Pemberley for a kind of model. There is not a finer county in England than Derbyshire.”
“With all my heart: I will buy Pemberley itself, if Darcy will sell it.”
“I am talking of possibilities, Charles.”
“Upon my word, Caroline, I should think it more possible to get Pemberley by purchase than by imitation.”

events.title: Debating the Definition of an Accomplished Woman
detailed_summary: Intrigued by the conversation, Elizabeth sets aside her book and approaches the card table, standing between Bingley and Miss Bingley.
Miss Bingley asks Darcy about his sister's growth and compares her potential height to Elizabeth's.
Darcy replies that his sister is likely about Elizabeth's height or slightly taller.
Miss Bingley gushes about her fondness for Miss Darcy, praising her manners, accomplishments, and musical talent.
Mr. Bingley expresses wonder at the patience required for young women to become so accomplished.
Miss Bingley challenges his assumption that all young women are accomplished.
Bingley lists common, superficial accomplishments (painting tables, netting purses) and notes how frequently he hears young ladies described as accomplished.
Darcy agrees the term is often applied lightly but asserts he knows very few women—perhaps half a dozen—who are truly accomplished.
Miss Bingley echoes Darcy's sentiment.
Elizabeth observes their definition must be quite demanding.
Darcy confirms it is.
Miss Bingley elaborates on the requirements: thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing, dancing, modern languages, plus an indefinable quality in manner, voice, and expression.
Darcy adds the necessity of intellectual improvement through extensive reading.
Elizabeth remarks she is now surprised Darcy knows even six such women, rather than none.
Darcy questions if she is judging her own sex so harshly as to doubt such a combination is possible.
Elizabeth states she has never personally encountered such a union of capacity, taste, application, and elegance.
Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley protest Elizabeth's skepticism, claiming they know many women who fit the description.
Mr. Hurst interrupts, irritated by their lack of attention to the card game, effectively silencing the discussion.
Elizabeth leaves the room soon after.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth was so much caught by what passed, as to leave her very little attention for her book; and, soon laying it wholly aside, she drew near the card-table, and stationed herself between Mr. Bingley and his eldest sister, to observe the game.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As all conversation was thereby at an end, Elizabeth soon afterwards left the room.

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth was so much caught by what passed, as to leave her very little attention for her book; and, soon laying it wholly aside, she drew near the card-table, and stationed herself between Mr. Bingley and his eldest sister, to observe the game.
“Is Miss Darcy much grown since the spring?” said Miss Bingley: “will she be as tall as I am?”
“I think she will. She is now about Miss Elizabeth Bennet’s height, or rather taller.”
“How I long to see her again! I never met with anybody who delighted me so much. Such a countenance, such manners, and so extremely accomplished for her age! Her performance on the pianoforte is exquisite.”
“It is amazing to me,” said Bingley, “how young ladies can have patience to be so very accomplished as they all are.”
“All young ladies accomplished! My dear Charles, what do you mean?”
“Yes, all of them, I think. They all paint tables, cover screens, and net purses. I scarcely know any one who cannot do all this; and I am sure I never heard a young lady spoken of for the first time, without being informed that she was very accomplished.”
“Your list of the common extent of accomplishments,” said Darcy, “has too much truth. The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no otherwise than by netting a purse or covering a screen; but I am very far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I cannot boast of knowing more than half-a-dozen in the whole range of my acquaintance that are really accomplished.”
“Nor I, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley.
“Then,” observed Elizabeth, “you must comprehend a great deal in your idea of an accomplished woman.”
“Yes; I do comprehend a great deal in it.”
“Oh, certainly,” cried his faithful assistant, “no one can be really esteemed accomplished who does not greatly surpass what is usually met with. A woman must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing, dancing, and the modern languages, to deserve the word; and, besides all this, she must possess a certain something in her air and manner of walking, the tone of her voice, her address and expressions, or the word will be but half deserved.”
“All this she must possess,” added Darcy; “and to all she must yet add something more substantial in the improvement of her mind by extensive reading.”
“I am no longer surprised at your knowing only six accomplished women. I rather wonder now at your knowing any.”
“Are you so severe upon your own sex as to doubt the possibility of all this?”
“I never saw such a woman. I never saw such capacity, and taste, and application, and elegance, as you describe, united.”
Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley both cried out against the injustice of her implied doubt, and were both protesting that they knew many women who answered this description, when Mr. Hurst called them to order, with bitter complaints of their inattention to what was going forward. As all conversation was thereby at an end, Elizabeth soon afterwards left the room.

"I think she will. She is now about Miss Elizabeth Bennet's height, or rather taller."

"How I long to see her again! I never met with anybody who delighted me so much. Such a countenance, such manners! And so extremely accomplished for her age! Her performance on the pianoforte is exquisite."

"It is amazing to me," said Bingley, "how young ladies can have patience to be so very accomplished as they all are."

"All young ladies accomplished! My dear Charles, what do you mean?"

"Yes, all of them, I think. They all paint tables, cover screens, and net purses. I scarcely know anyone who cannot do all this, and I am sure I never heard a young lady spoken of for the first time, without being informed that she was very accomplished."

"Your list of the common extent of accomplishments," said Darcy, "has too much truth. The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no otherwise than by netting a purse or covering a screen. But I am very far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I cannot boast of knowing more than half-a-dozen, in the whole range of my acquaintance, that are really accomplished."

"Nor I, I am sure," said Miss Bingley.

"Then," observed Elizabeth, "you must comprehend a great deal in your idea of an accomplished woman."

"Yes, I do comprehend a great deal in it."

"Oh! certainly," cried his faithful assistant, "no one can be really esteemed accomplished who does not greatly surpass what is usually met with. A woman must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing, dancing, and the modern languages, to deserve the word; and besides all this, she must possess a certain something in her air and manner of walking, the tone of her voice, her address and expressions, or the word will be but half-deserved."

"All this she must possess," added Darcy, "and to all this she must yet add something more substantial, in the improvement of her mind by extensive reading."

"I am no longer surprised at your knowing only six accomplished women. I rather wonder now at your knowing any."

"Are you so severe upon your own sex as to doubt the possibility of all this?"

"I never saw such a woman. I never saw such capacity, and taste, and application, and elegance, as you describe united."

Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley both cried out against the injustice of her implied doubt, and were both protesting that they knew many women who answered this description, when Mr. Hurst called them to order, with bitter complaints of their inattention to what was going forward. As all conversation was thereby at an end, Elizabeth soon afterwards left the room.

events.title: Miss Bingley's Renewed Criticism and Darcy's Ambiguous Rebuke
detailed_summary: Once Elizabeth has left, Miss Bingley remarks to Darcy that Elizabeth employs the tactic of undervaluing women to appeal to men.
She dismisses this perceived strategy as a 'paltry device' and 'mean art'.
Darcy, understanding the comment is directed at him, responds that all manipulative arts used by women for captivation, especially those involving cunning, are contemptible.
His reply does not fully satisfy Miss Bingley, causing her to abandon the topic.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Eliza Bennet,” said Miss Bingley, when the door was closed on her, “is one of those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the other sex by undervaluing their own; and with many men, I daresay, it succeeds; but, in my opinion, it is a paltry device, a very mean art.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Miss Bingley was not so entirely satisfied with this reply as to continue the subject.

events.text_segment:
“Eliza Bennet,” said Miss Bingley, when the door was closed on her, “is one of those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the other sex by undervaluing their own; and with many men, I daresay, it succeeds; but, in my opinion, it is a paltry device, a very mean art.”
“Undoubtedly,” replied Darcy, to whom this remark was chiefly addressed, “there is meanness in all the arts which ladies sometimes condescend to employ for captivation. Whatever bears affinity to cunning is despicable.”
Miss Bingley was not so entirely satisfied with this reply as to continue the subject.

"Whatever bears affinity to cunning is despicable," said Darcy.

Miss Bingley was not so entirely satisfied with this reply as to continue the subject.

events.title: Jane's Worsening Condition and Evening Arrangements
detailed_summary: Elizabeth reappears briefly to inform the party that Jane's condition has deteriorated and she cannot leave her.
Mr. Bingley immediately advocates for sending for Mr. Jones, the apothecary.
The Bingley sisters dismiss the effectiveness of country medical practitioners and suggest sending for a renowned London physician instead.
Elizabeth rejects the London option but consents to Bingley's proposal to call Mr. Jones.
They agree to send for Mr. Jones in the morning if Jane shows no definite improvement.
Bingley expresses significant unease over Jane's condition.
His sisters proclaim their own misery.
Later, the sisters find solace by playing musical duets after supper.
Bingley, seeking a practical outlet for his concern, instructs his housekeeper to ensure the utmost care and attention are provided to both Jane and Elizabeth.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth joined them again only to say that her sister was worse, and that she could not leave her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They solaced their wretchedness, however, by duets after supper; while he could find no better relief to his feelings than by giving his housekeeper directions that every possible attention might be paid to the sick lady and her sister.

events.text_segment: Elizabeth joined them again only to say that her sister was worse, and that she could not leave her. Bingley urged Mr. Jones’s being sent for immediately; while his sisters, convinced that no country advice could be of any service, recommended an express to town for one of the most eminent physicians. This she would not hear of; but she was not so unwilling to comply with their brother’s proposal; and it was settled that Mr. Jones should be sent for early in the morning, if Miss Bennet were not decidedly better. Bingley was quite uncomfortable; his sisters declared that they were miserable. They solaced their wretchedness, however, by duets after supper; while he could find no better relief to his feelings than by giving his housekeeper directions that every possible attention might be paid to the sick lady and her sister.

events.title: Elizabeth Tends to Jane and Sends for Mrs. Bennet
detailed_summary: Elizabeth spends the night caring for her sister, Jane.
In the morning, she reports Jane's condition as tolerable to Mr. Bingley and his sisters via servants.
Despite Jane's improvement, Elizabeth sends a note home requesting their mother visit and judge Jane's situation herself.
The request is quickly fulfilled, and Mrs. Bennet arrives with Lydia and Kitty shortly after breakfast at Netherfield.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth passed the chief of the night in her sister’s room, and in the morning had the pleasure of being able to send a tolerable answer to the inquiries which she very early received from Mr. Bingley by a housemaid, and some time afterwards from the two elegant ladies who waited on his sisters.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mrs. Bennet, accompanied by her two youngest girls, reached Netherfield soon after the family breakfast.

events.text_segment: Elizabeth passed the chief of the night in her sister’s room, and in the morning had the pleasure of being able to send a tolerable answer to the inquiries which she very early received from Mr. Bingley by a housemaid, and some time afterwards from the two elegant ladies who waited on his sisters. In spite of this amendment, however, she requested to have a note sent to Longbourn, desiring her mother to visit Jane, and form her own judgment of her situation. The note was immediately despatched, and its contents as quickly complied with. Mrs. Bennet, accompanied by her two youngest girls, reached Netherfield soon after the family breakfast.

In spite of this amendment, however, she requested to have a note sent to Longbourn, desiring her mother to visit Jane, and form her own judgement of her situation. The note was immediately dispatched, and its contents as quickly complied with. Mrs. Bennet, accompanied by her two youngest girls, reached Netherfield soon after the family breakfast.

Had she found Jane in any apparent danger, Mrs. Bennet would have been very miserable; but being satisfied on seeing her that her illness was not alarming, she had no wish of her recovering immediately, as her restoration to health would probably remove her from Netherfield. She would not listen, therefore, to her daughter's proposal of being carried home; neither did the apothecary, who arrived about the same time, think it at all advisable. After sitting a little while with Jane, on Miss Bingley's appearance and invitation, the mother and three daughters all attended her into the breakfast parlour. Bingley met them with hopes that Mrs. Bennet had not found Miss Bennet worse than she expected.
