LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Elizabeth quietly answered "undoubtedly;" and, after an awkward pause, they returned to the rest of the family. Charlotte greeted them with a knowing smile, while Mrs. Bennet fussed over refreshments. Mr. Darcy stood somewhat apart, his expression unreadable as he observed Elizabeth across the room.

The evening progressed with polite conversation, though Elizabeth found herself distracted. Her thoughts kept returning to their earlier exchange, wondering if she had misunderstood his intentions once again. She caught his gaze several times, each glance carrying unspoken questions.

When the time came for departures, Mr. Darcy approached her once more. "Miss Bennet," he said quietly, "I hope our conversation has cleared some misunderstandings between us."

"It has given me much to consider," she replied carefully.

He nodded, seeming satisfied with her response. As carriages were called and goodbyes exchanged, Elizabeth realized their relationship had shifted into unfamiliar territory—one requiring careful navigation of both heart and mind.

events.title: Sir William Lucas Announces Charlotte's Engagement
detailed_summary: While Elizabeth contemplates Charlotte Lucas's news, Sir William Lucas arrives.
He has been sent by his daughter, Charlotte, to officially inform the Bennets of her engagement to Mr. Collins.
Sir William expresses his pleasure at the upcoming family connection.
The news is met with disbelief by the listeners.
Mrs. Bennet vehemently insists Sir William must be mistaken.
Lydia rudely questions the announcement, reminding everyone that Mr. Collins intended to propose to Elizabeth.
Sir William maintains his composure despite the impolite reactions, politely affirming the truth of his news.
Elizabeth intervenes to support Sir William's account, confirming she already knew from Charlotte.
She tries to silence her mother and Lydia by offering sincere congratulations to Sir William.
Jane quickly joins Elizabeth in offering congratulations.
Elizabeth further smooths the situation by commenting positively on the potential happiness of the couple, Mr. Collins's qualities, and the location of his parsonage.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters, reflecting on what she had heard, and doubting whether she was authorized to mention it, when Sir William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his daughter to announce her engagement to the family.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth, feeling it incumbent on her to relieve him from so unpleasant a situation, now put herself forward to confirm his account, by mentioning her prior knowledge of it from Charlotte herself; and endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of her mother and sisters, by the earnestness of her congratulations to Sir William, in which she was readily joined by Jane, and by making a variety of remarks on the happiness that might be expected from the match, the excellent character of Mr. Collins, and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London.

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters, reflecting on what she had heard, and doubting whether she was authorized to mention it, when Sir William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his daughter to announce her engagement to the family. With many compliments to them, and much self-gratulation on the prospect of a connection between the houses, he unfolded the matter,—to an audience not merely wondering, but incredulous; for Mrs. Bennet, with more perseverance than politeness, protested he must be entirely mistaken; and Lydia, always unguarded and often uncivil, boisterously exclaimed,—
“Good Lord! Sir William, how can you tell such a story? Do not you know that Mr. Collins wants to marry Lizzy?”
Nothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne without anger such treatment: but Sir William’s good-breeding carried him through it all; and though he begged leave to be positive as to the truth of his information, he listened to all their impertinence with the most forbearing courtesy.
Elizabeth, feeling it incumbent on her to relieve him from so unpleasant a situation, now put herself forward to confirm his account, by mentioning her prior knowledge of it from Charlotte herself; and endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of her mother and sisters, by the earnestness of her congratulations to Sir William, in which she was readily joined by Jane, and by making a variety of remarks on the happiness that might be expected from the match, the excellent character of Mr. Collins, and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London.

Nothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne without anger such treatment; but Sir William's good breeding carried him through it all; and though he begged leave to be positive as to the truth of his information, he listened to all their impertinence with the most forbearing courtesy.

events.title: Mrs. Bennet's Furious Reaction and Lingering Resentment
detailed_summary: After Sir William's departure, Mrs. Bennet unleashes her pent-up emotions.
She initially declares the engagement news must be entirely false.
She then theorizes that Mr. Collins must have been manipulated or tricked into the engagement.
She expresses a spiteful hope that the couple will be unhappy.
She clings to the possibility that the engagement might still be cancelled.
Mrs. Bennet concludes that Elizabeth is primarily responsible for this outcome.
She also feels deeply mistreated by everyone involved.
Her anger and complaints focus on these two points for the remainder of the day.
Nothing can soothe or placate her.

Her resentment persists long after the initial day; she continues to scold Elizabeth for a week, treats Sir William and Lady Lucas rudely for a month, and takes many months to even begin forgiving Charlotte.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mrs. Bennet was, in fact, too much overpowered to say a great deal while Sir William remained; but no sooner had he left them than her feelings found a rapid vent.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A week elapsed before she could see Elizabeth without scolding her: a month passed away before she could speak to Sir William or Lady Lucas without being rude; and many months were gone before she could at all forgive their daughter.

events.text_segment: Mrs. Bennet was, in fact, too much overpowered to say a great deal while Sir William remained; but no sooner had he left them than her feelings found a rapid vent. In the first place, she persisted in disbelieving the whole of the matter; secondly, she was very sure that Mr. Collins had been taken in; thirdly, she trusted that they would never be happy together; and, fourthly, that the match might be broken off. Two inferences, however, were plainly deduced from the whole: one, that Elizabeth was the real cause of all the mischief; and the other, that she herself had been barbarously used by them all; and on these two points she principally dwelt during the rest of the day. Nothing could console and nothing appease her. Nor did that day wear out her resentment. A week elapsed before she could see Elizabeth without scolding her: a month passed away before she could speak to Sir William or Lady Lucas without being rude; and many months were gone before she could at all forgive their daughter.

events.title: Varied Reactions from Mr. Bennet and Other Daughters
detailed_summary: Mr. Bennet reacts to the news with calm amusement.

He finds the situation pleasing because it reveals Charlotte Lucas, whom he considered reasonably intelligent, to be as foolish as Mrs. Bennet and even more foolish than Elizabeth (for rejecting Collins).
Jane admits to being somewhat surprised by the engagement.
However, Jane focuses more on expressing her wish for the couple's happiness than on her surprise.
Elizabeth cannot convince Jane that the match is unlikely to bring happiness.
Kitty and Lydia feel no jealousy towards Charlotte.
They view Mr. Collins as merely a clergyman, not a particularly desirable husband.
The engagement interests them only as gossip to share in Meryton.

**text_segment**: 

Mr. Bennet's emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion, and such as he did experience he pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort; for it gratified him, he said, to discover that Charlotte Lucas, whom he had been used to think tolerably sensible, was as foolish as his wife, and more foolish than his daughter!

Jane confessed herself a little surprised at the match; but she said less of her astonishment than of her earnest desire for their happiness; nor could Elizabeth persuade her to consider it as improbable. Kitty and Lydia were far from envying Miss Lucas, for Mr. Collins was only a clergyman; and it affected them in no other way than as a piece of news to spread at Meryton.

Lady Lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort on Mrs. Bennet the comfort of having a daughter well married; and she called at Longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy she was, though Mrs. Bennet's sour looks and ill-natured remarks might have been enough to drive happiness away.

Between Elizabeth and Charlotte there was a restraint which kept them mutually silent on the subject; and Elizabeth felt persuaded that no real confidence could ever subsist between them again. Her disappointment in Charlotte made her turn with fonder regard to her sister, of whose rectitude and delicacy she was sure her opinion could never be shaken, and for whose happiness she grew daily more anxious, as Bingley had now been gone a week and nothing more was heard of his return.

Jane had sent Caroline an early answer to her letter, and was counting the days till she might reasonably hope to hear again. The promised letter of thanks from Mr. Collins arrived on Tuesday, addressed to their father, and written with all the solemnity of gratitude which a twelvemonth's abode in the family might have prompted. After discharging his conscience on that head, he proceeded to inform them, with many rapturous expressions, of his happiness in having obtained the affection of their amiable neighbour, Miss Lucas, and then explained that it was merely with the view of enjoying her society that he had been so ready to close with their kind wish of seeing him again at Longbourn, whither he hoped to be able to return on Monday fortnight; for Lady Catherine, he added, so heartily approved his marriage, that she wished it to take place as soon as possible, which he trusted would be an unanswerable argument with his amiable Charlotte to name an early day for making him the happiest of men.

events.title: Correspondence: Jane Awaits News, Mr. Collins Confirms Plans
detailed_summary: Jane has replied promptly to Caroline Bingley's letter and is anxiously awaiting a response.
Mr. Collins's expected letter of thanks arrives on Tuesday, addressed to Mr. Bennet.
The letter is written with exaggerated formality and gratitude, as if he had stayed with the family for a year.
Having fulfilled his obligation of thanks, Mr. Collins enthusiastically describes his joy at securing Charlotte Lucas's affections.
He clarifies that his eagerness to accept their invitation to return to Longbourn was primarily motivated by his desire to be near Charlotte.
He announces his plan to return in two weeks, on the Monday.
He adds that his patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, strongly approves of the marriage and wants it to happen quickly.
Mr. Collins hopes Lady Catherine's endorsement will persuade Charlotte to set an early wedding date.

events.title: Anxiety Mounts Over Bingley's Continued Absence
detailed_summary: Mrs. Bennet now dreads Mr. Collins's return, sharing her husband's previous sentiment.
She finds it peculiar that he would stay at Longbourn instead of Lucas Lodge.
She complains about the inconvenience and trouble of his visit, especially given her 'indifferent' health.
She declares engaged couples are the most bothersome type of guests.
These complaints are secondary to her greater worry over Mr. Bingley's continued absence.
Both Jane and Elizabeth are troubled by the lack of news concerning Bingley.
Time passes, and the only information is a growing rumor in Meryton that Bingley will not return to Netherfield all winter.
This rumor greatly angers Mrs. Bennet, who consistently denies it as slanderous.
Even Elizabeth starts to worry, not that Bingley is uninterested, but that his sisters and friend Darcy might successfully prevent his return.
She finds this possibility distressing for Jane's happiness and damaging to Bingley's reputation for constancy.
Elizabeth fears the combined influence of Bingley's sisters, Darcy, the appeal of Miss Darcy, and London's distractions might overcome his feelings for Jane.
Jane's anxiety is deeper than Elizabeth's, but she tries hard to hide it.
Consequently, the sisters avoid discussing Bingley's absence.
Mrs. Bennet, however, lacks such sensitivity and frequently talks about Bingley, expresses impatience for his return, and pressures Jane to admit she'll feel wronged if he doesn't come back.
Jane requires significant composure to endure her mother's constant remarks calmly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Collins’s return into Hertfordshire was no longer a matter of pleasure to Mrs. Bennet.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It needed all Jane’s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable tranquillity.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Collins’s return into Hertfordshire was no longer a matter of pleasure to Mrs. Bennet. On the contrary, she was as much disposed to complain of it as her husband. It was very strange that he should come to Longbourn instead of to Lucas Lodge; it was also very inconvenient and exceedingly troublesome. She hated having visitors in the house while her health was so indifferent, and lovers were of all people the most disagreeable. Such were the gentle murmurs of Mrs. Bennet, and they gave way only to the greater distress of Mr. Bingley’s continued absence.
Neither Jane nor Elizabeth were comfortable on this subject. Day after day passed away without bringing any other tidings of him than the report which shortly prevailed in Meryton of his coming no more to Netherfield the whole winter; a report which highly incensed Mrs. Bennet, and which she never failed to contradict as a most scandalous falsehood.
Even Elizabeth began to fear—not that Bingley was indifferent—but that his sisters would be successful in keeping him away. Unwilling as she was to admit an idea so destructive to Jane’s happiness, and so dishonourable to the stability of her lover, she could not prevent its frequently recurring. The united efforts of his two unfeeling sisters, and of his overpowering friend, assisted by the attractions of Miss Darcy and the amusements of London, might be too much, she feared, for the strength of his attachment.
As for Jane, her anxiety under this suspense was, of course, more painful than Elizabeth’s: but whatever she felt she was desirous of concealing; and between herself and Elizabeth, therefore, the subject was never alluded to. But as no such delicacy restrained her mother, an hour seldom passed in which she did not talk of Bingley, express her impatience for his arrival, or even require Jane to confess that if he did not come back she should think herself very ill-used. It needed all Jane’s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable tranquillity.

events.title: Mr. Collins Returns; Mrs. Bennet's Misery Intensifies
detailed_summary: Mr. Collins arrives back at Longbourn exactly as planned.
His welcome from the Bennets is noticeably cooler than during his first visit.
His own happiness makes him largely oblivious to the lack of attention.

Mrs. Bennet is in a state of deep distress.
Any mention of the engagement plunges her into bad temper.

Mrs. Bennet views Charlotte with jealous hatred as the future mistress of Longbourn.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Collins returned most punctually on the Monday fortnight, but his reception at Longbourn was not quite so gracious as it had been on his first introduction.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Whenever Charlotte came to see them, she concluded her to be anticipating the hour of possession; and whenever she spoke in a low voice to Mr. Collins, was convinced that they were talking of the Longbourn estate, and resolving to turn herself and her daughters out of the house as soon as Mr. Bennet was dead.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Collins returned most punctually on the Monday fortnight, but his reception at Longbourn was not quite so gracious as it had been on his first introduction. He was too happy, however, to need much attention; and, luckily for the others, the business of love-making relieved them from a great deal of his company. The chief of every day was spent by him at Lucas Lodge, and he sometimes returned to Longbourn only in time to make an apology for his absence before the family went to bed.
Mrs. Bennet was really in a most pitiable state. The very mention of anything concerning the match threw her into an agony of ill-humour, and wherever she went she was sure of hearing it talked of. The sight of Miss Lucas was odious to her. As her successor in that house, she regarded her with jealous abhorrence. Whenever Charlotte came to see them, she concluded her to be anticipating the hour of possession; and whenever she spoke in a low voice to Mr. Collins, was convinced that they were talking of the Longbourn estate, and resolving to turn herself and her daughters out of the house as soon as Mr. Bennet was dead.

events.title: Mr. and Mrs. Bennet Discuss the Entailment
detailed_summary: Mrs. Bennet expresses her deep grievances about Charlotte and the entailment to Mr. Bennet.
She laments the hardship of knowing Charlotte Lucas will eventually become the mistress of Longbourn.
She dreads having to yield her position to Charlotte and witnessing her take over.
Mr. Bennet advises her not to dwell on such morbid thoughts and suggests hoping for a better outcome, humorously implying he might outlive her.
Finding no comfort in his reply, Mrs. Bennet ignores it and continues her complaint.
She reiterates her inability to accept that Charlotte and Mr. Collins will inherit the estate.
She states that if not for the entail, she wouldn't mind.
Mr. Bennet dryly asks what exactly she wouldn't mind.
Mrs. Bennet vaguely replies she wouldn't mind anything at all.
Mr. Bennet sarcastically suggests they should be grateful she hasn't reached such a state of complete indifference.
Mrs. Bennet declares she can never be thankful for anything related to the entail.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: She complained bitterly of all this to her husband.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I leave it to yourself to determine,” said Mr. Bennet.

events.text_segment:
She complained bitterly of all this to her husband.
“Indeed, Mr. Bennet,” said she, “it is very hard to think that Charlotte Lucas should ever be mistress of this house, that I should be forced to make way for her, and live to see her take my place in it!”
“My dear, do not give way to such gloomy thoughts. Let us hope for better things. Let us flatter ourselves that I may be the survivor.”
This was not very consoling to Mrs. Bennet; and, therefore, instead of making any answer, she went on as before.
“I cannot bear to think that they should have all this estate. If it was not for the entail, I should not mind it.”
“What should not you mind?”
“I should not mind anything at all.”
“Let us be thankful that you are preserved from a state of such insensibility.”
“I never can be thankful, Mr. Bennet, for anything about the entail. How anyone could have the conscience to entail away an estate from one’s own daughters I cannot understand; and all for the sake of Mr. Collins, too! Why should he have it more than anybody else?”
“I leave it to yourself to determine,” said Mr. Bennet.

events.title: Confirmation of Bingley's Departure and Caroline's Hopes
detailed_summary: A letter from Caroline Bingley confirms the Bingley party has relocated to London for the winter season.

Caroline expresses pleasure in her growing closeness with Miss Darcy and confidently anticipates the fulfillment of wishes hinted at previously (likely regarding a match between Bingley and Miss Darcy).

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Miss Bingley's letter arrived, and put an end to doubt.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She wrote also with great pleasure of her brother’s being an inmate of Mr. Darcy’s house, and mentioned with raptures some plans of the latter with regard to new furniture.

events.text_segment:
Miss Bingley's letter arrived, and put an end to doubt. The very first sentence conveyed the assurance of their being all settled in London for the winter, and concluded with her brother’s regret at not having had time to pay his respects to his friends in Hertfordshire before he left the country.
Hope was over, entirely over; and when Jane could attend to the rest of the letter, she found little, except the professed affection of the writer, that could give her any comfort. Miss Darcy’s praise occupied the chief of it. Her many attractions were again dwelt on; and Caroline boasted joyfully of their increasing intimacy, and ventured to predict the accomplishment of the wishes which had been unfolded in her former letter. She wrote also with great pleasure of her brother’s being an inmate of Mr. Darcy’s house, and mentioned with raptures some plans of the latter with regard to new furniture.

events.title: Elizabeth's Indignation and Analysis of Bingley's Conduct
detailed_summary: Jane shares the contents of the letter with Elizabeth, who reacts with silent fury.
Elizabeth feels torn between sympathy for Jane and anger towards the others involved.

Elizabeth remains convinced of Bingley's genuine affection for Jane.
Despite her previous inclination to like Bingley, Elizabeth now feels anger and contempt towards his perceived weakness and lack of resolve.
She blames his susceptibility to his friends' manipulation for sacrificing his own potential happiness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth, to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this, heard it in silent indignation.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Whichever were the case, though her opinion of him must be materially affected by the difference, her sister’s situation remained the same, her peace equally wounded.

events.text_segment: Elizabeth, to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this, heard it in silent indignation. Her heart was divided between concern for her sister and resentment against all others. To Caroline’s assertion of her brother’s being partial to Miss Darcy, she paid no credit. That he was really fond of Jane, she doubted no more than she had ever done; and much as she had always been disposed to like him, she could not think without anger, hardly without contempt, on that easiness of temper, that want of proper resolution, which now made him the slave of his designing friends, and led him to sacrifice his own happiness to the caprice of their inclinations. Had his own happiness, however, been the only sacrifice, he might have been allowed to sport with it in whatever manner he thought best; but her sister’s was involved in it, as she thought he must be sensible himself. It was a subject, in short, on which reflection would be long indulged, and must be unavailing. She could think of nothing else; and yet, whether Bingley’s regard had really died away, or were suppressed by his friends’ interference; whether he had been aware of Jane’s attachment, or whether it had escaped his observation; whichever were the case, though her opinion of him must be materially affected by the difference, her sister’s situation remained the same, her peace equally wounded.

events.text_segment:
A day or two passed before Jane had courage to speak of her feelings to Elizabeth; but at last, on Mrs. Bennet’s leaving them together, after a longer irritation than usual about Netherfield and its master, she could not help saying,—
“O that my dear mother had more command over herself! she can have no idea of the pain she gives me by her continual reflections on him. But I will not repine. It cannot last long. He will be forgot, and we shall all be as we were before.”
Elizabeth looked at her sister with incredulous solicitude, but said nothing.
“You doubt me,” cried Jane, slightly colouring; “indeed, you have no reason. He may live in my memory as the most amiable man of my acquaintance but that is all. I have nothing either to hope or fear, and nothing to reproach him with. Thank God I have not that pain. A little time, therefore—I shall certainly try to get the better——”
With a stronger voice she soon added, “I have this comfort immediately, that it has not been more than an error of fancy on my side, and that it has done no harm to anyone but myself.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
"Oh, Lizzy! I find myself quite distressed by mother's constant remarks about Mr. Bingley. I know she means well, but her persistent hopes only serve to remind me of what might have been. I have tried to convince myself that I am perfectly content, yet each mention of his name reopens wounds I had hoped were healing. I wish she would understand that such conversations bring me no comfort."

Elizabeth regarded her sister with sympathy, knowing Jane's gentle nature made her reluctant to voice any complaint against their mother.

"I have resolved," Jane continued with quiet determination, "to think of him as little as possible, though I fear mother's frequent references make this nearly impossible. I do not blame him for his departure—surely he had his reasons—but I cannot help wondering if I might have been mistaken in believing his regard for me was genuine."

events.title: Elizabeth Praises Jane and Laments Worldly Inconsistencies
detailed_summary: Elizabeth praises Jane's exceptional goodness, sweetness, and selflessness, calling her angelic.
She feels she hasn't previously appreciated or loved Jane sufficiently.
Jane deflects the compliment, attributing Elizabeth's words to her own affectionate nature.
Elizabeth counters, contrasting Jane's desire to see good in everyone with her own wish to see Jane as perfect.
She assures Jane not to worry about her becoming overly critical, stating she loves few people and thinks well of even fewer.
Elizabeth reveals her growing dissatisfaction with the world and its inconsistencies.
She remarks that daily experiences reinforce her belief in the unreliability of appearances of merit or sense.
Elizabeth mentions two recent examples illustrating her point: one she refrains from naming, and the other being Charlotte Lucas's marriage.
She calls Charlotte's marriage completely baffling from every perspective.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “My dear Jane,” exclaimed Elizabeth, “you are too good.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It is unaccountable! in every view it is unaccountable!”

events.text_segment:
“My dear Jane,” exclaimed Elizabeth, “you are too good. Your sweetness and disinterestedness are really angelic; I do not know what to say to you. I feel as if I had never done you justice, or loved you as you deserve.”
Miss Bennet eagerly disclaimed all extraordinary merit, and threw back the praise on her sister’s warm affection.
“Nay,” said Elizabeth, “this is not fair. You wish to think all the world respectable, and are hurt if I speak ill of anybody. I only want to think you perfect, and you set yourself against it. Do not be afraid of my running into any excess, of my encroaching on your privilege of universal good-will. You need not. There are few people whom I really love, and still fewer of whom I think well. The more I see of the world the more am I dissatisfied with it; and every day confirms my belief of the inconsistency of all human characters, and of the little dependence that can be placed on the appearance of either merit or sense. I have met with two instances lately: one I will not mention, the other is Charlotte’s marriage. It is unaccountable! in every view it is unaccountable!”

events.title: Debate Over Charlotte's Marriage and Principles
detailed_summary: Jane urges Elizabeth not to indulge such negative feelings, warning they will destroy her happiness.
She advises Elizabeth to consider differences in circumstances and personalities more charitably.
Jane points to Mr. Collins's social standing and Charlotte's practical, sensible nature.
She reminds Elizabeth that Charlotte comes from a large family and the marriage is financially advantageous.
Jane suggests that for everyone's peace of mind, they should try to believe Charlotte might feel some affection and respect for Mr. Collins.
Elizabeth replies she would try to believe it for Jane's sake, but questions who else benefits from such a belief.
She argues that if she believed Charlotte had genuine regard for Mr. Collins, she would think even less of Charlotte's judgment than she currently does of her emotional choices.
Elizabeth bluntly describes Mr. Collins as conceited, pompous, narrow-minded, and foolish, stating Jane knows this too.
She insists that any woman marrying him must lack proper judgment.
Elizabeth forbids Jane from defending Charlotte in this matter.
She argues that defending Charlotte involves distorting the meanings of principle and integrity, equating selfishness with prudence and ignoring danger as a guarantee of happiness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “My dear Lizzy, do not give way to such feelings as these.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: You shall not, for the sake of one individual, change the meaning of principle and integrity, nor endeavour to persuade yourself or me, that selfishness is prudence, and insensibility of danger security for happiness.”

events.text_segment:
“My dear Lizzy, do not give way to such feelings as these. They will ruin your happiness. You do not make allowance enough for difference of situation and temper. Consider Mr. Collins’s respectability, and Charlotte’s prudent, steady character. Remember that she is one of a large family; that as to fortune it is a most eligible match; and be ready to believe, for everybody’s sake, that she may feel something like regard and esteem for our cousin.”
“To oblige you, I would try to believe almost anything, but no one else could be benefited by such a belief as this; for were I persuaded that Charlotte had any regard for him, I should only think worse of her understanding than I now do of her heart. My dear Jane, Mr. Collins is a conceited, pompous, narrow-minded, silly man: you know he is, as well as I do; and you must feel, as well as I do, that the woman who marries him cannot have a proper way of thinking. You shall not defend her, though it is Charlotte Lucas. You shall not, for the sake of one individual, change the meaning of principle and integrity, nor endeavour to persuade yourself or me, that selfishness is prudence, and insensibility of danger security for happiness.”

events.title: Jane Defends Bingley and His Sisters Against Elizabeth's Suspicions
detailed_summary: Jane finds Elizabeth's criticism of both Charlotte/Collins and Bingley too harsh, hoping Elizabeth will reconsider when she sees them happy.
She shifts the conversation back to Elizabeth's unnamed second instance of disillusionment.
Jane correctly guesses Elizabeth was referring to Mr. Bingley.
She implores Elizabeth not to cause her pain by blaming Bingley or lowering her opinion of him.
Jane argues against assuming intentional harm, suggesting people shouldn't expect young men like Bingley to be constantly cautious.
She posits that often, it's women's vanity that misinterprets attentions, leading to deception.
Elizabeth retorts that men sometimes encourage such misinterpretations.
Jane concedes that intentional deceit is unjustifiable but doubts the world is as full of scheming as some believe.
Elizabeth clarifies she doesn't accuse Bingley of deliberate wrongdoing or scheming to cause unhappiness.
Instead, she attributes the outcome to potential errors, thoughtlessness, disregard for others' feelings, and lack of resolution.
When asked by Jane, Elizabeth confirms she blames Bingley's lack of resolution.
She offers to stop talking before she upsets Jane by criticizing people Jane esteems.
Jane asks if Elizabeth still believes Bingley's sisters influenced him.
Elizabeth confirms, adding that his friend (Darcy) was also involved.
Jane finds this hard to believe, questioning why they would interfere against his happiness.
She argues that if Bingley is attached to her, no other woman (like Miss Darcy) could make him happy.
Elizabeth refutes Jane's premise, stating Bingley's connections might desire other things for him, such as increased wealth, status, or marriage to someone with money, connections, and pride.
Jane acknowledges they likely prefer Miss Darcy but suggests this might stem from genuine affection, as they've known her longer.
She finds it improbable that sisters would oppose a brother's attachment unless the object was highly unsuitable.
Jane believes if Bingley were truly attached, his sisters wouldn't try to separate them, or if they did, they wouldn't succeed.
She tells Elizabeth that assuming such interference paints everyone involved as acting unnaturally and wrongly, causing Jane great distress.
Jane asks Elizabeth to drop the subject, stating she is not ashamed of being mistaken about Bingley's feelings, viewing it as minor compared to thinking ill of him or his sisters.
She prefers to interpret the situation in the most favorable way possible.
Elizabeth respects Jane's wish, and they cease discussing Mr. Bingley from then on.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I must think your language too strong in speaking of both,” replied Jane; “and I hope you will be convinced of it, by seeing them happy together.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth could not oppose such a wish; and from this time Mr. Bingley’s name was scarcely ever mentioned between them.

events.text_segment:
“I must think your language too strong in speaking of both,” replied Jane; “and I hope you will be convinced of it, by seeing them happy together. But enough of this. You alluded to something else. You mentioned two instances. I cannot misunderstand you, but I entreat you, dear Lizzy, not to pain me by thinking that person to blame, and saying your opinion of him is sunk. We must not be so ready to fancy ourselves intentionally injured. We must not expect a lively young man to be always so guarded and circumspect. It is very often nothing but our own vanity that deceives us. Women fancy admiration means more than it does.”
“And men take care that they should.”
“If it is designedly done, they cannot be justified; but I have no idea of there being so much design in the world as some persons imagine.”
“I am far from attributing any part of Mr. Bingley’s conduct to design,” said Elizabeth; “but, without scheming to do wrong, or to make others unhappy, there may be error and there may be misery. Thoughtlessness, want of attention to other people’s feelings, and want of resolution, will do the business.”
“And do you impute it to either of those?”
“Yes; to the last. But if I go on I shall displease you by saying what I think of persons you esteem. Stop me, whilst you can.”
“You persist, then, in supposing his sisters influence him?”
“Yes, in conjunction with his friend.”
“I cannot believe it. Why should they try to influence him? They can only wish his happiness; and if he is attached to me no other woman can secure it.”
“Your first position is false. They may wish many things besides his happiness: they may wish his increase of wealth and consequence; they may wish him to marry a girl who has all the importance of money, great connections, and pride.”
“Beyond a doubt they do wish him to choose Miss Darcy,” replied Jane; “but this may be from better feelings than you are supposing. They have known her much longer than they have known me; no wonder if they love her better. But, whatever may be their own wishes, it is very unlikely they should have opposed their brother’s. What sister would think herself at liberty to do it, unless there were something very objectionable? If they believed him attached to me they would not try to part us; if he were so, they could not succeed. By supposing such an affection, you make everybody acting unnaturally and wrong, and me most unhappy. Do not distress me by the idea. I am not ashamed of having been mistaken—or, at least, it is slight, it is nothing in comparison of what I should feel in thinking ill of him or his sisters. Let me take it in the best light, in the light in which it may be understood.”
Elizabeth could not oppose such a wish; and from this time Mr. Bingley’s name was scarcely ever mentioned between them.

events.title: Mrs. Bennet's Continued Lament and Lingering Hope
detailed_summary: Mrs. Bennet persistently frets and complains about Mr. Bingley's continued absence.
Despite Elizabeth's frequent attempts to explain the situation clearly, Mrs. Bennet remains perplexed.
Elizabeth tries to convince her mother (without believing it herself) that Bingley's interest in Jane was merely a casual liking that faded with distance.
Although Mrs. Bennet might temporarily accept this explanation, she requires the same reassurance daily.
Mrs. Bennet's primary source of comfort becomes the hope that Mr. Bingley will inevitably return during the summer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mrs. Bennet still continued to wonder and repine at his returning no more; and though a day seldom passed in which Elizabeth did not account for it clearly, there seemed little chance of her ever considering it with less perplexity.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mrs. Bennet’s best comfort was, that Mr. Bingley must be down again in the summer.

events.text_segment: Mrs. Bennet still continued to wonder and repine at his returning no more; and though a day seldom passed in which Elizabeth did not account for it clearly, there seemed little chance of her ever considering it with less perplexity. Her daughter endeavoured to convince her of what she did not believe herself, that his attentions to Jane had been merely the effect of a common and transient liking, which ceased when he saw her no more; but though the probability of the statement was admitted at the time, she had the same story to repeat every day. Mrs. Bennet’s best comfort was, that Mr. Bingley must be down again in the summer.

events.title: Mr. Bennet's Cynical Consolation Regarding Jane's Heartbreak
detailed_summary: Mr. Bennet addresses Jane's situation with a different attitude.
He speaks to Elizabeth, noting Jane's romantic disappointment.
He cynically congratulates Jane, remarking that experiencing unrequited love is second only to marriage in a young woman's life.
He suggests it provides something to contemplate and distinguishes her among peers.
He playfully asks Elizabeth when her turn for heartbreak will come, implying she wouldn't want Jane to surpass her for long.
He points out the abundance of officers in Meryton capable of disappointing local young ladies.
Mr. Bennet specifically suggests Wickham as a suitable candidate to jilt Elizabeth respectably, calling him a pleasant fellow.
Elizabeth dryly replies that a less agreeable man would suffice, implying she doesn't expect Jane's level of 'good fortune' in love.
Mr. Bennet agrees, adding humorously that whatever romantic misfortunes befall Elizabeth, she can rely on her mother to dramatize the situation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Bennet treated the matter differently.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “True,” said Mr. Bennet; “but it is a comfort to think that, whatever of that kind may befall you, you have an affectionate mother who will always make the most of it.”

events.text_segment:
Mr. Bennet treated the matter differently. “So, Lizzy,” said he, one day, “your sister is crossed in love, I find. I congratulate her. Next to being married, a girl likes to be crossed in love a little now and then. It is something to think of, and gives her a sort of distinction among her companions. When is your turn to come? You will hardly bear to be long outdone by Jane. Now is your time. Here are officers enough at Meryton to disappoint all the young ladies in the country. Let Wickham be your man. He is a pleasant fellow, and would jilt you creditably.”
“Thank you, sir, but a less agreeable man would satisfy me. We must not all expect Jane’s good fortune.”
“True,” said Mr. Bennet; “but it is a comfort to think that, whatever of that kind may befall you, you have an affectionate mother who will always make the most of it.”

"Thank you, sir, but a less agreeable man would satisfy me. We must not all expect Jane's good fortune."

"True," said Mr. Bennet, "but it is a comfort to think that whatever of that kind may befall you, you have an affectionate mother who will make the most of it."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Mr. Bennet treated the matter differently. While Mrs. Bennet was in a flurry of excitement over the prospect of Mr. Bingley as a potential husband for one of their daughters, Mr. Bennet maintained his characteristic detachment and dry humor. He seemed amused by his wife's enthusiastic matchmaking schemes rather than sharing her urgency.

Instead of openly supporting Mrs. Bennet's plans, he responded with irony and wit, often teasing her about her preoccupation with finding wealthy husbands for their daughters. His approach was more measured, observing the unfolding events with a philosopher's distance rather than a participant's eagerness.

This difference in attitude between the Bennets highlighted their contrasting personalities - Mrs. Bennet being emotional and sometimes ridiculous in her social ambitions, while Mr. Bennet retreated into his library and his books, finding solace in intellectual pursuits rather than the marriage market that so consumed his wife's attention.

events.title: Wickham's Story Spreads, Solidifying Darcy's Poor Reputation

The family sees him frequently, and his initial positive impression is enhanced by his apparent openness.
The entire story Elizabeth had previously heard from him – his grievances against Mr. Darcy and his alleged suffering – is now public knowledge.
This information is openly discussed within their social circle.
The community takes satisfaction in believing they had instinctively disliked Mr. Darcy even before knowing the details of Wickham's claims.
Jane Bennet stands alone in thinking there might be unknown factors that could mitigate Darcy's blame.

However, everyone else in Hertfordshire society condemns Mr. Darcy unequivocally as a terrible man.

Mr. Wickham’s society was of material service in dispelling the gloom which the late perverse occurrences had thrown on many of the Longbourn family. events.title: Mr. Collins Departs Longbourn
detailed_summary: Following a week dedicated to expressing affection for Charlotte Lucas and planning their future happiness, Mr. Collins departs Longbourn.
His departure coincides with the arrival of Saturday, necessitating his return home.
He anticipates returning soon to Hertfordshire to finalize the wedding date, which he expects will make him exceedingly happy.
Mr. Collins bids farewell to his Longbourn relatives with the same gravity as before.
He extends wishes for health and happiness to his female cousins and assures Mr. Bennet he will send another letter expressing his gratitude.

events.text_segment: After a week spent in professions of love and schemes of felicity, Mr. Collins was called from his amiable Charlotte by the arrival of Saturday. events.title: Mrs. Bennet Voices Her Grievances
detailed_summary: Upon arrival, Mrs. Gardiner first attends to distributing gifts and discussing current fashion trends.
After this initial activity, her role shifts to being a listener.
Mrs. Bennet proceeds to share her numerous complaints and feelings of being mistreated since their last meeting.
She recounts the near-marriages of two daughters, emphasizing that ultimately, nothing came of either prospect.
Mrs. Bennet absolves Jane of blame regarding Mr. Bingley, believing Jane did her best.
She expresses intense frustration with Elizabeth for refusing Mr. Collins, lamenting that Elizabeth could have been married by now.
She highlights the consequence: Lady Lucas will have a married daughter before her, and the Longbourn estate remains entailed.
Mrs. Bennet criticizes the Lucas family as calculating and self-serving.
She voices her distress and ill-health caused by being opposed within her family and by neighbors prioritizing their own interests.
She concludes by expressing gratitude for the Gardiners' timely visit as a great comfort, mentioning her gladness about the fashion news regarding long sleeves.

events.text_segment:
The first part of Mrs. Gardiner’s business, on her arrival, was to distribute her presents and describe the newest fashions. When this was done, she had a less active part to play. It became her turn to listen. Mrs. Bennet had many grievances to relate, and much to complain of. They had all been very ill-used since she last saw her sister. Two of her girls had been on the point of marriage, and after all there was nothing in it.
“I do not blame Jane,” she continued, “for Jane would have got Mr. Bingley if she could. But, Lizzy! Oh, sister! it is very hard to think that she might have been Mr. Collins’s wife by this time, had not it been for her own perverseness. He made her an offer in this very room, and she refused him. The consequence of it is, that Lady Lucas will have a daughter married before I have, and that Longbourn estate is just as much entailed as ever. The Lucases are very artful people, indeed, sister. They are all for what they can get. I am sorry to say it of them, but so it is. It makes me very nervous and poorly, to be thwarted so in my own family, and to have neighbours who think of themselves before anybody else. However, your coming just at this time is the greatest of comforts, and I am very glad to hear what you tell us of long sleeves.”

events.title: Elizabeth and Mrs. Gardiner Discuss Jane and Bingley
detailed_summary: Mrs. Gardiner, already aware of the main points from letters exchanged with Jane and Elizabeth, gives a brief response to Mrs. Bennet.
Out of consideration for her nieces' feelings, she redirects the conversation.
Later, in private with Elizabeth, Mrs. Gardiner addresses Jane's situation more directly.
She acknowledges that the match with Bingley seemed promising and expresses sorrow that it ended.
Mrs. Gardiner generalizes about such occurrences, suggesting young men like Bingley can easily fall in love and just as easily forget when separated.
Elizabeth dismisses this as poor consolation, asserting their situation wasn't accidental.
She argues that it's uncommon for friends' interference to successfully deter a wealthy young man who was, days earlier, intensely in love.
Mrs. Gardiner questions the term 'violently in love,' finding it vague and overused.
She asks Elizabeth to clarify the actual intensity of Bingley's feelings for Jane.
Elizabeth describes Bingley's affection as very promising, noting his increasing inattentiveness to others and complete focus on Jane.

She recounts his behavior becoming more obvious at each meeting, citing his neglect of other ladies at his ball and his unresponsiveness even to Elizabeth herself as clear evidence of genuine love, equating general impoliteness with being deeply in love.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mrs. Gardiner, to whom the chief of this news had been given before, in the course of Jane and Elizabeth’s correspondence with her, made her sister a slight answer, and, in compassion to her nieces, turned the conversation.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Is not general incivility the very essence of love?”

events.text_segment:
Mrs. Gardiner, to whom the chief of this news had been given before, in the course of Jane and Elizabeth’s correspondence with her, made her sister a slight answer, and, in compassion to her nieces, turned the conversation.
When alone with Elizabeth afterwards, she spoke more on the subject. “It seems likely to have been a desirable match for Jane,” said she. “I am sorry it went off. But these things happen so often! A young man, such as you describe Mr. Bingley, so easily falls in love with a pretty girl for a few weeks, and, when accident separates them, so easily forgets her, that these sort of inconstancies are very frequent.”
“An excellent consolation in its way,” said Elizabeth; “but it will not do for us. We do not suffer by accident. It does not often happen that the interference of friends will persuade a young man of independent fortune to think no more of a girl whom he was violently in love with only a few days before.”
“But that expression of ‘violently in love’ is so hackneyed, so doubtful, so indefinite, that it gives me very little idea. It is as often applied to feelings which arise only from a half hour’s acquaintance, as to a real, strong attachment. Pray, how violent was Mr. Bingley’s love?”
“I never saw a more promising inclination; he was growing quite inattentive to other people, and wholly engrossed by her. Every time they met, it was more decided and remarkable. At his own ball he offended two or three young ladies by not asking them to dance; and I spoke to him twice myself without receiving an answer. Could there be finer symptoms? Is not general incivility the very essence of love?”

events.title: Mrs. Gardiner Invites Jane to London
detailed_summary: Mrs. Gardiner concedes that Bingley likely felt the type of love Elizabeth described and expresses sympathy for Jane, noting her sensitive nature might make recovery difficult.
She remarks that Elizabeth, with her temperament, would have overcome such disappointment more quickly through humor.
Mrs. Gardiner proposes that Jane return to London with them, suggesting a change of location and distance from home might be beneficial.
Elizabeth reacts very positively to this suggestion, confident Jane will agree.
Mrs. Gardiner adds a condition, hoping Jane's decision won't be influenced by any thoughts of encountering Bingley.
She emphasizes their different London location, social circles, and infrequent outings make a meeting highly improbable unless Bingley intentionally seeks Jane out.
Elizabeth deems a deliberate visit impossible, stating Bingley is under the influence of his friend, Mr. Darcy.
She asserts Darcy would never permit Bingley to visit Jane in a location like Gracechurch Street.
Elizabeth humorously exaggerates Darcy's likely disdain for the area, suggesting he might have barely heard of it and would consider it utterly contaminating.
She firmly states that Bingley never acts independently of Darcy.
Mrs. Gardiner expresses relief, hoping they won't meet.
She inquires if Jane corresponds with Bingley's sister, suggesting Caroline might visit.
Elizabeth confidently asserts that Jane will cease the acquaintance entirely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Oh, yes! of that kind of love which I suppose him to have felt.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “She will drop the acquaintance entirely.”

events.text_segment:
“Oh, yes! of that kind of love which I suppose him to have felt. Poor Jane! I am sorry for her, because, with her disposition, she may not get over it immediately. It had better have happened to you, Lizzy; you would have laughed yourself out of it sooner. But do you think she would be prevailed on to go back with us? Change of scene might be of service—and perhaps a little relief from home may be as useful as anything.”
Elizabeth was exceedingly pleased with this proposal, and felt persuaded of her sister’s ready acquiescence.
“I hope,” added Mrs. Gardiner, “that no consideration with regard to this young man will influence her. We live in so different a part of town, all our connections are so different, and, as you well know, we go out so little, that it is very improbable they should meet at all, unless he really comes to see her.”
“And that is quite impossible; for he is now in the custody of his friend, and Mr. Darcy would no more suffer him to call on Jane in such a part of London! My dear aunt, how could you think of it? Mr. Darcy may, perhaps, have heard of such a place as Gracechurch Street, but he would hardly think a month’s ablution enough to cleanse him from its impurities, were he once to enter it; and, depend upon it, Mr. Bingley never stirs without him.”
“So much the better. I hope they will not meet at all. But does not Jane correspond with his sister? She will not be able to help calling.”
“She will drop the acquaintance entirely.”

Her thoughts about the Bingleys at that moment are limited to hoping Caroline's separate residence from her brother will allow occasional visits with Caroline without risking an encounter with Bingley.

But, in spite of the certainty in which Elizabeth affected to place this point, as well as the still more interesting one of Bingley’s being withheld from seeing Jane, she felt a solicitude on the subject which convinced her, on examination, that she did not consider it entirely hopeless. events.title: Gardiners' Visit and Mrs. Gardiner's Observations of Wickham
detailed_summary: The Gardiners remain at Longbourn for a week.
Their visit is marked by constant social engagements involving the Philipses, the Lucases, and local military officers.
Mrs. Bennet diligently arranges entertainment, ensuring the Gardiners never have a simple family dinner.
When gatherings are held at Longbourn, officers are always included.
Mr. Wickham is invariably among the officers present.
Prompted by Elizabeth's enthusiastic praise of Wickham, Mrs. Gardiner closely observes both him and Elizabeth during these occasions.
While not concluding they are deeply in love, she perceives a clear mutual preference that causes her some concern.
Mrs. Gardiner decides to speak with Elizabeth before leaving Hertfordshire to caution her against encouraging such an imprudent attachment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Gardiners stayed a week at Longbourn; and what with the Philipses, the Lucases, and the officers, there was not a day without its engagement.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Without supposing them, from what she saw, to be very seriously in love, their preference of each other was plain enough to make her a little uneasy; and she resolved to speak to Elizabeth on the subject before she left Hertfordshire, and represent to her the imprudence of encouraging such an attachment.

events.text_segment: The Gardiners stayed a week at Longbourn; and what with the Philipses, the Lucases, and the officers, there was not a day without its engagement. Mrs. Bennet had so carefully provided for the entertainment of her brother and sister, that they did not once sit down to a family dinner. When the engagement was for home, some of the officers always made part of it, of which officers Mr. Wickham was sure to be one; and on these occasions Mrs. Gardiner, rendered suspicious by Elizabeth’s warm commendation of him, narrowly observed them both. Without supposing them, from what she saw, to be very seriously in love, their preference of each other was plain enough to make her a little uneasy; and she resolved to speak to Elizabeth on the subject before she left Hertfordshire, and represent to her the imprudence of encouraging such an attachment.

The officers stationed nearby also provided opportunities for social interaction, much to the delight of the younger Bennet daughters, particularly Kitty and Lydia who were especially fond of their company. These daily gatherings offered chances for conversation, card games, and occasional dancing, creating a pleasant atmosphere despite the winter season. The constant stream of visitors and outings kept the family occupied and provided welcome diversion during what might otherwise have been a quiet country week.

events.title: Mrs. Gardiner and Wickham Discuss Derbyshire and Darcy
detailed_summary: Mrs. Gardiner finds a specific source of pleasure in Wickham unrelated to his general charm.
She discovers they share a connection to a particular area of Derbyshire where she spent significant time before her marriage, about ten or twelve years prior.
This shared past provides them with mutual acquaintances.
Although Wickham has spent little time there since the elder Mr. Darcy's death five years ago, he can still offer Mrs. Gardiner more recent news of her former friends than she could otherwise obtain.
Mrs. Gardiner has visited Pemberley and knew the late Mr. Darcy's reputation well.
This shared knowledge becomes a rich topic for conversation.
She enjoys comparing her memories of Pemberley with Wickham's detailed descriptions and praising the character of the estate's former owner, delighting both herself and Wickham.
Upon learning about the current Mr. Darcy's alleged mistreatment of Wickham, she tries to recall any childhood accounts of Darcy's character that might align with this behavior.
She ultimately feels certain she remembers hearing Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy described in his youth as a very proud and ill-natured boy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: To Mrs. Gardiner, Wickham had one means of affording pleasure, unconnected with his general powers.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Here, consequently, was an inexhaustible subject of discourse. In comparing her recollection of Pemberley with the minute description which Wickham could give, and in bestowing her tribute of praise on the character of its late possessor, she was delighting both him and herself. On being made acquainted with the present Mr. Darcy’s treatment of him, she tried to remember something of that gentleman’s reputed disposition, when quite a lad, which might agree with it; and was confident, at last, that she recollected having heard Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy formerly spoken of as a very proud, ill-natured boy.

events.text_segment:
To Mrs. Gardiner, Wickham had one means of affording pleasure, unconnected with his general powers. About ten or a dozen years ago, before her marriage, she had spent a considerable time in that very part of Derbyshire to which he belonged. They had, therefore, many acquaintance in common; and, though Wickham had been little there since the death of Darcy’s father, five years before, it was yet in his power to give her fresher intelligence of her former friends than she had been in the way of procuring.
Mrs. Gardiner had seen Pemberley, and known the late Mr. Darcy by character perfectly well. Here, consequently, was an inexhaustible subject of discourse. In comparing her recollection of Pemberley with the minute description which Wickham could give, and in bestowing her tribute of praise on the character of its late possessor, she was delighting both him and herself. On being made acquainted with the present Mr. Darcy’s treatment of him, she tried to remember something of that gentleman’s reputed disposition, when quite a lad, which might agree with it; and was confident, at last, that she recollected having heard Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy formerly spoken of as a very proud, ill-natured boy.

events.title: Mrs. Gardiner Cautions Elizabeth Regarding Mr. Wickham
detailed_summary: Mrs. Gardiner finds a private moment to speak with Elizabeth, expressing her concerns candidly.
She warns Elizabeth against developing or encouraging feelings for Mr. Wickham, highlighting the financial imprudence of such a match.
While acknowledging Wickham's appealing qualities, Mrs. Gardiner emphasizes his lack of fortune as a serious obstacle.
She appeals to Elizabeth's known sensibility, urging her not to let fancy overtake reason and reminding her of her father's trust in her judgment.
Elizabeth initially treats the warning lightly but then adopts a more serious tone.
She confesses she is not in love with Wickham at present but admits he is the most charming man she has ever met.
Elizabeth acknowledges the lack of wisdom in pursuing the connection and laments Mr. Darcy's negative influence on Wickham's circumstances.
She affirms the importance of her father's good opinion, though she notes his own favourable view of Wickham.
Elizabeth expresses reluctance to cause unhappiness but points out that financial issues often fail to deter young couples in love.
She questions the certainty that resisting such feelings is always the wisest path.
She commits to being cautious, promising not to rush into believing Wickham's affections are serious or to encourage wishful thinking when with him.
Mrs. Gardiner further advises Elizabeth to discourage Wickham's frequent visits and avoid prompting her mother to invite him.
Elizabeth acknowledges she recently encouraged an invitation but agrees this was unwise and will stop.
She explains his recent frequent presence was largely due to the Gardiners' visit and Mrs. Bennet's ideas about entertaining guests.
Elizabeth reassures her aunt she will genuinely try to act prudently.
Mrs. Gardiner expresses satisfaction, and Elizabeth gratefully acknowledges the advice, concluding the conversation without resentment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mrs. Gardiner's caution to Elizabeth was punctually and kindly given on the first favourable opportunity of speaking to her alone: after honestly telling her what she thought, she thus went on:—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her aunt assured her that she was; and Elizabeth, having thanked her for the kindness of her hints, they parted,—a wonderful instance of advice being given on such a point without being resented.

events.text_segment:
Mrs. Gardiner's caution to Elizabeth was punctually and kindly given on the first favourable opportunity of speaking to her alone: after honestly telling her what she thought, she thus went on:—
“You are too sensible a girl, Lizzy, to fall in love merely because you are warned against it; and, therefore, I am not afraid of speaking openly. Seriously, I would have you be on your guard. Do not involve yourself, or endeavour to involve him, in an affection which the want of fortune would make so very imprudent. I have nothing to say against him: he is a most interesting young man; and if he had the fortune he ought to have, I should think you could not do better. But as it is—you must not let your fancy run away with you. You have sense, and we all expect you to use it. Your father would depend on your resolution and good conduct, I am sure. You must not disappoint your father.”
“My dear aunt, this is being serious indeed.”
“Yes, and I hope to engage you to be serious likewise.”
“Well, then, you need not be under any alarm. I will take care of myself, and of Mr. Wickham too. He shall not be in love with me, if I can prevent it.”
“Elizabeth, you are not serious now.”
“I beg your pardon. I will try again. At present I am not in love with Mr. Wickham; no, I certainly am not. But he is, beyond all comparison, the most agreeable man I ever saw—and if he becomes really attached to me—I believe it will be better that he should not. I see the imprudence of it. Oh, that abominable Mr. Darcy! My father’s opinion of me does me the greatest honour; and I should be miserable to forfeit it. My father, however, is partial to Mr. Wickham. In short, my dear aunt, I should be very sorry to be the means of making any of you unhappy; but since we see, every day, that where there is affection young people are seldom withheld, by immediate want of fortune, from entering into engagements with each other, how can I promise to be wiser than so many of my fellow-creatures, if I am tempted, or how am I even to know that it would be wiser to resist? All that I can promise you, therefore, is not to be in a hurry. I will not be in a hurry to believe myself his first object. When I am in company with him, I will not be wishing. In short, I will do my best.”
“Perhaps it will be as well if you discourage his coming here so very often. At least you should not remind your mother of inviting him.”
“As I did the other day,” said Elizabeth, with a conscious smile; “very true, it will be wise in me to refrain from that. But do not imagine that he is always here so often. It is on your account that he has been so frequently invited this week. You know my mother’s ideas as to the necessity of constant company for her friends. But really, and upon my honour, I will try to do what I think to be wisest; and now I hope you are satisfied.”
Her aunt assured her that she was; and Elizabeth, having thanked her for the kindness of her hints, they parted,—a wonderful instance of advice being given on such a point without being resented.

events.title: Charlotte Lucas's Farewell Visit and Invitation to Hunsford
detailed_summary: Mr. Collins arrives back in Hertfordshire soon after the Gardiners and Jane depart.
His lodging with the Lucas family prevents him from being a major burden to Mrs. Bennet.
The date for his wedding to Charlotte Lucas is drawing near.
Mrs. Bennet has come to accept the marriage as unavoidable, though she sometimes voices ill-tempered hopes for their happiness.
The wedding is scheduled for Thursday; Charlotte visits the Bennets on Wednesday for her farewell.
Feeling embarrassed by her mother's ungraciousness and genuinely emotional herself, Elizabeth accompanies Charlotte out of the room.
While walking downstairs, Charlotte expresses her expectation of hearing from Elizabeth frequently.
Elizabeth assures her she will definitely write.
Charlotte then asks Elizabeth for another favour: to visit her in Kent.
Elizabeth suggests they might meet in Hertfordshire, but Charlotte states she is unlikely to leave Kent for a while.
Charlotte insists, and Elizabeth agrees to visit Hunsford, though she does not anticipate much pleasure from the trip.
Charlotte informs Elizabeth that her father and sister Maria plan to visit in March and warmly invites Elizabeth to join their party, emphasizing she would be as welcome as family.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Collins returned into Hertfordshire soon after it had been quitted by the Gardiners and Jane; but, as he took up his abode with the Lucases, his arrival was no great inconvenience to Mrs. Bennet.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Indeed, Eliza, you will be as welcome to me as either of them.”

events.text_segment:
Mr. Collins returned into Hertfordshire soon after it had been quitted by the Gardiners and Jane; but, as he took up his abode with the Lucases, his arrival was no great inconvenience to Mrs. Bennet. His marriage was now fast approaching; and she was at length so far resigned as to think it inevitable, and even repeatedly to say, in an ill-natured tone, that she “wished they might be happy.” Thursday was to be the wedding-day, and on Wednesday Miss Lucas paid her farewell visit; and when she rose to take leave, Elizabeth, ashamed of her mother’s ungracious and reluctant good wishes, and sincerely affected herself, accompanied her out of the room. As they went down stairs together, Charlotte said,—
“I shall depend on hearing from you very often, Eliza.”
“That you certainly shall.”
“And I have another favour to ask. Will you come and see me?”
“We shall often meet, I hope, in Hertfordshire.”
“I am not likely to leave Kent for some time. Promise me, therefore, to come to Hunsford.”
Elizabeth could not refuse, though she foresaw little pleasure in the visit.
“My father and Maria are to come to me in March,” added Charlotte, “and I hope you will consent to be of the party. Indeed, Eliza, you will be as welcome to me as either of them.”

events.title: Charlotte's Marriage and Guarded Correspondence from Hunsford
detailed_summary: The wedding takes place, and Mr. and Mrs. Collins leave for Kent directly from the church.
The event generates the customary level of local gossip.
Elizabeth soon receives letters from Charlotte, and their correspondence continues with its usual regularity.
Elizabeth feels, however, that the marriage has irrevocably altered their friendship, ending their former comfortable intimacy.
She continues to write more out of obligation to their past bond than to their current connection.
Elizabeth reads Charlotte's first letters with considerable curiosity about her new life, her opinion of Lady Catherine, and the degree of happiness she would profess.
Upon reading the letters, Elizabeth finds Charlotte's accounts entirely predictable.
Charlotte maintains a cheerful tone, details the comforts surrounding her, and praises everything she mentions.
The house, furnishings, neighbourhood, roads, and Lady Catherine's conduct are all described favourably.
Elizabeth recognizes this as Mr. Collins's idealized depiction of Hunsford and Rosings, merely adjusted to seem more rational.
She realizes she will need to visit Hunsford herself to grasp the true nature of Charlotte's situation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The wedding took place: the bride and bridegroom set off for Kent from the church door, and everybody had as much to say or to hear on the subject as usual.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth perceived that she must wait for her own visit there, to know the rest.

events.text_segment: The wedding took place: the bride and bridegroom set off for Kent from the church door, and everybody had as much to say or to hear on the subject as usual. Elizabeth soon heard from her friend, and their correspondence was as regular and frequent as it ever had been: that it should be equally unreserved was impossible. Elizabeth could never address her without feeling that all the comfort of intimacy was over; and, though determined not to slacken as a correspondent, it was for the sake of what had been rather than what was. Charlotte’s first letters were received with a good deal of eagerness: there could not but be curiosity to know how she would speak of her new home, how she would like Lady Catherine, and how happy she would dare pronounce herself to be; though, when the letters were read, Elizabeth felt that Charlotte expressed herself on every point exactly as she might have foreseen. She wrote cheerfully, seemed surrounded with comforts, and mentioned nothing which she could not praise. The house, furniture, neighbourhood, and roads, were all to her taste, and Lady Catherine’s behaviour was most friendly and obliging. It was Mr. Collins’s picture of Hunsford and Rosings rationally softened; and Elizabeth perceived that she must wait for her own visit there, to know the rest.

Elizabeth could never address her without feeling that all the comfort of intimacy was over, and though determined not to slacken as a correspondent, it was for the sake of what had been, rather than what was. Charlotte's first letters were received with a good deal of eagerness; there could not but be curiosity to know how she would speak of her new home, how she would like Lady Catherine, and how happy she would dare pronounce herself to be; though, when the letters were read, Elizabeth felt that Charlotte expressed herself on every point exactly as she might have foreseen. She wrote cheerfully, seemed surrounded with comforts, and mentioned nothing which she could not praise. The house, furniture, neighbourhood, and roads, were all to her taste, and Lady Catherine's behaviour was most friendly and obliging. It was Mr. Collins's picture of Hunsford and Rosings rationally softened; and Elizabeth perceived that she must wait for her own visit there, to know the rest.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The wedding took place: the bride and bridegroom set off for Kent from the church door, and everybody had as much to say or to hear on the subject as usual.

Elizabeth was left to reflect on the day's events. Mr. Collins and Charlotte were now husband and wife, a match that still bewildered her. Though she had initially judged Charlotte harshly for accepting Mr. Collins, Elizabeth now found herself contemplating the practical considerations that had guided her friend's decision.

As the carriage bearing the newlyweds disappeared from view, Elizabeth turned to her father, who wore an expression of quiet amusement. "Well, my dear," he said, "I suppose we must congratulate ourselves on having one daughter well settled at least."

Elizabeth smiled wryly. "Charlotte seems content with her choice."

"Indeed. And Mr. Collins appears delighted with his good fortune."

Walking home with her family, Elizabeth wondered what life at Hunsford Parsonage would be like for Charlotte. She had promised to visit in the spring, though the prospect of being in such close proximity to Lady Catherine de Bourgh was not entirely pleasant.

The Bennet household would certainly feel Charlotte's absence in the coming days.

events.title: Jane's Initial Experience in London and First Contact with Caroline Bingley
detailed_summary: Jane sends a short note to Elizabeth confirming her safe arrival in London.
Elizabeth anxiously awaits further news, hoping for information about the Bingleys.
Jane's second letter arrives after a week, reporting no contact from Caroline Bingley.

events.text_segment:
Jane had already written a few lines to her sister, to announce their safe arrival in London; and when she wrote again, Elizabeth hoped it would be in her power to say something of the Bingleys.
Her impatience for this second letter was as well rewarded as impatience generally is. Jane had been a week in town, without either seeing or hearing from Caroline. She accounted for it, however, by supposing that her last letter to her friend from Longbourn had by some accident been lost.
“My aunt,” she continued, “is going to-morrow into that part of the town, and I shall take the opportunity of calling in Grosvenor Street.”
She wrote again when the visit was paid, and she had seen Miss Bingley. “I did not think Caroline in spirits,” were her words, “but she was very glad to see me, and reproached me for giving her no notice of my coming to London. I was right, therefore; my last letter had never reached her. I inquired after their brother, of course. He was well, but so much engaged with Mr. Darcy that they scarcely ever saw him. I found that Miss Darcy was expected to dinner: I wish I could see her. My visit was not long, as Caroline and Mrs. Hurst were going out. I dare say I shall soon see them here.”
Elizabeth shook her head over this letter. It convinced her that accident only could discover to Mr. Bingley her sister’s being in town.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Her impatience for this second letter was as well rewarded as impatience generally is. Jane had been a week in town without either seeing or hearing from Caroline. She accounted for it, however, by supposing that her last letter from Netherfield had somehow been delayed, preventing Caroline from knowing of her presence in London.

"My aunt is convinced it must be so," wrote Jane, "and I shall therefore venture to call on Grosvenor Street tomorrow. I shall write again once I have seen her."

Elizabeth shook her head over this letter. It convinced her that accident alone could discover to Mr. Bingley that his beloved was in town.

Four weeks passed, and Jane saw nothing of him. She endeavored to persuade herself that she did not regret it, but she could no longer be blind to Caroline Bingley's inattention. After waiting at home every morning for a fortnight, she finally received a visit from Caroline, whose manner was cold and altered. It was evident that Caroline had no pleasure in the meeting, made only brief inquiries about Jane's family, and said little else. The visit was returned promptly but with equal formality, and the acquaintance seemed likely to dissolve entirely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Four weeks passed away, and Jane saw nothing of him.

events.text_segment:
Four weeks passed away, and Jane saw nothing of him. She endeavoured to persuade herself that she did not regret it; but she could no longer be blind to Miss Bingley’s inattention. After waiting at home every morning for a fortnight, and inventing every evening a fresh excuse for her, the visitor did at last appear; but the shortness of her stay, and, yet more, the alteration of her manner, would allow Jane to deceive herself no longer. The letter which she wrote on this occasion to her sister will prove what she felt:—
“My dearest Lizzy will, I am sure, be incapable of triumphing in her better judgment, at my expense, when I confess myself to have been entirely deceived in Miss Bingley’s regard for me. But, my dear sister, though the event has proved you right, do not think me obstinate if I still assert that, considering what her behaviour was, my confidence was as natural as your suspicion. I do not at all comprehend her reason for wishing to be intimate with me; but, if the same circumstances were to happen again, I am sure I should be deceived again. Caroline did not return my visit till yesterday; and not a note, not a line, did I receive in the meantime. When she did come, it was very evident that she had no pleasure in it; she made a slight, formal apology for not calling before, said not a word of wishing to see me again, and was, in every respect, so altered a creature, that when she went away I was perfectly resolved to continue the acquaintance no longer. I pity, though I cannot help blaming, her. She was very wrong in singling me out as she did; I can safely say, that every advance to intimacy began on her side. But I pity her, because she must feel that she has been acting wrong, and because I am very sure that anxiety for her brother is the cause of it. I need not explain myself farther; and though we know this anxiety to be quite needless, yet if she feels it, it will easily account for her behaviour to me; and so deservedly dear as he is to his sister, whatever anxiety she may feel on his behalf is natural and amiable. I cannot but wonder, however, at her having any such fears now, because if he had at all cared about me, we must have met long, long ago. He knows of my being in town, I am certain, from something she said herself; and yet it would seem, by her manner of talking, as if she wanted to persuade herself that he is really partial to Miss Darcy. I cannot understand it. If I were not afraid of judging harshly, I should be almost tempted to say, that there is a strong appearance of duplicity in all this. I will endeavour to banish every painful thought, and think only of what will make me happy, your affection, and the invariable kindness of my dear uncle and aunt. Let me hear from you very soon. Miss Bingley said something of his never returning to Netherfield again, of giving up the house, but not with any certainty. We had better not mention it. I am extremely glad that you have such pleasant accounts from our friends at Hunsford. Pray go to see them, with Sir William and Maria. I am sure you will be very comfortable there.
“Yours, etc.”
