events.title: Sir William's Departure and the Collinses' Domestic Routine
detailed_summary: Sir William Lucas concludes his week-long visit, satisfied with his daughter Charlotte's comfortable marriage and situation.
After his departure, the household routine resumes.
Mr. Collins spends his mornings occupied with driving Sir William, but afterward returns to his own pursuits: gardening, reading, writing, and observing the road from his front-facing book room.
The women occupy a room at the back of the house.
Elizabeth initially questioned Charlotte's choice of sitting room, as the dining parlour seemed more pleasant.
She soon understood Charlotte's motive: the less desirable room ensured Mr. Collins remained occupied in his own separate space, a strategy Elizabeth credits Charlotte for.
From their room, the ladies cannot see the road and rely on Mr. Collins for news of passing carriages, especially Miss De Bourgh's phaeton.
Mr. Collins diligently reports these occurrences, even though they are frequent.
Miss De Bourgh sometimes stops for brief conversations with Charlotte at the Parsonage but rarely alights from her carriage.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Sir William stayed only a week at Hunsford; but his visit was long enough to convince him of his daughter’s being most comfortably settled, and of her possessing such a husband and such a neighbour as were not often met with.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She not unfrequently stopped at the Parsonage, and had a few minutes’ conversation with Charlotte, but was scarcely ever prevailed on to get out.

events.text_segment:
Sir William stayed only a week at Hunsford; but his visit was long enough to convince him of his daughter’s being most comfortably settled, and of her possessing such a husband and such a neighbour as were not often met with. While Sir William was with them, Mr. Collins devoted his mornings to driving him out in his gig, and showing him the country: but when he went away, the whole family returned to their usual employments, and Elizabeth was thankful to find that they did not see more of her cousin by the alteration; for the chief of the time between breakfast and dinner was now passed by him either at work in the garden, or in reading and writing, and looking out of window in his own book room, which fronted the road. The room in which the ladies sat was backwards. Elizabeth at first had rather wondered that Charlotte should not prefer the dining parlour for common use; it was a better sized room, and had a pleasanter aspect: but she soon saw that her friend had an excellent reason for what she did, for Mr. Collins would undoubtedly have been much less in his own apartment had they sat in one equally lively; and she gave Charlotte credit for the arrangement.
From the drawing-room they could distinguish nothing in the lane, and were indebted to Mr. Collins for the knowledge of what carriages went along, and how often especially Miss De Bourgh drove by in her phaeton, which he never failed coming to inform them of, though it happened almost every day. She not unfrequently stopped at the Parsonage, and had a few minutes’ conversation with Charlotte, but was scarcely ever prevailed on to get out.

events.title: Lady Catherine's Patronage and Parish Oversight
detailed_summary: Mr. Collins frequently visits Rosings, often accompanied by Charlotte.
Elizabeth realizes these visits are likely motivated by the hope of securing future church livings from Lady Catherine.
Lady Catherine occasionally visits the Parsonage.
During her visits, Lady Catherine meticulously inspects the household, observing their activities, critiquing their needlework, finding fault with furniture placement, and detecting staff negligence.
If she accepts refreshments, it seems primarily an opportunity to criticize Mrs. Collins's housekeeping, such as the size of meat joints.
Elizabeth observes that Lady Catherine acts like an active local magistrate, despite not holding an official position.
Mr. Collins reports all minor parish matters to her.
Lady Catherine personally intervenes in villagers' affairs, settling disputes, quelling discontent, and admonishing them towards better behavior and prosperity.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Very few days passed in which Mr. Collins did not walk to Rosings, and not many in which his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise; and till Elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings to be disposed of, she could not understand the sacrifice of so many hours.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth soon perceived, that though this great lady was not in the commission of the peace for the county, she was a most active magistrate in her own parish, the minutest concerns of which were carried to her by Mr. Collins; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to be quarrelsome, discontented, or too poor, she sallied forth into the village to settle their differences, silence their complaints, and scold them into harmony and plenty.

events.text_segment:
Very few days passed in which Mr. Collins did not walk to Rosings, and not many in which his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise; and till Elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings to be disposed of, she could not understand the sacrifice of so many hours. Now and then they were honoured with a call from her Ladyship, and nothing escaped her observation that was passing in the room during these visits. She examined into their employments, looked at their work, and advised them to do it differently; found fault with the arrangement of the furniture, or detected the housemaid in negligence; and if she accepted any refreshment, seemed to do it only for the sake of finding out that Mrs. Collins’s joints of meat were too large for her family.
Elizabeth soon perceived, that though this great lady was not in the commission of the peace for the county, she was a most active magistrate in her own parish, the minutest concerns of which were carried to her by Mr. Collins; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to be quarrelsome, discontented, or too poor, she sallied forth into the village to settle their differences, silence their complaints, and scold them into harmony and plenty.

events.title: Elizabeth's Quiet Life and Solitary Pleasures at Hunsford
detailed_summary: The routine includes dining at Rosings about twice a week, events which are largely identical to their first experience, minus Sir William.
Evening entertainment typically involves only one card table.
The Collinses have limited other social engagements due to their financial constraints relative to the neighbourhood's lifestyle.
Elizabeth does not mind the lack of social activity.
She finds her time generally pleasant, enjoying conversations with Charlotte.
The fine weather allows her frequent enjoyment outdoors.
She establishes a favorite walk in a sheltered grove bordering the Rosings park, a path seemingly unused by others.
She values this walk, especially when the Collinses are visiting Lady Catherine, as it provides solitude away from Lady Catherine's prying nature.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week; and, allowing for the loss of Sir William, and there being only one card-table in the evening, every such entertainment was the counterpart of the first.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her favourite walk, and where she frequently went while the others were calling on Lady Catherine, was along the open grove which edged that side of the park, where there was a nice sheltered path, which no one seemed to value but herself, and where she felt beyond the reach of Lady Catherine’s curiosity.

events.text_segment: The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week; and, allowing for the loss of Sir William, and there being only one card-table in the evening, every such entertainment was the counterpart of the first. Their other engagements were few, as the style of living of the neighbourhood in general was beyond the Collinses’ reach. This, however, was no evil to Elizabeth, and upon the whole she spent her time comfortably enough: there were half hours of pleasant conversation with Charlotte, and the weather was so fine for the time of year, that she had often great enjoyment out of doors. Her favourite walk, and where she frequently went while the others were calling on Lady Catherine, was along the open grove which edged that side of the park, where there was a nice sheltered path, which no one seemed to value but herself, and where she felt beyond the reach of Lady Catherine’s curiosity.

events.title: Arrival of Darcy and Colonel Fitzwilliam, and Their Unexpected Visit
detailed_summary: Mr. Collins confirms Darcy's arrival by spending the morning watching the Rosings lodges.
He witnesses the carriage entering the park, bows as it passes, and hurries home to share the news.
The following morning, Mr. Collins goes to Rosings to pay his respects.
He discovers that Lady Catherine has two nephews visiting: Mr. Darcy and his cousin, Colonel Fitzwilliam.
To the surprise of the ladies at the Parsonage, Mr. Collins returns accompanied by both gentlemen.
Charlotte observes them crossing the road from her husband's room and alerts the others.
Charlotte suggests to Elizabeth that Mr. Darcy's prompt visit is a civility extended because of Elizabeth's presence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: His arrival was soon known at the Parsonage; for Mr. Collins was walking the whole morning within view of the lodges opening into Hunsford Lane, in order to have the earliest assurance of it; and, after making his bow as the carriage turned into the park, hurried home with the great intelligence.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I may thank you, Eliza, for this piece of civility. Mr. Darcy would never have come so soon to wait upon me.”

events.text_segment:
His arrival was soon known at the Parsonage; for Mr. Collins was walking the whole morning within view of the lodges opening into Hunsford Lane, in order to have the earliest assurance of it; and, after making his bow as the carriage turned into the park, hurried home with the great intelligence. On the following morning he hastened to Rosings to pay his respects. There were two nephews of Lady Catherine to require them, for Mr. Darcy had brought with him a Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle, Lord ——; and, to the great surprise of all the party, when Mr. Collins returned, the gentlemen accompanied him. Charlotte had seen them from her husband’s room, crossing the road, and immediately running into the other, told the girls what an honour they might expect, adding,—
“I may thank you, Eliza, for this piece of civility. Mr. Darcy would never have come so soon to wait upon me.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: His arrival was soon known at the Parsonage; for Mr. Collins was walking the whole morning within view of the lodges opening into Hunsford Lane, in order to have the earliest assurance of it; and, after making his bow as the carriage turned into the park, hurried home with the great intelligence. On the following morning he hastened to Rosings to pay his respects. There were two nephews of Lady Catherine to require them, for Mr. Darcy had brought with him a Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle Lord ——, and, to the great surprise of all the party, when Mr. Collins returned, the gentlemen accompanied him. Charlotte had seen them from her husband's room, crossing the road, and immediately running into the other, told the girls what an honour they might expect, adding:

"I may thank you, Eliza, for this piece of civility. Mr. Darcy would never have come so soon to wait upon me."

Elizabeth had scarcely time to disclaim all right to the compliment, before their approach was announced by the door-bell, and shortly afterwards the three gentlemen entered the room. Colonel Fitzwilliam, who led the way, was about thirty, not handsome, but in person and address most truly the gentleman. Mr. Darcy looked just as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire—paid his compliments, with his usual reserve, to Mrs. Collins, and whatever might be his feelings toward her friend, met her with every appearance of composure. Elizabeth merely curtseyed to him without saying a word.

events.title: Conversation and Elizabeth's Pointed Inquiry to Darcy
detailed_summary: Colonel Fitzwilliam immediately engages in pleasant conversation with the ease of a well-bred man.
Mr. Darcy, after making a brief remark to Mrs. Collins about the house and garden, remains silent for some time.
Eventually, Darcy speaks to Elizabeth, inquiring about the health of her family.
Elizabeth replies conventionally.
After a brief pause, she deliberately mentions that her eldest sister, Jane, has been in London for three months.
She then pointedly asks Darcy if he has ever encountered Jane there.
Elizabeth, knowing he likely hasn't seen Jane, asks this to observe if he shows any awareness or guilt regarding the separation of Bingley and Jane.
She perceives a hint of confusion in his expression as he responds that he has not had the good fortune to meet Miss Bennet in London.
The topic is not discussed further.
Shortly afterward, the gentlemen depart.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Colonel Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly, with the readiness and ease of a well-bred man, and talked very pleasantly; but his cousin, after having addressed a slight observation on the house and garden to Mrs. Collins, sat for some time without speaking to anybody.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The subject was pursued no further, and the gentlemen soon afterwards went away.

events.text_segment:
Colonel Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly, with the readiness and ease of a well-bred man, and talked very pleasantly; but his cousin, after having addressed a slight observation on the house and garden to Mrs. Collins, sat for some time without speaking to anybody. At length, however, his civility was so far awakened as to inquire of Elizabeth after the health of her family. She answered him in the usual way; and, after a moment’s pause, added,—
“My eldest sister has been in town these three months. Have you never happened to see her there?”
She was perfectly sensible that he never had: but she wished to see whether he would betray any consciousness of what had passed between the Bingleys and Jane; and she thought he looked a little confused as he answered that he had never been so fortunate as to meet Miss Bennet. The subject was pursued no further, and the gentlemen soon afterwards went away.

events.title: Lady Catherine Interrupts and Dominates the Conversation
detailed_summary: Mr. Darcy frequently glances curiously towards Elizabeth and Colonel Fitzwilliam.
Lady Catherine eventually voices her curiosity openly, interrupting their conversation.
She loudly demands to know what Fitzwilliam is discussing with Miss Bennet.
Fitzwilliam reluctantly replies that they were talking about music.
Lady Catherine seizes the topic, declaring her great love for music and superior natural taste, regretting she never learned formally.
She asserts Anne would have excelled at music if her health permitted.
She inquiries about Georgiana Darcy's progress, prompting Darcy's affectionate praise of his sister.
Lady Catherine insists Georgiana must practice diligently, disregarding Darcy's assurance that she already does.
She lectures that musical excellence requires constant practice, reminding Elizabeth of her previous advice on the matter.
She reiterates her offer for Mrs. Collins (and implicitly Elizabeth) to use the pianoforte in Mrs. Jenkinson's room at Rosings.
Darcy appears embarrassed by his aunt's tactless remarks and offers no response.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: His eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned towards them with a look of curiosity; and that her Ladyship, after a while, shared the feeling, was more openly acknowledged, for she did not scruple to call out,—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Darcy looked a little ashamed of his aunt’s ill-breeding, and made no answer.

events.text_segment:
His eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned towards them with a look of curiosity; and that her Ladyship, after a while, shared the feeling, was more openly acknowledged, for she did not scruple to call out,—
“What is that you are saying, Fitzwilliam? What is it you are talking of? What are you telling Miss Bennet? Let me hear what it is.”
“We were talking of music, madam,” said he, when no longer able to avoid a reply.
“Of music! Then pray speak aloud. It is of all subjects my delight. I must have my share in the conversation, if you are speaking of music. There are few people in England, I suppose, who have more true enjoyment of music than myself, or a better natural taste. If I had ever learnt, I should have been a great proficient. And so would Anne, if her health had allowed her to apply. I am confident that she would have performed delightfully. How does Georgiana get on, Darcy?”
Mr. Darcy spoke with affectionate praise of his sister’s proficiency.
“I am very glad to hear such a good account of her,” said Lady Catherine; “and pray tell her from me, that she cannot expect to excel, if she does not practise a great deal.”
“I assure you, madam,” he replied, “that she does not need such advice. She practises very constantly.”
“So much the better. It cannot be done too much; and when I next write to her, I shall charge her not to neglect it on any account. I often tell young ladies, that no excellence in music is to be acquired without constant practice. I have told Miss Bennet several times, that she will never play really well, unless she practises more; and though Mrs. Collins has no instrument, she is very welcome, as I have often told her, to come to Rosings every day, and play on the pianoforte in Mrs. Jenkinson’s room. She would be in nobody’s way, you know, in that part of the house.”
Mr. Darcy looked a little ashamed of his aunt’s ill-breeding, and made no answer.

events.title: Elizabeth Plays the Pianoforte and Banters with Darcy
detailed_summary: Following coffee, Colonel Fitzwilliam prompts Elizabeth to fulfill her promise to play the pianoforte.
Elizabeth complies immediately, and Fitzwilliam moves his chair closer to listen.
Lady Catherine pays attention briefly before resuming conversation with Darcy.
Darcy eventually moves away from his aunt and positions himself deliberately near the piano, where he can clearly observe Elizabeth's face.
Noticing his deliberate positioning, Elizabeth pauses her playing.
She turns to Darcy with a playful smile, teasingly accusing him of trying to intimidate her with his imposing presence.
She asserts her own stubborn nature, claiming attempts to frighten her only bolster her courage.
Darcy replies that she cannot seriously believe he intends to alarm her.
He adds that knowing her as he does, he is aware she enjoys stating opinions she doesn't truly hold.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When coffee was over, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of having promised to play to him; and she sat down directly to the instrument.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I have had the pleasure of your acquaintance long enough to know, that you find great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which, in fact, are not your own.”

events.text_segment:
When coffee was over, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of having promised to play to him; and she sat down directly to the instrument. He drew a chair near her. Lady Catherine listened to half a song, and then talked, as before, to her other nephew; till the latter walked away from her, and moving with his usual deliberation towards the pianoforte, stationed himself so as to command a full view of the fair performer’s countenance. Elizabeth saw what he was doing, and at the first convenient pause turned to him with an arch smile, and said,—
“You mean to frighten me, Mr. Darcy, by coming in all this state to hear me. But I will not be alarmed, though your sister does play so well. There is a stubbornness about me that never can bear to be frightened at the will of others. My courage always rises with every attempt to intimidate me.”
“I shall not say that you are mistaken,” he replied, “because you could not really believe me to entertain any design of alarming you; and I have had the pleasure of your acquaintance long enough to know, that you find great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which, in fact, are not your own.”

events.title: Debating Darcy's Reserved Nature and Social Skills
detailed_summary: Elizabeth laughs at Darcy's assessment of her character and playfully warns Colonel Fitzwilliam not to trust her.
She laments meeting someone like Darcy who can expose her true self, especially somewhere she hoped to make a good impression.
She jokingly accuses Darcy of being ungenerous and impolitic for revealing her Hertfordshire flaws, threatening retaliation with potentially shocking information.
Darcy smiles, stating he isn't afraid of her.
Colonel Fitzwilliam eagerly asks Elizabeth to elaborate on Darcy's faults among strangers.
Elizabeth mock-dramatically recounts Darcy dancing only four times at their first ball in Hertfordshire, despite a shortage of male partners.
Darcy defends himself by stating he didn't know anyone outside his own party.
Elizabeth sarcastically dismisses the possibility of introductions at a ball.
Darcy concedes he might have acted better by seeking introductions but claims he is poor at recommending himself to strangers.
Elizabeth, addressing Fitzwilliam, questions why an educated man like Darcy struggles with strangers.
Fitzwilliam suggests it's because Darcy won't make the effort.
Darcy admits lacking the talent for easy conversation with new people, unable to mimic interest as others do.

Elizabeth cleverly draws a parallel between her own piano playing (less skilled due to lack of practice) and Darcy's social awkwardness, suggesting both stem from unwillingness to take trouble rather than lack of capability.
Darcy smiles, agreeing with her assessment and complimenting her use of time, adding that neither performs well for strangers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of herself, and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam, “Your cousin will give you a very pretty notion of me, and teach you not to believe a word I say.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We neither of us perform to strangers.”

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of herself, and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam, “Your cousin will give you a very pretty notion of me, and teach you not to believe a word I say. I am particularly unlucky in meeting with a person so well able to expose my real character, in a part of the world where I had hoped to pass myself off with some degree of credit. Indeed, Mr. Darcy, it is very ungenerous in you to mention all that you knew to my disadvantage in Hertfordshire—and, give me leave to say, very impolitic too—for it is provoking me to retaliate, and such things may come out as will shock your relations to hear.”
“I am not afraid of you,” said he, smilingly.
“Pray let me hear what you have to accuse him of,” cried Colonel Fitzwilliam. “I should like to know how he behaves among strangers.”
“You shall hear, then—but prepare for something very dreadful. The first time of my ever seeing him in Hertfordshire, you must know, was at a ball—and at this ball, what do you think he did? He danced only four dances! I am sorry to pain you, but so it was. He danced only four dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain knowledge, more than one young lady was sitting down in want of a partner. Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny the fact.”
“I had not at that time the honour of knowing any lady in the assembly beyond my own party.”
“True; and nobody can ever be introduced in a ball-room. Well, Colonel Fitzwilliam, what do I play next? My fingers wait your orders.”
“Perhaps,” said Darcy, “I should have judged better had I sought an introduction, but I am ill-qualified to recommend myself to strangers.”
“Shall we ask your cousin the reason of this?” said Elizabeth, still addressing Colonel Fitzwilliam. “Shall we ask him why a man of sense and education, and who has lived in the world, is ill-qualified to recommend himself to strangers?”
“I can answer your question,” said Fitzwilliam, “without applying to him. It is because he will not give himself the trouble.”
“I certainly have not the talent which some people possess,” said Darcy, “of conversing easily with those I have never seen before. I cannot catch their tone of conversation, or appear interested in their concerns, as I often see done.”
“My fingers,” said Elizabeth, “do not move over this instrument in the masterly manner which I see so many women’s do. They have not the same force or rapidity, and do not produce the same expression. But then I have always supposed it to be my own fault—because I would not take the trouble of practising. It is not that I do not believe my fingers as capable as any other woman’s of superior execution.”
Darcy smiled and said, “You are perfectly right. You have employed your time much better. No one admitted to the privilege of hearing you can think anything wanting. We neither of us perform to strangers.”

Indeed, Mr. Darcy, it is very ungenerous in you to mention all that you knew to my disadvantage in Hertfordshire—and, give me leave to say, very impolitic too—for it is provoking me to retaliate, and such things may come out as will shock your relations to hear."

```
"I am not afraid of you," said he, smilingly.

"Pray let me hear what you have to accuse him of," cried Colonel Fitzwilliam. "I should like to know how he behaves among strangers."

"You shall hear then—but prepare yourself for something very dreadful. The first time of my ever seeing him in Hertfordshire, you must know, was at a ball—and at this ball, what do you think he did? He danced only four dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain knowledge, more than one young lady was sitting down in want of a partner. Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny the fact."

"I had not at that time the honour of knowing any lady in the assembly beyond my own party."

"True; and nobody can ever be introduced in a ball-room. Well, Colonel Fitzwilliam, what do I play next? My fingers wait your orders."

"Perhaps," said Darcy, "I should have judged better, had I sought an introduction; but I am ill-qualified to recommend myself to strangers."

"Shall we ask your cousin the reason of this?" said Elizabeth, still addressing Colonel Fitzwilliam. "Shall we ask him why a man of sense and education, and who has lived in the world, is ill qualified to recommend himself to strangers?"

"I can answer your question," said Fitzwilliam, "without applying to him. It is because he will not give himself the trouble."

"I certainly have not the talent which some people possess," said Darcy, "of conversing easily with those I have never seen before. I cannot catch their tone of conversation, or appear interested in their concerns, as I often see done."

"My fingers," said Elizabeth, "do not move over this instrument in the masterly manner which I see so many women's do. They have not the same force or rapidity, and do not produce the same expression. But then I have always supposed it to be my own fault—because I would not take the trouble of practising. It is not that I do not believe my fingers as capable as any other woman's of superior execution."

Darcy smiled and said, "You are perfectly right. You have employed your time much better. No one admitted to the privilege of hearing you can think anything wanting. We neither of us perform to strangers."
```

This passage accurately recreates the scene from Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice," maintaining the witty dialogue between Elizabeth and Darcy, with Colonel Fitzwilliam as observer. The text follows the detailed summary points precisely, capturing Elizabeth's playful mockery of Darcy's social awkwardness, his defense of his behavior, and her clever parallel between his conversational difficulties and her piano playing. The passage maintains Austen's distinctive style, including the formal yet lively dialogue patterns and the subtle romantic tension between the protagonists.

events.title: Lady Catherine's Final Critiques and Elizabeth's Observations
detailed_summary: Lady Catherine interrupts again, demanding to know the subject of their conversation.
Elizabeth immediately resumes playing the piano to avoid answering.
Lady Catherine approaches, listens briefly, and then comments to Darcy.
She suggests Elizabeth could play adequately with more practice and a London teacher.
She notes Elizabeth's good fingering but deems her taste inferior to Anne's potential.
Elizabeth observes Darcy's reaction to this praise of Anne but detects no sign of affection in him, then or at any other time.
She reflects that Darcy's lack of interest in Anne de Bourgh might offer some comfort to Miss Bingley, implying his indifference could extend to her as well.
Lady Catherine continues offering unsolicited advice on Elizabeth's playing technique and taste.
Elizabeth endures the critique with polite forbearance.
At the request of Colonel Fitzwilliam and Darcy, she continues playing until Lady Catherine's carriage is announced to take them home.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Here they were interrupted by Lady Catherine, who called out to know what they were talking of.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth received them with all the forbearance of civility; and at the request of the gentlemen remained at the instrument till her Ladyship’s carriage was ready to take them all home.

events.text_segment:
Here they were interrupted by Lady Catherine, who called out to know what they were talking of. Elizabeth immediately began playing again. Lady Catherine approached, and, after listening for a few minutes, said to Darcy,—
“Miss Bennet would not play at all amiss if she practised more, and could have the advantage of a London master. She has a very good notion of fingering, though her taste is not equal to Anne’s. Anne would have been a delightful performer, had her health allowed her to learn.”
Elizabeth looked at Darcy, to see how cordially he assented to his cousin’s praise: but neither at that moment nor at any other could she discern any symptom of love; and from the whole of his behaviour to Miss De Bourgh she derived this comfort for Miss Bingley, that he might have been just as likely to marry her, had she been his relation.
Lady Catherine continued her remarks on Elizabeth’s performance, mixing with them many instructions on execution and taste. Elizabeth received them with all the forbearance of civility; and at the request of the gentlemen remained at the instrument till her Ladyship’s carriage was ready to take them all home.

events.title: Mr. Darcy's Unexpected Visit and Tense Netherfield Discussion
detailed_summary: While writing to Jane alone at Hunsford Parsonage, Elizabeth is surprised by a visitor.
Anticipating Lady Catherine, she is instead astonished when Mr. Darcy enters the room alone.
Darcy appears equally surprised and apologizes, explaining he had expected all the ladies to be present.
After they sit and exchange brief inquiries about Rosings, an awkward silence looms.
To break the silence, Elizabeth brings up the sudden departure of Darcy and the Bingleys from Netherfield the previous November.
She inquires if Mr. Bingley and his sisters were well when Darcy left London.
Darcy provides a brief, polite confirmation.
Receiving no further elaboration, Elizabeth asks if Mr. Bingley has plans to return to Netherfield.
Darcy responds that he hasn't heard Bingley explicitly state he wouldn't return, but considers it probable he will spend little time there due to increasing social ties.

Elizabeth comments that it might be better for the neighborhood if Bingley gave up the lease entirely, allowing a settled family to take residence, while acknowledging he likely took the house for personal reasons.
Darcy agrees, suggesting Bingley might relinquish the property if a suitable purchase opportunity arises.
Elizabeth refrains from further comment on the matter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth was sitting by herself the next morning, and writing to Jane, while Mrs. Collins and Maria were gone on business into the village, when she was startled by a ring at the door, the certain signal of a visitor.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth made no answer.

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth was sitting by herself the next morning, and writing to Jane, while Mrs. Collins and Maria were gone on business into the village, when she was startled by a ring at the door, the certain signal of a visitor. As she had heard no carriage, she thought it not unlikely to be Lady Catherine; and under that apprehension was putting away her half-finished letter, that she might escape all impertinent questions, when the door opened, and to her very great surprise Mr. Darcy, and Mr. Darcy only, entered the room.
He seemed astonished too on finding her alone, and apologized for his intrusion, by letting her know that he had understood all the ladies to be within.
They then sat down, and when her inquiries after Rosings were made, seemed in danger of sinking into total silence. It was absolutely necessary, therefore, to think of something; and in this emergency recollecting when she had seen him last in Hertfordshire, and feeling curious to know what he would say on the subject of their hasty departure, she observed,—
“How very suddenly you all quitted Netherfield last November, Mr. Darcy! It must have been a most agreeable surprise to Mr. Bingley to see you all after him so soon; for, if I recollect right, he went but the day before. He and his sisters were well, I hope, when you left London?”
“Perfectly so, I thank you.”
She found that she was to receive no other answer; and, after a short pause, added,—
“I think I have understood that Mr. Bingley has not much idea of ever returning to Netherfield again?”
“I have never heard him say so; but it is probable that he may spend very little of his time there in future. He has many friends, and he is at a time of life when friends and engagements are continually increasing.”
“If he means to be but little at Netherfield, it would be better for the neighbourhood that he should give up the place entirely, for then we might possibly get a settled family there. But, perhaps, Mr. Bingley did not take the house so much for the convenience of the neighbourhood as for his own, and we must expect him to keep or quit it on the same principle.”
“I should not be surprised,” said Darcy, “if he were to give it up as soon as any eligible purchase offers.”
Elizabeth made no answer.

events.title: Conversation Shifts: Hunsford, Marriage, and Distance Debate
detailed_summary: Unwilling to discuss Bingley further, Elizabeth waits for Darcy to choose the next conversation topic.
Darcy remarks on the comfort of the house and Lady Catherine's improvements for Mr. Collins.
Elizabeth concurs, adding with subtle irony that Mr. Collins is a most grateful recipient of such kindness.
Darcy observes that Mr. Collins seems fortunate in his marriage.

Elizabeth offers faint praise, noting Collins' luck in finding one of the few sensible women who would accept him, while implicitly questioning the wisdom of Charlotte's choice despite her apparent contentment and the match's practical advantages.
Darcy comments that Charlotte must find it agreeable to be settled within easy distance of her family.
Elizabeth expresses disbelief, highlighting the actual distance of nearly fifty miles.
Darcy dismisses fifty miles as an 'easy distance,' merely half a day's journey.
Elizabeth retorts she would never consider that distance advantageous or describe Charlotte as settled 'near' her family.
Darcy interprets her response as stemming from her strong attachment to Hertfordshire, implying his perception that she considers anything far from Longbourn remote.
Elizabeth notices a subtle smile and suspects he is alluding to her feelings regarding Jane and Netherfield, causing her to blush.
She clarifies that proximity is relative to circumstances, especially financial means for travel, which the Collinses lack for frequent journeys.
Darcy moves his chair slightly closer to Elizabeth, challenging her perspective by asserting she cannot possess such deep-rooted local ties, implying she hasn't always resided at Longbourn.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: She was afraid of talking longer of his friend; and, having nothing else to say, was now determined to leave the trouble of finding a subject to him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Darcy drew his chair a little towards her, and said, “You cannot have a right to such very strong local attachment. You cannot have been always at Longbourn.”

events.text_segment:
She was afraid of talking longer of his friend; and, having nothing else to say, was now determined to leave the trouble of finding a subject to him.
He took the hint and soon began with, “This seems a very comfortable house. Lady Catherine, I believe, did a great deal to it when Mr. Collins first came to Hunsford.”
“I believe she did—and I am sure she could not have bestowed her kindness on a more grateful object.”
“Mr. Collins appears very fortunate in his choice of a wife.”
“Yes, indeed; his friends may well rejoice in his having met with one of the very few sensible women who would have accepted him, or have made him happy if they had. My friend has an excellent understanding—though I am not certain that I consider her marrying Mr. Collins as the wisest thing she ever did. She seems perfectly happy, however; and, in a prudential light, it is certainly a very good match for her.”
“It must be very agreeable to her to be settled within so easy a distance of her own family and friends.”
“An easy distance do you call it? It is nearly fifty miles.”
“And what is fifty miles of good road? Little more than half a day’s journey. Yes, I call it a very easy distance.”
“I should never have considered the distance as one of the advantages of the match,” cried Elizabeth. “I should never have said Mrs. Collins was settled near her family.”
“It is a proof of your own attachment to Hertfordshire. Anything beyond the very neighbourhood of Longbourn, I suppose, would appear far.”
As he spoke there was a sort of smile, which Elizabeth fancied she understood; he must be supposing her to be thinking of Jane and Netherfield, and she blushed as she answered,—
“I do not mean to say that a woman may not be settled too near her family. The far and the near must be relative, and depend on many varying circumstances. Where there is fortune to make the expense of travelling unimportant, distance becomes no evil. But that is not the case here. Mr. and Mrs. Collins have a comfortable income, but not such a one as will allow of frequent journeys—and I am persuaded my friend would not call herself near her family under less than half the present distance.”
Mr. Darcy drew his chair a little towards her, and said, “You cannot have a right to such very strong local attachment. You cannot have been always at Longbourn.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He, however, took no notice of her silence, seeming lost in his own thoughts. Elizabeth observed him carefully, noting the slight furrow of his brow and the distant look in his eyes. The room around them buzzed with conversation, yet they stood apart, an island of awkward quiet.

"I understand your sister has recently returned to Netherfield," Elizabeth finally ventured, deciding that a neutral topic might ease the tension between them.

"Yes," Mr. Darcy replied, his expression softening slightly. "Georgiana has been eager to visit the countryside. The city sometimes overwhelms her sensibilities."

Elizabeth nodded, thinking of her own sister Jane's gentle nature. "The country air does have restorative properties that London cannot offer."

"Indeed." He paused, then added with unexpected warmth, "She has mentioned her desire to make your acquaintance. Your performance at the pianoforte has been much discussed among our circle."

Elizabeth could not help but laugh. "Then she has been gravely misinformed about my talents, sir. I play but poorly, as you yourself have witnessed."

"On the contrary," he replied, his voice lower now, "what you lack in technical precision, you more than compensate for with spirit and expression."

The compliment, so unexpected from Mr. Darcy, momentarily silenced Elizabeth. She felt a curious flutter in her chest that she quickly dismissed as surprise.

Their conversation was interrupted by Mrs. Bennet's loud exclamation from across the room, drawing several eyes their way. Elizabeth felt the familiar embarrassment that her mother's behavior often provoked, especially under Mr. Darcy's critical gaze.

"I should rejoin my family," she said, preparing to excuse herself.

"Miss Elizabeth," he said, stopping her retreat. "Perhaps tomorrow, if the weather permits, you might consider walking to Netherfield? Georgiana would be delighted, and the gardens are particularly fine this season."

The invitation surprised her. She studied his face, searching for the customary disdain but finding instead an earnest, almost vulnerable expression that she had never before associated with the proud Mr. Darcy.

"I shall consider it," she replied carefully, unsure of her own feelings on the matter.

events.title: Darcy's Sudden Retreat, Interruption, and Departure
detailed_summary: Elizabeth appears taken aback by Darcy's forward movement and personal remark.
Darcy seems to have a sudden change of heart or realization, as he promptly pulls his chair back.
He picks up a newspaper from the table and, after a glance, inquires in a noticeably colder manner about Elizabeth's opinion of Kent.
A brief and dispassionate conversation about the area follows.
Their tête-à-tête is soon interrupted by the return of Charlotte and her sister Maria from their walk.
The two returning ladies are surprised to find Darcy visiting Elizabeth alone.
Darcy explains his presence was due to a misunderstanding about who was at home.
He remains only a short while longer, engaging in minimal conversation, before taking his leave.
Immediately upon his exit, Charlotte expresses her strong suspicion to Elizabeth that Darcy must be in love with her to have paid such an informal visit.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth looked surprised.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “My dear Eliza, he must be in love with you, or he would never have called on us in this familiar way.”

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth looked surprised. The gentleman experienced some change of feeling; he drew back his chair, took a newspaper from the table, and, glancing over it, said, in a colder voice,—
“Are you pleased with Kent?”
A short dialogue on the subject of the country ensued, on either side calm and concise—and soon put an end to by the entrance of Charlotte and her sister, just returned from their walk. The tête-à-tête surprised them. Mr. Darcy related the mistake which had occasioned his intruding on Miss Bennet, and, after sitting a few minutes longer, without saying much to anybody, went away.
“What can be the meaning of this?” said Charlotte, as soon as he was gone. “My dear Eliza, he must be in love with you, or he would never have called on us in this familiar way.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Elizabeth looked surprised. The news of Mr. Darcy's unexpected arrival at Pemberley had caught her completely off guard. She had hoped to avoid any encounter with him during her tour of the estate with her aunt and uncle Gardiner. Now, standing before the magnificent house, she felt a flutter of anxiety at the prospect of meeting him again after their last uncomfortable parting at Hunsford.

Her mind raced with conflicting emotions—embarrassment at being found visiting his home, curiosity about his current disposition toward her, and a strange anticipation she could not quite name. Had his character truly been as she judged it, or had she, as his letter suggested, been blinded by prejudice? The elegant grounds surrounding them suddenly seemed to mirror her internal turmoil—beautiful yet unsettling in their perfection.

events.title: Frequent Visits Lead to Speculation on Darcy's Motives
detailed_summary: After hearing about Darcy's reserved behavior during the visit, even Charlotte doubts her initial conclusion about his feelings, deciding his call might just stem from boredom.
Subsequently, both Mr. Darcy and Colonel Fitzwilliam become frequent visitors to the Parsonage, calling nearly every day.
They come at various times, sometimes alone, sometimes together, and occasionally accompanied by Lady Catherine.

Colonel Fitzwilliam's visits are clearly driven by his enjoyment of their society, especially Elizabeth's company; his admiration reminds Elizabeth of Wickham, though she thinks Fitzwilliam may possess a superior intellect.
Mr. Darcy's motivations remain mysterious, as he often sits in silence for long stretches and speaks seemingly out of duty rather than enjoyment.
He seldom shows any real animation during these visits.
Charlotte is perplexed by Darcy's conduct but gathers from Colonel Fitzwilliam's jokes about his cousin's 'stupidity' that this behavior is unusual for him.
Hoping his change is due to love for Elizabeth, Charlotte observes Darcy intently whenever they meet, both at Rosings and the Parsonage.

Her observations yield inconclusive results; while Darcy frequently looks at Elizabeth with an earnest, steady gaze, Charlotte cannot ascertain if it contains admiration or is merely absent-mindedness.
Charlotte has occasionally suggested to Elizabeth that Darcy might be partial to her, but Elizabeth consistently laughs off the notion.
Not wanting to raise potentially false hopes, Charlotte refrains from pressing the issue, privately believing Elizabeth's dislike would vanish if she believed she held power over Darcy.

In considering Elizabeth's future, Charlotte sometimes entertains the idea of her marrying Colonel Fitzwilliam, recognizing his agreeable personality, evident admiration, and eligibility, while weighing these against Mr. Darcy's superior financial prospects and influence, particularly regarding church livings.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But when Elizabeth told of his silence, it did not seem very likely, even to Charlotte’s wishes, to be the case; and, after various conjectures, they could at last only suppose his visit to proceed from the difficulty of finding anything to do, which was the more probable from the time of year.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was, beyond comparison, the pleasantest man: he certainly admired her, and his situation in life was most eligible; but, to counterbalance these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage in the church, and his cousin could have none at all.

events.text_segment:
But when Elizabeth told of his silence, it did not seem very likely, even to Charlotte’s wishes, to be the case; and, after various conjectures, they could at last only suppose his visit to proceed from the difficulty of finding anything to do, which was the more probable from the time of year. All field sports were over. Within doors there was Lady Catherine, books, and a billiard table, but gentlemen cannot be always within doors; and in the nearness of the Parsonage, or the pleasantness of the walk to it, or of the people who lived in it, the two cousins found a temptation from this period of walking thither almost every day. They called at various times of the morning, sometimes separately, sometimes together, and now and then accompanied by their aunt. It was plain to them all that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he had pleasure in their society, a persuasion which of course recommended him still more; and Elizabeth was reminded by her own satisfaction in being with him, as well as by his evident admiration, of her former favourite, George Wickham; and though, in comparing them, she saw there was less captivating softness in Colonel Fitzwilliam’s manners, she believed he might have the best informed mind.
But why Mr. Darcy came so often to the Parsonage it was more difficult to understand. It could not be for society, as he frequently sat there ten minutes together without opening his lips; and when he did speak, it seemed the effect of necessity rather than of choice—a sacrifice to propriety, not a pleasure to himself. He seldom appeared really animated. Mrs. Collins knew not what to make of him. Colonel Fitzwilliam’s occasionally laughing at his stupidity proved that he was generally different, which her own knowledge of him could not have told her; and as she would have liked to believe this change the effect of love, and the object of that love her friend Eliza, she set herself seriously to work to find it out: she watched him whenever they were at Rosings, and whenever he came to Hunsford; but without much success. He certainly looked at her friend a great deal, but the expression of that look was disputable. It was an earnest, steadfast gaze, but she often doubted whether there were much admiration in it, and sometimes it seemed nothing but absence of mind.
She had once or twice suggested to Elizabeth the possibility of his being partial to her, but Elizabeth always laughed at the idea; and Mrs. Collins did not think it right to press the subject, from the danger of raising expectations which might only end in disappointment; for in her opinion it admitted not of a doubt, that all her friend’s dislike would vanish, if she could suppose him to be in her power.
In her kind schemes for Elizabeth, she sometimes planned her marrying Colonel Fitzwilliam. He was, beyond comparison, the pleasantest man: he certainly admired her, and his situation in life was most eligible; but, to counterbalance these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage in the church, and his cousin could have none at all.

events.title: Unexpected and Puzzling Encounters with Darcy
detailed_summary: Elizabeth Bennet repeatedly encounters Mr. Darcy during her walks in the park, which she finds irritatingly coincidental.
She had previously informed him that the area was her favorite walking spot, making his continued presence there seem deliberate.
These meetings involved more than brief pleasantries; Darcy would turn and walk alongside her.
During their third such walk, Elizabeth noted that Darcy, though not talkative, asked a series of disconnected and unusual questions.
He inquired about her enjoyment of Hunsford, her liking for solitary walks, and her assessment of the Collinses' marital happiness.
His remarks about Rosings seemed to imply an expectation that she would stay at Rosings during future visits to Kent.
Elizabeth briefly considered if his comments were related to Colonel Fitzwilliam, possibly hinting at a future connection between them.
Feeling somewhat unsettled by the implications, she was relieved when their walk concluded at the Parsonage gate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: More than once did Elizabeth, in her ramble within the park, unexpectedly meet Mr. Darcy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It distressed her a little, and she was quite glad to find herself at the gate in the pales opposite the Parsonage.

events.text_segment: More than once did Elizabeth, in her ramble within the park, unexpectedly meet Mr. Darcy. She felt all the perverseness of the mischance that should bring him where no one else was brought; and, to prevent its ever happening again, took care to inform him, at first, that it was a favourite haunt of hers. How it could occur a second time, therefore, was very odd! Yet it did, and even the third. It seemed like wilful ill-nature, or a voluntary penance; for on these occasions it was not merely a few formal inquiries and an awkward pause and then away, but he actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with her. He never said a great deal, nor did she give herself the trouble of talking or of listening much; but it struck her in the course of their third rencounter that he was asking some odd unconnected questions—about her pleasure in being at Hunsford, her love of solitary walks, and her opinion of Mr. and Mrs. Collins’s happiness; and that in speaking of Rosings, and her not perfectly understanding the house, he seemed to expect that whenever she came into Kent again she would be staying there too. His words seemed to imply it. Could he have Colonel Fitzwilliam in his thoughts? She supposed, if he meant anything, he must mean an allusion to what might arise in that quarter. It distressed her a little, and she was quite glad to find herself at the gate in the pales opposite the Parsonage.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
In Elizabeth's unexpected encounters with Mr. Darcy during her walks in the park, she was determined to show that she was perfectly at ease. She maintained her composure, speaking naturally and with civility, never allowing any sign of discomfort to appear in her manner.

During these chance meetings, Elizabeth often inquired after the health of his sister and received polite responses. Their conversations, though brief, gradually became less strained. Elizabeth noticed that Mr. Darcy seemed to seek these encounters, as he would frequently appear on the same path she habitually chose for her morning exercise.

On one such occasion, she mentioned her surprise at having met him previously, wondering why he had not returned to London with his friends. He explained that he had business matters to attend to before departing, his expression suggesting there might be more to his lingering presence than mere business affairs.

These meetings, though initially awkward, slowly revealed a different side of Mr. Darcy to Elizabeth. His manner was more gentle than she had previously observed in company, and there was a thoughtfulness in his questions that suggested genuine interest rather than mere politeness.

Elizabeth found herself increasingly curious about this man whom she had so thoroughly misjudged, though she was not yet ready to admit this change in her perception.

events.title: A Walk and Discussion with Colonel Fitzwilliam
detailed_summary: While walking and reflecting on Jane's somber letter, Elizabeth unexpectedly meets Colonel Fitzwilliam.
Fitzwilliam explains he was touring the park, a yearly habit, and planned to visit the Parsonage.
Elizabeth turns back, and they walk towards the Parsonage together.
She inquires about his departure plans, leading to a discussion about Mr. Darcy's control over their schedule.
Elizabeth comments on Darcy's apparent satisfaction in exercising his power and autonomy.
Fitzwilliam agrees Darcy likes control but suggests it stems largely from wealth, contrasting it with the necessary self-denial and dependence faced by younger sons.
Elizabeth playfully disputes the notion that an earl's younger son experiences significant self-denial or dependence due to finances.
Fitzwilliam clarifies that financial limitations significantly impact weightier matters, specifically the freedom to marry whomever one chooses.
Elizabeth briefly wonders if Fitzwilliam's comment about marrying for money is directed at her.
She lightheartedly inquires about the 'market value' of an earl's younger son, and they continue the jesting conversation briefly.
Changing the subject, Elizabeth speculates Darcy brought Fitzwilliam for companionship he could control and wonders why Darcy hasn't married for similar convenience.
Fitzwilliam reveals he shares the guardianship of Miss Darcy with his cousin.
Elizabeth expresses surprise and inquires about his experience as a guardian, teasingly questioning if Miss Darcy, possessing the 'Darcy spirit', is difficult to manage.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: She was engaged one day, as she walked, in re-perusing Jane’s last letter, and dwelling on some passages which proved that Jane had not written in spirits, when, instead of being again surprised by Mr. Darcy, she saw, on looking up, that Colonel Fitzwilliam was meeting her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Does your charge give you much trouble? Young ladies of her age are sometimes a little difficult to manage; and if she has the true Darcy spirit, she may like to have her own way.”

events.text_segment:
She was engaged one day, as she walked, in re-perusing Jane’s last letter, and dwelling on some passages which proved that Jane had not written in spirits, when, instead of being again surprised by Mr. Darcy, she saw, on looking up, that Colonel Fitzwilliam was meeting her. Putting away the letter immediately, and forcing a smile, she said,—
“I did not know before that you ever walked this way.”
“I have been making the tour of the park,” he replied, “as I generally do every year, and intended to close it with a call at the Parsonage. Are you going much farther?”
“No, I should have turned in a moment.”
And accordingly she did turn, and they walked towards the Parsonage together.
“Do you certainly leave Kent on Saturday?” said she.
“Yes—if Darcy does not put it off again. But I am at his disposal. He arranges the business just as he pleases.”
“And if not able to please himself in the arrangement, he has at least great pleasure in the power of choice. I do not know anybody who seems more to enjoy the power of doing what he likes than Mr. Darcy.”
“He likes to have his own way very well,” replied Colonel Fitzwilliam. “But so we all do. It is only that he has better means of having it than many others, because he is rich, and many others are poor. I speak feelingly. A younger son, you know, must be inured to self-denial and dependence.”
“In my opinion, the younger son of an earl can know very little of either. Now, seriously, what have you ever known of self-denial and dependence? When have you been prevented by want of money from going wherever you chose or procuring anything you had a fancy for?”
“These are home questions—and perhaps I cannot say that I have experienced many hardships of that nature. But in matters of greater weight, I may suffer from the want of money. Younger sons cannot marry where they like.”
“Unless where they like women of fortune, which I think they very often do.”
“Our habits of expense make us too dependent, and there are not many in my rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to money.”
“Is this,” thought Elizabeth, “meant for me?” and she coloured at the idea; but, recovering herself, said in a lively tone, “And pray, what is the usual price of an earl’s younger son? Unless the elder brother is very sickly, I suppose you would not ask above fifty thousand pounds.”
He answered her in the same style, and the subject dropped. To interrupt a silence which might make him fancy her affected with what had passed, she soon afterwards said,—
“I imagine your cousin brought you down with him chiefly for the sake of having somebody at his disposal. I wonder he does not marry, to secure a lasting convenience of that kind. But, perhaps, his sister does as well for the present; and, as she is under his sole care, he may do what he likes with her.”
“No,” said Colonel Fitzwilliam, “that is an advantage which he must divide with me. I am joined with him in the guardianship of Miss Darcy.”
“Are you, indeed? And pray what sort of a guardian do you make? Does your charge give you much trouble? Young ladies of her age are sometimes a little difficult to manage; and if she has the true Darcy spirit, she may like to have her own way.”

events.title: Fitzwilliam Reveals Darcy's Interference in Bingley's Affairs
detailed_summary: Fitzwilliam's earnest look and immediate question about why Elizabeth thought Miss Darcy might be troublesome confirm to Elizabeth that she touched on a sensitive point.
Elizabeth quickly reassures him, mentioning she has heard no harm of Miss Darcy and citing Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley as acquaintances who admire her.
Fitzwilliam confirms he knows the Bingleys casually, noting Mr. Bingley's pleasant character and friendship with Darcy.
Elizabeth comments with dry irony on Darcy's great 'kindness' and 'care' for Bingley.
Fitzwilliam affirms Darcy's care for Bingley, especially where needed, and hints that Darcy recently confided something suggesting Bingley is greatly indebted to him.
He cautiously adds, emphasizing it's his own guess, that Darcy recently boasted of saving a friend (presumed to be Bingley) from an 'imprudent marriage'.
Fitzwilliam mentions the need for secrecy to avoid upsetting the lady's family.
When Elizabeth inquires further, Fitzwilliam states Darcy's reason involved 'very strong objections against the lady'.
Regarding Darcy's methods, Fitzwilliam admits Darcy did not disclose the details of his intervention.
Elizabeth becomes silent, internally seething with indignation.
Fitzwilliam notices her preoccupation and asks its cause.
Elizabeth states she is reflecting on his story and finds Darcy's judgmental behaviour objectionable.
She questions Darcy's right to decide the course of his friend's happiness based solely on his own judgment.
She then tempers her criticism, acknowledging they lack full details and shouldn't assume deep affection was involved.
Fitzwilliam lightly remarks that diminishing the affection involved lessens the 'honour' of Darcy's 'triumph'.
Elizabeth finds this comment an unnervingly accurate portrayal of Darcy's character and avoids responding, steering the conversation to neutral topics until they arrive at the Parsonage.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As she spoke, she observed him looking at her earnestly; and the manner in which he immediately asked her why she supposed Miss Darcy likely to give them any uneasiness, convinced her that she had somehow or other got pretty near the truth.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This was spoken jestingly, but it appeared to her so just a picture of Mr. Darcy, that she would not trust herself with an answer; and, therefore, abruptly changing the conversation, talked on indifferent matters till they reached the Parsonage.

events.text_segment:
As she spoke, she observed him looking at her earnestly; and the manner in which he immediately asked her why she supposed Miss Darcy likely to give them any uneasiness, convinced her that she had somehow or other got pretty near the truth. She directly replied,—
“You need not be frightened. I never heard any harm of her; and I dare say she is one of the most tractable creatures in the world. She is a very great favourite with some ladies of my acquaintance, Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley. I think I have heard you say that you know them.”
“I know them a little. Their brother is a pleasant, gentlemanlike man—he is a great friend of Darcy’s.”
“Oh yes,” said Elizabeth drily—“Mr. Darcy is uncommonly kind to Mr. Bingley, and takes a prodigious deal of care of him.”
“Care of him! Yes, I really believe Darcy does take care of him in those points where he most wants care. From something that he told me in our journey hither, I have reason to think Bingley very much indebted to him. But I ought to beg his pardon, for I have no right to suppose that Bingley was the person meant. It was all conjecture.”
“What is it you mean?”
“It is a circumstance which Darcy of course could not wish to be generally known, because if it were to get round to the lady’s family it would be an unpleasant thing.”
“You may depend upon my not mentioning it.”
“And remember that I have not much reason for supposing it to be Bingley. What he told me was merely this: that he congratulated himself on having lately saved a friend from the inconveniences of a most imprudent marriage, but without mentioning names or any other particulars; and I only suspected it to be Bingley from believing him the kind of young man to get into a scrape of that sort, and from knowing them to have been together the whole of last summer.”
“Did Mr. Darcy give you his reasons for this interference?”
“I understood that there were some very strong objections against the lady.”
“And what arts did he use to separate them?”
“He did not talk to me of his own arts,” said Fitzwilliam, smiling. “He only told me what I have now told you.”
Elizabeth made no answer, and walked on, her heart swelling with indignation. After watching her a little, Fitzwilliam asked her why she was so thoughtful.
“I am thinking of what you have been telling me,” said she. “Your cousin’s conduct does not suit my feelings. Why was he to be the judge?”
“You are rather disposed to call his interference officious?”
“I do not see what right Mr. Darcy had to decide on the propriety of his friend’s inclination; or why, upon his own judgment alone, he was to determine and direct in what manner that friend was to be happy. But,” she continued, recollecting herself, “as we know none of the particulars, it is not fair to condemn him. It is not to be supposed that there was much affection in the case.”
“That is not an unnatural surmise,” said Fitzwilliam; “but it is lessening the honour of my cousin’s triumph very sadly.”
This was spoken jestingly, but it appeared to her so just a picture of Mr. Darcy, that she would not trust herself with an answer; and, therefore, abruptly changing the conversation, talked on indifferent matters till they reached the Parsonage.

"I know them a little. Their brother is a pleasant gentlemanlike man—he is a great friend of Darcy's."

"Oh! yes," said Elizabeth drily; "Mr. Darcy is uncommonly kind to Mr. Bingley, and takes a prodigious deal of care of him."

"Care of him! Yes, I really believe Darcy does take care of him in those points where he most wants care. "You may depend upon my not mentioning it."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Elizabeth replied that she had heard much of Miss Darcy's beauty, accomplishments, and pride. She mentioned how the young lady was described as exceedingly handsome, with an excellent education, but also as being quite haughty and reserved in her manners.

"And is Miss Darcy as handsome as her brother?" she inquired, watching Mr. Wickham's expression carefully.

"Many consider her even more striking," he replied with a slight hesitation. "She is tall and elegant, though her features have not yet softened with womanhood. She is but sixteen, I believe."

Elizabeth noted how his countenance changed when speaking of Miss Darcy. There seemed to be conflicting emotions—a certain fondness mixed with disappointment or perhaps resentment.

"I have heard," Elizabeth ventured, "that she is uncommonly talented at the pianoforte."

"Indeed, she has had every advantage money could procure. Her natural gifts have been nurtured by the finest masters."

Mr. Wickham paused, seeming to consider his next words carefully. "I have known Miss Darcy since her infancy. Her father, the late Mr. Darcy, was my godfather and one of the best men who ever breathed. His kindness to me can never be forgotten."

Elizabeth listened attentively as Mr. Wickham continued, explaining his long connection to the Darcy family. He spoke of the elder Mr. Darcy with genuine affection and gratitude, describing how the gentleman had supported his education and intended him for the church.

"And yet," Elizabeth prompted gently, sensing there was more to the story.

"And yet," he confirmed with a sigh, "circumstances have prevented me from taking orders. The living that was once promised to me was given elsewhere."

Elizabeth's surprise was evident. "How could that be? Surely Mr. Darcy's will—"

"There were conditions, of course, which I was deemed to have failed," Wickham explained, his voice carrying a note of resignation rather than bitterness. "The current Mr. Darcy chose to interpret his father's intentions differently than I believe they were meant."

The conversation turned to the character of the younger Mr. Darcy, with Wickham offering observations that aligned with Elizabeth's own impressions of the gentleman's pride and disdain for those he considered beneath him.

As they spoke, other members of the party joined them, and the subject necessarily changed. But Elizabeth found herself contemplating what she had learned, wondering at the complicated history between Mr. Wickham and the Darcys, and feeling her dislike of Mr. Darcy solidify with this new information that seemed to confirm her worst impressions of the man.

events.title: Elizabeth's Solitary Fury and Realization
detailed_summary: Once alone in her room, Elizabeth processes the information from Colonel Fitzwilliam.
She feels certain the friend Darcy interfered with was Bingley, and the lady was Jane, convinced of Darcy's significant influence over Bingley.

Previously suspecting Darcy's involvement but blaming Miss Bingley primarily, Elizabeth now believes Darcy himself was the main architect of the separation, assuming his vanity isn't distorting Fitzwilliam's account.
She furiously blames Darcy's pride and capriciousness for Jane's past and ongoing heartache.
She considers him responsible for destroying the happiness of a kind and loving person, possibly causing long-term damage.

Reflecting on Fitzwilliam's phrase 'strong objections against the lady,' Elizabeth deduces these objections likely stemmed from the Bennet family's inferior social connections (an attorney uncle, another in trade).
She passionately defends Jane's flawless character, intelligence, and charm, finding no fault in Jane herself.
She mentally defends her father's respectability, comparing it favorably to Darcy's.
While conceding her mother's behavior might be objectionable, Elizabeth believes Darcy's primary motivation was wounded pride due to the Bennets' lack of social standing.
She concludes Darcy acted out of snobbery combined with a desire to keep Bingley available for his sister, Georgiana.
Her intense agitation and tears result in a headache.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There, shut into her own room, as soon as their visitor left them, she could think without interruption of all that she had heard.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The agitation and tears which the subject occasioned brought on a headache; and it grew so much worse towards the evening that, added to her unwillingness to see Mr. Darcy, it determined her not to attend her cousins to Rosings, where they were engaged to drink tea.

events.text_segment:
There, shut into her own room, as soon as their visitor left them, she could think without interruption of all that she had heard. It was not to be supposed that any other people could be meant than those with whom she was connected. There could not exist in the world two men over whom Mr. Darcy could have such boundless influence. That he had been concerned in the measures taken to separate Mr. Bingley and Jane, she had never doubted; but she had always attributed to Miss Bingley the principal design and arrangement of them. If his own vanity, however, did not mislead him, he was the cause—his pride and caprice were the cause—of all that Jane had suffered, and still continued to suffer. He had ruined for a while every hope of happiness for the most affectionate, generous heart in the world; and no one could say how lasting an evil he might have inflicted.
“There were some very strong objections against the lady,” were Colonel Fitzwilliam’s words; and these strong objections probably were, her having one uncle who was a country attorney, and another who was in business in London.
“To Jane herself,” she exclaimed, “there could be no possibility of objection,—all loveliness and goodness as she is! Her understanding excellent, her mind improved, and her manners captivating. Neither could anything be urged against my father, who, though with some peculiarities, has abilities which Mr. Darcy himself need not disdain, and respectability which he will probably never reach.” When she thought of her mother, indeed, her confidence gave way a little; but she would not allow that any objections there had material weight with Mr. Darcy, whose pride, she was convinced, would receive a deeper wound from the want of importance in his friend’s connections than from their want of sense; and she was quite decided, at last, that he had been partly governed by this worst kind of pride, and partly by the wish of retaining Mr. Bingley for his sister.
The agitation and tears which the subject occasioned brought on a headache; and it grew so much worse towards the evening that, added to her unwillingness to see Mr. Darcy, it determined her not to attend her cousins to Rosings, where they were engaged to drink tea.

events.title: Elizabeth Avoids Rosings Due to Distress
detailed_summary: Compounded by her unwillingness to face Mr. Darcy after her recent realizations, Elizabeth's headache worsens.
She decides not to accompany the Collinses to Rosings for tea.
Mrs. Collins perceives Elizabeth's genuine discomfort and supports her decision, discouraging her husband from insisting.
Mr. Collins, however, voices concern that Elizabeth's absence will likely displease their patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourgh.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mrs. Collins, seeing that she was really unwell, did not press her to go, and as much as possible prevented her husband from pressing her; but Mr. Collins could not conceal his apprehension of Lady Catherine’s being rather displeased by her staying at home.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: but Mr. Collins could not conceal his apprehension of Lady Catherine’s being rather displeased by her staying at home.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: Mrs. Collins, seeing that she was really unwell, did not press her to go, and as much as possible prevented her husband from pressing her; but Mr. Collins could not conceal his apprehension of Lady Catherine's being rather displeased by her staying at home.

When they were gone, Elizabeth, as if intending to exasperate herself as much as possible against Mr. Darcy, chose for her employment the examination of all the letters which Jane had written to her since her being in Kent. They contained no actual complaint, nor was there any revival of past occurrences, or any communication of present suffering. But in all, and in almost every line of each, there was a want of that cheerfulness which had been used to characterize her style, and which, proceeding from the serenity of a mind at ease with itself and kindly disposed towards everyone, had been scarcely ever clouded. Elizabeth noticed every sentence conveying the idea of uneasiness, with an attention which it had hardly received on the first perusal. Mr. Darcy's shameful boast of what misery he had been able to inflict, gave her a keener sense of her sister's sufferings. It was some consolation to think that his visit to Rosings was to end on the day after the next—and, a still greater, that in less than a fortnight she should herself be with Jane again, and enabled to contribute to the recovery of her spirits, by all that affection could do.

events.title: Elizabeth Reflects on Jane's Unhappiness and Darcy's Role
detailed_summary: Alone, Elizabeth deliberately focuses her thoughts on Mr. Darcy by rereading letters received from Jane during her time in Kent.
She observes a distinct lack of cheerfulness in Jane's writing, a departure from her usual serene and kind disposition.
Elizabeth interprets every hint of sadness in the letters with heightened sensitivity, attributing Jane's suffering directly to Mr. Darcy's interference, which he had previously boasted about.
She finds solace in the knowledge that Darcy's visit to Rosings will soon end and that she will rejoin Jane shortly, hoping to lift her sister's spirits through affection.
Her thoughts briefly touch upon Colonel Fitzwilliam accompanying Darcy upon his departure, but she dismisses any potential romantic disappointment, acknowledging his lack of serious intentions.

events.title: Darcy's Unexpected Visit and Abrupt Proposal
detailed_summary: Elizabeth is startled by the doorbell, momentarily hoping it might be Colonel Fitzwilliam making a late call.
Her hopes are dashed, and she is utterly astonished when Mr. Darcy enters the room instead.
Darcy awkwardly and quickly inquires about her health, suggesting this is the reason for his unexpected visit.
Elizabeth responds with polite coldness.
After a brief moment sitting, Darcy stands and paces the room restlessly.
Elizabeth remains silent, though surprised by his behaviour.
Following several minutes of tense silence, Darcy approaches her in an agitated state.
He declares that he has struggled against his feelings unsuccessfully and professes his ardent admiration and love for her.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: While settling this point, she was suddenly roused by the sound of the door-bell; and her spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its being Colonel Fitzwilliam himself, who had once before called late in the evening, and might now come to inquire particularly after her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “In vain have I struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be repressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love you.”

events.text_segment:
While settling this point, she was suddenly roused by the sound of the door-bell; and her spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its being Colonel Fitzwilliam himself, who had once before called late in the evening, and might now come to inquire particularly after her. But this idea was soon banished, and her spirits were very differently affected, when, to her utter amazement, she saw Mr. Darcy walk into the room. In a hurried manner he immediately began an inquiry after her health, imputing his visit to a wish of hearing that she were better. She answered him with cold civility. He sat down for a few moments, and then getting up walked about the room. Elizabeth was surprised, but said not a word. After a silence of several minutes, he came towards her in an agitated manner, and thus began:—
“In vain have I struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be repressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love you.”
