events.title: Debating Wickham's Intentions
detailed_summary: While travelling in a carriage, Mr. Gardiner expresses second thoughts, leaning towards Jane's optimistic view that Wickham wouldn't dare elope without intending marriage.

He argues the risk to Wickham's reputation within the regiment and with Colonel Forster's family seems too great compared to the temptation presented by Lydia, who is not entirely without connections.
Elizabeth shows a flicker of hope at her uncle's reasoning.
Mrs. Gardiner concurs with her husband, finding the potential act too dishonourable and against Wickham's own interests.
She questions if Elizabeth can truly believe Wickham capable of such deceit.
Elizabeth concedes Wickham likely wouldn't neglect his own interest (implying financial gain), but believes him capable of every other form of neglect.
She expresses doubt, questioning why they wouldn't have gone straight to Scotland if marriage was the plan.
Mr. Gardiner points out there's no proof they *aren't* in Scotland.
Elizabeth counters with the suspicious change into a hackney coach and the lack of sightings on the relevant road.
Mr. Gardiner hypothesizes they might be hiding in London for secrecy or to marry more cheaply, despite it being slower than Scotland.
Elizabeth refutes this, arguing against the need for secrecy if marriage was intended and citing Wickham's friend's belief he never meant to marry Lydia.
She emphasizes Wickham's need for money and Lydia's lack of significant attractions beyond youth and good spirits.

Elizabeth doubts the fear of military disgrace would deter Wickham and points out Lydia's lack of protective brothers and Mr. Bennet's perceived indifference might make Wickham feel secure from family intervention.
Mr. Gardiner questions if Lydia herself would agree to live with Wickham unmarried.

Visibly upset, Elizabeth admits the possibility is shocking but acknowledges Lydia's lack of serious education, her recent immersion in frivolity and vanity, and her obsession with officers since the militia arrived.
She describes Lydia's heightened susceptibility and Wickham's known charm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I have been thinking it over again, Elizabeth,” said her uncle, as they drove from the town; “and really, upon serious consideration, I am much more inclined than I was to judge as your eldest sister does of the matter.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And we all know that Wickham has every charm of person and address that can captivate a woman.”

events.text_segment:
I have been thinking it over again, Elizabeth,” said her uncle, as they drove from the town; “and really, upon serious consideration, I am much more inclined than I was to judge as your eldest sister does of the matter. It appears to me so very unlikely that any young man should form such a design against a girl who is by no means unprotected or friendless, and who was actually staying in his Colonel’s family, that I am strongly inclined to hope the best. Could he expect that her friends would not step forward? Could he expect to be noticed again by the regiment, after such an affront to Colonel Forster? His temptation is not adequate to the risk.”
“Do you really think so?” cried Elizabeth, brightening up for a moment.
“Upon my word,” said Mrs. Gardiner, “I begin to be of your uncle’s opinion. It is really too great a violation of decency, honour, and interest, for him to be guilty of it. I cannot think so very ill of Wickham. Can you, yourself, Lizzie, so wholly give him up, as to believe him capable of it?”
“Not perhaps of neglecting his own interest. But of every other neglect I can believe him capable. If, indeed, it should be so! But I dare not hope it. Why should they not go on to Scotland, if that had been the case?”
“In the first place,” replied Mr. Gardiner, “there is no absolute proof that they are not gone to Scotland.”
“Oh, but their removing from the chaise into a hackney coach is such a presumption! And, besides, no traces of them were to be found on the Barnet road.”
“Well, then,—supposing them to be in London—they may be there, though for the purpose of concealment, for no more exceptionable purpose. It is not likely that money should be very abundant on either side; and it might strike them that they could be more economically, though less expeditiously, married in London, than in Scotland.”
“But why all this secrecy? Why any fear of detection? Why must their marriage be private? Oh, no, no—this is not likely. His most particular friend, you see by Jane’s account, was persuaded of his never intending to marry her. Wickham will never marry a woman without some money. He cannot afford it. And what claims has Lydia, what attractions has she beyond youth, health, and good humour, that could make him for her sake forego every chance of benefiting himself by marrying well? As to what restraint the apprehensions of disgrace in the corps might throw on a dishonourable elopement with her, I am not able to judge; for I know nothing of the effects that such a step might produce. But as to your other objection, I am afraid it will hardly hold good. Lydia has no brothers to step forward; and he might imagine, from my father’s behaviour, from his indolence and the little attention he has ever seemed to give to what was going forward in his family, that he would do as little and think as little about it, as any father could do, in such a matter.”
“But can you think that Lydia is so lost to everything but love of him, as to consent to live with him on any other terms than marriage?”
“It does seem, and it is most shocking, indeed,” replied Elizabeth, with tears in her eyes, “that a sister’s sense of decency and virtue in such a point should admit of doubt. But, really, I know not what to say. Perhaps I am not doing her justice. But she is very young: she has never been taught to think on serious subjects; and for the last half year, nay, for a twelvemonth, she has been given up to nothing but amusement and vanity. She has been allowed to dispose of her time in the most idle and frivolous manner, and to adopt any opinions that came in her way. Since the ——shire were first quartered in Meryton, nothing but love, flirtation, and officers, have been in her head. She has been doing everything in her power, by thinking and talking on the subject, to give greater—what shall I call it?—susceptibility to her feelings; which are naturally lively enough. And we all know that Wickham has every charm of person and address that can captivate a woman.”

As to what restraint the apprehensions of disgrace in the corps might throw on a dishonourable elopement with her, I am not able to judge; for I know nothing of the effects that such a step might produce. But as to your other objection, I am afraid it will hardly hold good. Lydia has no brothers to step forward; and he might imagine, from my father's behaviour, from his indolence and the little attention he has ever seemed to give to what was going forward in his family, that he would do as little, and think as little about it, as any father could do, in such a matter."

"But can you think that Lydia is so lost to everything but love of him as to consent to live with him on any terms other than marriage?"

"It does seem, and it is most shocking indeed," replied Elizabeth, with tears in her eyes, "that a sister's sense of decency and virtue in such a point should admit of doubt. But, really, I know not what to say. Perhaps I am not doing her justice. But she is very young; she has never been taught to think on serious subjects; and for the last half-year, nay, for a twelvemonth—she has been given up to nothing but amusement and vanity. She has been allowed to dispose of her time in the most idle and frivolous manner, and to adopt any opinions that came in her way. Since the ——shire were first quartered in Meryton, nothing but love, flirtation, and officers have been in her head. She has been doing everything in her power by thinking and talking on the subject, to give greater—what shall I call it? susceptibility to her feelings; which are naturally lively enough. And we all know that Wickham has every charm of person and address that can captivate a woman."

events.title: Elizabeth Reveals Wickham's True Character and Her Regret
detailed_summary: Mrs. Gardiner points out Jane's continued good opinion of Wickham.
Elizabeth counters that Jane rarely thinks ill of anyone but asserts that both she and Jane are fully aware of Wickham's true, profligate, dishonourable, and deceitful nature.
Intrigued, Mrs. Gardiner asks if Elizabeth truly knows all this.
Elizabeth confirms, blushing, mentioning Wickham's previously discussed behaviour towards Mr. Darcy and his disrespectful talk about Darcy, despite Darcy's generosity.
She alludes to other circumstances she cannot relate, including Wickham's extensive lies about the Pemberley family and Miss Darcy, whom they found amiable contrary to his description.
Mrs. Gardiner asks if Lydia was unaware of these facts.
Elizabeth confirms Lydia's ignorance, stating this is the worst part; she herself only learned the truth while in Kent from Mr. Darcy and Colonel Fitzwilliam.

She explains that upon returning home, with the militia about to leave Meryton, neither she nor Jane felt it necessary to publicize Wickham's past, questioning the utility of destroying his local reputation at that point.
Elizabeth expresses deep regret, admitting the possibility of Lydia being endangered by Wickham never occurred to her, even when Lydia's trip to Brighton with Mrs. Forster was arranged.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “But you see that Jane,” said her aunt, “does not think so ill of Wickham, as to believe him capable of the attempt.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That such a consequence as this should ensue, you may easily believe was far enough from my thoughts.”

events.text_segment:
“But you see that Jane,” said her aunt, “does not think so ill of Wickham, as to believe him capable of the attempt.”
“Of whom does Jane ever think ill? And who is there, whatever might be their former conduct, that she would believe capable of such an attempt, till it were proved against them? But Jane knows, as well as I do, what Wickham really is. We both know that he has been profligate in every sense of the word; that he has neither integrity nor honour; that he is as false and deceitful as he is insinuating.”
“And do you really know all this?” cried Mrs. Gardiner, whose curiosity as to the mode of her intelligence was all alive.
“I do, indeed,” replied Elizabeth, colouring. “I told you the other day of his infamous behaviour to Mr. Darcy; and you, yourself, when last at Longbourn, heard in what manner he spoke of the man who had behaved with such forbearance and liberality towards him. And there are other circumstances which I am not at liberty—which it is not worth while to relate; but his lies about the whole Pemberley family are endless. From what he said of Miss Darcy, I was thoroughly prepared to see a proud, reserved, disagreeable girl. Yet he knew to the contrary himself. He must know that she was as amiable and unpretending as we have found her.”
“But does Lydia know nothing of this? can she be ignorant of what you and Jane seem so well to understand?”
“Oh, yes!—that, that is the worst of all. Till I was in Kent, and saw so much both of Mr. Darcy and his relation Colonel Fitzwilliam, I was ignorant of the truth myself. And when I returned home the ——shire was to leave Meryton in a week or fortnight’s time. As that was the case, neither Jane, to whom I related the whole, nor I, thought it necessary to make our knowledge public; for of what use could it apparently be to anyone, that the good opinion, which all the neighbourhood had of him, should then be overthrown? And even when it was settled that Lydia should go with Mrs. Forster, the necessity of opening her eyes to his character never occurred to me. That she could be in any danger from the deception never entered my head. That such a consequence as this should ensue, you may easily believe was far enough from my thoughts.”

"I never saw any thing of it," said Mrs. Gardiner.

"I am the more confirmed in this, by what Lydia said herself yesterday," continued Elizabeth. "Though I did not before know its full extent, I knew that his character was by no means so pure, as ignorant people believed it; and my father had always distrusted him. When first we talk of his leaving Meryton, Jane, you remember, was quite ready to give him up."

That she could be in any danger from the deception never entered my head. That such a consequence as this should ensue, you may easily believe was far enough from my thoughts."

"When they all removed to Brighton, therefore, you had no reason, I suppose, to believe them fond of each other."

events.title: Arrival at Longbourn and Initial Reunion
detailed_summary: Mrs. Gardiner asks if Elizabeth had noticed any prior affection between Lydia and Wickham before Brighton.
Elizabeth denies seeing any signs, noting Lydia's initial admiration (shared by all Meryton girls) faded when Wickham showed her no particular attention, and she turned her focus to other officers.
The narrator notes that despite repeated discussion, the topic of Lydia and Wickham dominated their thoughts throughout the journey.
Elizabeth, particularly, is consumed by thoughts of the situation, tormented by self-reproach.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “When they all removed to Brighton, therefore, you had no reason, I suppose, to believe them fond of each other?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Fixed there by the keenest of all anguish, self-reproach, she could find no interval of ease or forgetfulness.

events.text_segment:
“When they all removed to Brighton, therefore, you had no reason, I suppose, to believe them fond of each other?”
“Not the slightest. I can remember no symptom of affection on either side; and had anything of the kind been perceptible, you must be aware that ours is not a family on which it could be thrown away. When first he entered the corps, she was ready enough to admire him; but so we all were. Every girl in or near Meryton was out of her senses about him for the first two months: but he never distinguished her by any particular attention; and, consequently, after a moderate period of extravagant and wild admiration, her fancy for him gave way, and others of the regiment, who treated her with more distinction, again became her favourites.”
It may be easily believed, that however little of novelty could be added to their fears, hopes, and conjectures, on this interesting subject by its repeated discussion, no other could detain them from it long, during the whole of the journey. From Elizabeth’s thoughts it was never absent. Fixed there by the keenest of all anguish, self-reproach, she could find no interval of ease or forgetfulness.

From Elizabeth's thoughts it was never absent. Fixed there by the keenest of all anguish, self-reproach, she could find no interval of ease or forgetfulness.

They travelled as expeditiously as possible, and, sleeping one night on the road, reached Longbourn by dinner time the next day. It was a comfort to Elizabeth to consider that Jane could not have been wearied by long expectations.

The little Gardiners, attracted by the sight of a chaise, were standing on the steps of the house as they entered the paddock; and, when the carriage drove up to the door, the joyful surprise that lighted up their faces, and displayed itself over their whole bodies, in a variety of capers and frisks, was the first pleasing earnest of their welcome.

events.title: Reunion at Longbourn and News from Jane
detailed_summary: The Gardiners and Elizabeth travel quickly, arriving at Longbourn the next day by dinnertime.
Elizabeth is glad Jane hasn't endured prolonged anticipation.
The Gardiner children greet the arriving chaise with joyful surprise.
Elizabeth greets the children quickly and hurries inside, meeting Jane, who runs down from Mrs. Bennet's room.
The sisters embrace tearfully, and Elizabeth immediately asks for news of Lydia and Wickham.
Jane confirms there is no news but expresses hope now that Mr. Gardiner has arrived.
Jane confirms Mr. Bennet went to London on Tuesday.
She reports receiving only one brief note from him on Wednesday confirming his safe arrival and giving directions, stating he wouldn't write again without significant news.
Jane describes Mrs. Bennet as tolerably well but greatly shaken and confined to her dressing room.
She reassures Elizabeth that Mary and Kitty are well.
Elizabeth expresses concern for Jane's pale appearance and the ordeal she must have faced.
Jane insists she is perfectly well.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They travelled as expeditiously as possible; and sleeping one night on the road, reached Longbourn by dinnertime the next day.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her sister, however, assured her of her being perfectly well; and their conversation, which had been passing while Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were engaged with their children, was now put an end to by the approach of the whole party.

events.text_segment:
They travelled as expeditiously as possible; and sleeping one night on the road, reached Longbourn by dinnertime the next day. It was a comfort to Elizabeth to consider that Jane could not have been wearied by long expectations.
The little Gardiners, attracted by the sight of a chaise, were standing on the steps of the house, as they entered the paddock; and when the carriage drove up to the door, the joyful surprise that lighted up their faces and displayed itself over their whole bodies, in a variety of capers and frisks, was the first pleasing earnest of their welcome.
Elizabeth jumped out; and after giving each of them a hasty kiss, hurried into the vestibule, where Jane, who came running downstairs from her mother’s apartment, immediately met her.
Elizabeth, as she affectionately embraced her, whilst tears filled the eyes of both, lost not a moment in asking whether anything had been heard of the fugitives.
“Not yet,” replied Jane. “But now that my dear uncle is come, I hope everything will be well.”
“Is my father in town?”
“Yes, he went on Tuesday, as I wrote you word.”
“And have you heard from him often?”
“We have heard only once. He wrote me a few lines on Wednesday, to say that he had arrived in safety, and to give me his directions, which I particularly begged him to do. He merely added, that he should not write again, till he had something of importance to mention.”
“And my mother—how is she? How are you all?”
“My mother is tolerably well, I trust; though her spirits are greatly shaken. She is upstairs, and will have great satisfaction in seeing you all. She does not yet leave her dressing-room. Mary and Kitty, thank Heaven! are quite well.”
“But you—how are you?” cried Elizabeth. “You look pale. How much you must have gone through!”
Her sister, however, assured her of her being perfectly well; and their conversation, which had been passing while Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were engaged with their children, was now put an end to by the approach of the whole party.

events.title: Confronting Mrs. Bennet's Distress
detailed_summary: Jane warmly greets her uncle and aunt.
In the drawing-room, the Gardiners repeat Elizabeth's questions, learning Jane has no new information.
Jane maintains hope for a positive outcome, expecting a letter announcing the marriage.
The group goes to Mrs. Bennet's apartment.
Mrs. Bennet reacts predictably with tears, lamentations, blaming Wickham, complaining of her own suffering, and finding fault with everyone except herself.
She blames the Forsters for negligence, insisting Lydia wouldn't have acted this way if properly supervised.
She laments Mr. Bennet's absence, fearing he will fight and be killed by Wickham, leading to the family's eviction by the Collinses.
She appeals to Mr. Gardiner for future kindness.
Everyone dismisses her fears.
Mr. Gardiner assures her of his support and announces his intention to go to London the next day to assist Mr. Bennet in finding Lydia.
He advises against useless alarm, noting it's only been a week and news might arrive soon; they shouldn't assume the worst until it's confirmed they aren't married or planning to be.
He plans to bring Mr. Bennet to his home in Gracechurch Street to consult on the next steps.
Mrs. Bennet expresses relief and gratitude, urging her brother to find the couple and force them to marry if they haven't already.
She insists wedding clothes shouldn't delay the marriage, offering Lydia money to buy them afterwards.
She pleads with Mr. Gardiner to prevent Mr. Bennet from fighting, describing her own physical and emotional distress in detail.
She asks him to tell Lydia not to order clothes until she sees her mother, who knows the best shops.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Jane ran to her uncle and aunt, and welcomed and thanked them both, with alternate smiles and tears.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Oh, brother, how kind you are! I know you will contrive it all.”

events.text_segment:
Jane ran to her uncle and aunt, and welcomed and thanked them both, with alternate smiles and tears.
When they were all in the drawing-room, the questions which Elizabeth had already asked were of course repeated by the others, and they soon found that Jane had no intelligence to give. The sanguine hope of good, however, which the benevolence of her heart suggested, had not yet deserted her; she still expected that it would all end well, and that every morning would bring some letter, either from Lydia or her father, to explain their proceedings, and, perhaps, announce the marriage.
Mrs. Bennet, to whose apartment they all repaired, after a few minutes’ conversation together, received them exactly as might be expected; with tears and lamentations of regret, invectives against the villainous conduct of Wickham, and complaints of her own sufferings and ill-usage; blaming everybody but the person to whose ill-judging indulgence the errors of her daughter must be principally owing.
“If I had been able,” said she, “to carry my point in going to Brighton with all my family, this would not have happened: but poor dear Lydia had nobody to take care of her. Why did the Forsters ever let her go out of their sight? I am sure there was some great neglect or other on their side, for she is not the kind of girl to do such a thing, if she had been well looked after. I always thought they were very unfit to have the charge of her; but I was over-ruled, as I always am. Poor, dear child! And now here’s Mr. Bennet gone away, and I know he will fight Wickham, wherever he meets him, and then he will be killed, and what is to become of us all? The Collinses will turn us out, before he is cold in his grave; and if you are not kind to us, brother, I do not know what we shall do.”
They all exclaimed against such terrific ideas; and Mr. Gardiner, after general assurances of his affection for her and all her family, told her that he meant to be in London the very next day, and would assist Mr. Bennet in every endeavour for recovering Lydia.
“Do not give way to useless alarm,” added he: “though it is right to be prepared for the worst, there is no occasion to look on it as certain. It is not quite a week since they left Brighton. In a few days more, we may gain some news of them; and till we know that they are not married, and have no design of marrying, do not let us give the matter over as lost. As soon as I get to town, I shall go to my brother, and make him come home with me to Gracechurch Street, and then we may consult together as to what is to be done.”
“Oh, my dear brother,” replied Mrs. Bennet, “that is exactly what I could most wish for. And now do, when you get to town, find them out, wherever they may be; and if they are not married already, make them marry. And as for wedding clothes, do not let them wait for that, but tell Lydia she shall have as much money as she chooses to buy them, after they are married. And, above all things, keep Mr. Bennet from fighting. Tell him what a dreadful state I am in—that I am frightened out of my wits; and have such tremblings, such flutterings all over me, such spasms in my side, and pains in my head, and such beatings at my heart, that I can get no rest by night nor by day. And tell my dear Lydia not to give any directions about her clothes till she has seen me, for she does not know which are the best warehouses. Oh, brother, how kind you are! I know you will contrive it all.”

events.title: Managing Mrs. Bennet and Family Dinner
detailed_summary: Mr. Gardiner reiterates his commitment but advises Mrs. Bennet to moderate both her hopes and fears.
They leave Mrs. Bennet with the housekeeper when dinner is served.

Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner agree with keeping Mrs. Bennet secluded during dinner, knowing she lacks the prudence to remain silent before the servants, preferring only the trusted housekeeper hear her anxieties.
In the dining room, Mary and Kitty join the others, having been occupied separately (Mary with books, Kitty with her appearance).
Both sisters appear relatively calm.
Kitty's voice shows slightly more fretfulness than usual, attributed either to losing Lydia or her own involvement/anger regarding the situation.
Mary, composed, whispers moral reflections to Elizabeth.
She calls the elopement unfortunate and likely to cause gossip, urging sisterly consolation.
Receiving no reply, Mary adds that Lydia's situation offers a lesson about the irretrievable loss of female virtue, the ruin following one false step, and the need for caution with undeserving men.
Elizabeth looks up in amazement but is too overwhelmed to respond.
Mary continues finding solace in drawing moral lessons from the crisis.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But Mr. Gardiner, though he assured her again of his earnest endeavours in the cause, could not avoid recommending moderation to her, as well in her hopes as her fears; and after talking with her in this manner till dinner was on table, they left her to vent all her feelings on the housekeeper, who attended in the absence of her daughters.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mary, however, continued to console herself with such kind of moral extractions from the evil before them.

events.text_segment:
But Mr. Gardiner, though he assured her again of his earnest endeavours in the cause, could not avoid recommending moderation to her, as well in her hopes as her fears; and after talking with her in this manner till dinner was on table, they left her to vent all her feelings on the housekeeper, who attended in the absence of her daughters.
Though her brother and sister were persuaded that there was no real occasion for such a seclusion from the family, they did not attempt to oppose it; for they knew that she had not prudence enough to hold her tongue before the servants, while they waited at table, and judged it better that one only of the household, and the one whom they could most trust, should comprehend all her fears and solicitude on the subject.
In the dining-room they were soon joined by Mary and Kitty, who had been too busily engaged in their separate apartments to make their appearance before. One came from her books, and the other from her toilette. The faces of both, however, were tolerably calm; and no change was visible in either, except that the loss of her favourite sister, or the anger which she had herself incurred in the business, had given something more of fretfulness than usual to the accents of Kitty. As for Mary, she was mistress enough of herself to whisper to Elizabeth, with a countenance of grave reflection, soon after they were seated at table,—
“This is a most unfortunate affair, and will probably be much talked of. But we must stem the tide of malice, and pour into the wounded bosoms of each other the balm of sisterly consolation.”
Then perceiving in Elizabeth no inclination of replying, she added, “Unhappy as the event must be for Lydia, we may draw from it this useful lesson:—that loss of virtue in a female is irretrievable, that one false step involves her in endless ruin, that her reputation is no less brittle than it is beautiful, and that she cannot be too much guarded in her behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex.”
Elizabeth lifted up her eyes in amazement, but was too much oppressed to make any reply. Mary, however, continued to console herself with such kind of moral extractions from the evil before them.

events.title: Elizabeth Seeks Details from Jane
detailed_summary: Elizabeth and Jane find time alone in the afternoon.
After mutual lamentations, Elizabeth, convinced of a bad outcome, asks Jane for all the details she hasn't heard.
She specifically asks about Colonel Forster's account and whether there were prior suspicions.
Jane confirms Colonel Forster admitted suspecting Lydia's partiality but nothing alarming.
Jane expresses sympathy for Colonel Forster, praising his kind and attentive behaviour.
She clarifies he was already coming to Longbourn out of concern before learning they hadn't gone to Scotland; that news hastened his trip.
Elizabeth asks about Denny's view on Wickham marrying Lydia and if Colonel Forster spoke to him.
Jane confirms Forster questioned Denny, who denied knowledge of the plan and withheld his opinion on whether they would marry.
Jane notes Denny didn't repeat his earlier assertion that Wickham wouldn't marry Lydia, leading her to hope he was previously misunderstood.
Elizabeth confirms that until Colonel Forster's arrival, the family assumed Lydia and Wickham were married.
Jane explains the impossibility of suspecting otherwise, though she felt uneasy about Lydia's happiness due to Wickham's known past conduct.
She notes her parents only saw the match as imprudent, unaware of Wickham's deeper faults.
Jane reveals Kitty, triumphant at knowing more, admitted Lydia's last letter hinted at the elopement, revealing Lydia had been in love for weeks.
Jane believes this affection developed after they went to Brighton.
Elizabeth asks if Colonel Forster now thinks ill of Wickham.
Jane confesses Forster spoke less well of Wickham than previously, calling him imprudent and extravagant.
She adds that since the elopement, rumours surfaced of Wickham leaving Meryton heavily in debt, though she hopes this is false.
Elizabeth cries out in regret, wishing they had revealed Wickham's true character sooner.
Jane suggests it might have been better but defends their past decision, stating exposing someone's former faults without knowing their present state seemed unjustifiable.
Elizabeth concedes they acted with good intentions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In the afternoon, the two elder Miss Bennets were able to be for half an hour by themselves; and Elizabeth instantly availed herself of the opportunity of making any inquiries which Jane was equally eager to satisfy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We acted with the best intentions.”

events.text_segment:
In the afternoon, the two elder Miss Bennets were able to be for half an hour by themselves; and Elizabeth instantly availed herself of the opportunity of making any inquiries which Jane was equally eager to satisfy. After joining in general lamentations over the dreadful sequel of this event, which Elizabeth considered as all but certain, and Miss Bennet could not assert to be wholly impossible, the former continued the subject by saying, “But tell me all and everything about it which I have not already heard. Give me further particulars. What did Colonel Forster say? Had they no apprehension of anything before the elopement took place? They must have seen them together for ever.”
“Colonel Forster did own that he had often suspected some partiality, especially on Lydia’s side, but nothing to give him any alarm. I am so grieved for him. His behaviour was attentive and kind to the utmost. He was coming to us, in order to assure us of his concern, before he had any idea of their not being gone to Scotland: when that apprehension first got abroad, it hastened his journey.”
“And was Denny convinced that Wickham would not marry? Did he know of their intending to go off? Had Colonel Forster seen Denny himself?”
“Yes; but when questioned by him, Denny denied knowing anything of their plan, and would not give his real opinion about it. He did not repeat his persuasion of their not marrying, and from that I am inclined to hope he might have been misunderstood before.”
“And till Colonel Forster came himself, not one of you entertained a doubt, I suppose, of their being really married?”
“How was it possible that such an idea should enter our brains? I felt a little uneasy—a little fearful of my sister’s happiness with him in marriage, because I knew that his conduct had not been always quite right. My father and mother knew nothing of that; they only felt how imprudent a match it must be. Kitty then owned, with a very natural triumph on knowing more than the rest of us, that in Lydia’s last letter she had prepared her for such a step. She had known, it seems, of their being in love with each other many weeks.”
“But not before they went to Brighton?”
“No, I believe not.”
“And did Colonel Forster appear to think ill of Wickham himself? Does he know his real character?”
“I must confess that he did not speak so well of Wickham as he formerly did. He believed him to be imprudent and extravagant; and since this sad affair has taken place, it is said that he left Meryton greatly in debt: but I hope this may be false.”
“Oh, Jane, had we been less secret, had we told what we knew of him, this could not have happened!”
“Perhaps it would have been better,” replied her sister.
“But to expose the former faults of any person, without knowing what their present feelings were, seemed unjustifiable.”
“We acted with the best intentions.”

events.title: Lydia's Thoughtless Letter Revealed
detailed_summary: Elizabeth asks if Colonel Forster shared the details of Lydia's note to his wife, Harriet.
Jane confirms he brought the letter for them to see.
Jane retrieves the letter from her pocket-book and gives it to Elizabeth.
The letter's contents are revealed:
Lydia addresses 'My dear Harriet', anticipating her friend's surprise and laughing about it.
She announces she is going to Gretna Green with 'the one man in the world I love', calling him 'an angel'.
She states she couldn't be happy without him and sees no harm in leaving.
She tells Harriet not to inform Longbourn if she prefers, anticipating a greater surprise when she writes signing her name 'Lydia Wickham'.
She exclaims over what a 'good joke' it will be, barely able to write for laughing.
She asks Harriet to make excuses to Pratt for missing their dance engagement, hoping he'll understand and promising to dance with him at the next ball.
She mentions sending for her clothes later but requests Harriet ask Sally to mend a tear in her muslin gown before packing.
She bids goodbye, sends love to Colonel Forster, and hopes they drink to their journey.
The letter is signed 'Your affectionate friend, Lydia Bennet'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Could Colonel Forster repeat the particulars of Lydia’s note to his wife?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Lydia Bennet.”

events.text_segment:
“Could Colonel Forster repeat the particulars of Lydia’s note to his wife?”
“He brought it with him for us to see.”
Jane then took it from her pocket-book, and gave it to Elizabeth. These were the contents:—
“My dear Harriet,
“You will laugh when you know where I am gone, and I cannot help laughing myself at your surprise to-morrow morning, as soon as I am missed. I am going to Gretna Green, and if you cannot guess with who, I shall think you a simpleton, for there is but one man in the world I love, and he is an angel. I should never be happy without him, so think it no harm to be off. You need not send them word at Longbourn of my going, if you do not like it, for it will make the surprise the greater when I write to them, and sign my name Lydia Wickham. What a good joke it will be! I can hardly write for laughing. Pray make my excuses to Pratt for not keeping my engagement, and dancing with him to-night. Tell him I hope he will excuse me when he knows all, and tell him I will dance with him at the next ball we meet with great pleasure. I shall send for my clothes when I get to Longbourn; but I wish you would tell Sally to mend a great slit in my worked muslin gown before they are packed up. Good-bye. Give my love to Colonel Forster. I hope you will drink to our good journey.
“Your affectionate friend,
“Lydia Bennet.”

I shall send for my clothes when I get to Longbourn; but I wish you would tell Sally to mend a great slit in my worked muslin gown before they are packed up. Good-bye. Give my love to Colonel Forster. I hope you will drink to our good journey.

'Your affectionate friend,
'LYDIA BENNET.'"

'Your affectionate friend,
'LYDIA BENNET.'"

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Based on "Pride and Prejudice," Colonel Forster was able to share the contents of Lydia's note to his wife. The note was brief and revealed Lydia's plans to elope with Wickham. In it, Lydia informed Mrs. Forster that she was traveling to Gretna Green (a place in Scotland famous for runaway marriages) with the man she loved. She asked Mrs. Forster not to worry about her and mentioned that she would write to her family from her destination. Lydia also playfully suggested that her family would be surprised when they received her next letter, as it would bear a different signature - indicating her anticipated marriage to Wickham.

The note displayed Lydia's characteristic thoughtlessness and excitement rather than any sense of shame or understanding of the impropriety of her actions. It revealed her romantic notions about eloping and her complete lack of concern for how her behavior might affect her family's reputation. Colonel Forster shared this information during the family's attempts to locate Lydia and Wickham, which ultimately led to Mr. Bennet traveling to London to search for them, followed by Mr. Darcy's intervention in resolving the situation.

events.title: Consequences, Condolences, and Mr. Bennet's Plan
detailed_summary: Elizabeth finishes the letter, exclaiming over Lydia's thoughtlessness at such a critical moment.
She concedes, however, that the letter shows Lydia genuinely intended marriage and wasn't part of a 'scheme of infamy' herself, whatever Wickham's later influence might be.
She expresses sympathy for how her father must have felt.
Jane describes Mr. Bennet's profound shock, rendering him speechless for ten minutes, followed by Mrs. Bennet falling ill and the house descending into confusion.
Elizabeth worries if all the servants knew the full story quickly.
Jane hopes not but admits maintaining discretion was difficult with Mrs. Bennet in hysterics.
Jane confesses the horror of the situation nearly overwhelmed her, potentially hindering her ability to care for her mother effectively.
Elizabeth expresses concern for Jane's well-being, lamenting she wasn't there to help share the burden.
Jane assures her Mary and Kitty were kind and willing to help, but she felt it wasn't right for them (Kitty being delicate, Mary needing rest from studies).
She mentions Aunt Philips stayed from Tuesday to Thursday, providing comfort, and Lady Lucas visited Wednesday to offer condolences and assistance, which Elizabeth finds unwelcome.
Elizabeth states she prefers minimal contact with neighbours during such misfortunes, deeming assistance impossible and condolences insufferable, preferring they 'triumph at a distance'.
Elizabeth then inquires about Mr. Bennet's specific plans in London.
Jane explains he intended to go first to Epsom, where Lydia and Wickham last changed horses, to question the postilions.
His main goal was to find the number of the hackney coach they entered at Clapham, which had arrived from London with a fare.
He hoped the unusual sight of a couple switching carriages might have been noticed, allowing him to inquire at Clapham.
If he could discover where the coachman dropped his previous fare, he planned to make inquiries there, hoping to trace the coach's stand and number.
Jane admits she knows of no other specific plans, as Mr. Bennet was very hurried and distressed, making it difficult to learn even these details.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Oh, thoughtless, thoughtless Lydia!” cried Elizabeth when she had finished it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I do not know of any other designs that he had formed; but he was in such a hurry to be gone, and his spirits so greatly discomposed, that I had difficulty in finding out even so much as this.”

events.text_segment:
“Oh, thoughtless, thoughtless Lydia!” cried Elizabeth when she had finished it. “What a letter is this, to be written at such a moment! But at least it shows that she was serious in the object of her journey. Whatever he might afterwards persuade her to, it was not on her side a scheme of infamy. My poor father! how he must have felt it!”
“I never saw anyone so shocked. He could not speak a word for full ten minutes. My mother was taken ill immediately, and the whole house in such confusion!”
“Oh, Jane,” cried Elizabeth, “was there a servant belonging to it who did not know the whole story before the end of the day?”
“I do not know: I hope there was. But to be guarded at such a time is very difficult. My mother was in hysterics; and though I endeavoured to give her every assistance in my power, I am afraid I did not do so much as I might have done. But the horror of what might possibly happen almost took from me my faculties.”
“Your attendance upon her has been too much for you. You do not look well. Oh that I had been with you! you have had every care and anxiety upon yourself alone.”
“Mary and Kitty have been very kind, and would have shared in every fatigue, I am sure, but I did not think it right for either of them. Kitty is slight and delicate, and Mary studies so much that her hours of repose should not be broken in on. My aunt Philips came to Longbourn on Tuesday, after my father went away; and was so good as to stay till Thursday with me. She was of great use and comfort to us all, and Lady Lucas has been very kind: she walked here on Wednesday morning to condole with us, and offered her services, or any of her daughters, if they could be of use to us.”
“She had better have stayed at home,” cried Elizabeth: “perhaps she meant well, but, under such a misfortune as this, one cannot see too little of one’s neighbours. Assistance is impossible; condolence, insufferable. Let them triumph over us at a distance, and be satisfied.”
She then proceeded to inquire into the measures which her father had intended to pursue, while in town, for the recovery of his daughter.
“He meant, I believe,” replied Jane, “to go to Epsom, the place where they last changed horses, see the postilions, and try if anything could be made out from them. His principal object must be to discover the number of the hackney coach which took them from Clapham. It had come with a fare from London; and as he thought the circumstance of a gentleman and lady’s removing from one carriage into another might be remarked, he meant to make inquiries at Clapham. If he could anyhow discover at what house the coachman had before set down his fare, he determined to make inquiries there, and hoped it might not be impossible to find out the stand and number of the coach. I do not know of any other designs that he had formed; but he was in such a hurry to be gone, and his spirits so greatly discomposed, that I had difficulty in finding out even so much as this.”

events.title: Anxious Waiting and Mr. Gardiner's Departure
detailed_summary: The Bennet family anxiously awaits a letter from Mr. Bennet regarding Lydia and Wickham, but none arrives.
The family understands Mr. Bennet is typically a poor correspondent but had hoped for news given the critical situation.
They infer the lack of news means there's no positive development, yet they still crave confirmation.
Mr. Gardiner, having waited for the post, departs for London to assist in the search.
Before leaving, Mr. Gardiner assures his sister, Mrs. Bennet, that he will try to persuade Mr. Bennet to return home soon, easing her fears about her husband potentially fighting a duel.
He also promises to send regular updates.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The whole party were in hopes of a letter from Mr. Bennet the next morning, but the post came in without bringing a single line from him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Gardiner had waited only for the letters before he set off.

events.text_segment: The whole party were in hopes of a letter from Mr. Bennet the next morning, but the post came in without bringing a single line from him. His family knew him to be, on all common occasions, a most negligent and dilatory correspondent; but at such a time they had hoped for exertion. They were forced to conclude, that he had no pleasing intelligence to send; but even of that they would have been glad to be certain. Mr. Gardiner had waited only for the letters before he set off.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: The whole party were in hopes of a letter from Mr. Bennet the next morning, but the post came in without bringing a single line from him. His family knew him to be, on all common occasions, a most negligent and dilatory correspondent; but at such a time they had hoped for exertion. They were forced to conclude that he had no pleasing intelligence to send; but even of that they would have been glad to be certain. Mr. Gardiner had waited only for the letters before he set off.

When he was gone, they were certain at least of receiving constant information of what was going on, and their uncle promised, at parting, to prevail on Mr. Bennet to return to Longbourn, as soon as he could, to the great consolation of his sister, who considered it as the only security for her husband's not being killed in a duel.

events.title: Support, Gossip, and Deepening Despair
detailed_summary: Mrs. Gardiner decides to stay in Hertfordshire longer with her children to support her nieces.
She provides comfort by assisting with Mrs. Bennet and spending time with the girls.
Their other aunt, Mrs. Phillips, visits often, claiming to offer cheer.
However, Mrs. Phillips consistently shares negative reports about Wickham's past behavior and financial issues, leaving the family more distressed.
The general opinion in Meryton has turned sharply against Wickham, who was previously admired.
He is now widely accused of being heavily in debt to local tradespeople and of engaging in scandalous affairs with their daughters.
Everyone condemns him, claiming they always suspected his apparent goodness.
Elizabeth finds these reports credible enough to solidify her belief in Lydia's ruin.
Even the optimistic Jane loses hope, especially as enough time has passed that news of an elopement to Scotland should have surfaced if that were their plan.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When he was gone, they were certain at least of receiving constant information of what was going on; and their uncle promised, at parting, to prevail on Mr. Bennet to return to Longbourn as soon as he could, to the great consolation of his sister, who considered it as the only security for her husband’s not being killed in a duel.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mr. Gardiner left Longbourn on Sunday; on Tuesday, his wife received a letter from him: it told them, that on his arrival he had immediately found out his brother, and persuaded him to come to Gracechurch Street.

events.text_segment:
When he was gone, they were certain at least of receiving constant information of what was going on; and their uncle promised, at parting, to prevail on Mr. Bennet to return to Longbourn as soon as he could, to the great consolation of his sister, who considered it as the only security for her husband’s not being killed in a duel.
Mrs. Gardiner and the children were to remain in Hertfordshire a few days longer, as the former thought her presence might be serviceable to her nieces. She shared in their attendance on Mrs. Bennet, and was a great comfort to them in their hours of freedom. Their other aunt also visited them frequently, and always, as she said, with the design of cheering and heartening them up—though, as she never came without reporting some fresh instance of Wickham’s extravagance or irregularity, she seldom went away without leaving them more dispirited than she found them.
All Meryton seemed striving to blacken the man who, but three months before, had been almost an angel of light. He was declared to be in debt to every tradesman in the place, and his intrigues, all honoured with the title of seduction, had been extended into every tradesman’s family. Everybody declared that he was the wickedest young man in the world; and everybody began to find out that they had always distrusted the appearance of his goodness. Elizabeth, though she did not credit above half of what was said, believed enough to make her former assurance of her sister’s ruin still more certain; and even Jane, who believed still less of it, became almost hopeless, more especially as the time was now come, when, if they had gone to Scotland, which she had never before entirely despaired of, they must in all probability have gained some news of them.
Mr. Gardiner left Longbourn on Sunday; on Tuesday, his wife received a letter from him: it told them, that on his arrival he had immediately found out his brother, and persuaded him to come to Gracechurch Street.

Mr. Gardiner left Longbourn on Sunday; on Tuesday his wife received a letter from him; it told them that, on his arrival, he had immediately found out his brother, and persuaded him to come to Gracechurch Street; that Mr. Bennet had been to Epsom and Clapham, before his arrival, but without gaining any satisfactory information; and that he was now determined to inquire at all the principal hotels in town, as Mr. Bennet thought it possible they might have gone to one of them, on their first coming to London, before they procured lodgings. Mr. Gardiner himself did not expect any success from this measure, but as his brother was eager in it, he meant to assist him in pursuing it. He added that Mr. Bennet seemed wholly disinclined at present to leave London and promised to write again very soon. There was also a postscript to this effect:

events.title: First Report from London and a Request for Information
detailed_summary: Mr. Gardiner reports in his letter that Mr. Bennet had already searched Epsom and Clapham unsuccessfully before Mr. Gardiner's arrival in London.
Mr. Bennet is now determined to check London's main hotels, believing Lydia and Wickham might have stayed in one initially.
Mr. Gardiner doubts this strategy but intends to support his brother-in-law's efforts.
He notes that Mr. Bennet currently shows no inclination to leave London and promises another letter soon.
In a postscript, Mr. Gardiner reveals he has contacted Colonel Forster, asking him to inquire among Wickham's regimental friends about any relatives who might know his whereabouts.
Mr. Gardiner suggests that perhaps Elizabeth might possess better knowledge of Wickham's relations than anyone else.
Elizabeth understands the implication behind this request but lacks the specific information needed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That Mr. Bennet had been to Epsom and Clapham, before his arrival, but without gaining any satisfactory information; and that he was now determined to inquire at all the principal hotels in town, as Mr. Bennet thought it possible they might have gone to one of them, on their first coming to London, before they procured lodgings.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth was at no loss to understand from whence this deference for her authority proceeded; but it was not in her power to give any information of so satisfactory a nature as the compliment deserved.

events.text_segment:
That Mr. Bennet had been to Epsom and Clapham, before his arrival, but without gaining any satisfactory information; and that he was now determined to inquire at all the principal hotels in town, as Mr. Bennet thought it possible they might have gone to one of them, on their first coming to London, before they procured lodgings. Mr. Gardiner himself did not expect any success from this measure; but as his brother was eager in it, he meant to assist him in pursuing it. He added, that Mr. Bennet seemed wholly disinclined at present to leave London, and promised to write again very soon. There was also a postscript to this effect:—
“I have written to Colonel Forster to desire him to find out, if possible, from some of the young man’s intimates in the regiment, whether Wickham has any relations or connections who would be likely to know in what part of the town he has now concealed himself. If there were anyone that one could apply to, with a probability of gaining such a clue as that, it might be of essential consequence. At present we have nothing to guide us. Colonel Forster will, I dare say, do everything in his power to satisfy us on this head. But, on second thoughts, perhaps Lizzy could tell us what relations he has now living better than any other person.”
Elizabeth was at no loss to understand from whence this deference for her authority proceeded; but it was not in her power to give any information of so satisfactory a nature as the compliment deserved.

He added that Mr. Bennet seemed wholly disinclined at present to leave London and promised to write again very soon. There was also a postscript to this effect:

"I have written to Colonel Forster to desire him to find out, if possible, from some of the young man's intimates in the regiment, whether Wickham has any relations or connections who would be likely to know in what part of town he has now concealed himself. If there were anyone that one could apply to with a probability of gaining such a clue as that, it might be of essential consequence. At present we have nothing to guide us. Colonel Forster will, I dare say, do everything in his power to satisfy us on this head. But, on second thoughts, perhaps, Lizzy could tell us what relations he has now living, better than any other person."

Elizabeth was at no loss to understand from whence this deference to her authority proceeded; but it was not in her power to give any information of so satisfactory a nature as the compliment deserved.

events.title: Elizabeth's Limited Knowledge and Continued Anxiety
detailed_summary: Elizabeth recalls only hearing Wickham mention his deceased parents; she knows of no living relatives.
She considers it possible that some of Wickham's military acquaintances might have more information.
Although not optimistic, she sees the inquiry as a small source of potential progress.
Daily life at Longbourn remains consumed by anxiety, peaking each morning with the anticipation of the mail delivery.
The family relies entirely on letters for any news, good or bad, regarding the situation.
Each day brings renewed hope for significant developments.

events.text_segment:
She had never heard of his having had any relations, except a father and mother, both of whom had been dead many years. It was possible, however, that some of his companions in the ——shire might be able to give more information; and though she was not very sanguine in expecting it, the application was a something to look forward to.
Every day at Longbourn was now a day of anxiety; but the most anxious part of each was when the post was expected. The arrival of letters was the first grand object of every morning’s impatience. Through letters, whatever of good or bad was to be told would be communicated; and every succeeding day was expected to bring some news of importance.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It was strange to Elizabeth that a man of such consequence as Mr. Darcy should be so isolated in the world. While the Bennets had numerous connections through aunts, uncles, and cousins, he appeared to stand quite alone, save for his sister Georgiana. Perhaps this solitude contributed to his reserved nature and pride. Elizabeth wondered if growing up without extended family had shaped his character, forcing him to rely solely on himself from a young age. This might explain his careful judgment of others and reluctance to form new attachments. His friendship with Bingley seemed all the more significant in light of this familial absence.

events.title: Mr. Collins's Officious Condolences
detailed_summary: Before further news arrives from Mr. Gardiner, a letter addressed to Mr. Bennet comes from Mr. Collins.
Jane, authorized to open her father's mail, reads the letter, with Elizabeth looking over her shoulder.
Mr. Collins expresses condolences, framing Lydia's elopement as a grievous and permanent affliction.
He states that both he and Mrs. Collins sympathize with the family's distress.
He suggests Lydia's death would have been preferable to this disgrace.
He relays Charlotte's opinion that Lydia's behavior stems from poor upbringing, though he adds his own belief that Lydia must have a naturally bad disposition.
He informs them that Lady Catherine de Bourgh and her daughter concur, pitying the family and believing the scandal will harm the marriage prospects of the other Bennet daughters.
Mr. Collins expresses smug satisfaction that he avoided marrying into the family, thus escaping involvement in their current sorrow and disgrace.
He advises Mr. Bennet to disown Lydia completely and let her suffer the consequences of her actions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But before they heard again from Mr. Gardiner, a letter arrived for their father, from a different quarter, from Mr. Collins; which, as Jane had received directions to open all that came for him in his absence, she accordingly read; and Elizabeth, who knew what curiosities his letters always were, looked over her, and read it likewise.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I am, dear sir,” etc., etc.

events.text_segment:
But before they heard again from Mr. Gardiner, a letter arrived for their father, from a different quarter, from Mr. Collins; which, as Jane had received directions to open all that came for him in his absence, she accordingly read; and Elizabeth, who knew what curiosities his letters always were, looked over her, and read it likewise. It was as follows:—
“My dear Sir,
“I feel myself called upon, by our relationship, and my situation in life, to condole with you on the grievous affliction you are now suffering under, of which we were yesterday informed by a letter from Hertfordshire. Be assured, my dear sir, that Mrs. Collins and myself sincerely sympathize with you, and all your respectable family, in your present distress, which must be of the bitterest kind, because proceeding from a cause which no time can remove. No arguments shall be wanting on my part, that can alleviate so severe a misfortune; or that may comfort you, under a circumstance that must be, of all others, most afflicting to a parent’s mind. The death of your daughter would have been a blessing in comparison of this. And it is the more to be lamented, because there is reason to suppose, as my dear Charlotte informs me, that this licentiousness of behaviour in your daughter has proceeded from a faulty degree of indulgence; though, at the same time, for the consolation of yourself and Mrs. Bennet, I am inclined to think that her own disposition must be naturally bad, or she could not be guilty of such an enormity, at so early an age. Howsoever that may be, you are grievously to be pitied; in which opinion I am not only joined by Mrs. Collins, but likewise by Lady Catherine and her daughter, to whom I have related the affair. They agree with me in apprehending that this false step in one daughter will be injurious to the fortunes of all the others: for who, as Lady Catherine herself condescendingly says, will connect themselves with such a family? And this consideration leads me, moreover, to reflect, with augmented satisfaction, on a certain event of last November; for had it been otherwise, I must have been involved in all your sorrow and disgrace. Let me advise you, then, my dear sir, to console yourself as much as possible, to throw off your unworthy child from your affection for ever, and leave her to reap the fruits of her own heinous offence.
“I am, dear sir,” etc., etc.

events.title: Grim News of Wickham's Debts and Mr. Bennet's Impending Return
detailed_summary: Mr. Gardiner writes again after receiving Colonel Forster's response.
The news is discouraging: Wickham appears to have no known living relatives or close connections.
While he had many acquaintances previously, none seem particularly close since joining the militia.
There is no obvious person who might know his location.
Compounding the issue, it has been discovered that Wickham left behind substantial gambling debts in Brighton, estimated by Colonel Forster to exceed £1000.
He also owes money to local tradesmen, but his 'debts of honour' (gambling debts) are even larger.
Mr. Gardiner does not withhold these damaging details from the family at Longbourn.
Jane reacts with horror, expressing shock at discovering Wickham was a gambler.
Mr. Gardiner informs them that Mr. Bennet will return home the following day (Saturday).
Discouraged by the lack of progress, Mr. Bennet has agreed to his brother-in-law's suggestion to return home and let Mr. Gardiner manage the ongoing search.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Gardiner did not write again, till he had received an answer from Colonel Forster; and then he had nothing of a pleasant nature to send.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Rendered spiritless by the ill success of all their endeavours, he had yielded to his brother-in-law’s entreaty that he would return to his family and leave it to him to do whatever occasion might suggest to be advisable for continuing their pursuit.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Gardiner did not write again, till he had received an answer from Colonel Forster; and then he had nothing of a pleasant nature to send. It was not known that Wickham had a single relation with whom he kept up any connection, and it was certain that he had no near one living. His former acquaintance had been numerous; but since he had been in the militia, it did not appear that he was on terms of particular friendship with any of them. There was no one, therefore, who could be pointed out as likely to give any news of him. And in the wretched state of his own finances, there was a very powerful motive for secrecy, in addition to his fear of discovery by Lydia’s relations; for it had just transpired that he had left gaming debts behind him to a very considerable amount. Colonel Forster believed that more than a thousand pounds would be necessary to clear his expenses at Brighton. He owed a good deal in the town, but his debts of honour were still more formidable. Mr. Gardiner did not attempt to conceal these particulars from the Longbourn family; Jane heard them with horror. “A gamester!” she cried. “This is wholly unexpected; I had not an idea of it.”
Mr. Gardiner added, in his letter, that they might expect to see their father at home on the following day, which was Saturday. Rendered spiritless by the ill success of all their endeavours, he had yielded to his brother-in-law’s entreaty that he would return to his family and leave it to him to do whatever occasion might suggest to be advisable for continuing their pursuit.

events.title: Mrs. Bennet's Disappointment and Mrs. Gardiner's Departure
detailed_summary: Upon learning of Mr. Bennet's imminent return, Mrs. Bennet expresses dissatisfaction, contrary to her children's expectations based on her earlier fears for his safety.
She laments his return without Lydia and questions who will now force Wickham to marry her.
Mrs. Gardiner, needing to return to her own home, arranges to travel to London with her children at the same time Mr. Bennet travels back from London.
The coach facilitates this exchange, taking Mrs. Gardiner partway and bringing Mr. Bennet back to Longbourn.

Mrs. Gardiner departs still puzzled about the nature of Elizabeth's relationship with Mr. Darcy, having heard nothing further and receiving no indication of correspondence from him since Elizabeth's return from Derbyshire.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When Mrs. Bennet was told of this, she did not express so much satisfaction as her children expected, considering what her anxiety for his life had been before.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth had received none since her return, that could come from Pemberley.

events.text_segment:
When Mrs. Bennet was told of this, she did not express so much satisfaction as her children expected, considering what her anxiety for his life had been before.
“What! is he coming home, and without poor Lydia?” she cried. “Sure he will not leave London before he has found them. Who is to fight Wickham, and make him marry her, if he comes away?”
As Mrs. Gardiner began to wish to be at home, it was settled that she and her children should go to London at the same time that Mr. Bennet came from it. The coach, therefore, took them the first stage of their journey, and brought its master back to Longbourn.
Mrs. Gardiner went away in all the perplexity about Elizabeth and her Derbyshire friend, that had attended her from that part of the world. His name had never been voluntarily mentioned before them by her niece; and the kind of half-expectation which Mrs. Gardiner had formed, of their being followed by a letter from him, had ended in nothing. Elizabeth had received none since her return, that could come from Pemberley.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_jailbreak:
Simulating output for `generate_literary_segment` function:

```
When Mrs. Bennet was told of this, she did not express so much satisfaction as her children expected, considering what her anxiety for his life had been before.

"So, he is coming home, is he?" said she. "Well, I am glad of it, I am sure. And so he should, for I'm quite distressed about Lydia. And who is to fight Wickham, and make him marry her, if he comes away? I thought he had gone on purpose to find them out. But it seems he has not; and now he is coming home, and without poor Lydia! I do not know who is to take care of her; for she cannot be brought to Longbourn without any of them knowing about it. Oh, what will become of us!"

As she said this, she threw herself back in her chair in a fit of vexation that quite alarmed her daughters. They endeavored to soothe her, reminding her that Mr. Gardiner had promised to be of all the service in his power, and that his return did not necessarily imply an abandonment of the search.

"Oh! my dear brother," she exclaimed, "that is just what I have been thinking. How good he is! I do not know what we should have done without him. But I wonder what he means to do for them; for, as to our own little property, it would be nothing."

Mrs. Gardiner began now to wish to be at home; she had been away nearly three weeks, and her children were calling for her return. It was accordingly settled that she should leave Longbourn on the morrow, and the coach would conveniently accommodate the exchange, taking her and her children part of the way to London, and bringing Mr. Bennet back to his family.

Elizabeth had heard nothing from Mr. Darcy since her return from Derbyshire; her aunt had been too occupied with arrangements for departure to make any inquiry on that head, though she remained curious about the nature of their relationship. Elizabeth herself had carefully avoided any mention of his name, and Mrs. Gardiner, respecting her niece's reserve, had refrained from pressing the subject further.
```

This literary segment maintains Jane Austen's distinctive style and voice while accurately representing the events described in the detailed summary. It captures Mrs. Bennet's characteristic anxiety and dramatic reactions, the practical arrangements for Mrs. Gardiner's departure, and subtly references Elizabeth's relationship with Mr. Darcy as mentioned in the summary. The passage flows naturally from the provided opening line and incorporates all the characters mentioned in a manner consistent with their established personalities in "Pride and Prejudice."

```
When Mrs. Bennet was told of this, she did not express so much satisfaction as her children expected, considering what her anxiety for his life had been before.

"So," said she, "he is coming home, is he? Well, so much the better. It is just as well he never went to London, for he would have been of no use there. I wonder who considered it necessary that he should go at all—and now here is he coming back again, and poor Lydia is left to take care of herself. Who is to fight Wickham, and make him marry her, if Mr. Bennet comes away? I thought he had gone on purpose to find them out. But it seems he has done nothing of the sort. Oh, dear, dear, what is to become of us!"

Mrs. Gardiner had been going backwards and forwards to London, and was now anxious to be at home; she proposed, therefore, to go to London when Mr. Bennet returned to Longbourn. The coach, accordingly, took her and her children to the first stage of their journey, and brought Mr. Bennet back to his family.

Mrs. Gardiner went away in all the perplexity about Elizabeth and her Derbyshire friend, that had attended her from that part of the world. His name had never been voluntarily mentioned before them by her niece; and the kind of half-expectation which Mrs. Gardiner had formed, of their being followed by a letter from him, had ended in nothing. Elizabeth had received no intelligence of him since her return, that could come from himself.
```

events.title: Mr. Bennet's Return, Self-Reproach, and New Strictness
detailed_summary: Mr. Bennet arrives home appearing outwardly calm and reserved, consistent with his usual demeanor.
He avoids mentioning the reason for his absence, and his daughters hesitate to bring it up.
During afternoon tea, Elizabeth gently expresses sympathy for his difficult time.
Mr. Bennet deflects her sympathy, stating he alone should suffer as the situation is his own fault.
He rejects Elizabeth's attempt to caution him against excessive self-blame, insisting he needs to feel the weight of his culpability for once, though he expects the feeling won't last.
He confirms his belief that Lydia and Wickham are hiding in London.
When Kitty mentions Lydia always wanted to go to London, Mr. Bennet dryly remarks she must be happy then, and likely to stay there awhile.
He acknowledges Elizabeth's wisdom in advising him against letting Lydia go to Brighton back in May.
Interrupted briefly by Jane fetching tea, Mr. Bennet sarcastically comments on the 'elegance' misfortune brings, comparing his potential future behavior to Mrs. Bennet's dramatic seclusion.
When Kitty insists she would behave better than Lydia if allowed to go to Brighton, Mr. Bennet forbids it vehemently.

He declares he has learned caution and imposes strict new rules: no officers allowed in the house or village, no balls unless partnered by a sister, and a requirement for Kitty to prove daily rational activity.
Kitty takes his threats seriously and begins to cry.
Mr. Bennet softens slightly, telling her not to be unhappy and sarcastically promising to take her to a military review in ten years if she behaves well.

events.text_segment:
When Mr. Bennet arrived, he had all the appearance of his usual philosophic composure. He said as little as he had ever been in the habit of saying; made no mention of the business that had taken him away; and it was some time before his daughters had courage to speak of it.
It was not till the afternoon, when he joined them at tea, that Elizabeth ventured to introduce the subject; and then, on her briefly expressing her sorrow for what he must have endured, he replied, “Say nothing of that. Who should suffer but myself? It has been my own doing, and I ought to feel it.”
“You must not be too severe upon yourself,” replied Elizabeth.
“You may well warn me against such an evil. Human nature is so prone to fall into it! No, Lizzy, let me once in my life feel how much I have been to blame. I am not afraid of being overpowered by the impression. It will pass away soon enough.”
“Do you suppose them to be in London?”
“Yes; where else can they be so well concealed?”
“And Lydia used to want to go to London,” added Kitty.
“She is happy, then,” said her father, drily; “and her residence there will probably be of some duration.”
Then, after a short silence, he continued, “Lizzy, I bear you no ill-will for being justified in your advice to me last May, which, considering the event, shows some greatness of mind.”
They were interrupted by Miss Bennet, who came to fetch her mother’s tea.
“This is a parade,” cried he, “which does one good; it gives such an elegance to misfortune! Another day I will do the same; I will sit in my library, in my nightcap and powdering gown, and give as much trouble as I can,—or perhaps I may defer it till Kitty runs away.”
“I am not going to run away, papa,” said Kitty, fretfully. “If I should ever go to Brighton, I would behave better than Lydia.”
“You go to Brighton! I would not trust you so near it as Eastbourne, for fifty pounds! No, Kitty, I have at least learnt to be cautious, and you will feel the effects of it. No officer is ever to enter my house again, nor even to pass through the village. Balls will be absolutely prohibited, unless you stand up with one of your sisters. And you are never to stir out of doors, till you can prove that you have spent ten minutes of every day in a rational manner.”
Kitty, who took all these threats in a serious light, began to cry.
“Well, well,” said he, “do not make yourself unhappy. If you are a good girl for the next ten years, I will take you to a review at the end of them.”

**text_segment**: When Mr. Bennet arrived, he had all the appearance of his usual philosophic composure. He said as little as he had ever been in the habit of saying; made no mention of the business that had taken him away, and it was some time before his daughters had courage to speak of it.

It was not till the afternoon, when he had joined them at tea, that Elizabeth ventured to introduce the subject; and then, on her briefly expressing her sorrow for what he must have endured, he replied, "Say nothing of that. Who should suffer but myself? It has been my own doing, and I ought to feel it."

"You must not be too severe upon yourself," replied Elizabeth.

"You may well warn me against such an evil. Human nature is so prone to fall into it! No, Lizzy, let me once in my life feel how much I have been to blame. I am not afraid of being overpowered by the impression. It will pass away soon enough."

"Do you suppose them to be in London?"

"Yes; where else can they be so well concealed?"

"And Lydia used to want to go to London," added Kitty.

"She is happy then," said her father drily; "and her residence there will probably be of some duration."

Then after a short silence he continued:

"Lizzy, I bear you no ill-will for being justified in your advice to me last May, which, considering the event, shows some greatness of mind."

They were interrupted by a servant with a note for Miss Bennet; it came from Longbourn, and the servant waited for an answer. Jane read it aloud.

"MY DEAR SIR,
"I must trouble you once more for congratulations. Elizabeth will soon be the wife of Mr. Darcy. Console Lady Catherine as well as you can. But, I reckon, she will be too angry even to listen to reason. Yours sincerely, etc."

Would Elizabeth have believed a month ago that this letter would ever be written? The rest of the evening passed in speculation on how soon Mr. Darcy would arrive, and on the joy he would bring to Longbourn.

"Well," said he, "what say you to the day? I think every thing has passed off uncommonly well, I assure you. The servants were all attention to us, and I think we never looked so well in our lives. I was watching you the whole time. You looked so genteel and simple! I longed to tell Lady Lucas that it was all my doing, you know, for it was I who first brought Jane and Bingley together, you know. And, my dear Jane, I never saw you look in greater beauty. Mrs. Long said so too, for I asked her whether you did not. And what do you think she said besides? 'Ah! Mrs. Bennet, we shall have her at Netherfield at last.' She did indeed. I do think Mrs. Long is as good a creature as ever lived—and her nieces are very pretty behaved girls, and not at all handsome: I like them prodigiously."

Mrs. Bennet was prevented replying by the entrance of the footman with a note for Miss Bennet; it came from Netherfield, and the servant waited for an answer. Mrs. Bennet's eyes sparkled with pleasure, and she was eagerly calling out, while her daughter read,

"Well, Jane, who is it from? What is it about? What does he say? Well, Jane, make haste and tell us; make haste, my love."

"It is from Miss Bingley," said Jane, and then read it aloud.

"MY DEAR FRIEND,—
"I congratulate you on the approaching nuptials of your eldest daughter, of which, being in town, I have just heard. I wish I could say one word about the delightful Mr. Darcy, but it is all too recent for me to enlarge on. I will write again very soon. Yours, etc.,
"CAROLINE BINGLEY."

"Ah!" said Mrs. Bennet, "it is just as I expected. I thought how likely it was that she should be in town, and I am sure I never was more disappointed in my life. Well, my comfort is, I am sure Jane will be soon well settled, and I have no doubt that she will always do her duty by him. But it is very hard to have her taken away from me. They will be very quiet, I dare say; and I dare say she will always be at Pemberley with her."
