They were interrupted by a servant with a note for Miss Bennet; it came from Longbourn, and the servant waited for an answer. Jane read it aloud.

"Well," said he, "if I should ever make you an offer of marriage now, I suppose there would be nothing for it but to find out when Wickham would be at Gretna Green, that I might be in time to stop him."

He made no answer, and each of them deep in thought continued silent till they reached the house. Their father then went to the library to write, and the girls walked into the breakfast-room.

"And they are really to be married!" exclaimed Elizabeth, as soon as they were by themselves. "How strange this is! And for this we are to be thankful. That they should marry, small as is their chance of happiness, and wretched as is his character, we are forced to rejoice. Oh, Lydia!"

"I comfort myself with thinking," replied Jane, "that he certainly would not marry Lydia if he had not a real regard for her. Though our kind uncle has done something towards clearing him, I cannot believe that ten thousand pounds, or anything like it, has been advanced. He has children of his own, and may have more. How could he spare half ten thousand pounds?"

"If he were ever able to learn what Wickham's debts have been," said Elizabeth, "and how much is settled on his side on our sister, we shall exactly know what Mr. Gardiner has done for them, because Wickham has not sixpence of his own. The kindness of my uncle and aunt can never be requited. Their taking her home, and affording her their personal protection and countenance, is such a sacrifice to her advantage as years of gratitude cannot enough acknowledge. By this time she is actually with them! If such goodness does not make her miserable now, she will never deserve to be happy! What a meeting for her, when she first sees my aunt!"

"We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side," said Jane: "I hope and trust they will yet be happy. His consenting to marry her is a proof, I will believe, that he is come to a right way of thinking. Their mutual affection will steady them; and I flatter myself they will settle so quietly, and live in so rational a manner, as may in time make their past imprudence forgotten."

"Their conduct has been such," replied Elizabeth, "as neither you, nor I, nor anybody can ever forget. It is useless to talk of it."

It now occurred to the girls that their mother was in all likelihood perfectly ignorant of what had happened. They went to the library, therefore, and asked their father whether he would not wish them to make it known to her. He was writing and, without raising his head, coolly replied:

"Just as you please."

"May we take my uncle's letter to read to her?"

"Take whatever you like, and get away."

Elizabeth took the letter from his writing-table, and they went upstairs together. Mary and Kitty were both with Mrs. Bennet: one communication would, therefore, do for all. After a slight preparation for good news, the letter was read aloud. Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself. As soon as Jane had read Mr. Gardiner's hope of Lydia's being soon married, her joy burst forth, and every following sentence added to its exuberance. She was now in an irritation as violent from delight, as she had ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation. To know that her daughter would be married was enough. She was disturbed by no fear for her felicity, nor humbled by any remembrance of her misconduct.

"My dear, dear Lydia!" she cried. "This is delightful indeed! She will be married! I shall see her again! She will be married at sixteen! My good, kind brother! I knew how it would be. How merry we shall be together when we meet!"

"For we must attribute this happy conclusion," she added, "in a great measure to his kindness. We are persuaded that he has pledged himself to assist Mr. Wickham with money."

events.title: Urgent News from London Arrives
detailed_summary: Two days after Mr. Bennet's return from London, Jane and Elizabeth Bennet are walking in the grounds when the housekeeper, Mrs. Hill, approaches them.
Initially assuming Mrs. Hill is summoning them to their mother, they are surprised when she instead asks if they have received any positive news from London.
The sisters are confused, stating they have heard nothing.
Mrs. Hill reveals, in astonishment, that an express message from Mr. Gardiner has arrived for Mr. Bennet, and he has possessed the letter for half an hour.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Two days after Mr. Bennet’s return, as Jane and Elizabeth were walking together in the shrubbery behind the house, they saw the housekeeper coming towards them, and concluding that she came to call them to their mother, went forward to meet her; but instead of the expected summons, when they approached her, she said to Miss Bennet, “I beg your pardon, madam, for interrupting you, but I was in hopes you might have got some good news from town, so I took the liberty of coming to ask.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He has been here this half hour, and master has had a letter.”

events.text_segment:
Two days after Mr. Bennet’s return, as Jane and Elizabeth were walking together in the shrubbery behind the house, they saw the housekeeper coming towards them, and concluding that she came to call them to their mother, went forward to meet her; but instead of the expected summons, when they approached her, she said to Miss Bennet, “I beg your pardon, madam, for interrupting you, but I was in hopes you might have got some good news from town, so I took the liberty of coming to ask.”
“What do you mean, Hill? We have heard nothing from town.”
“Dear madam,” cried Mrs. Hill, in great astonishment, “don’t you know there is an express come for master from Mr. Gardiner? He has been here this half hour, and master has had a letter.”

"What do you mean, Hill?" said Jane. "We have heard nothing from town."

"Dear madam," cried Mrs. Hill, in great astonishment, "don't you know there is an express come for master from Mr. Gardiner? He has been here this half-hour, and master has had a letter."

"If you are looking for my master, ma'am, he is walking towards the little copse."

events.title: Finding Mr. Bennet and Receiving the Letter
detailed_summary: Jane and Elizabeth immediately abandon their walk and rush back to the house, too anxious to speak.
They search the breakfast-room and library but do not find their father.
As they are about to search upstairs, the butler informs them that Mr. Bennet is walking towards the small copse.
The sisters hurry through the hall again and run across the lawn to catch up with their father, who is walking slowly towards the woods.
Elizabeth, being faster, reaches him first, out of breath, and eagerly inquires about the news from their uncle.
Mr. Bennet confirms he has received a letter via express.
When asked if the news is good or bad, he responds cynically about the likelihood of good news.
He takes the letter from his pocket and offers it to Elizabeth to read.
Elizabeth snatches it impatiently just as Jane arrives.
Mr. Bennet instructs Elizabeth to read the letter aloud, admitting he himself is unclear about its contents.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Away ran the girls, too eager to get in to have time for speech.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Read it aloud,” said their father, “for I hardly know myself what it is about.”

events.text_segment:
Away ran the girls, too eager to get in to have time for speech. They ran through the vestibule into the breakfast-room; from thence to the library;—their father was in neither; and they were on the point of seeking him upstairs with their mother, when they were met by the butler, who said,—
“If you are looking for my master, ma’am, he is walking towards the little copse.”
Upon this information, they instantly passed through the hall once more, and ran across the lawn after their father, who was deliberately pursuing his way towards a small wood on one side of the paddock.
Jane, who was not so light, nor so much in the habit of running as Elizabeth, soon lagged behind, while her sister, panting for breath, came up with him, and eagerly cried out,—
“Oh, papa, what news? what news? have you heard from my uncle?”
“Yes, I have had a letter from him by express.”
“Well, and what news does it bring—good or bad?”
“What is there of good to be expected?” said he, taking the letter from his pocket; “but perhaps you would like to read it.”
Elizabeth impatiently caught it from his hand. Jane now came up.
“Read it aloud,” said their father, “for I hardly know myself what it is about.”

Jane, who was not so light nor so much in the habit of running as Elizabeth, soon lagged behind, while her sister, panting for breath, came up with him, and eagerly cried out:

"Oh, papa, what news—what news? Have you heard from my uncle?"

"Yes I have had a letter from him by express."

"Well, and what news does it bring—good or bad?"

"What is there of good to be expected?" said he, taking the letter from his pocket. "But perhaps you would like to read it."

Elizabeth impatiently caught it from his hand. Jane now came up.

"Read it aloud," said their father, "for I hardly know myself what it is about."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
They found Mr. Bennet still in his library, seemingly absorbed in his book despite the commotion their arrival had caused. Mrs. Bennet had followed them in, her face alight with anticipation of news from Netherfield.

"Oh! Mr. Bennet," she exclaimed, "we have had such a delightful evening! The dinner was splendid, and Mr. Bingley was exceedingly attentive to Jane."

Mr. Bennet looked up with his customary dry expression. "I suppose this means we shall soon be planning a wedding?"

"Father!" Jane protested, her cheeks coloring.

Elizabeth smiled. "Mr. Darcy was there as well, though he spent most of the evening observing rather than participating."

"And why should we care about Mr. Darcy?" Mrs. Bennet huffed. "Such a proud, disagreeable man! Did you see how he barely spoke to anyone but Mr. Bingley's sisters?"

"He danced with Miss Bingley twice," Kitty added.

"And looked as though it pained him greatly," Elizabeth remarked with a laugh.

Mr. Bennet set his book aside. "Well, it seems I have missed quite the spectacle. Perhaps next time I shall accompany you, if only to witness this parade of pride and pretension firsthand."

events.title: Mr. Gardiner's Letter: Terms for Lydia's Marriage
detailed_summary: Elizabeth reads the letter from Mr. Gardiner, dated Monday, August 2nd, from Gracechurch Street.
Mr. Gardiner announces he has found Lydia and Wickham in London, providing hope for resolution.
Jane joyfully interrupts, assuming this means they are married.
Elizabeth continues reading, revealing that they are not married and had no plans to be.
Mr. Gardiner explains that a marriage can be arranged if Mr. Bennet agrees to certain financial conditions.
These conditions involve settling Lydia's equal share of the £5,000 inheritance (due after Mr. and Mrs. Bennet's deaths) and providing her an allowance of £100 per year during Mr. Bennet's lifetime.
Mr. Gardiner states he has tentatively agreed to these terms on Mr. Bennet's behalf and requires immediate confirmation via the express messenger.
He assures Mr. Bennet that Wickham's financial situation is not as dire as commonly believed, implying there will be some funds left for Lydia even after Wickham's debts are cleared.
Mr. Gardiner offers to manage the entire settlement process through lawyers (Haggerston) if given the authority, advising Mr. Bennet to remain at Longbourn.
He adds that Lydia is coming to stay with the Gardiners that day and the wedding will take place from their home, requesting Mr. Bennet's approval.
He concludes by promising more information soon.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Gracechurch Street, Monday, August 2.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence:
Yours, etc. 
“Edw. Gardiner.”

events.text_segment:
“Gracechurch Street, Monday, August 2.
“My dear Brother,
“At last I am able to send you some tidings of my niece, and such as, upon the whole, I hope will give you satisfaction. Soon after you left me on Saturday, I was fortunate enough to find out in what part of London they were. The particulars I reserve till we meet. It is enough to know they are discovered: I have seen them both——”
“Then it is as I always hoped,” cried Jane: “they are married!”
Elizabeth read on: “I have seen them both. They are not married, nor can I find there was any intention of being so; but if you are willing to perform the engagements which I have ventured to make on your side, I hope it will not be long before they are. All that is required of you is, to assure to your daughter, by settlement, her equal share of the five thousand pounds, secured among your children after the decease of yourself and my sister; and, moreover, to enter into an engagement of allowing her, during your life, one hundred pounds per annum. These are conditions which, considering everything, I had no hesitation in complying with, as far as I thought myself privileged, for you. I shall send this by express, that no time may be lost in bringing me your answer. You will easily comprehend, from these particulars, that Mr. Wickham’s circumstances are not so hopeless as they are generally believed to be. The world has been deceived in that respect; and I am happy to say, there will be some little money, even when all his debts are discharged, to settle on my niece, in addition to her own fortune. If, as I conclude will be the case, you send me full powers to act in your name throughout the whole of this business, I will immediately give directions to Haggerston for preparing a proper settlement. There will not be the smallest occasion for your coming to town again; therefore stay quietly at Longbourn, and depend on my diligence and care. Send back your answer as soon as you can, and be careful to write explicitly. We have judged it best that my niece should be married from this house, of which I hope you will approve. She comes to us to-day. I shall write again as soon as anything more is determined on. Yours, etc.
“Edw. Gardiner.”

events.title: Discussion of Terms and Mr. Gardiner's Suspected Role
detailed_summary: Upon finishing the letter, Elizabeth expresses disbelief that Wickham would actually consent to marry Lydia.
Jane, focusing on the positive, remarks that Wickham must not be as bad as they thought and congratulates her father.
Elizabeth urgently asks if Mr. Bennet has replied yet.
Mr. Bennet confirms he hasn't but acknowledges it must be done soon.
Elizabeth implores him not to delay writing.
Jane offers to write the letter for him if he finds it troublesome.
Mr. Bennet admits his dislike for the task but agrees it's necessary, turning back towards the house with them.
Elizabeth asks if the terms must be complied with.
Mr. Bennet replies that he's only ashamed Wickham is asking for so little.
Despite lamenting Wickham's character, he affirms the marriage is unavoidable.
He reveals his primary concerns: firstly, how much money Mr. Gardiner contributed to make the marriage happen, and secondly, how he will ever manage to repay his brother-in-law.
Jane expresses surprise at the idea of their uncle providing money.
Mr. Bennet explains his reasoning: no rational man would marry Lydia for the small sums stipulated in the agreement (£100/year during his life, £50/year after).
Elizabeth concurs, realizing for the first time that Wickham's debts being paid and additional funds remaining must be due to their uncle's generosity, fearing he has financially strained himself.
Mr. Bennet wryly comments that Wickham would be a fool to accept Lydia for less than £10,000, expressing mock concern about thinking ill of his future son-in-law.
Elizabeth is appalled at the figure of £10,000 and the impossibility of repaying such a sum.
Lost in thought, Mr. Bennet and his daughters walk silently back to the house.
Upon arrival, Mr. Bennet retreats to the library to write his response, while Jane and Elizabeth enter the breakfast-room.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Is it possible?” cried Elizabeth, when she had finished.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Their father then went to the library to write, and the girls walked into the breakfast-room.

events.text_segment:
“Is it possible?” cried Elizabeth, when she had finished. “Can it be possible that he will marry her?”
“Wickham is not so undeserving, then, as we have thought him,” said her sister. “My dear father, I congratulate you.”
“And have you answered the letter?” said Elizabeth.
“No; but it must be done soon.”
Most earnestly did she then entreat him to lose no more time before he wrote.
“Oh! my dear father,” she cried, “come back and write immediately. Consider how important every moment is in such a case.”
“Let me write for you,” said Jane, “if you dislike the trouble yourself.”
“I dislike it very much,” he replied; “but it must be done.”
And so saying, he turned back with them, and walked towards the house.
“And—may I ask?” said Elizabeth; “but the terms, I suppose, must be complied with.”
“Complied with! I am only ashamed of his asking so little.”
“And they must marry! Yet he is such a man.”
“Yes, yes, they must marry. There is nothing else to be done. But there are two things that I want very much to know:—one is, how much money your uncle has laid down to bring it about; and the other, how I am ever to pay him.”
“Money! my uncle!” cried Jane, “what do you mean, sir?”
“I mean that no man in his proper senses would marry Lydia on so slight a temptation as one hundred a year during my life, and fifty after I am gone.”
“That is very true,” said Elizabeth; “though it had not occurred to me before. His debts to be discharged, and something still to remain! Oh, it must be my uncle’s doings! Generous, good man, I am afraid he has distressed himself. A small sum could not do all this.”
“No,” said her father. “Wickham’s a fool if he takes her with a farthing less than ten thousand pounds: I should be sorry to think so ill of him, in the very beginning of our relationship.”
“Ten thousand pounds! Heaven forbid! How is half such a sum to be repaid?”
Mr. Bennet made no answer; and each of them, deep in thought, continued silent till they reached the house. Their father then went to the library to write, and the girls walked into the breakfast-room.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
"Is it possible?" cried Elizabeth, when she had finished reading the letter from Mr. Darcy. Her hands trembled as she folded the pages, her mind reeling with the revelations contained within.

Could she have been so wrong about him? The man she had despised, whose character she had judged so harshly, now appeared in an entirely different light. His explanation regarding Wickham's true nature and the circumstances surrounding Jane and Bingley's separation forced her to question everything she had believed.

Elizabeth paced the garden path, the morning sun casting dappled shadows through the trees. How blind she had been, how prejudiced in her assessment! She had prided herself on her discernment, yet had been utterly deceived by Wickham's charming manners and ready smile.

"I have been so foolish," she whispered to herself. "So determined to think ill of him from the very beginning."

She recalled their first meeting at the Meryton assembly, how his pride had wounded her own, and how that initial impression had colored every subsequent interaction. Now she understood that what she had perceived as arrogance might have been reserve, what seemed like disdain perhaps only awkwardness.

The truth about Wickham particularly disturbed her. That gentleman's attempted elopement with Darcy's young sister, his squandering of opportunities and funds - all painted a picture vastly different from the one he had presented to her willing ears.

Elizabeth found a bench beneath an old oak and sat, rereading portions of the letter. Each word seemed to reveal more of her own folly. She had accused Darcy of pride, yet her own pride had blinded her to the truth.

"How despicably I have acted," she thought, pressing her hand to her forehead. "I, who have prided myself on my discernment! I, who have valued myself on my abilities!"

As birds sang overhead, seemingly oblivious to her distress, Elizabeth resolved to examine her own heart and behavior with the same critical eye she had so readily turned on others. Perhaps this painful lesson would lead to greater wisdom, to a character less hasty in judgment and more generous in understanding.

events.title: Sisters' Contrasting Reactions and Reflections
detailed_summary: Once alone, Elizabeth exclaims how strange the situation is, expressing mixed feelings about being forced to rejoice over Lydia's marriage given Wickham's character and their poor prospects for happiness.
Jane attempts to console herself and Elizabeth by suggesting Wickham must genuinely care for Lydia to agree to the marriage.
Jane expresses doubt that Mr. Gardiner could have afforded to provide a sum as large as £10,000, given his own family.
Elizabeth counters that since Wickham has no money himself, the amount Mr. Gardiner provided can eventually be deduced by learning the extent of Wickham's debts and the settlement made on Lydia.
Elizabeth emphasizes the immense, unrepayable debt of gratitude they owe their aunt and uncle for taking Lydia in and offering their protection.
She reflects on Lydia being with the Gardiners at that very moment, hoping the kindness shown might make Lydia reflect on her actions.

Jane advocates for trying to forget the past transgressions on both sides, expressing hope that Lydia and Wickham will find happiness and stability, interpreting Wickham's consent to marry as a sign of improvement.
Elizabeth firmly disagrees, stating that their scandalous behavior is unforgettable.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “And they are really to be married!” cried Elizabeth, as soon as they were by themselves.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It is useless to talk of it.”

events.text_segment:
“And they are really to be married!” cried Elizabeth, as soon as they were by themselves. “How strange this is! and for this we are to be thankful. That they should marry, small as is their chance of happiness, and wretched as is his character, we are forced to rejoice! Oh, Lydia!”
“I comfort myself with thinking,” replied Jane, “that he certainly would not marry Lydia, if he had not a real regard for her. Though our kind uncle has done something towards clearing him, I cannot believe that ten thousand pounds, or anything like it, has been advanced. He has children of his own, and may have more. How could he spare half ten thousand pounds?”
“If we are ever able to learn what Wickham’s debts have been,” said Elizabeth, “and how much is settled on his side on our sister, we shall exactly know what Mr. Gardiner has done for them, because Wickham has not sixpence of his own. The kindness of my uncle and aunt can never be requited. Their taking her home, and affording her their personal protection and countenance, is such a sacrifice to her advantage as years of gratitude cannot enough acknowledge. By this time she is actually with them! If such goodness does not make her miserable now, she will never deserve to be happy! What a meeting for her, when she first sees my aunt!”
“We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side,” said Jane: “I hope and trust they will yet be happy. His consenting to marry her is a proof, I will believe, that he is come to a right way of thinking. Their mutual affection will steady them; and I flatter myself they will settle so quietly, and live in so rational a manner, as may in time make their past imprudence forgotten.”
“Their conduct has been such,” replied Elizabeth, “as neither you, nor I, nor anybody, can ever forget. It is useless to talk of it.”

events.title: Informing Mrs. Bennet and Her Ecstatic Reaction
detailed_summary: Jane and Elizabeth realize their mother, Mrs. Bennet, is likely still unaware of the news.
They go to the library and ask their father, who is busy writing, if he wants them to inform her.
Mr. Bennet, without looking up, coolly tells them to do as they please.
He permits them to take Mr. Gardiner's letter to read to her, telling them to take what they need and leave.
Elizabeth takes the letter, and the sisters go upstairs.
They find Mrs. Bennet with Mary and Kitty, allowing them to share the news with everyone at once.
After preparing them for good news, Jane reads the letter aloud.
Mrs. Bennet becomes overwhelmed with joy upon hearing that Lydia will soon be married.
Each sentence confirming the arrangement increases her exuberant delight, replacing all previous anxiety.
She expresses no concern for Lydia's future happiness or shame over her past misconduct; the marriage itself is sufficient cause for celebration.
She cries out affectionately about her 'dear Lydia' being married at sixteen.
She profusely praises her 'good, kind brother' Mr. Gardiner, claiming she always knew he would resolve the situation.
Her thoughts immediately jump to practical matters, especially the wedding clothes, declaring her intention to write to Mrs. Gardiner instantly.
She initially asks Lizzy to get dowry details from Mr. Bennet, then decides impulsively to go herself and rings for the housekeeper, Mrs. Hill.
She anticipates future joyful gatherings with Lydia and Wickham.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It now occurred to the girls that their mother was in all likelihood perfectly ignorant of what had happened.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: How merry we shall be together when we meet!”

events.text_segment:
It now occurred to the girls that their mother was in all likelihood perfectly ignorant of what had happened. They went to the library, therefore, and asked their father whether he would not wish them to make it known to her. He was writing, and, without raising his head, coolly replied,—
“Just as you please.”
“May we take my uncle’s letter to read to her?”
“Take whatever you like, and get away.”
Elizabeth took the letter from his writing-table, and they went upstairs together. Mary and Kitty were both with Mrs. Bennet: one communication would, therefore, do for all. After a slight preparation for good news, the letter was read aloud. Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself. As soon as Jane had read Mr. Gardiner’s hope of Lydia’s being soon married, her joy burst forth, and every following sentence added to its exuberance. She was now in an irritation as violent from delight as she had ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation. To know that her daughter would be married was enough. She was disturbed by no fear for her felicity, nor humbled by any remembrance of her misconduct.
“My dear, dear Lydia!” she cried: “this is delightful indeed! She will be married! I shall see her again! She will be married at sixteen! My good, kind brother! I knew how it would be—I knew he would manage everything. How I long to see her! and to see dear Wickham too! But the clothes, the wedding clothes! I will write to my sister Gardiner about them directly. Lizzy, my dear, run down to your father, and ask him how much he will give her. Stay, stay, I will go myself. Ring the bell, Kitty, for Hill. I will put on my things in a moment. My dear, dear Lydia! How merry we shall be together when we meet!”

```
It now occurred to the girls that their mother was in all likelihood perfectly ignorant of what had happened. They went to the library, where they found their father still seated at his desk, engaged in writing.

"May we take your letter to read to mama?" said Elizabeth; "or would you prefer communicating the news yourself?"

"Take whatever you like," said he, without raising his eyes from his employment, "and do as you please. You may go and tell her, if you think it worth while."

Elizabeth took the letter from his hand, and they went upstairs together. Mary and Kitty were both with Mrs. Bennet: one communication would, therefore, do for all. After a slight preparation for good news, the letter was read aloud. Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself. As soon as Jane had read Mr. Gardiner's hope of Lydia's being soon married, her joy burst forth, and every following sentence added to its exuberance. She was now in an irritation as violent from delight, as she had ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation. To know that her daughter would be married was enough. She was disturbed by no fear for her felicity, nor humbled by any remembrance of her misconduct.

"My dear, dear Lydia!" she cried. "This is delightful indeed! She will be married! I shall see her again! She will be married at sixteen! My good, kind brother! I knew how it would be. I knew he would manage everything! How I long to see her! and to see dear Wickham too! But the clothes, the wedding clothes! I will write to my sister Gardiner about them directly. Lizzy, my dear, run down to your father, and ask him how much he will give her. Stay, stay, I will go myself. Ring the bell, Kitty, for Hill. I will put on my things in a moment. My dear, dear Lydia! How merry we shall be together when we meet!"
```

This passage closely follows the detailed summary while maintaining Jane Austen's distinctive style from "Pride and Prejudice." It captures Mrs. Bennet's excitable character, the family dynamics, and the precise sequence of events described in the summary. The dialogue and narrative voice match Austen's characteristic blend of wit, irony, and precise observation of social behavior.

Mrs. Bennet continued her usual chatter about lace and officers, completely unaware of the momentous conversation that had taken place in Mr. Bennet's library.

Mary adjusted her spectacles with an air of wisdom. "Perhaps it is not our place to interfere in matters between Mr. Darcy and our parents."

Elizabeth remained silent, her mind racing with possibilities. Could Mr. Darcy's unexpected visit relate to Jane and Mr. Bingley? Or was it something concerning herself? The memory of his intense gaze during their last meeting at Pemberley made her heart quicken.

Jane noticed her sister's distraction. "Lizzy, you seem troubled. Is something the matter?"

"Nothing of consequence," Elizabeth replied with a forced smile. "I merely wonder what business brought Mr. Darcy to Longbourn today."

Their father emerged from his sanctuary looking unusually thoughtful. He glanced at his daughters, his eyes lingering on Elizabeth before he announced he would take a walk in the garden.

"How strange Papa seems today," observed Lydia with uncharacteristic perception.

Mrs. Bennet, oblivious to the undercurrents of tension, continued planning what gowns would be suitable for Jane's next visit to Netherfield.

The sisters exchanged meaningful glances, each wondering what secrets their father now held and how long it would be before the household learned the true purpose of Mr. Darcy's visit.

events.title: Managing Mrs. Bennet's Plans and Elizabeth's Retreat
detailed_summary: Jane gently attempts to moderate Mrs. Bennet's transports of joy by highlighting their significant debt to Mr. Gardiner for his likely financial intervention.
Mrs. Bennet dismisses this concern entirely, arguing it was simply Mr. Gardiner's duty as Lydia's uncle and noting it was the first real financial help they had ever received from him.
She continues to express immense happiness, delighting in the idea of having a married daughter and the sound of 'Mrs. Wickham'.
Feeling too agitated and joyful to write herself, she declares she will dictate orders for wedding fabrics (calico, muslin, cambric) to Jane immediately.
Jane, with some effort, persuades her mother to postpone ordering the items for one day, until Mr. Bennet is available for consultation.
Mrs. Bennet, buoyed by happiness, readily agrees and quickly forms new plans.
She decides to go to Meryton at once to share the 'good news' with her sister, Mrs. Philips, and intends to call on Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long on her way back.
She instructs Kitty to order the carriage for an airing.
As Mrs. Hill enters, Mrs. Bennet excitedly tells her the news of Lydia's engagement and promises celebratory punch for the staff.
Mrs. Hill expresses her congratulations along with the others.
Elizabeth, finding the excessive and misplaced joy unbearable ('sick of this folly'), escapes to the solitude of her own room.

She reflects privately, acknowledging that while Lydia's situation is far from ideal, it is a significant relief compared to their fears just hours before, providing a sense of thankfulness despite the lack of prospects for Lydia's true happiness or prosperity.

events.text_segment:
Her eldest daughter endeavoured to give some relief to the violence of these transports, by leading her thoughts to the obligations which Mr. Gardiner’s behaviour laid them all under.
“For we must attribute this happy conclusion,” she added, “in a great measure to his kindness. We are persuaded that he has pledged himself to assist Mr. Wickham with money.”
“Well,” cried her mother, “it is all very right; who should do it but her own uncle? If he had not had a family of his own, I and my children must have had all his money, you know; and it is the first time we have ever had anything from him except a few presents. Well! I am so happy. In a short time, I shall have a daughter married. Mrs. Wickham! How well it sounds! And she was only sixteen last June. My dear Jane, I am in such a flutter, that I am sure I can’t write; so I will dictate, and you write for me. We will settle with your father about the money afterwards; but the things should be ordered immediately.”
She was then proceeding to all the particulars of calico, muslin, and cambric, and would shortly have dictated some very plentiful orders, had not Jane, though with some difficulty, persuaded her to wait till her father was at leisure to be consulted. One day’s delay, she observed, would be of small importance; and her mother was too happy to be quite so obstinate as usual. Other schemes, too, came into her head.
“I will go to Meryton,” said she, “as soon as I am dressed, and tell the good, good news to my sister Philips. And as I come back, I can call on Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long. Kitty, run down and order the carriage. An airing would do me a great deal of good, I am sure. Girls, can I do anything for you in Meryton? Oh! here comes Hill. My dear Hill, have you heard the good news? Miss Lydia is going to be married; and you shall all have a bowl of punch to make merry at her wedding.”
Mrs. Hill began instantly to express her joy. Elizabeth received her congratulations amongst the rest, and then, sick of this folly, took refuge in her own room, that she might think with freedom. Poor Lydia’s situation must, at best, be bad enough; but that it was no worse, she had need to be thankful. She felt it so; and though, in looking forward, neither rational happiness, nor worldly prosperity could be justly expected for her sister, in looking back to what they had feared, only two hours ago, she felt all the advantages of what they had gained.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: Her eldest daughter endeavoured to give some relief to the violence of these transports, by leading her thoughts to the obligations which Mr. Gardiner's behaviour laid them all under.

"I am sure," she added, "that my uncle has done something for them, because Wickham has not the smallest bit of money, or any friends who would help him. The kindness of my uncle and aunt can never be requited. Their taking her home, and affording her their personal protection and countenance, is such a sacrifice to her advantage as years of gratitude cannot enough acknowledge. By this time she is actually with them! If such goodness does not make her miserable now, she will never deserve to be happy! What a meeting for her, when she first sees my aunt!"

"We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side," said Jane: "I hope and trust they will yet be happy. His consenting to marry her is a proof, I will believe, that he is come to a right way of thinking. Their mutual affection will steady them; and I flatter myself they will settle so quietly, and live in so rational a manner, as may in time make their past imprudence forgotten."

"Their conduct has been such," replied Elizabeth, "as neither you, nor I, nor anybody can ever forget. It is useless to talk of it."

It now occurred to the girls that their mother was in all likelihood perfectly ignorant of what had happened. They went to the library, therefore, and asked their father whether he would not wish them to make it known to her. He was writing and, without raising his head, coolly replied:

"Just as you please."

"May we take my uncle's letter to read to her?"

"Take whatever you like, and get away."

Elizabeth took the letter from his writing-table, and they went up stairs together. Mary and Kitty were both with Mrs. Bennet: one communication would, therefore, do for all. After a slight preparation for good news, the letter was read aloud. Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself. As soon as Jane had read Mr. Gardiner's hope of Lydia's being soon married, her joy burst forth, and every following sentence added to its exuberance. She was now in an irritation as violent from delight, as she had ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation. To know that her daughter would be married was enough. She was disturbed by no fear for her felicity, nor humbled by any remembrance of her misconduct.

"My dear, dear Lydia!" she cried. "This is delightful indeed! She will be married! I shall see her again! She will be married at sixteen! My good, kind brother! I knew how it would be. I knew he would manage everything! How I long to see her! and to see dear Wickham too! But the clothes, the wedding clothes! I will write to my sister Gardiner about them directly. Lizzy, my dear, run down to your father, and ask him how much he will give her. Stay, stay, I will go myself. Ring the bell, Kitty, for Hill. I will put on my things in a moment. My dear, dear Lydia! How merry we shall be together when we meet!"

Her eldest daughter endeavoured to give some relief to the violence of these transports, by leading her thoughts to the obligations which Mr. Gardiner's behaviour laid them all under.

"For we must attribute this happy conclusion," she added, "in a great measure to his kindness. We are persuaded that he has pledged himself to assist Mr. Wickham with money."

"Well," cried her mother, "it is all very right; who should do it but her own uncle? If he had not had a family of his own, I and my children must have had all his money, you know; and it is the first time we have ever had anything from him, except a few presents. Well! I am so happy! In a short time I shall have a daughter married. Mrs. Wickham! How well it sounds! And she was only sixteen last June. My dear Jane, I am in such a flutter, that I am sure I can't write; so I will dictate, and you write for me. We will settle with your father about the money afterwards; but the things should be ordered immediately."

She was then proceeding to all the particulars of calico, muslin, and cambric, and would shortly have dictated some very plentiful orders, had not Jane, though with some difficulty, persuaded her to wait till her father was at leisure to be consulted. One day's delay, she observed, would be of small importance; and her mother was too happy to be quite so obstinate as usual. Other schemes, too, came into her head.

"I will go to Meryton," said she, "as soon as I am dressed, and tell the good, good news to my sister Philips. And as I come back, I can call on Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long. Kitty, run down and order the carriage. An airing would do me a great deal of good, I am sure. Girls, can I do anything for you in Meryton? Oh! Here comes Hill! My dear Hill, have you heard the good news? Miss Lydia is going to be married; and you shall all have a bowl of punch to make merry at her wedding."

Mrs. Hill began instantly to express her joy. Elizabeth received her congratulations amongst the rest, and then, sick of this folly, took refuge in her own room, that she might think with freedom.

Poor Lydia's situation must, at best, be bad enough; but that it was no worse, she had need to be thankful. She felt it so; and though, in looking forward, neither rational happiness nor worldly prosperity could be justly expected for her sister, in looking back to what they had feared, only two hours ago, she felt all the advantages of what they had gained.

events.title: Mr. Bennet's Financial Regrets and Resolve
detailed_summary: Mr. Bennet experienced profound regret for not having saved money consistently throughout his marriage to better provide for his wife and daughters.
This regret intensified with the current situation, as he realized prudent savings could have secured Lydia's future without relying on her uncle, Mr. Gardiner.
He felt it was improper that the resolution, marrying Lydia to Wickham, came entirely at his brother-in-law's expense.
He resolved to ascertain the full amount Mr. Gardiner had spent and to repay this debt promptly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Bennet had very often wished, before this period of his life, that, instead of spending his whole income, he had laid by an annual sum, for the better provision of his children, and of his wife, if she survived him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was seriously concerned that a cause of so little advantage to anyone should be forwarded at the sole expense of his brother-in-law; and he was determined, if possible, to find out the extent of his assistance, and to discharge the obligation as soon as he could.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Bennet had very often wished, before this period of his life, that, instead of spending his whole income, he had laid by an annual sum, for the better provision of his children, and of his wife, if she survived him. He now wished it more than ever. Had he done his duty in that respect, Lydia need not have been indebted to her uncle for whatever of honour or credit could now be purchased for her. The satisfaction of prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be her husband might then have rested in its proper place.
He was seriously concerned that a cause of so little advantage to anyone should be forwarded at the sole expense of his brother-in-law; and he was determined, if possible, to find out the extent of his assistance, and to discharge the obligation as soon as he could.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: Mr. Bennet had very often wished, before this period of his life, that, instead of spending his whole income, he had laid by an annual sum, for the better provision of his children, and of his wife, if she survived him. He now wished it more than ever. Had he done his duty in that respect, Lydia need not have been indebted to her uncle for whatever of honour or credit could now be purchased for her. The satisfaction of prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be her husband might then have rested in its proper place.

He was seriously concerned that a cause of so little advantage to anyone should be forwarded at the sole expense of his brother-in-law, and he was determined, if possible, to find out the extent of his assistance, and to discharge the obligation as soon as he could.

When first Mr. Bennet had married, economy was held to be perfectly useless, for, of course, they were to have a son. The son was to join in cutting off the entail, as soon as he should be of age, and the widow and younger children would by that means be provided for. Five daughters successively entered the world, but yet the son was to come; and Mrs. Bennet, for many years after Lydia's birth, had been certain that he would. This event had at last been despaired of, but it was then too late to be saving. Mrs. Bennet had no turn for economy, and her husband's love of independence had alone prevented their exceeding their income.

Mr. Bennet now regretted his financial imprudence. With five daughters to provide for, he realized too late the consequences of his failure to save. His estate was entailed to Mr. Collins, leaving his family vulnerable should he die. Mrs. Bennet, with her nervous disposition and obsession with marrying off their daughters, had never encouraged economy either.

Jane and Elizabeth, sensible and accomplished, might attract suitable matches, but his younger daughters lacked both fortune and proper guidance. Lydia's flirtatiousness particularly concerned him. events.title: Past Financial Decisions and Acceptance of Terms
detailed_summary: The narrative explains Mr. Bennet's past disregard for saving, stemming from the initial certainty that he and Mrs. Bennet would have a son to break the entail and provide for the family.
Despite the arrival of five daughters, Mrs. Bennet clung to the hope of a son for many years, delaying any attempt at economy until it was too late.
Mrs. Bennet's lack of financial sense meant that only Mr. Bennet's own desire for independence prevented them from living beyond their means.
The existing marriage settlement designated £5,000 for Mrs. Bennet and the children, with the division among the children left to parental discretion.
Mr. Bennet readily consented to the marriage settlement proposed for Lydia, formalizing his approval and gratitude to Mr. Gardiner in writing.

He was privately relieved that securing Wickham's marriage to Lydia involved minimal financial burden for him, calculating the net annual expense at less than ten pounds considering Lydia's previous allowances and gifts.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When first Mr. Bennet had married, economy was held to be perfectly useless; for, of course, they were to have a son.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He would scarcely be ten pounds a year the loser, by the hundred that was to be paid them; for, what with her board and pocket allowance, and the continual presents in money which passed to her through her mother’s hands, Lydia’s expenses had been very little within that sum.

events.text_segment:
When first Mr. Bennet had married, economy was held to be perfectly useless; for, of course, they were to have a son. This son was to join in cutting off the entail, as soon as he should be of age, and the widow and younger children would by that means be provided for. Five daughters successively entered the world, but yet the son was to come; and Mrs. Bennet, for many years after Lydia’s birth, had been certain that he would. This event had at last been despaired of, but it was then too late to be saving. Mrs. Bennet had no turn for economy; and her husband’s love of independence had alone prevented their exceeding their income.
Five thousand pounds was settled by marriage articles on Mrs. Bennet and the children. But in what proportions it should be divided amongst the latter depended on the will of the parents. This was one point, with regard to Lydia at least, which was now to be settled, and Mr. Bennet could have no hesitation in acceding to the proposal before him. In terms of grateful acknowledgment for the kindness of his brother, though expressed most concisely, he then delivered on paper his perfect approbation of all that was done, and his willingness to fulfil the engagements that had been made for him. He had never before supposed that, could Wickham be prevailed on to marry his daughter, it would be done with so little inconvenience to himself as by the present arrangement. He would scarcely be ten pounds a year the loser, by the hundred that was to be paid them; for, what with her board and pocket allowance, and the continual presents in money which passed to her through her mother’s hands, Lydia’s expenses had been very little within that sum.

events.title: Mr. Bennet's Relief, Return to Indolence, and Neighborhood Reaction
detailed_summary: Mr. Bennet found further relief in the fact that resolving the crisis required little personal effort, aligning with his inherent desire to avoid exertion.
His initial anger having subsided, his natural inclination towards inaction returned.
He quickly dispatched his letter of approval, inquiring about the debt to his brother-in-law but pointedly sending no message to Lydia, reflecting his lingering anger towards her.
News of the engagement spread rapidly through the Bennet household and the local Meryton community.
The neighborhood received the news with a pragmatic acceptance, acknowledging that while a more scandalous outcome might have provided better gossip, the marriage itself offered plenty to discuss.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That it would be done with such trifling exertion on his side, too, was another very welcome surprise; for his chief wish at present was to have as little trouble in the business as possible.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: To be sure, it would have been more for the advantage of conversation, had Miss Lydia Bennet come upon the town; or, as the happiest alternative, been secluded from the world in some distant farm-house.

events.text_segment:
That it would be done with such trifling exertion on his side, too, was another very welcome surprise; for his chief wish at present was to have as little trouble in the business as possible. When the first transports of rage which had produced his activity in seeking her were over, he naturally returned to all his former indolence. His letter was soon despatched; for though dilatory in undertaking business, he was quick in its execution. He begged to know further particulars of what he was indebted to his brother; but was too angry with Lydia to send any message to her.
The good news quickly spread through the house; and with proportionate speed through the neighbourhood. It was borne in the latter with decent philosophy. To be sure, it would have been more for the advantage of conversation, had Miss Lydia Bennet come upon the town; or, as the happiest alternative, been secluded from the world in some distant farm-house.

To be sure, it would have been more for the advantage of conversation had Miss Lydia Bennet come upon the town; or, as the happiest alternative, been secluded from the world, in some distant farmhouse. But there was much to be talked of in marrying her; and the good-natured wishes for her well-doing which had proceeded before, from all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton, lost but a little of their spirit in this change of circumstances, because with such an husband her misery was considered certain.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: When Elizabeth's refusal to dance had drawn on her the ill-will of Mr. Darcy, she had never imagined that he would later seek her hand in marriage. His proposal came unexpectedly, delivered with confidence that suggested he anticipated acceptance rather than rejection. The ease with which he approached this significant step surprised her greatly, as though he considered it merely a formality. His manner implied that he wished the matter settled quickly and with minimal inconvenience to himself. This attitude revealed much about his character - that even in pursuing what should be a matter of the heart, he sought efficiency and convenience above all. Elizabeth found this practical approach to matrimony distinctly at odds with her own romantic sensibilities, further confirming her impression of his pride.

events.title: Meryton Gossip and Mrs. Bennet's Unrestrained Joy
detailed_summary: Despite the veneer of well-wishing, the spiteful gossip in Meryton continued, with many predicting Lydia's future unhappiness with Wickham.
In stark contrast, Mrs. Bennet emerged from her two-week seclusion in a state of extreme elation and triumph.
She displayed no shame regarding the elopement, focusing entirely on the success of marrying off a daughter, an ambition she'd held since Jane was young.
Her conversation became solely fixated on the trappings of a wedding: clothes, carriages, servants, and securing a nearby residence for the newlyweds.
She began actively searching for houses, dismissing options based on perceived status or location without regard for Lydia and Wickham's financial reality.
She specifically mentioned and critiqued several local properties as potential homes for her daughter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But there was much to be talked of, in marrying her; and the good-natured wishes for her well-doing, which had proceeded before from all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton, lost but little of their spirit in this change of circumstances, because with such a husband her misery was considered certain.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Haye Park might do,” said she, “if the Gouldings would quit it, or the great house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Ashworth is too far off. I could not bear to have her ten miles from me; and as for Purvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.”

events.text_segment:
But there was much to be talked of, in marrying her; and the good-natured wishes for her well-doing, which had proceeded before from all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton, lost but little of their spirit in this change of circumstances, because with such a husband her misery was considered certain.
It was a fortnight since Mrs. Bennet had been down stairs, but on this happy day she again took her seat at the head of her table, and in spirits oppressively high. No sentiment of shame gave a damp to her triumph. The marriage of a daughter, which had been the first object of her wishes since Jane was sixteen, was now on the point of accomplishment, and her thoughts and her words ran wholly on those attendants of elegant nuptials, fine muslins, new carriages, and servants. She was busily searching through the neighbourhood for a proper situation for her daughter; and, without knowing or considering what their income might be, rejected many as deficient in size and importance.
“Haye Park might do,” said she, “if the Gouldings would quit it, or the great house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Ashworth is too far off. I could not bear to have her ten miles from me; and as for Purvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was generally agreed that Elizabeth had made a grave mistake in accepting Mr. Darcy. The neighborhood gossips predicted that her marriage would bring nothing but unhappiness, given what they perceived as his proud and disagreeable nature. Despite the congratulatory words offered to her face, behind closed doors these same well-wishers took a certain satisfaction in imagining the difficult life that surely awaited her.

Few could understand what had prompted Elizabeth to accept him, beyond the obvious attractions of his wealth and position. Those who had witnessed his cold demeanor at local gatherings felt certain that such a man could never make a suitable husband for the lively and spirited Elizabeth. They whispered that she would soon regret exchanging her beloved Hertfordshire for the grandeur of Pemberley, where she would undoubtedly be stifled by his arrogance and the rigid expectations of his social circle.

events.title: Confrontation Over Welcoming Lydia and Funding Wedding Clothes
detailed_summary: Mr. Bennet patiently listened to his wife's plans until the servants were absent.
He then firmly stated that Lydia and Wickham would not be permitted entry into Longbourn, as he refused to endorse their reckless behavior.
A heated argument ensued, during which Mr. Bennet remained unyielding.
The conflict escalated when Mrs. Bennet discovered, to her horror, that Mr. Bennet would not provide any money for Lydia's wedding attire.
He declared that Lydia would receive no token of paternal affection in connection with her marriage.

Mrs. Bennet found his stance incomprehensible, perceiving the lack of new clothes as a profound social embarrassment that overshadowed the actual scandal of Lydia's elopement and cohabitation with Wickham.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Her husband allowed her to talk on without interruption while the servants remained.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She was more alive to the disgrace, which her want of new clothes must reflect on her daughter’s nuptials, than to any sense of shame at her eloping and living with Wickham a fortnight before they took place.

events.text_segment:
Her husband allowed her to talk on without interruption while the servants remained. But when they had withdrawn, he said to her, “Mrs. Bennet, before you take any, or all of these houses, for your son and daughter, let us come to a right understanding. Into one house in this neighbourhood they shall never have admittance. I will not encourage the imprudence of either, by receiving them at Longbourn.”
A long dispute followed this declaration; but Mr. Bennet was firm: it soon led to another; and Mrs. Bennet found, with amazement and horror, that her husband would not advance a guinea to buy clothes for his daughter. He protested that she should receive from him no mark of affection whatever on the occasion. Mrs. Bennet could hardly comprehend it. That his anger could be carried to such a point of inconceivable resentment as to refuse his daughter a privilege, without which her marriage would scarcely seem valid, exceeded all that she could believe possible. She was more alive to the disgrace, which her want of new clothes must reflect on her daughter’s nuptials, than to any sense of shame at her eloping and living with Wickham a fortnight before they took place.

events.title: Elizabeth's Regret Over Confiding in Darcy and Its Implications
detailed_summary: Elizabeth felt intense regret for having revealed Lydia's elopement to Mr. Darcy, especially since the imminent marriage might otherwise have concealed the scandal from those unaware.
Although she trusted Darcy's discretion, the thought of him knowing about her sister's disgrace caused her deep mortification.
This feeling wasn't rooted in concern for her own prospects with Darcy, as she already considered the gap between them impassable.
She reasoned that Darcy would never wish to marry into her family, and this new, close connection to Wickham—a man Darcy rightly despised—made any alliance utterly unthinkable.
Elizabeth acknowledged that Darcy's aversion to such a family connection was completely understandable.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth was now most heartily sorry that she had, from the distress of the moment, been led to make Mr. Darcy acquainted with their fears for her sister; for since her marriage would so shortly give the proper termination to the elopement, they might hope to conceal its unfavourable beginning from all those who were not immediately on the spot.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: From such a connection she could not wonder that he should shrink.

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth was now most heartily sorry that she had, from the distress of the moment, been led to make Mr. Darcy acquainted with their fears for her sister; for since her marriage would so shortly give the proper termination to the elopement, they might hope to conceal its unfavourable beginning from all those who were not immediately on the spot.
She had no fear of its spreading farther, through his means. There were few people on whose secrecy she would have more confidently depended; but at the same time there was no one whose knowledge of a sister’s frailty would have mortified her so much. Not, however, from any fear of disadvantage from it individually to herself; for at any rate there seemed a gulf impassable between them. Had Lydia’s marriage been concluded on the most honourable terms, it was not to be supposed that Mr. Darcy would connect himself with a family, where to every other objection would now be added an alliance and relationship of the nearest kind with the man whom he so justly scorned.
From such a connection she could not wonder that he should shrink.

**text_segment**: Elizabeth was now most heartily sorry that she had, from the distress of the moment, been led to make Mr. Darcy acquainted with their fears for her sister; for since her marriage would so shortly give the proper termination to the elopement, they might hope to conceal its unfavourable beginning from all those who were not immediately on the spot.

Had Lydia's marriage been concluded on the most honourable terms, it was not to be supposed that Mr. Darcy would connect himself with a family where, to every other objection, would now be added an alliance and relationship of the nearest kind with a man whom he so justly scorned.

From such a connection she could not wonder that he would shrink. The wish of procuring her regard, which she had assured herself of his feeling in Derbyshire, could not in rational expectation survive such a blow as this. She was humbled, she was grieved; she repented, though she hardly knew of what. She became jealous of his esteem, when she could no longer hope to be benefited by it. She wanted to hear of him, when there seemed the least chance of gaining intelligence. She was convinced that she could have been happy with him, when it was no longer likely they should meet.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
She reflected that the knowledge of Lydia's situation would spread among their acquaintances despite their best efforts at discretion. Though Mr. Darcy was discreet by nature, Elizabeth worried about the impression this scandal would leave on him. Her family's reputation was already compromised, and she feared this would only confirm his worst opinions about their lack of propriety.

Elizabeth wondered if this revelation would destroy any remaining regard he might have had for her. After all, to be connected with a family whose youngest daughter had run away unmarried with a man of Wickham's character would surely be intolerable to someone of Mr. Darcy's standing. She could hardly blame him if he now wished to distance himself entirely from any association with the Bennets.

events.title: Elizabeth's Painful Recognition of Darcy's Suitability and Lost Possibility
detailed_summary: Elizabeth believed any affection Darcy may have developed for her could not possibly endure the impact of Lydia's scandalous marriage.
She felt humbled and sorrowful, experiencing a vague sense of repentance.
Paradoxically, she began to value Darcy's good opinion more deeply now that she could no longer realistically hope to gain from it.
She longed for news of him precisely when communication seemed impossible and became convinced of their potential happiness together only when reunion seemed out of reach.
She reflected on the irony that she would now welcome the proposal she had once rejected so forcefully, acknowledging Darcy's generosity but imagining his justifiable sense of triumph.
Elizabeth came to a profound realization: Darcy possessed the exact combination of character and intellect that would perfectly complement her own.
She envisioned their marriage as mutually enriching—her liveliness improving his reserve, his wisdom benefiting her.
She lamented that this potentially ideal union, capable of demonstrating true marital happiness, was now prevented by circumstance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The wish of procuring her regard, which she had assured herself of his feeling in Derbyshire, could not in rational expectation survive such a blow as this.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But no such happy marriage could now teach the admiring multitude what connubial felicity really was.

events.text_segment:
The wish of procuring her regard, which she had assured herself of his feeling in Derbyshire, could not in rational expectation survive such a blow as this. She was humbled, she was grieved; she repented, though she hardly knew of what. She became jealous of his esteem, when she could no longer hope to be benefited by it. She wanted to hear of him, when there seemed the least chance of gaining intelligence. She was convinced that she could have been happy with him, when it was no longer likely they should meet.
What a triumph for him, as she often thought, could he know that the proposals which she had proudly spurned only four months ago would now have been gladly and gratefully received! He was as generous, she doubted not, as the most generous of his sex. But while he was mortal, there must be a triumph.
She began now to comprehend that he was exactly the man who, in disposition and talents, would most suit her. His understanding and temper, though unlike her own, would have answered all her wishes. It was an union that must have been to the advantage of both: by her ease and liveliness, his mind might have been softened, his manners improved; and from his judgment, information, and knowledge of the world, she must have received benefit of greater importance.
But no such happy marriage could now teach the admiring multitude what connubial felicity really was.

events.title: Practical Arrangements for Wickham and Lydia, and the Decision for a Visit
detailed_summary: Elizabeth contemplated Lydia and Wickham's impending marriage, foreseeing little chance of financial security or true happiness for a couple united by passion rather than virtue.
A letter arrived from Mr. Gardiner, briefly acknowledging Mr. Bennet's gratitude while firmly requesting the financial assistance never be mentioned again.
Mr. Gardiner reported that Wickham had agreed to leave the militia for a position in the regular army, a move Gardiner strongly advocated for both their sakes.
Wickham was promised an ensigncy in a regiment stationed far away in the north.
Gardiner hoped the new environment would encourage more prudent behavior from the couple.
He confirmed he had contacted Colonel Forster regarding Wickham's Brighton debts, pledged himself for their payment, and asked Mr. Bennet to handle the Meryton creditors based on an enclosed list.
He relayed that Lydia was well and wished to visit Longbourn before departing for the north.
Mr. Bennet, Jane, and Elizabeth saw the wisdom in Wickham's distant posting, but Mrs. Bennet was displeased, mourning the loss of proximity to Lydia and her connections in the militia.
Mr. Bennet initially refused to allow Lydia and Wickham to visit Longbourn.
Jane and Elizabeth intervened, persuading their father with calm, rational arguments focused on Lydia's feelings and social standing, to permit the visit after the wedding.
Mrs. Bennet was gratified by the opportunity to display her married daughter locally.
Mr. Bennet communicated his permission to Mr. Gardiner.
Elizabeth, despite the arrangement, was personally displeased at the prospect of seeing Wickham again and puzzled that he would agree to visit Longbourn.

events.text_segment:
An union of a different tendency, and precluding the possibility of the other, was soon to be formed in their family.
How Wickham and Lydia were to be supported in tolerable independence she could not imagine. But how little of permanent happiness could belong to a couple who were only brought together because their passions were stronger than their virtue, she could easily conjecture.
Mr. Gardiner soon wrote again to his brother. To Mr. Bennet’s acknowledgments he briefly replied, with assurances of his eagerness to promote the welfare of any of his family; and concluded with entreaties that the subject might never be mentioned to him again. The principal purport of his letter was to inform them, that Mr. Wickham had resolved on quitting the militia.
“It was greatly my wish that he should do so,” he added, “as soon as his marriage was fixed on. And I think you will agree with me, in considering a removal from that corps as highly advisable, both on his account and my niece’s. It is Mr. Wickham’s intention to go into the Regulars; and, among his former friends, there are still some who are able and willing to assist him in the army. He has the promise of an ensigncy in General——’s regiment, now quartered in the north. It is an advantage to have it so far from this part of the kingdom. He promises fairly; and I hope among different people, where they may each have a character to preserve, they will both be more prudent. I have written to Colonel Forster, to inform him of our present arrangements, and to request that he will satisfy the various creditors of Mr. Wickham in and near Brighton with assurances of speedy payment, for which I have pledged myself. And will you give yourself the trouble of carrying similar assurances to his creditors in Meryton, of whom I shall subjoin a list, according to his information? He has given in all his debts; I hope at least he has not deceived us. Haggerston has our directions, and all will be completed in a week. They will then join his regiment, unless they are first invited to Longbourn; and I understand from Mrs. Gardiner that my niece is very desirous of seeing you all before she leaves the south. She is well, and begs to be dutifully remembered to you and her mother.—Yours, etc.
“E. Gardiner.”
Mr. Bennet and his daughters saw all the advantages of Wickham’s removal from the ——shire, as clearly as Mr. Gardiner could do. But Mrs. Bennet was not so well pleased with it. Lydia’s being settled in the north, just when she had expected most pleasure and pride in her company, for she had by no means given up her plan of their residing in Hertfordshire, was a severe disappointment; and, besides, it was such a pity that Lydia should be taken from a regiment where she was acquainted with everybody, and had so many favourites.
“She is so fond of Mrs. Forster,” said she, “it will be quite shocking to send her away! And there are several of the young men, too, that she likes very much. The officers may not be so pleasant in General——’s regiment.”
His daughter’s request, for such it might be considered, of being admitted into her family again, before she set off for the north, received at first an absolute negative. But Jane and Elizabeth, who agreed in wishing, for the sake of their sister’s feelings and consequence, that she should be noticed on her marriage by her parents, urged him so earnestly, yet so rationally and so mildly, to receive her and her husband at Longbourn, as soon as they were married, that he was prevailed on to think as they thought, and act as they wished. And their mother had the satisfaction of knowing, that she should be able to show her married daughter in the neighbourhood, before she was banished to the north. When Mr. Bennet wrote again to his brother, therefore, he sent his permission for them to come; and it was settled, that, as soon as the ceremony was over, they should proceed to Longbourn. Elizabeth was surprised, however, that Wickham should consent to such a scheme; and, had she consulted only her own inclination, any meeting with him would have been the last object of her wishes.

events.title: Arrival and Reception of Lydia and Wickham
detailed_summary: On Lydia's wedding day, Jane and Elizabeth feel more apprehension for her than she seems to feel for herself.
The elder Bennet sisters dread the couple's arrival, particularly Jane, who feels vicariously ashamed for Lydia.
The family gathers to receive them; Mrs. Bennet beams, Mr. Bennet appears severely grave, and the daughters are anxious.
Lydia enters boisterously, is embraced enthusiastically by her mother, who also warmly greets Wickham.
Mr. Bennet's reception is cold and silent, his austerity increasing in response to the couple's easy confidence.
Elizabeth is disgusted, and Jane is shocked by Lydia's unchanged behavior: wild, noisy, and completely unabashed.
Lydia demands congratulations from her sisters and casually remarks on changes in the room and the length of her absence.
Wickham appears equally untroubled, his pleasant manners striking Elizabeth as audacious given the circumstances.
Elizabeth resolves not to underestimate the impudence of such a man in the future.
While Elizabeth and Jane blush with embarrassment, Lydia and Wickham show no signs of shame or discomfort.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Their sister’s wedding-day arrived; and Jane and Elizabeth felt for her probably more than she felt for herself.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She blushed, and Jane blushed; but the cheeks of the two who caused their confusion suffered no variation of colour.

events.text_segment:
Their sister’s wedding-day arrived; and Jane and Elizabeth felt for her probably more than she felt for herself. The carriage was sent to meet them at——, and they were to return in it by dinnertime. Their arrival was dreaded by the elder Miss Bennets—and Jane more especially, who gave Lydia the feelings which would have attended herself, had she been the culprit, and was wretched in the thought of what her sister must endure.
They came. The family were assembled in the breakfast-room to receive them. Smiles decked the face of Mrs. Bennet, as the carriage drove up to the door; her husband looked impenetrably grave; her daughters, alarmed, anxious, uneasy.
Lydia’s voice was heard in the vestibule; the door was thrown open, and she ran into the room. Her mother stepped forwards, embraced her, and welcomed her with rapture; gave her hand with an affectionate smile to Wickham, who followed his lady; and wished them both joy, with an alacrity which showed no doubt of their happiness.
Their reception from Mr. Bennet, to whom they then turned, was not quite so cordial. His countenance rather gained in austerity; and he scarcely opened his lips. The easy assurance of the young couple, indeed, was enough to provoke him.
Elizabeth was disgusted, and even Miss Bennet was shocked. Lydia was Lydia still; untamed, unabashed, wild, noisy, and fearless. She turned from sister to sister, demanding their congratulations; and when at length they all sat down, looked eagerly round the room, took notice of some little alteration in it, and observed, with a laugh, that it was a great while since she had been there.
Wickham was not at all more distressed than herself; but his manners were always so pleasing, that, had his character and his marriage been exactly what they ought, his smiles and his easy address, while he claimed their relationship, would have delighted them all. Elizabeth had not before believed him quite equal to such assurance; but she sat down, resolving within herself to draw no limits in future to the impudence of an impudent man. She blushed, and Jane blushed; but the cheeks of the two who caused their confusion suffered no variation of colour.
