events.title: An Awkward Visit: Interactions and Embarrassments
detailed_summary: Elizabeth focused intently on her work, trying to appear composed, only glancing up as the gentlemen entered.
Jane appeared slightly pale but calmer than Elizabeth expected; her color rose as she greeted the visitors with polite composure.
Elizabeth kept her interaction with both men minimal and returned to her work.
She observed Darcy looked serious, resembling his former Hertfordshire demeanor more than his relaxed Pemberley manner, possibly due to Mrs. Bennet's presence.
She noticed Bingley seemed both pleased and embarrassed.
Mrs. Bennet received Bingley with excessive civility, which contrasted sharply with her cold politeness towards Darcy, embarrassing her daughters.
Elizabeth felt particularly pained by this distinction, knowing the family's debt to Darcy.
Darcy inquired politely after the Gardiners, causing Elizabeth confusion, but then fell silent.
He was not seated near Elizabeth, and she noticed him looking often at Jane or the floor, appearing thoughtful but less eager to please than during their last meeting.
Elizabeth felt disappointed by his reserve and angry at herself for feeling that way.
She felt unwilling to converse with anyone but Darcy, yet lacked the courage to address him directly, managing only to inquire about his sister.
Mrs. Bennet engaged Bingley in conversation, remarking on his long absence and mentioning local news, including Lydia's marriage to Wickham.
She complained about the newspaper announcement's brevity and subtly praised Wickham while hinting at his lack of deserving friends, a comment aimed at Darcy.
Elizabeth squirmed with shame and misery at her mother's pointed remarks and lack of tact.
Driven by embarrassment, Elizabeth interrupted to ask Bingley about the intended length of his stay.
Mrs. Bennet effusively invited Bingley to shoot on Mr. Bennet's property.
Elizabeth's distress intensified at her mother's overly eager attentions, fearing a repeat of the previous year's disappointments and feeling overwhelmed by the painful confusion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: She sat intently at work, striving to be composed, and without daring to lift up her eyes, till anxious curiosity carried them to the face of her sister as the servant was approaching the door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The first wish of my heart,” said she to herself, “is never more to be in company with either of them.

events.text_segment:
She sat intently at work, striving to be composed, and without daring to lift up her eyes, till anxious curiosity carried them to the face of her sister as the servant was approaching the door. Jane looked a little paler than usual, but more sedate than Elizabeth had expected. On the gentlemen’s appearing, her colour increased; yet she received them with tolerable ease, and with a propriety of behaviour equally free from any symptom of resentment, or any unnecessary complaisance.
Elizabeth said as little to either as civility would allow, and sat down again to her work, with an eagerness which it did not often command. She had ventured only one glance at Darcy. He looked serious as usual; and, she thought, more as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, than as she had seen him at Pemberley. But, perhaps, he could not in her mother’s presence be what he was before her uncle and aunt. It was a painful, but not an improbable, conjecture.
Bingley she had likewise seen for an instant, and in that short period saw him looking both pleased and embarrassed. He was received by Mrs. Bennet with a degree of civility which made her two daughters ashamed, especially when contrasted with the cold and ceremonious politeness of her courtesy and address of his friend.
Elizabeth particularly, who knew that her mother owed to the latter the preservation of her favourite daughter from irremediable infamy, was hurt and distressed to a most painful degree by a distinction so ill applied.
Darcy, after inquiring of her how Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner did—a question which she could not answer without confusion—said scarcely anything. He was not seated by her: perhaps that was the reason of his silence; but it had not been so in Derbyshire. There he had talked to her friends when he could not to herself. But now several minutes elapsed, without bringing the sound of his voice; and when occasionally, unable to resist the impulse of curiosity, she raised her eyes to his face, she as often found him looking at Jane as at herself, and frequently on no object but the ground. More thoughtfulness and less anxiety to please, than when they last met, were plainly expressed. She was disappointed, and angry with herself for being so.
“Could I expect it to be otherwise?” said she. “Yet why did he come?”
She was in no humour for conversation with anyone but himself; and to him she had hardly courage to speak.
She inquired after his sister, but could do no more.
“It is a long time, Mr. Bingley, since you went away,” said Mrs. Bennet.
He readily agreed to it.
“I began to be afraid you would never come back again. People did say, you meant to quit the place entirely at Michaelmas; but, however, I hope it is not true. A great many changes have happened in the neighbourhood since you went away. Miss Lucas is married and settled: and one of my own daughters. I suppose you have heard of it; indeed, you must have seen it in the papers. It was in the ‘Times’ and the ‘Courier,’ I know; though it was not put in as it ought to be. It was only said, ‘Lately, George Wickham, Esq., to Miss Lydia Bennet,’ without there being a syllable said of her father, or the place where she lived, or anything. It was my brother Gardiner’s drawing up, too, and I wonder how he came to make such an awkward business of it. Did you see it?”
Bingley replied that he did, and made his congratulations. Elizabeth dared not lift up her eyes. How Mr. Darcy looked, therefore, she could not tell.
“It is a delightful thing, to be sure, to have a daughter well married,” continued her mother; “but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very hard to have her taken away from me. They are gone down to Newcastle, a place quite northward it seems, and there they are to stay, I do not know how long. His regiment is there; for I suppose you have heard of his leaving the ——shire, and of his being gone into the Regulars. Thank heaven! he has some friends, though, perhaps, not so many as he deserves.”
Elizabeth, who knew this to be levelled at Mr. Darcy, was in such misery of shame that she could hardly keep her seat. It drew from her, however, the exertion of speaking, which nothing else had so effectually done before; and she asked Bingley whether he meant to make any stay in the country at present. A few weeks, he believed.
“When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley,” said her mother, “I beg you will come here and shoot as many as you please on Mr. Bennet’s manor. I am sure he will be vastly happy to oblige you, and will save all the best of the coveys for you.”
Elizabeth’s misery increased at such unnecessary, such officious attention! Were the same fair prospect to arise at present, as had flattered them a year ago, everything, she was persuaded, would be hastening to the same vexatious conclusion. At that instant she felt, that years of happiness could not make Jane or herself amends for moments of such painful confusion.
“The first wish of my heart,” said she to herself, “is never more to be in company with either of them.

She was in no humour for conversation with anyone but himself; and to him she had hardly courage to speak.

"It is a long time, Mr. Bingley, since you went away," said Mrs. Bennet.

He readily agreed to it.

Bingley replied that he did, and made his congratulations. Elizabeth dared not lift up her eyes. How Mr. Darcy looked, therefore, she could not tell.

"It is a delightful thing, to be sure, to have a daughter well married," continued her mother, "but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very hard to have her taken such a way from me. His regiment is there; for I suppose you have heard of his leaving the ——shire, and of his being gone into the regulars. Elizabeth, who knew this to be levelled at Mr. Darcy, was in such misery of shame, that she could hardly keep her seat. "When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley," said her mother, "I beg you will come here, and shoot as many as you please on Mr. Bennet's manor. I am sure he will be vastly happy to oblige you, and will save all the best of the covies for you."

Elizabeth's misery increased, at such unnecessary, such officious attention! Were the same fair prospect to arise at present as had flattered them a year ago, every thing, she was persuaded, would be hastening to the same vexatious conclusion. At that instant, she felt that years of happiness could not make Jane or herself amends for moments of such painful confusion.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Jane's countenance was as serene as ever, though Elizabeth could detect a slight tremor in her hands as she continued her needlework. The door opened, and Mr. Bingley was announced.

Elizabeth observed with keen interest the immediate flush that spread across Jane's cheeks, though her sister maintained her composure admirably. Mr. Bingley himself appeared somewhat nervous, his usual easy manner slightly strained as he made his bows and inquired after the health of the family.

"I hope Mrs. Bennet has been quite well since I had the pleasure of seeing her last," said he, his eyes darting frequently toward Jane, who kept her gaze steadfastly on her work.

"She is, I thank you, sir," Elizabeth replied, noting how her mother had suddenly become uncommonly silent upon his entrance, a circumstance as rare as it was welcome.

The conversation proceeded with painful formality, nothing like the easy intercourse that had characterized their acquaintance at Netherfield. Elizabeth found herself bearing the burden of maintaining the discourse, as Jane seemed incapable of more than monosyllabic responses, and Mr. Bingley, though clearly wishing to speak, appeared uncertain how to proceed.

After several minutes of this awkward exchange, Mrs. Bennet, with a significant glance at Elizabeth, suddenly remembered an errand that required her immediate attention in another part of the house. Elizabeth, understanding her mother's intention perfectly, found herself torn between amusement at such transparent maneuvering and genuine concern for her sister's feelings.

"Lizzy, my dear," said Mrs. Bennet, rising, "I believe I left my—my handkerchief in the morning room. Would you be so kind as to help me find it?"

Before Elizabeth could respond, Mr. Bingley intervened with unexpected decisiveness. "Actually, Miss Elizabeth, if you would be so kind, I should like a few moments of private conversation with Miss Bennet."

The directness of his request brought color to Jane's cheeks, and she finally raised her eyes from her work. Elizabeth, seeing the mixture of hope and apprehension in her sister's expression, nodded slightly.

"Of course," she replied, rising to follow her mother from the room.

As the door closed behind them, Elizabeth found herself stationed in the hallway beside her mother, who made no pretense of moving toward any morning room.

"Well, Lizzy," whispered Mrs. Bennet excitedly, "what do you make of that? He has come to propose, I am certain of it!"

"Mama, please," Elizabeth cautioned, though she herself harbored similar hopes. "We cannot know his intentions, and we must not listen at doors."

Mrs. Bennet looked affronted at the very suggestion, though she did take a small step away from the parlor door. "I would never! But oh, to think of Jane at Netherfield at last!"

Elizabeth smiled despite herself. For all her mother's impropriety, her joy in her daughters' happiness was genuine, if somewhat mercenary in its considerations.

They waited what seemed an interminable time, though in reality it could not have been above fifteen minutes, before the parlor door opened. Mr. Bingley emerged, his countenance transformed by such evident happiness that Elizabeth felt her own spirits rise in response.

"Mrs. Bennet," he said, bowing, "might I have the honor of speaking with Mr. Bennet?"

Mrs. Bennet's delight was almost painful to witness. "Of course, of course! He is in his library, as always. Lizzy will show you the way."

As Elizabeth led Mr. Bingley toward her father's sanctuary, he turned to her with a smile of such genuine warmth that she could not help but return it.

"Miss Elizabeth," he said quietly, "I believe I am about to make your sister very happy."

"I believe, sir," she replied with equal sincerity, "that the happiness will be mutual."

She left him at the library door and hurried back to the parlor, where she found Jane standing by the window, her work forgotten in her lap. As Elizabeth entered, Jane turned, and the sisters needed no words. The joy illuminating Jane's features told Elizabeth everything she needed to know.

"Oh, Lizzy," Jane whispered as Elizabeth embraced her, "can it be real? After all this time, all this uncertainty?"

"It is real," Elizabeth assured her, feeling her own eyes grow moist with sympathetic happiness. "And no one deserves such happiness more than you, dearest Jane."

They remained thus, sharing this moment of perfect understanding and joy, until the sound of approaching footsteps announced the return of Mr. Bingley, now accompanied by their father. Mr. Bennet's expression was one of quiet satisfaction as he regarded his eldest daughter.

"Well, Jane," he said with gentle humor, "it seems I am to lose you. Though I cannot think of a man more worthy of you than Mr. Bingley."

The remainder of the day passed in a blur of congratulations and planning, with Mrs. Bennet in particular exhibiting such effusions of joy that Mr. Bennet was driven to his library more than once. But through it all, Elizabeth observed the quiet happiness that surrounded Jane and Mr. Bingley like a protective sphere, rendering them almost oblivious to the commotion around them.

events.title: Bingley's Rekindled Interest and Dinner Invitation
detailed_summary: Elizabeth's distress was somewhat alleviated when she observed Bingley's renewed admiration for Jane's beauty.
Although initially reserved towards Jane, Bingley seemed to pay her increasing attention throughout the visit.
He perceived Jane as still beautiful, good-natured, and unaffected, though perhaps less talkative than before.
Jane, trying hard to appear unchanged, was often lost in thought and unaware of her own silences.
When Bingley and Darcy prepared to leave, Mrs. Bennet formally invited them to dine at Longbourn soon.
She pointedly reminded Bingley of his previous promise to dine with them, which he had broken.
Bingley appeared slightly foolish at the reminder and mumbled an excuse about business preventing his return.
The gentlemen then departed.

Mrs. Bennet confessed she had considered asking them to stay for dinner that day but decided against it, wanting a more elaborate meal (two courses) for Bingley, given her ambitions for him and his wealth.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Their society can afford no pleasure that will atone for such wretchedness as this!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mrs. Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine there that day; but, though she always kept a very good table, she did not think anything less than two courses could be good enough for a man on whom she had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride of one who had ten thousand a year.

events.text_segment:
Their society can afford no pleasure that will atone for such wretchedness as this! Let me never see either one or the other again!”
Yet the misery, for which years of happiness were to offer no compensation, received soon afterwards material relief, from observing how much the beauty of her sister rekindled the admiration of her former lover. When first he came in, he had spoken to her but little, but every five minutes seemed to be giving her more of his attention. He found her as handsome as she had been last year; as good-natured, and as unaffected, though not quite so chatty. Jane was anxious that no difference should be perceived in her at all, and was really persuaded that she talked as much as ever; but her mind was so busily engaged, that she did not always know when she was silent.
When the gentlemen rose to go away, Mrs. Bennet was mindful of her intended civility, and they were invited and engaged to dine at Longbourn in a few days’ time.
“You are quite a visit in my debt, Mr. Bingley,” she added; “for when you went to town last winter, you promised to take a family dinner with us as soon as you returned. I have not forgot, you see; and I assure you I was very much disappointed that you did not come back and keep your engagement.”
Bingley looked a little silly at this reflection, and said something of his concern at having been prevented by business. They then went away.
Mrs. Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine there that day; but, though she always kept a very good table, she did not think anything less than two courses could be good enough for a man on whom she had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride of one who had ten thousand a year.

events.title: Elizabeth's Vexation and Jane's Professed Indifference
detailed_summary: Following the departure of Bingley and Darcy, Elizabeth seeks solitude outdoors to process her feelings.
She is deeply perplexed and irritated by Mr. Darcy's reserved and seemingly indifferent demeanor during the visit.
Elizabeth questions his motives for visiting if he only intended to be silent and serious.
She contrasts his current behavior with his previous amiability towards her aunt and uncle in London.
She internally debates whether his silence stems from fear or lack of interest, finding his behavior utterly perplexing.
Elizabeth resolves to stop thinking about him, but her sister Jane interrupts this resolution.
Jane appears cheerful, expressing satisfaction with how the visit went and feeling confident she can maintain composure around Bingley.
Jane states her relief that the initial encounter is complete and anticipates the upcoming dinner on Tuesday as a public display of their mutual indifference.
Elizabeth responds with playful skepticism, warning Jane to be cautious.
Jane asserts her emotional strength, believing she is no longer vulnerable to Bingley.
Elizabeth counters, suggesting Jane is actually close to making Bingley fall deeply in love with her again.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As soon as they were gone, Elizabeth walked out to recover her spirits; or, in other words, to dwell without interruption on those subjects which must deaden them more.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I think you are in very great danger of making him as much in love with you as ever.”

events.text_segment:
As soon as they were gone, Elizabeth walked out to recover her spirits; or, in other words, to dwell without interruption on those subjects which must deaden them more. Mr. Darcy’s behaviour astonished and vexed her.
“Why, if he came only to be silent, grave, and indifferent,” said she, “did he come at all?”
She could settle it in no way that gave her pleasure.
“He could be still amiable, still pleasing to my uncle and aunt, when he was in town; and why not to me? If he fears me, why come hither? If he no longer cares for me, why silent? Teasing, teasing man! I will think no more about him.”
Her resolution was for a short time involuntarily kept by the approach of her sister, who joined her with a cheerful look which showed her better satisfied with their visitors than Elizabeth.
“Now,” said she, “that this first meeting is over, I feel perfectly easy. I know my own strength, and I shall never be embarrassed again by his coming. I am glad he dines here on Tuesday. It will then be publicly seen, that on both sides we meet only as common and indifferent acquaintance.”
“Yes, very indifferent, indeed,” said Elizabeth, laughingly. “Oh, Jane! take care.”
“My dear Lizzy, you cannot think me so weak as to be in danger now.”
“I think you are in very great danger of making him as much in love with you as ever.”

events.title: Dinner Observations: Bingley's Attention and Darcy's Distance
detailed_summary: Leading up to the Tuesday dinner, Mrs. Bennet indulges in optimistic plans based on Bingley's pleasant behavior during his short visit.
A large group gathers at Longbourn on Tuesday, with Bingley and Darcy arriving punctually.
As they enter the dining room, Elizabeth keenly observes Bingley to see if he will sit beside Jane as he used to.
Mrs. Bennet deliberately refrains from inviting Bingley to sit near her, sharing Elizabeth's focus.
Bingley hesitates upon entering, but Jane's glance and smile prompt him to take the seat next to her.
Elizabeth feels a sense of triumph and glances at Darcy, who maintains a stoic expression.
However, she notices Bingley looking towards Darcy with a mix of amusement and apprehension, suggesting Darcy's awareness or approval.

Throughout dinner, Bingley's conduct towards Jane reveals his admiration, albeit more restrained than before, convincing Elizabeth that their happiness could be secured if external factors didn't interfere.
Observing Bingley's behavior provides Elizabeth some pleasure, though her overall mood is low.
Mr. Darcy is seated far from Elizabeth, next to her mother.
Elizabeth recognizes this seating arrangement is unlikely to please either Darcy or Mrs. Bennet or allow them to show themselves well.
Though unable to hear their conversation, Elizabeth notes their infrequent interaction and the stiff, reserved manner between them.
She feels distressed by her mother's lack of graciousness towards Darcy, heightening her awareness of the family's debt to him, and wishes she could express their gratitude.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday; and Mrs. Bennet, in the meanwhile, was giving way to all the happy schemes which the good-humour and common politeness of Bingley, in half an hour’s visit, had revived.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her mother’s ungraciousness made the sense of what they owed him more painful to Elizabeth’s mind; and she would, at times, have given anything to be privileged to tell him, that his kindness was neither unknown nor unfelt by the whole of the family.

events.text_segment:
They did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday; and Mrs. Bennet, in the meanwhile, was giving way to all the happy schemes which the good-humour and common politeness of Bingley, in half an hour’s visit, had revived.
On Tuesday there was a large party assembled at Longbourn; and the two who were most anxiously expected, to the credit of their punctuality as sportsmen, were in very good time. When they repaired to the dining-room, Elizabeth eagerly watched to see whether Bingley would take the place which, in all their former parties, had belonged to him, by her sister. Her prudent mother, occupied by the same ideas, forbore to invite him to sit by herself. On entering the room, he seemed to hesitate; but Jane happened to look round, and happened to smile: it was decided. He placed himself by her.
Elizabeth, with a triumphant sensation, looked towards his friend. He bore it with noble indifference; and she would have imagined that Bingley had received his sanction to be happy, had she not seen his eyes likewise turned towards Mr. Darcy, with an expression of half-laughing alarm.
His behaviour to her sister was such during dinnertime as showed an admiration of her, which, though more guarded than formerly, persuaded Elizabeth, that, if left wholly to himself, Jane’s happiness, and his own, would be speedily secured. Though she dared not depend upon the consequence, she yet received pleasure from observing his behaviour. It gave her all the animation that her spirits could boast; for she was in no cheerful humour. Mr. Darcy was almost as far from her as the table could divide them. He was on one side of her mother. She knew how little such a situation would give pleasure to either, or make either appear to advantage. She was not near enough to hear any of their discourse; but she could see how seldom they spoke to each other, and how formal and cold was their manner whenever they did. Her mother’s ungraciousness made the sense of what they owed him more painful to Elizabeth’s mind; and she would, at times, have given anything to be privileged to tell him, that his kindness was neither unknown nor unfelt by the whole of the family.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
On Tuesday, when the gentlemen returned, Mrs. Bennet had spent the intervening time indulging in hopeful fantasies sparked by Bingley's brief but cordial visit. His pleasant demeanor and polite manners had rekindled her matrimonial ambitions for her daughters.

When Tuesday arrived, she was eager to see if her optimistic predictions might come to fruition. The gentlemen's appearance at Longbourn brought fresh excitement to the household. Mrs. Bennet observed with keen interest how Bingley's attention seemed particularly drawn to Jane, whose quiet beauty and gentle temperament had always made her a favorite among visitors.

Elizabeth watched the interactions with her characteristic discernment, noting both her mother's transparent schemes and the genuine warmth between Jane and Mr. Bingley. Mr. Darcy, meanwhile, maintained his reserved demeanor, though Elizabeth occasionally caught his gaze directed her way.

The conversation flowed more easily than at their previous meeting. Mr. Bingley spoke enthusiastically about the countryside and inquired after the family's health and activities since their last encounter. His sincere interest contrasted with Darcy's more measured contributions to the discussion.

As the visit progressed, Mrs. Bennet made several thinly veiled attempts to highlight Jane's accomplishments and virtues, causing Elizabeth to feel both amusement and embarrassment. Mr. Bennet, when present, offered dry observations that seemed to entertain Mr. Darcy more than the latter would admit.

By the time the gentlemen took their leave, Mrs. Bennet was more convinced than ever that Mr. Bingley's interest in Jane was significant. She immediately began planning for future encounters, speculating about invitations to dinners and balls where the attachment might grow.

Elizabeth, though pleased for her sister, maintained her skepticism about hasty conclusions, particularly regarding matters of the heart. She understood that in their society, many factors beyond mutual affection would influence any potential match.

events.title: Drawing Room Frustration: Hopes Dashed by Circumstance
detailed_summary: Elizabeth anticipates the post-dinner period, hoping for a chance to converse properly with Darcy.
The time spent waiting for the gentlemen in the drawing room feels tedious and vexing to her.
She views the gentlemen's arrival as her only prospect for enjoyment that evening.
Elizabeth resolves internally that if Darcy does not approach her, she will abandon any hope regarding him.
When the men enter, she initially perceives a sign that he might fulfill her hopes.
However, the women gather densely around the tea and coffee station where Jane and Elizabeth are occupied.
This arrangement leaves no space near Elizabeth for anyone to sit.
As the gentlemen draw near, one young woman moves even closer to Elizabeth, whispering her determination to prevent the men from joining them.
Observing this, Darcy retreats to another area of the room.
Elizabeth watches him, feeling envious of those he interacts with and impatient with her duties.
She then feels angry at herself for her own foolish expectations.
She reflects bitterly on the improbability of a man renewing affections after being refused once, considering it a weakness no man would exhibit and an affront to male pride.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: She was in hopes that the evening would afford some opportunity of bringing them together; that the whole of the visit would not pass away without enabling them to enter into something more of conversation, than the mere ceremonious salutation attending his entrance.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings.”

events.text_segment:
She was in hopes that the evening would afford some opportunity of bringing them together; that the whole of the visit would not pass away without enabling them to enter into something more of conversation, than the mere ceremonious salutation attending his entrance. Anxious and uneasy, the period which passed in the drawing-room before the gentlemen came, was wearisome and dull to a degree that almost made her uncivil. She looked forward to their entrance as the point on which all her chance of pleasure for the evening must depend.
“If he does not come to me, then,” said she, “I shall give him up for ever.”
The gentlemen came; and she thought he looked as if he would have answered her hopes; but, alas! the ladies had crowded round the table, where Miss Bennet was making tea, and Elizabeth pouring out the coffee, in so close a confederacy, that there was not a single vacancy near her which would admit of a chair. And on the gentlemen’s approaching, one of the girls moved closer to her than ever, and said, in a whisper,—
“The men shan’t come and part us, I am determined. We want none of them; do we?”
Darcy had walked away to another part of the room. She followed him with her eyes, envied everyone to whom he spoke, had scarcely patience enough to help anybody to coffee, and then was enraged against herself for being so silly!
“A man who has once been refused! How could I ever be foolish enough to expect a renewal of his love? Is there one among the sex who would not protest against such a weakness as a second proposal to the same woman? There is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings.”

And on the gentlemen's approaching, one of the girls moved closer to her than ever, and said, in a whisper, "The men shan't come and part us, I am determined. We want none of them; do we?"

Darcy had walked away to another part of the room. She followed him with her eyes, envied everyone to whom he spoke, had scarcely patience enough to help anybody to coffee; and then was enraged against herself for being so silly!

"A man who has once been refused! How could I ever be foolish enough to expect a renewal of his love? Is there one among the sex, who would not protest against such a weakness as a second proposal to the same woman? There is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings!"

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Anxious for an opportunity to better acquaint herself with Mr. Darcy, Elizabeth found herself watching the movements of the party with careful attention. The evening progressed with its usual diversions—card games occupied some guests while others engaged in lively conversation. Yet the gentleman in question remained somewhat removed from the general merriment, speaking primarily with Mr. Bingley or responding with brief civility when directly addressed.

When music was suggested, Elizabeth noticed Mr. Darcy's attention seemed to sharpen. As she took her place at the instrument upon request, she felt his eyes upon her, though when she glanced in his direction, he quickly averted his gaze. Her performance, though not technically perfect, was rendered with such spirit that several guests offered warm compliments.

Later, as the party dispersed into smaller groups, Elizabeth found herself momentarily alone near the window. Footsteps approached, and turning, she discovered Mr. Darcy standing nearby, apparently examining a book from the shelf.

"Do you find the selection to your liking, sir?" she ventured, determined to break through his reserve.

He looked up, seeming almost startled at being addressed. "It is... adequate," he replied, before adding with slightly more animation, "Though I confess a well-stocked library is something I consider essential."

Elizabeth smiled, sensing perhaps the first crack in his formidable composure. The conversation had begun at last.

events.title: A Fleeting Conversation Over Coffee
detailed_summary: Elizabeth's spirits lift slightly when Darcy personally returns his coffee cup.
She uses this moment to initiate conversation, inquiring if his sister is still at Pemberley.
Darcy confirms Georgiana will remain there until Christmas.
Elizabeth asks if Georgiana is alone, learning that Mrs. Annesley is with her while other friends left for Scarborough weeks ago.
Elizabeth struggles to find further topics for conversation.
She feels that if Darcy desired interaction, he could have guided the conversation more effectively.
He remains standing near her silently for several minutes.
The brief encounter ends when the same young lady whispers something to Elizabeth again, prompting Darcy to move away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: She was a little revived, however, by his bringing back his coffee-cup himself; and she seized the opportunity of saying,—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He stood by her, however, for some minutes, in silence; and, at last, on the young lady’s whispering to Elizabeth again, he walked away.

events.text_segment:
She was a little revived, however, by his bringing back his coffee-cup himself; and she seized the opportunity of saying,—
“Is your sister at Pemberley still?”
“Yes; she will remain there till Christmas.”
“And quite alone? Have all her friends left her?”
“Mrs. Annesley is with her. The others have been gone on to Scarborough these three weeks.”
She could think of nothing more to say; but if he wished to converse with her, he might have better success. He stood by her, however, for some minutes, in silence; and, at last, on the young lady’s whispering to Elizabeth again, he walked away.

events.title: Thwarted by Whist and an Early Departure
detailed_summary: After the tea service concludes and card tables are set up, Elizabeth briefly renews her hope of interacting with Darcy.
Her hopes are immediately dashed as she observes her mother eagerly recruit Darcy for a game of whist.
Shortly after, Darcy is seated at a card table with other guests.
Elizabeth abandons all expectation of pleasure for the remainder of the evening.
She and Darcy are confined to separate tables for the night.
Her only remaining, slightly malicious, hope is that Darcy might be distracted enough by looking her way to play poorly, mirroring her own likely performance.
Mrs. Bennet had intended to persuade Bingley and Darcy to stay for supper.
However, their carriage arrived earlier than anticipated, preventing Mrs. Bennet from extending the invitation or delaying their departure.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mrs. Bennet had designed to keep the two Netherfield gentlemen to supper; but their carriage was, unluckily, ordered before any of the others, and she had no opportunity of detaining them.

events.text_segment:
When the tea things were removed, and the card tables placed, the ladies all rose; and Elizabeth was then hoping to be soon joined by him, when all her views were overthrown, by seeing him fall a victim to her mother’s rapacity for whist players, and in a few moments after seated with the rest of the party. She now lost every expectation of pleasure. They were confined for the evening at different tables; and she had nothing to hope, but that his eyes were so often turned towards her side of the room, as to make him play as unsuccessfully as herself.
Mrs. Bennet had designed to keep the two Netherfield gentlemen to supper; but their carriage was, unluckily, ordered before any of the others, and she had no opportunity of detaining them.

events.title: Post-Party Reactions: Maternal Delight and Sisterly Disagreement
detailed_summary: Once the guests have departed, Mrs. Bennet eagerly asks her daughters for their assessment of the evening.
She declares the event a great success, praising the dinner lavishly.

She specifically mentions the perfectly roasted venison, the superior soup compared to the Lucases', and notes that even Mr. Darcy complimented the partridges, speculating about his likely number of French cooks.
Mrs. Bennet compliments Jane's appearance, relaying Mrs. Long's agreement and her comment predicting Jane's future residency at Netherfield.
She expresses fondness for Mrs. Long and her 'pretty behaved' but 'not at all handsome' nieces.
Mrs. Bennet is in high spirits, convinced by Bingley's behavior that he will eventually marry Jane.
Her optimistic expectations are so inflated that she is somewhat disappointed Bingley didn't propose the very next day.
Jane comments to Elizabeth that it was a pleasant day with a well-suited group of guests, hoping they might meet often.
Elizabeth smiles skeptically at Jane's remark.
Jane protests Elizabeth's suspicion, insisting she has learned to appreciate Bingley's conversation simply as an agreeable acquaintance without further wishes.
Jane asserts her belief that Bingley's current manners show he never intended to capture her affections, attributing his pleasing nature to general sweetness and politeness.
Elizabeth finds Jane's denial 'cruel' for provoking her skepticism while simultaneously asking not to be doubted.
Jane laments how difficult it is to be believed in some situations, questioning why Elizabeth insists she feels more than she admits.
Elizabeth finds the question difficult, musing on the human tendency to offer instruction.
She asks for forgiveness and tells Jane not to confide in her if she truly intends to maintain indifference.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well, girls,” said she, as soon as they were left to themselves, “what say you to the day?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Forgive me; and if you persist in indifference, do not make me your confidante.”

events.text_segment:
“Well, girls,” said she, as soon as they were left to themselves, “what say you to the day? I think everything has passed off uncommonly well, I assure you. The dinner was as well dressed as any I ever saw. The venison was roasted to a turn—and everybody said, they never saw so fat a haunch. The soup was fifty times better than what we had at the Lucases’ last week; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged that the partridges were remarkably well done; and I suppose he has two or three French cooks at least. And, my dear Jane, I never saw you look in greater beauty. Mrs. Long said so too, for I asked her whether you did not. And what do you think she said besides? ‘Ah! Mrs. Bennet, we shall have her at Netherfield at last!’ She did, indeed. I do think Mrs. Long is as good a creature as ever lived—and her nieces are very pretty behaved girls, and not at all handsome: I like them prodigiously.”
Mrs. Bennet, in short, was in very great spirits: she had seen enough of Bingley’s behaviour to Jane to be convinced that she would get him at last; and her expectations of advantage to her family, when in a happy humour, were so far beyond reason, that she was quite disappointed at not seeing him there again the next day, to make his proposals.
“It has been a very agreeable day,” said Miss Bennet to Elizabeth. “The party seemed so well selected, so suitable one with the other. I hope we may often meet again.”
Elizabeth smiled.
“Lizzy, you must not do so. You must not suspect me. It mortifies me. I assure you that I have now learnt to enjoy his conversation as an agreeable and sensible young man without having a wish beyond it. I am perfectly satisfied, from what his manners now are, that he never had any design of engaging my affection. It is only that he is blessed with greater sweetness of address, and a stronger desire of generally pleasing, than any other man.”
“You are very cruel,” said her sister, “you will not let me smile, and are provoking me to it every moment.”
“How hard it is in some cases to be believed! And how impossible in others! But why should you wish to persuade me that I feel more than I acknowledge?”
“That is a question which I hardly know how to answer. We all love to instruct, though we can teach only what is not worth knowing. Forgive me; and if you persist in indifference, do not make me your confidante.”

events.title: Bingley's Return and Invitation Accepted
detailed_summary: Mr. Bingley visited the Bennets alone a few days after his previous visit.
He informed them his friend (Mr. Darcy) had gone to London but would be back in ten days.
Bingley stayed for over an hour and seemed very cheerful.
Mrs. Bennet invited him to dinner, but he politely declined due to a prior commitment.
She expressed hope for better luck next time he called.
Bingley responded positively, asking for permission to visit again soon.
Mrs. Bennet immediately asked if he could come the following day.
Confirming he had no other plans, Bingley enthusiastically accepted her invitation for the next day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A few days after this visit, Mr. Bingley called again, and alone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Yes, he had no engagement at all for to-morrow; and her invitation was accepted with alacrity.

events.text_segment:
A few days after this visit, Mr. Bingley called again, and alone. His friend had left him that morning for London, but was to return home in ten days’ time. He sat with them above an hour, and was in remarkably good spirits. Mrs. Bennet invited him to dine with them; but, with many expressions of concern, he confessed himself engaged elsewhere.
“Next time you call,” said she, “I hope we shall be more lucky.”
He should be particularly happy at any time, etc., etc.; and if she would give him leave, would take an early opportunity of waiting on them.
“Can you come to-morrow?”
Yes, he had no engagement at all for to-morrow; and her invitation was accepted with alacrity.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: A few days after this visit, Mr. Bingley called again, and alone. His friend had left him that morning for London, but was to return home in ten days time. He sat with them above an hour, and was in remarkably good spirits. Mrs. Bennet invited him to dine with them; but, with many expressions of concern, he confessed himself engaged elsewhere.

"Next time you call," said she, "I hope we shall be more lucky."

"If you will give me leave, I will take an early opportunity of waiting on you and your family."

"Yes, do. But I always thought he must be a good-natured man. I wonder whether he would come to-morrow? He is just the kind of man I like. So much the man of fashion! So genteel and easy! He has always something to say to everybody. That is my idea of good breeding; and those persons who fancy themselves very important, and never open their mouths, quite mistake the matter."

"Would you like to have me ask him to come to-morrow?"

"Oh, dear! Yes, certainly. I mean—I do not know—but I think I shall. I will send a note home to Netherfield. But you had much better ask him yourself. But he is coming to-morrow, is not he?"

"I have not the smallest objection to explaining. He left Netherfield only on Sunday; and not a note, not a line, did I receive in the meantime. And when I called yesterday, there was nothing in his manner that gave me any alarm."

"My dear, how can you be so teasing! You must know that I am thinking of his marrying one of them."

"For which of your daughters do you ask the question? For they are all very pretty."

"Oh! the eldest. I dare say Mr. Bingley will be very glad to see you; and I will send a few lines by you to assure him of my hearty consent to his marrying whichever he chooses of the girls; though I must throw in a good word for my little Lizzy."

"And I am quite determined to keep him to myself. Is not that a good scheme?"

"I hope I never ridicule what is wise and good. Follies and nonsense, whims and inconsistencies, do divert me, I own, and I laugh at them whenever I can. But these, I suppose, are precisely what you are without."

"Perhaps that is not possible for anyone. But it has been the study of my life to avoid those weaknesses which often expose a strong understanding to ridicule."

"Such as vanity and pride."

"Yes, vanity is a weakness indeed. But pride—where there is a real superiority of mind, pride will be always under good regulation."

Elizabeth turned away to hide a smile.

"Your examination of Mr. Darcy is over, I presume," said Miss Bingley; "and pray what is the result?"

"I am perfectly convinced by it that Mr. Darcy has no defect. He owns it himself without disguise."

"No," said Darcy, "I have made no such pretension. I have faults enough, but they are not, I hope, of understanding. My temper I dare not vouch for. It is, I believe, too little yielding—certainly too little for the convenience of the world. I cannot forget the follies and vices of others so soon as I ought, nor their offenses against myself. My feelings are not puffed about with every attempt to move them. My temper would perhaps be called resentful. My good opinion once lost, is lost forever."

"That is a failing indeed!" cried Elizabeth. "Implacable resentment is a shade in a character. But you have chosen your fault well. I really cannot laugh at it. You are safe from me."

"There is, I believe, in every disposition a tendency to some particular evil—a natural defect, which not even the best education can overcome."

"And your defect is to hate everybody."

"And yours," he replied with a smile, "is willfully to misunderstand them."

"Do let us have a little music," cried Miss Bingley, tired of a conversation in which she had no share. "Louisa, you will not mind my waking Mr. Hurst?"

Her sister had not the smallest objection, and the pianoforte was opened; and Darcy, after a few moments' recollection, was not sorry for it. He began to feel the danger of paying Elizabeth too much attention.

events.title: Mrs. Bennet's First Matchmaking Attempt
detailed_summary: Bingley arrived so early the next day that the Bennet ladies were still getting ready.
Mrs. Bennet rushed to her daughters' room in disarray, urging Jane to hurry down because Bingley had arrived.
She prioritized Jane's readiness over Elizabeth's, calling for a maid to help Jane dress.
Jane insisted they would come down soon, suggesting Kitty might be ready first.
Mrs. Bennet dismissed Kitty's readiness and hurried Jane.
Once Mrs. Bennet left, Jane refused to go downstairs without a sister accompanying her.
Later that evening, Mrs. Bennet clearly attempted to leave Jane and Bingley alone.
After tea, Mr. Bennet went to his library and Mary went to her piano, removing two potential obstacles.
Mrs. Bennet then repeatedly winked at Elizabeth and Kitty, trying to signal them to leave, but without success.
Elizabeth ignored her, and Kitty, upon noticing, innocently asked what the winking meant.
Mrs. Bennet denied winking, but after a few more minutes, she abruptly got up.
She summoned Kitty out of the room under the pretense of needing to speak with her.
Jane gave Elizabeth a look conveying her distress at their mother's obvious scheming and pleading with Elizabeth not to cooperate.
Shortly after, Mrs. Bennet partially opened the door and called for Elizabeth.
Once Elizabeth was in the hall, Mrs. Bennet stated plainly that she and Kitty were going upstairs to leave Jane and Bingley alone.
Elizabeth didn't argue but waited until her mother and Kitty were gone before returning to the drawing-room.
Mrs. Bennet's plans for that day ultimately failed; Bingley behaved charmingly but did not propose.
He was a pleasant guest, tolerating Mrs. Bennet's unsubtle efforts and silly comments with composure, which Jane appreciated.
Bingley readily accepted an implied invitation to stay for supper.
Before leaving, an arrangement was made, largely through his and Mrs. Bennet's efforts, for him to go shooting with Mr. Bennet the next morning.
Following this visit, Jane no longer feigned indifference towards Bingley.
The sisters didn't discuss Bingley directly, but Elizabeth felt confident that matters would soon resolve favorably, unless Darcy returned.
Elizabeth also suspected that Bingley's renewed attention likely had Darcy's approval.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He came, and in such very good time, that the ladies were none of them dressed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Seriously, however, she felt tolerably persuaded that all this must have taken place with that gentleman’s concurrence.

events.text_segment:
He came, and in such very good time, that the ladies were none of them dressed. In ran Mrs. Bennet to her daughters’ room, in her dressing-gown, and with her hair half finished, crying out,—
“My dear Jane, make haste and hurry down. He is come—Mr. Bingley is come. He is, indeed. Make haste, make haste. Here, Sarah, come to Miss Bennet this moment, and help her on with her gown. Never mind Miss Lizzy’s hair.”
“We will be down as soon as we can,” said Jane; “but I dare say Kitty is forwarder than either of us, for she went upstairs half an hour ago.”
“Oh! hang Kitty! what has she to do with it? Come, be quick, be quick! where is your sash, my dear?”
But when her mother was gone, Jane would not be prevailed on to go down without one of her sisters.
The same anxiety to get them by themselves was visible again in the evening. After tea, Mr. Bennet retired to the library, as was his custom, and Mary went upstairs to her instrument. Two obstacles of the five being thus removed, Mrs. Bennet sat looking and winking at Elizabeth and Catherine for a considerable time, without making any impression on them. Elizabeth would not observe her; and when at last Kitty did, she very innocently said, “What is the matter, mamma? What do you keep winking at me for? What am I to do?”
“Nothing, child, nothing. I did not wink at you.” She then sat still five minutes longer; but unable to waste such a precious occasion, she suddenly got up, and saying to Kitty,—
“Come here, my love, I want to speak to you,” took her out of the room. Jane instantly gave a look at Elizabeth which spoke her distress at such premeditation, and her entreaty that she would not give in to it. In a few minutes, Mrs. Bennet half opened the door and called out,—
“Lizzy, my dear, I want to speak with you.”
Elizabeth was forced to go.
“We may as well leave them by themselves, you know,” said her mother as soon as she was in the hall. “Kitty and I are going upstairs to sit in my dressing-room.”
Elizabeth made no attempt to reason with her mother, but remained quietly in the hall till she and Kitty were out of sight, then returned into the drawing-room.
Mrs. Bennet’s schemes for this day were ineffectual. Bingley was everything that was charming, except the professed lover of her daughter. His ease and cheerfulness rendered him a most agreeable addition to their evening party; and he bore with the ill-judged officiousness of the mother, and heard all her silly remarks with a forbearance and command of countenance particularly grateful to the daughter.
He scarcely needed an invitation to stay supper; and before he went away an engagement was formed, chiefly through his own and Mrs. Bennet’s means, for his coming next morning to shoot with her husband.
After this day, Jane said no more of her indifference. Not a word passed between the sisters concerning Bingley; but Elizabeth went to bed in the happy belief that all must speedily be concluded, unless Mr. Darcy returned within the stated time. Seriously, however, she felt tolerably persuaded that all this must have taken place with that gentleman’s concurrence.

events.title: Bingley Proposes to Jane
detailed_summary: Bingley arrived on time for his shooting engagement with Mr. Bennet.
Mr. Bennet found Bingley more pleasant than anticipated, noting his lack of arrogance or foolishness and his relatively communicative manner.
Bingley naturally stayed for dinner.
In the evening, Mrs. Bennet resumed her efforts to isolate Bingley and Jane.
Elizabeth decided to write a letter in the breakfast-room shortly after tea, partly because the others were starting a card game and partly to avoid interfering with her mother's plans.
When Elizabeth finished her letter and returned to the drawing-room, she was surprised to find evidence that her mother's scheming might have succeeded.
She saw Jane and Bingley standing close together by the fireplace, seemingly in deep conversation.
Their hurried movement apart and embarrassed expressions upon noticing Elizabeth confirmed her suspicion that something significant had occurred.
The situation felt awkward for all three.
Silence ensued, and Elizabeth considered leaving again.
Just then, Bingley, who had briefly sat down like Jane, abruptly stood up, spoke quietly to Jane, and quickly left the room.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Bingley was punctual to his appointment; and he and Mr. Bennet spent the morning together, as had been agreed on.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Not a syllable was uttered by either; and Elizabeth was on the point of going away again, when Bingley, who as well as the other had sat down, suddenly rose, and, whispering a few words to her sister, ran out of the room.

events.text_segment:
Bingley was punctual to his appointment; and he and Mr. Bennet spent the morning together, as had been agreed on. The latter was much more agreeable than his companion expected. There was nothing of presumption or folly in Bingley that could provoke his ridicule, or disgust him into silence; and he was more communicative, and less eccentric, than the other had ever seen him. Bingley of course returned with him to dinner; and in the evening Mrs. Bennet’s invention was again at work to get everybody away from him and her daughter. Elizabeth, who had a letter to write, went into the breakfast-room for that purpose soon after tea; for as the others were all going to sit down to cards, she could not be wanted to counteract her mother’s schemes.
But on her returning to the drawing-room, when her letter was finished, she saw, to her infinite surprise, there was reason to fear that her mother had been too ingenious for her. On opening the door, she perceived her sister and Bingley standing together over the hearth, as if engaged in earnest conversation; and had this led to no suspicion, the faces of both, as they hastily turned round and moved away from each other, would have told it all. Their situation was awkward enough; but hers she thought was still worse. Not a syllable was uttered by either; and Elizabeth was on the point of going away again, when Bingley, who as well as the other had sat down, suddenly rose, and, whispering a few words to her sister, ran out of the room.

events.title: Jane Shares Her Joy with Elizabeth
detailed_summary: Jane immediately turned to Elizabeth, ready to share her happy news.
Embracing her sister, Jane emotionally declared herself the happiest person alive.
She felt overwhelmed by her joy, expressing feelings of unworthiness and wishing everyone could be as happy.
Elizabeth offered heartfelt congratulations, full of sincerity and delight.
Jane was deeply moved by Elizabeth's kind words.
However, Jane felt she couldn't stay long with Elizabeth.
She declared her intention to immediately tell their mother, not wanting to delay sharing the news or let Mrs. Bennet hear it from someone else.
Jane mentioned Bingley had already gone to speak with their father.
She expressed immense happiness at the thought of bringing such joy to her family.
Jane then quickly left to find Mrs. Bennet, who had deliberately ended the card game and was waiting upstairs with Kitty.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Jane could have no reserves from Elizabeth, where confidence would give pleasure; and, instantly embracing her, acknowledged, with the liveliest emotion, that she was the happiest creature in the world.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She then hastened away to her mother, who had purposely broken up the card-party, and was sitting upstairs with Kitty.

events.text_segment:
Jane could have no reserves from Elizabeth, where confidence would give pleasure; and, instantly embracing her, acknowledged, with the liveliest emotion, that she was the happiest creature in the world.
“’Tis too much!” she added, “by far too much. I do not deserve it. Oh, why is not everybody as happy?”
Elizabeth’s congratulations were given with a sincerity, a warmth, a delight, which words could but poorly express. Every sentence of kindness was a fresh source of happiness to Jane. But she would not allow herself to stay with her sister, or say half that remained to be said, for the present.
“I must go instantly to my mother,” she cried. “I would not on any account trifle with her affectionate solicitude, or allow her to hear it from anyone but myself. He is gone to my father already. Oh, Lizzy, to know that what I have to relate will give such pleasure to all my dear family! how shall I bear so much happiness?”
She then hastened away to her mother, who had purposely broken up the card-party, and was sitting upstairs with Kitty.

events.title: Bingley and Elizabeth's Cordial Exchange
detailed_summary: Alone, Elizabeth reflected with a smile on how quickly and smoothly the engagement had been settled after months of uncertainty.
She mused ironically that this outcome was the end result of Darcy's cautious interference and Bingley's sisters' scheming - terming it the best possible conclusion.
Bingley joined her shortly after, having had a brief and successful conversation with Mr. Bennet.
He urgently asked for Jane's whereabouts.
Elizabeth informed him Jane was upstairs with their mother but would likely be down soon.
Bingley closed the door, approached Elizabeth, and requested her good wishes and sisterly affection.
Elizabeth genuinely expressed her happiness about their future connection.
They shook hands warmly.
While waiting for Jane, Elizabeth listened to Bingley talk about his happiness and praise Jane's qualities.
Despite his lover's enthusiasm, Elizabeth felt his hopes for happiness were well-grounded, based on Jane's excellent character and their mutual compatibility.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth, who was left by herself, now smiled at the rapidity and ease with which an affair was finally settled, that had given them so many previous months of suspense and vexation.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Elizabeth really believed all his expectations of felicity to be rationally founded, because they had for basis the excellent understanding and super-excellent disposition of Jane, and a general similarity of feeling and taste between her and himself.

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth, who was left by herself, now smiled at the rapidity and ease with which an affair was finally settled, that had given them so many previous months of suspense and vexation.
“And this,” said she, “is the end of all his friend’s anxious circumspection! of all his sister’s falsehood and contrivance! the happiest, wisest, and most reasonable end!”
In a few minutes she was joined by Bingley, whose conference with her father had been short and to the purpose.
“Where is your sister?” said he hastily, as he opened the door.
“With my mother upstairs. She will be down in a moment, I dare say.”
He then shut the door, and, coming up to her, claimed the good wishes and affection of a sister. Elizabeth honestly and heartily expressed her delight in the prospect of their relationship. They shook hands with great cordiality; and then, till her sister came down, she had to listen to all he had to say of his own happiness, and of Jane’s perfections; and in spite of his being a lover, Elizabeth really believed all his expectations of felicity to be rationally founded, because they had for basis the excellent understanding and super-excellent disposition of Jane, and a general similarity of feeling and taste between her and himself.

events.title: Family Celebrates the Engagement
detailed_summary: The evening was exceptionally joyful for the entire family.
Jane's happiness made her appear even more beautiful.
Kitty expressed hopeful smiles, perhaps anticipating her own future prospects.
Mrs. Bennet was ecstatic, unable to express her approval adequately, and spoke only of the engagement to Bingley for a solid half-hour.
When Mr. Bennet joined them for supper, his demeanor clearly showed his genuine happiness.
Mr. Bennet didn't mention the engagement until Bingley had left for the night.
After Bingley's departure, Mr. Bennet turned to Jane and congratulated her, predicting she would be a very happy woman.
Jane approached him, kissed him, and thanked him.
He affectionately called her a good girl, pleased she would be well-settled.

He humorously commented on their compatible temperaments, suggesting their compliance would lead to indecision, their easy-going nature would invite being cheated by servants, and their generosity would cause them to overspend.
Jane protested that financial imprudence would be inexcusable for her.
Mrs. Bennet interjected, dismissing concerns about income by stating Bingley's substantial wealth.
She then expressed overwhelming joy to Jane, claiming she wouldn't sleep all night and had always predicted this outcome, attributing it to Jane's beauty.
Thoughts of Wickham and Lydia were forgotten as Jane became Mrs. Bennet's undisputed favorite child.
The younger sisters quickly began asking Jane for future favors related to Netherfield.
Mary asked about using the library, while Kitty requested future balls at Netherfield.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was an evening of no common delight to them all; the satisfaction of Miss Bennet’s mind gave such a glow of sweet animation to her face, as made her look handsomer than ever.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mary petitioned for the use of the library at Netherfield; and Kitty begged very hard for a few balls there every winter.

events.text_segment:
It was an evening of no common delight to them all; the satisfaction of Miss Bennet’s mind gave such a glow of sweet animation to her face, as made her look handsomer than ever. Kitty simpered and smiled, and hoped her turn was coming soon. Mrs. Bennet could not give her consent, or speak her approbation in terms warm enough to satisfy her feelings, though she talked to Bingley of nothing else, for half an hour; and when Mr. Bennet joined them at supper, his voice and manner plainly showed how really happy he was.
Not a word, however, passed his lips in allusion to it, till their visitor took his leave for the night; but as soon as he was gone, he turned to his daughter and said,—
“Jane, I congratulate you. You will be a very happy woman.”
Jane went to him instantly, kissed him, and thanked him for his goodness.
“You are a good girl,” he replied, “and I have great pleasure in thinking you will be so happily settled. I have not a doubt of your doing very well together. Your tempers are by no means unlike. You are each of you so complying, that nothing will ever be resolved on; so easy, that every servant will cheat you; and so generous, that you will always exceed your income.”
“I hope not so. Imprudence or thoughtlessness in money matters would be unpardonable in me.”
“Exceed their income! My dear Mr. Bennet,” cried his wife, “what are you talking of? Why, he has four or five thousand a year, and very likely more.” Then addressing her daughter, “Oh, my dear, dear Jane, I am so happy! I am sure I shan’t get a wink of sleep all night. I knew how it would be. I always said it must be so, at last. I was sure you could not be so beautiful for nothing! I remember, as soon as ever I saw him, when he first came into Hertfordshire last year, I thought how likely it was that you should come together. Oh, he is the handsomest young man that ever was seen!”
Wickham, Lydia, were all forgotten. Jane was beyond competition her favourite child. At that moment she cared for no other. Her younger sisters soon began to make interest with her for objects of happiness which she might in future be able to dispense.
Mary petitioned for the use of the library at Netherfield; and Kitty begged very hard for a few balls there every winter.

events.title: Jane and Elizabeth Discuss Past Misunderstandings
detailed_summary: Bingley became a constant presence at Longbourn, often arriving before breakfast and staying until after supper, except when obligated to dine elsewhere.
Elizabeth had less time to talk with Jane, as Jane's attention was focused on Bingley when he was present.
However, Elizabeth found she was useful to both during their occasional separations.
Bingley sought out Elizabeth to talk about Jane when Jane wasn't around, and Jane sought Elizabeth for the same purpose when Bingley was gone.
One evening, Jane told Elizabeth how happy she was that Bingley had revealed he was completely unaware she had been in London the previous spring, something Jane hadn't thought possible.
Elizabeth admitted she had suspected as much.
Jane explained Bingley attributed his ignorance to his sisters, acknowledging they likely didn't approve of the match but hoping they would eventually accept it for their brother's happiness.
Jane hoped they could be on good terms again, though recognizing their relationship wouldn't be the same.
Elizabeth praised Jane's less forgiving attitude, saying it was the least forgiving she'd ever heard Jane be and expressing relief Jane wouldn't be fooled by Miss Bingley's false friendship again.
Jane then revealed Bingley confessed he truly loved her when he left for London the previous November and only his mistaken belief in her indifference stopped him from returning sooner.
Elizabeth remarked it was a mistake, but one that spoke well of his modesty.
This led Jane to praise Bingley's diffidence.
Elizabeth was privately pleased that Bingley hadn't revealed Mr. Darcy's role in the separation, knowing it would prejudice the forgiving Jane against Darcy.
Jane exclaimed she was the most fortunate person ever and lamented that she was singled out for such happiness in her family.
She expressed a fervent wish for Elizabeth to find similar happiness and a comparable partner.

Elizabeth replied that even forty such men couldn't make her as happy as Jane, attributing Jane's happiness to her unique disposition and goodness, concluding she would manage on her own and perhaps find another Mr. Collins.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If you were to give me forty such men I never could be so happy as you. Till I have your disposition, your goodness, I never can have your happiness. No, no, let me shift for myself; and, perhaps, if I have very good luck, I may meet with another Mr. Collins in time.”

events.text_segment:
Bingley, from this time, was of course a daily visitor at Longbourn; coming frequently before breakfast, and always remaining till after supper; unless when some barbarous neighbour, who could not be enough detested, had given him an invitation to dinner, which he thought himself obliged to accept.
Elizabeth had now but little time for conversation with her sister; for while he was present Jane had no attention to bestow on anyone else: but she found herself considerably useful to both of them, in those hours of separation that must sometimes occur. In the absence of Jane, he always attached himself to Elizabeth for the pleasure of talking of her; and when Bingley was gone, Jane constantly sought the same means of relief.
“He has made me so happy,” said she, one evening, “by telling me that he was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring! I had not believed it possible.”
“I suspected as much,” replied Elizabeth. “But how did he account for it?”
“It must have been his sisters’ doing. They were certainly no friends to his acquaintance with me, which I cannot wonder at, since he might have chosen so much more advantageously in many respects. But when they see, as I trust they will, that their brother is happy with me, they will learn to be contented, and we shall be on good terms again: though we can never be what we once were to each other.”
“That is the most unforgiving speech,” said Elizabeth, “that I ever heard you utter. Good girl! It would vex me, indeed, to see you again the dupe of Miss Bingley’s pretended regard.”
“Would you believe it, Lizzy, that when he went to town last November he really loved me, and nothing but a persuasion of my being indifferent would have prevented his coming down again?”
“He made a little mistake, to be sure; but it is to the credit of his modesty.”
This naturally introduced a panegyric from Jane on his diffidence, and the little value he put on his own good qualities.
Elizabeth was pleased to find that he had not betrayed the interference of his friend; for, though Jane had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, she knew it was a circumstance which must prejudice her against him.
“I am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed!” cried Jane. “Oh, Lizzy, why am I thus singled from my family, and blessed above them all? If I could but see you as happy! If there were but such another man for you!”
“If you were to give me forty such men I never could be so happy as you. Till I have your disposition, your goodness, I never can have your happiness. No, no, let me shift for myself; and, perhaps, if I have very good luck, I may meet with another Mr. Collins in time.”

events.title: Engagement News Spreads, Changing Fortunes
detailed_summary: The news of the engagement did not remain private for long.
Mrs. Bennet shared the secret with Mrs. Philips.
She then proceeded, without seeking permission, to inform all her neighbors in Meryton.
Very quickly, the Bennet family gained a reputation as the world's luckiest family.
This was a significant reversal from just weeks prior, when Lydia's elopement had led people to view them as destined for misfortune.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The situation of affairs in the Longbourn family could not be long a secret.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the world; though only a few weeks before, when Lydia had first run away, they had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune.

events.text_segment:
The situation of affairs in the Longbourn family could not be long a secret. Mrs. Bennet was privileged to whisper it to Mrs. Philips, and she ventured, without any permission, to do the same by all her neighbours in Meryton.
The Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the world; though only a few weeks before, when Lydia had first run away, they had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune.

events.title: Lady Catherine's Unexpected Arrival
detailed_summary: While the Bennet women and Bingley are seated together, the sound of an approaching carriage captures their attention.
They observe the unfamiliar carriage and horses, noting it arrives too early for typical visitors and doesn't belong to any neighbours.
Recognizing an intrusion is imminent, Bingley persuades Jane Bennet to walk with him into the shrubbery, allowing them privacy.
Elizabeth, Mrs. Bennet, and Kitty remain, speculating about the visitor's identity with growing curiosity.
The door opens, revealing the visitor to be Lady Catherine de Bourgh.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One morning, about a week after Bingley’s engagement with Jane had been formed, as he and the females of the family were sitting together in the dining-room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window by the sound of a carriage; and they perceived a chaise and four driving up the lawn.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.

events.text_segment: One morning, about a week after Bingley’s engagement with Jane had been formed, as he and the females of the family were sitting together in the dining-room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window by the sound of a carriage; and they perceived a chaise and four driving up the lawn. It was too early in the morning for visitors; and besides, the equipage did not answer to that of any of their neighbours. The horses were post; and neither the carriage, nor the livery of the servant who preceded it, were familiar to them. As it was certain, however, that somebody was coming, Bingley instantly prevailed on Miss Bennet to avoid the confinement of such an intrusion, and walk away with him into the shrubbery. They both set off; and the conjectures of the remaining three continued, though with little satisfaction, till the door was thrown open, and their visitor entered. It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.

events.title: A Tense and Puzzling Parlor Interaction
detailed_summary: The Bennet family members present are genuinely astonished by Lady Catherine's appearance, exceeding their prepared reactions; Elizabeth feels this surprise most acutely.
Lady Catherine enters with a particularly unpleasant demeanor, offering only a slight nod in response to Elizabeth's greeting and taking a seat without speaking.
Elizabeth identifies Lady Catherine to her mother, despite no formal introduction being requested.
Mrs. Bennet, amazed yet flattered by the high-status guest, greets her with great politeness.
After a silence, Lady Catherine stiffly addresses Elizabeth, confirming her identity and inquiring about her mother.
Elizabeth replies briefly.
Lady Catherine then inquires about Kitty.
Mrs. Bennet delightedly confirms Kitty's identity, volunteers information about Lydia's recent marriage, and mentions Jane walking outside with a young man expected to join the family.
Lady Catherine curtly remarks on the small size of their park.
Mrs. Bennet defensively compares it favorably to Sir William Lucas's property, while acknowledging it doesn't compare to Rosings.
Lady Catherine criticizes the sitting room's westward windows as inconvenient for summer evenings.
Mrs. Bennet explains they use a different room after dinner and then politely asks about the well-being of Mr. and Mrs. Collins.
Lady Catherine confirms she saw the Collinses recently.
Elizabeth anticipates receiving a letter from Charlotte via Lady Catherine, thinking it the only likely reason for the visit, but no letter is produced, leaving Elizabeth confused.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They were of course all intending to be surprised: but their astonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of Mrs. Bennet and Kitty, though she was perfectly unknown to them, even inferior to what Elizabeth felt.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But no letter appeared, and she was completely puzzled.

events.text_segment:
They were of course all intending to be surprised: but their astonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of Mrs. Bennet and Kitty, though she was perfectly unknown to them, even inferior to what Elizabeth felt.
She entered the room with an air more than usually ungracious, made no other reply to Elizabeth’s salutation than a slight inclination of the head, and sat down without saying a word. Elizabeth had mentioned her name to her mother on her Ladyship’s entrance, though no request of introduction had been made.
Mrs. Bennet, all amazement, though flattered by having a guest of such high importance, received her with the utmost politeness. After sitting for a moment in silence, she said, very stiffly, to Elizabeth,—
“I hope you are well, Miss Bennet. That lady, I suppose, is your mother?”
Elizabeth replied very concisely that she was.
“And that, I suppose, is one of your sisters?”
“Yes, madam,” said Mrs. Bennet, delighted to speak to a Lady Catherine. “She is my youngest girl but one. My youngest of all is lately married, and my eldest is somewhere about the ground, walking with a young man, who, I believe, will soon become a part of the family.”
“You have a very small park here,” returned Lady Catherine, after a short silence.
“It is nothing in comparison of Rosings, my Lady, I dare say; but, I assure you, it is much larger than Sir William Lucas’s.”
“This must be a most inconvenient sitting-room for the evening in summer: the windows are full west.”
Mrs. Bennet assured her that they never sat there after dinner; and then added,—
“May I take the liberty of asking your Ladyship whether you left Mr. and Mrs. Collins well?”
“Yes, very well. I saw them the night before last.”
Elizabeth now expected that she would produce a letter for her from Charlotte, as it seemed the only probable motive for her calling. But no letter appeared, and she was completely puzzled.

events.title: Invitation to a Private Walk
detailed_summary: Despite Mrs. Bennet's civil offer of refreshments, Lady Catherine firmly and impolitely refuses.
Lady Catherine then stands and requests Elizabeth accompany her for a walk in a small wooded area on the property.
Mrs. Bennet eagerly encourages Elizabeth to comply and show Lady Catherine the grounds, suggesting the hermitage.
Elizabeth obeys, fetches her parasol, and leads Lady Catherine downstairs.
As they pass through the hall, Lady Catherine inspects the dining-parlour and drawing-room, pronouncing them merely 'decent'.
Her carriage waits at the door, and Elizabeth observes her waiting-woman inside.
They proceed silently towards the copse; Elizabeth decides against attempting conversation with the increasingly insolent Lady Catherine.
Observing her guest, Elizabeth inwardly reflects on how mistaken she was to ever perceive a resemblance between Lady Catherine and Mr. Darcy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mrs. Bennet, with great civility, begged her Ladyship to take some refreshment: but Lady Catherine very resolutely, and not very politely, declined eating anything; and then, rising up, said to Elizabeth,—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “How could I ever think her like her nephew?” said she, as she looked in her face.

events.text_segment:
Mrs. Bennet, with great civility, begged her Ladyship to take some refreshment: but Lady Catherine very resolutely, and not very politely, declined eating anything; and then, rising up, said to Elizabeth,—
“Miss Bennet, there seemed to be a prettyish kind of a little wilderness on one side of your lawn. I should be glad to take a turn in it, if you will favour me with your company.”
“Go, my dear,” cried her mother, “and show her Ladyship about the different walks. I think she will be pleased with the hermitage.”
Elizabeth obeyed; and, running into her own room for her parasol, attended her noble guest downstairs. As they passed through the hall, Lady Catherine opened the doors into the dining-parlour and drawing-room, and pronouncing them, after a short survey, to be decent-looking rooms, walked on.
Her carriage remained at the door, and Elizabeth saw that her waiting-woman was in it. They proceeded in silence along the gravel walk that led to the copse; Elizabeth was determined to make no effort for conversation with a woman who was now more than usually insolent and disagreeable.
“How could I ever think her like her nephew?” said she, as she looked in her face.
