events.title: Discussion of Bingley's Engagement and Return to Longbourn
detailed_summary: Elizabeth expresses gratitude once more regarding his help with Lydia, but the topic is too sensitive for further discussion.
After walking leisurely for miles, lost in conversation, they check their watches and realize it's time to return home.
Wondering about Bingley and Jane leads to discussing their relationship.
Darcy expresses delight at their engagement, having received the news early from Bingley.
Elizabeth asks if he was surprised by the engagement.
Darcy states he wasn't surprised and expected it would happen soon after he left.
Elizabeth playfully suggests he means he granted permission, which Darcy acknowledges was essentially true.
Darcy recounts confessing to Bingley before leaving for London about his past interference and admitting it was wrong.
He shares Bingley's immense surprise, as he had no prior suspicion.
Darcy further explains he told Bingley he now believed Jane was not indifferent to him and, seeing Bingley's continued attachment, felt confident in their future happiness.
Elizabeth smiles inwardly at how easily Darcy directs his friend.
She questions whether Darcy's assessment of Jane's feelings came from his own recent observations or her information from the previous spring.
Darcy confirms it was based on his close observation of Jane during his recent visits.
Elizabeth implies his assurance likely convinced Bingley immediately.
Darcy agrees, noting Bingley's modesty and reliance on Darcy's judgment in uncertain matters.
He reveals one difficult confession: telling Bingley that Jane had been in London the previous winter, and Darcy had known and deliberately concealed it.
Bingley was initially angry, but Darcy believes the anger subsided once Bingley was assured of Jane's affection, and he has now forgiven Darcy.
Elizabeth resists the urge to comment humorously on Bingley's easy guidance but refrains, feeling it's too soon to tease Darcy.
Darcy continues discussing Bingley's happiness (secondary only to his own) until they reach the house.
They part ways in the entrance hall.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: She expressed her gratitude again, but it was too painful a subject to each to be dwelt on farther.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In the hall they parted.

events.text_segment:
She expressed her gratitude again, but it was too painful a subject to each to be dwelt on farther.
After walking several miles in a leisurely manner, and too busy to know anything about it, they found at last, on examining their watches, that it was time to be at home.
“What could have become of Mr. Bingley and Jane?” was a wonder which introduced the discussion of their affairs. Darcy was delighted with their engagement; his friend had given him the earliest information of it.
“I must ask whether you were surprised?” said Elizabeth.
“Not at all. When I went away, I felt that it would soon happen.”
“That is to say, you had given your permission. I guessed as much.” And though he exclaimed at the term, she found that it had been pretty much the case.
“On the evening before my going to London,” said he, “I made a confession to him, which I believe I ought to have made long ago. I told him of all that had occurred to make my former interference in his affairs absurd and impertinent. His surprise was great. He had never had the slightest suspicion. I told him, moreover, that I believed myself mistaken in supposing, as I had done, that your sister was indifferent to him; and as I could easily perceive that his attachment to her was unabated, I felt no doubt of their happiness together.”
Elizabeth could not help smiling at his easy manner of directing his friend.
“Did you speak from your own observation,” said she, “when you told him that my sister loved him, or merely from my information last spring?”
“From the former. I had narrowly observed her, during the two visits which I had lately made her here; and I was convinced of her affection.”
“And your assurance of it, I suppose, carried immediate conviction to him.”
“It did. Bingley is most unaffectedly modest. His diffidence had prevented his depending on his own judgment in so anxious a case, but his reliance on mine made everything easy. I was obliged to confess one thing, which for a time, and not unjustly, offended him. I could not allow myself to conceal that your sister had been in town three months last winter, that I had known it, and purposely kept it from him. He was angry. But his anger, I am persuaded, lasted no longer than he remained in any doubt of your sister’s sentiments. He has heartily forgiven me now.”
Elizabeth longed to observe that Mr. Bingley had been a most delightful friend; so easily guided that his worth was invaluable; but she checked herself. She remembered that he had yet to learn to be laughed at, and it was rather too early to begin. In anticipating the happiness of Bingley, which of course was to be inferior only to his own, he continued the conversation till they reached the house. In the hall they parted.

events.title: An Evening of Quiet Contrasts and Apprehension
detailed_summary: Upon returning from her walk, Elizabeth evasively answers questions about her whereabouts, blushing but raising no suspicion.
The evening proceeds calmly, highlighting the difference between the openly affectionate engaged couple (Jane and Bingley) and the silently happy, newly engaged pair (Elizabeth and Darcy).
Darcy's happiness manifests quietly, not through outward mirth.
Elizabeth feels agitated and confused, intellectually recognizing her happiness rather than fully experiencing it emotionally.
She worries about the practical difficulties ahead, particularly how her family will react to the engagement.
Elizabeth acknowledges that only Jane holds any positive feelings for Darcy, fearing the others' deep-seated dislike might not be overcome even by his wealth and status.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: My dear Lizzy, where can you have been walking to?” was a question which Elizabeth received from Jane as soon as she entered the room, and from all the others when they sat down to table.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She anticipated what would be felt in the family when her situation became known: she was aware that no one liked him but Jane; and even feared that with the others it was a dislike which not all his fortune and consequence might do away.

events.text_segment:
My dear Lizzy, where can you have been walking to?” was a question which Elizabeth received from Jane as soon as she entered the room, and from all the others when they sat down to table. She had only to say in reply, that they had wandered about till she was beyond her own knowledge. She coloured as she spoke; but neither that, nor anything else, awakened a suspicion of the truth.
The evening passed quietly, unmarked by anything extraordinary. The acknowledged lovers talked and laughed; the unacknowledged were silent. Darcy was not of a disposition in which happiness overflows in mirth; and Elizabeth, agitated and confused, rather knew that she was happy than felt herself to be so; for, besides the immediate embarrassment, there were other evils before her. She anticipated what would be felt in the family when her situation became known: she was aware that no one liked him but Jane; and even feared that with the others it was a dislike which not all his fortune and consequence might do away.

events.title: Elizabeth Confides Her Engagement to an Incredulous Jane
detailed_summary: Elizabeth reveals her engagement to Darcy when alone with Jane.
Jane initially reacts with complete disbelief, assuming Elizabeth is joking due to her known prior dislike of Darcy.
Elizabeth insists she is serious and that Darcy still loves her.
Jane expresses concern, wanting assurance that Elizabeth can truly be happy with him and questioning if she genuinely loves him sufficiently.
Elizabeth reassures Jane, humorously claiming to love Darcy more than Bingley and admitting her feelings developed gradually, possibly starting from her visit to Pemberley.
After Elizabeth's solemn assurances of her deep attachment, Jane becomes fully convinced and joyful.
Jane expresses her happiness for Elizabeth and her high regard for Darcy, especially now as Bingley's friend and Elizabeth's future husband.
Jane gently chides Elizabeth for her previous secrecy regarding events at Pemberley and Lambton.
Elizabeth explains her reasons for silence, related to Bingley and the uncertainty of her own feelings for Darcy.
Elizabeth then fully discloses Darcy's crucial role in arranging Lydia's marriage.
The sisters spend hours talking, sharing all the details.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At night she opened her heart to Jane.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All was acknowledged, and half the night spent in conversation.

events.text_segment:
At night she opened her heart to Jane. Though suspicion was very far from Miss Bennet’s general habits, she was absolutely incredulous here.
“You are joking, Lizzy. This cannot be! Engaged to Mr. Darcy! No, no, you shall not deceive me: I know it to be impossible.”
“This is a wretched beginning, indeed! My sole dependence was on you; and I am sure nobody else will believe me, if you do not. Yet, indeed, I am in earnest. I speak nothing but the truth. He still loves me, and we are engaged.”
Jane looked at her doubtingly. “Oh, Lizzy! it cannot be. I know how much you dislike him.”
“You know nothing of the matter. That is all to be forgot. Perhaps I did not always love him so well as I do now; but in such cases as these a good memory is unpardonable. This is the last time I shall ever remember it myself.”
Miss Bennet still looked all amazement. Elizabeth again, and more seriously, assured her of its truth.
“Good heaven! can it be really so? Yet now I must believe you,” cried Jane. “My dear, dear Lizzy, I would, I do congratulate you; but are you certain—forgive the question—are you quite certain that you can be happy with him?”
“There can be no doubt of that. It is settled between us already that we are to be the happiest couple in the world. But are you pleased, Jane? Shall you like to have such a brother?”
“Very, very much. Nothing could give either Bingley or myself more delight. But we considered it, we talked of it as impossible. And do you really love him quite well enough? Oh, Lizzy! do anything rather than marry without affection. Are you quite sure that you feel what you ought to do?”
“Oh, yes! You will only think I feel more than I ought to do when I tell you all.”
“What do you mean?”
“Why, I must confess that I love him better than I do Bingley. I am afraid you will be angry.”
“My dearest sister, now be, be serious. I want to talk very seriously. Let me know everything that I am to know without delay. Will you tell me how long you have loved him?”
“It has been coming on so gradually, that I hardly know when it began; but I believe I must date it from my first seeing his beautiful grounds at Pemberley.”
Another entreaty that she would be serious, however, produced the desired effect; and she soon satisfied Jane by her solemn assurances of attachment. When convinced on that article, Miss Bennet had nothing further to wish.
“Now I am quite happy,” said she, “for you will be as happy as myself. I always had a value for him. Were it for nothing but his love of you, I must always have esteemed him; but now, as Bingley’s friend and your husband, there can be only Bingley and yourself more dear to me. But, Lizzy, you have been very sly, very reserved with me. How little did you tell me of what passed at Pemberley and Lambton! I owe all that I know of it to another, not to you.”
Elizabeth told her the motives of her secrecy. She had been unwilling to mention Bingley; and the unsettled state of her own feelings had made her equally avoid the name of his friend: but now she would no longer conceal from her his share in Lydia’s marriage. All was acknowledged, and half the night spent in conversation.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
At night she opened her heart to Jane. Elizabeth could no longer contain the tumult of emotions that had been building within her since Mr. Darcy's unexpected proposal. The quiet of their shared bedroom provided the sanctuary she needed to confide in her most trusted confidante.

"Oh, Jane," Elizabeth began, her voice barely above a whisper, "you cannot imagine what has occurred today."

Jane, ever patient and kind, sat beside her sister on the bed, her gentle eyes encouraging Elizabeth to continue.

"Mr. Darcy has proposed to me," Elizabeth said, the words still sounding foreign to her ears.

Jane's expression transformed from curiosity to astonishment. "Mr. Darcy? But I thought—"

"That I despised him? Yes, and I told him as much," Elizabeth replied, recounting the details of their encounter—how he had declared his feelings despite his better judgment, how he had spoken of the inferiority of her connections, and how she had rejected him with perhaps more vehemence than was necessary.

"I cannot believe it," Jane said softly. "He has always seemed so proud, so distant. To think that he harbored such feelings for you all this time."

Elizabeth paced the room, her thoughts racing. "He gave me a letter, Jane. A letter that has shaken everything I believed to be true."

She explained the contents—Mr. Darcy's justification for separating Bingley from Jane, his history with Wickham that painted the charming officer in an entirely different light.

"Could I have been so blind? So prejudiced?" Elizabeth wondered aloud. "I prided myself on my discernment, yet I allowed Wickham's pleasing manners to deceive me completely."

Jane, ever reluctant to think ill of anyone, suggested that perhaps there had been misunderstandings on both sides.

"That is your goodness speaking, dear Jane," Elizabeth said with a sad smile. "I fear my judgment was clouded by vanity—vanity that was wounded when Mr. Darcy first dismissed me as merely 'tolerable.'"

As the night deepened, the sisters continued their conversation, examining each revelation from every angle. Elizabeth confessed her growing uncertainty about her feelings toward Mr. Darcy, while Jane offered comfort and perspective.

"People are rarely as simple as we first judge them to be," Jane observed. "Perhaps Mr. Darcy, like all of us, is a mixture of good and bad qualities."

Elizabeth nodded, remembering his dignified bearing at Pemberley, his kindness to his sister, the respect shown to him by his servants. "I have been so preoccupied with his pride that I failed to see my own prejudice," she admitted.

As dawn approached, Elizabeth felt a strange sense of clarity emerging from her confusion. She had not forgiven Mr. Darcy entirely, nor had she determined what her feelings toward him truly were, but she had begun to see him—and herself—more clearly.

"Whatever happens," Jane said, squeezing her sister's hand, "you must follow your heart, Lizzy."

Elizabeth smiled gratefully at her sister. In Jane's compassionate presence, she had found not answers, but something perhaps more valuable: the space to question her own certainties and the courage to face whatever truths might emerge.

events.title: Mrs. Bennet's Unwitting Matchmaking
detailed_summary: The next morning, Mrs. Bennet expresses annoyance at seeing Darcy arrive again with Bingley, calling him tiresome and disagreeable.
She suggests Elizabeth walk out with Darcy again, solely to keep him out of Bingley's way.
Elizabeth is amused by the convenience but annoyed by her mother's persistent insults towards Darcy.
Bingley's warm greeting to Elizabeth shows he is aware of the engagement.
Bingley openly teases Elizabeth about getting lost in lanes again.
Mrs. Bennet proposes a long walk to Oakham Mount for Darcy, Lizzy, and Kitty.
Bingley intervenes, suggesting the walk is too far for Kitty, who agrees.
Darcy expresses interest in the view, and Elizabeth silently agrees to the walk.

As Elizabeth prepares, Mrs. Bennet follows her, expressing pity that Elizabeth must entertain the 'disagreeable man' alone but urging her to do it for Jane's sake and suggesting minimal conversation is needed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Good gracious!” cried Mrs. Bennet, as she stood at a window the next morning, “if that disagreeable Mr. Darcy is not coming here again with our dear Bingley!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I am quite sorry, Lizzy, that you should be forced to have that disagreeable man all to yourself; but I hope you will not mind it. It is all for Jane’s sake, you know; and there is no occasion for talking to him except just now and then; so do not put yourself to inconvenience.”

events.text_segment:
“Good gracious!” cried Mrs. Bennet, as she stood at a window the next morning, “if that disagreeable Mr. Darcy is not coming here again with our dear Bingley! What can he mean by being so tiresome as to be always coming here? I had no notion but he would go a-shooting, or something or other, and not disturb us with his company. What shall we do with him? Lizzy, you must walk out with him again, that he may not be in Bingley’s way.”
Elizabeth could hardly help laughing at so convenient a proposal; yet was really vexed that her mother should be always giving him such an epithet.
As soon as they entered, Bingley looked at her so expressively, and shook hands with such warmth, as left no doubt of his good information; and he soon afterwards said aloud, “Mrs. Bennet, have you no more lanes hereabouts in which Lizzy may lose her way again to-day?”
“I advise Mr. Darcy, and Lizzy, and Kitty,” said Mrs. Bennet, “to walk to Oakham Mount this morning. It is a nice long walk, and Mr. Darcy has never seen the view.”
“It may do very well for the others,” replied Mr. Bingley; “but I am sure it will be too much for Kitty. Won’t it, Kitty?”
Kitty owned that she had rather stay at home. Darcy professed a great curiosity to see the view from the Mount, and Elizabeth silently consented. As she went upstairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed her, saying,—
“I am quite sorry, Lizzy, that you should be forced to have that disagreeable man all to yourself; but I hope you will not mind it. It is all for Jane’s sake, you know; and there is no occasion for talking to him except just now and then; so do not put yourself to inconvenience.”

events.title: Planning the Parental Consent Strategy
detailed_summary: While walking, Elizabeth and Darcy decide he will approach Mr. Bennet for consent that evening.
Elizabeth decides she will be the one to inform her mother.
She feels uncertain about her mother's reaction, wondering if even Darcy's wealth can overcome Mrs. Bennet's dislike.
Elizabeth anticipates that her mother's reaction, whether furious opposition or excessive delight, will be embarrassing and inappropriate.
She dreads Darcy witnessing either extreme of her mother's potential response.

events.title: Darcy Seeks Consent; Elizabeth Summoned
detailed_summary: Later that evening, after Mr. Bennet retreats to his library, Elizabeth anxiously watches Darcy get up and follow him.
Her distress is significant, not because she fears her father's refusal, but because she knows the conversation will upset him.
She feels miserable reflecting that she, his favorite daughter, is the cause of his potential unhappiness and worry regarding her future.
She waits in misery until Darcy reappears.
Darcy's smile upon returning offers her some relief.
He approaches the table where she sits with Kitty.
Under the guise of admiring her needlework, Darcy whispers that her father wishes to see her in the library.
Elizabeth immediately leaves to go to her father.

events.text_segment: In the evening, soon after Mr. Bennet withdrew to the library, she saw Mr. Darcy rise also and follow him, and her agitation on seeing it was extreme. She did not fear her father’s opposition, but he was going to be made unhappy, and that it should be through her means; that she, his favourite child, should be distressing him by her choice, should be filling him with fears and regrets in disposing of her, was a wretched reflection, and she sat in misery till Mr. Darcy appeared again, when, looking at him, she was a little relieved by his smile. In a few minutes he approached the table where she was sitting with Kitty; and, while pretending to admire her work, said in a whisper, “Go to your father; he wants you in the library.” She was gone directly.

events.title: Elizabeth Convinces a Skeptical Mr. Bennet
detailed_summary: Elizabeth finds her father pacing, looking serious and worried.
He immediately questions her sanity in accepting Darcy, reminding her of her long-professed hatred for him.
Elizabeth regrets her past strong opinions and expressions, realizing they now necessitate awkward explanations.
She assures her father, with some embarrassment, of her genuine attachment to Darcy.
Mr. Bennet skeptically interprets this as determination, suggesting wealth (fine clothes, carriages) is her motivation.
Elizabeth asks if he has any objection besides his belief in her indifference.
Mr. Bennet concedes that Darcy's known pride and unpleasantness wouldn't matter if Elizabeth truly liked him.
With tears, Elizabeth insists she loves Darcy and that his pride is not improper; he is truly amiable, and her father doesn't know his real character.
Mr. Bennet reveals he has already given Darcy his consent, partly out of perceived intimidation.
He formally gives Elizabeth his consent but strongly advises her to reconsider, emphasizing his knowledge of her character.

He warns her that marrying without true esteem and respect, especially given her lively mind, would lead to misery and disgrace, begging her not to cause him the grief of seeing her unable to respect her life partner.
Affected, Elizabeth earnestly and solemnly reiterates her feelings, explaining the gradual change in her estimation of Darcy and her certainty of his steadfast affection.
She passionately lists Darcy's good qualities, finally overcoming her father's disbelief and reconciling him to the match.
Mr. Bennet, convinced, declares Darcy deserving of her and that he couldn't have parted with her to anyone less worthy.
Elizabeth solidifies his approval by revealing Darcy's secret, generous actions in resolving Lydia's situation.
Mr. Bennet is astonished by this revelation, calling it an evening of wonders.
He remarks humorously on how Darcy handled everything, saving him trouble and expense, and anticipates Darcy's likely reaction if offered repayment.
He then recalls and teases Elizabeth about her embarrassment over Mr. Collins's letter days earlier.
He finally allows her to leave, jokingly telling her to send in any suitors for Mary or Kitty as he is now 'at leisure'.

events.text_segment:
Her father was walking about the room, looking grave and anxious. “Lizzy,” said he, “what are you doing? Are you out of your senses to be accepting this man? Have not you always hated him?”
How earnestly did she then wish that her former opinions had been more reasonable, her expressions more moderate! It would have spared her from explanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give; but they were now necessary, and she assured him, with some confusion, of her attachment to Mr. Darcy.
“Or, in other words, you are determined to have him. He is rich, to be sure, and you may have more fine clothes and fine carriages than Jane. But will they make you happy?”
“Have you any other objection,” said Elizabeth, “than your belief of my indifference?”
“None at all. We all know him to be a proud, unpleasant sort of man; but this would be nothing if you really liked him.”
“I do, I do like him,” she replied, with tears in her eyes; “I love him. Indeed he has no improper pride. He is perfectly amiable. You do not know what he really is; then pray do not pain me by speaking of him in such terms.”
“Lizzy,” said her father, “I have given him my consent. He is the kind of man, indeed, to whom I should never dare refuse anything, which he condescended to ask. I now give it to you, if you are resolved on having him. But let me advise you to think better of it. I know your disposition, Lizzy. I know that you could be neither happy nor respectable, unless you truly esteemed your husband, unless you looked up to him as a superior. Your lively talents would place you in the greatest danger in an unequal marriage. You could scarcely escape discredit and misery. My child, let me not have the grief of seeing you unable to respect your partner in life. You know not what you are about.”
Elizabeth, still more affected, was earnest and solemn in her reply; and, at length, by repeated assurances that Mr. Darcy was really the object of her choice, by explaining the gradual change which her estimation of him had undergone, relating her absolute certainty that his affection was not the work of a day, but had stood the test of many months’ suspense, and enumerating with energy all his good qualities, she did conquer her father’s incredulity, and reconcile him to the match.
“Well, my dear,” said he, when she ceased speaking, “I have no more to say. If this be the case, he deserves you. I could not have parted with you, my Lizzy, to anyone less worthy.”
To complete the favourable impression, she then told him what Mr. Darcy had voluntarily done for Lydia. He heard her with astonishment.
“This is an evening of wonders, indeed! And so, Darcy did everything; made up the match, gave the money, paid the fellow’s debts, and got him his commission! So much the better. It will save me a world of trouble and economy. Had it been your uncle’s doing, I must and would have paid him; but these violent young lovers carry everything their own way. I shall offer to pay him to-morrow, he will rant and storm about his love for you, and there will be an end of the matter.”
He then recollected her embarrassment a few days before on his reading Mr. Collins’s letter; and after laughing at her some time, allowed her at last to go, saying, as she quitted the room, “If any young men come for Mary or Kitty, send them in, for I am quite at leisure.”

events.title: Mrs. Bennet's Overjoyed (and Materialistic) Reaction
detailed_summary: Feeling relieved after gaining her father's consent, Elizabeth composes herself before rejoining the family.
The evening passes calmly, the immediate anxieties removed.
Later, Elizabeth follows her mother to her dressing-room to share the news.
Mrs. Bennet is initially stunned into speechlessness upon hearing of the engagement.
It takes her several minutes to comprehend the news, despite usually being quick to grasp advantageous prospects.
She gradually recovers, fidgeting, standing up, sitting down, expressing wonder.
Mrs. Bennet erupts in ecstatic exclamations focused entirely on Darcy's wealth and status.
She marvels at how rich and great Elizabeth will be, anticipating jewels, carriages, and pin-money, declaring Jane's match insignificant in comparison.
She expresses immense happiness and abruptly revises her opinion of Darcy, now finding him charming, handsome, and tall.
She asks Elizabeth to apologize to Darcy for her previous dislike and hopes he will forgive her.
She lists the perceived benefits: a house in town, three daughters married, ten thousand a year, feeling overwhelmed with joy.
Elizabeth, relieved her mother approves but glad only she witnessed the outburst, escapes to her room.
Mrs. Bennet quickly follows, still fixated on the fortune ('Ten thousand a year, and very likely more! ’Tis as good as a lord!').
She insists on a special license for the wedding.
She then immediately asks Elizabeth about Darcy's favorite food to prepare it for him the next day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth’s mind was now relieved from a very heavy weight; and, after half an hour’s quiet reflection in her own room, she was able to join the others with tolerable composure.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But, my dearest love, tell me what dish Mr. Darcy is particularly fond of, that I may have it to-morrow.”

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth’s mind was now relieved from a very heavy weight; and, after half an hour’s quiet reflection in her own room, she was able to join the others with tolerable composure. Everything was too recent for gaiety, but the evening passed tranquilly away; there was no longer anything material to be dreaded, and the comfort of ease and familiarity would come in time.
When her mother went up to her dressing-room at night, she followed her, and made the important communication. Its effect was most extraordinary; for, on first hearing it, Mrs. Bennet sat quite still, and unable to utter a syllable. Nor was it under many, many minutes, that she could comprehend what she heard, though not in general backward to credit what was for the advantage of her family, or that came in the shape of a lover to any of them. She began at length to recover, to fidget about in her chair, get up, sit down again, wonder, and bless herself.
“Good gracious! Lord bless me! only think! dear me! Mr. Darcy! Who would have thought it? And is it really true? Oh, my sweetest Lizzy! how rich and how great you will be! What pin-money, what jewels, what carriages you will have! Jane’s is nothing to it—nothing at all. I am so pleased—so happy. Such a charming man! so handsome! so tall! Oh, my dear Lizzy! pray apologize for my having disliked him so much before. I hope he will overlook it. Dear, dear Lizzy. A house in town! Everything that is charming! Three daughters married! Ten thousand a year! Oh, Lord! what will become of me? I shall go distracted.”
This was enough to prove that her approbation need not be doubted; and Elizabeth, rejoicing that such an effusion was heard only by herself, soon went away. But before she had been three minutes in her own room, her mother followed her.
“My dearest child,” she cried, “I can think of nothing else. Ten thousand a year, and very likely more! ’Tis as good as a lord! And a special licence—you must and shall be married by a special licence. But, my dearest love, tell me what dish Mr. Darcy is particularly fond of, that I may have it to-morrow.”

What pin-money, what jewels, what carriages you will have! Jane's is nothing to it—nothing at all. I am so pleased—so happy. Such a charming man!—so handsome! so tall!—Oh, my dear Lizzy! pray apologise for my having disliked him so much before. I hope he will overlook it. Dear, dear Lizzy. A house in town! Every thing that is charming! Three daughters married! Ten thousand a year! Oh, Lord! What will become of me. I shall go distracted."

```
This was enough to prove that her approbation need not be doubted: and Elizabeth, rejoicing that such an effusion was heard only by herself, soon went away. But before she had been three minutes in her own room, her mother followed her.

"My dearest child," she cried, "I can think of nothing else! Ten thousand a year, and very likely more! 'Tis as good as a Lord! And a special licence. You must and shall be married by a special licence. But my dearest love, tell me what dish Mr. Darcy is particularly fond of, that I may have it tomorrow."

This was a sad omen of what her mother's behaviour to the gentleman himself might be; and Elizabeth found that though in the certain possession of his warmest affection, and secure of her relations' consent, there was still something to be wished for.
```

This segment faithfully reproduces the scene from Chapter 59 of Pride and Prejudice where Elizabeth informs her mother about her engagement to Mr. Darcy, capturing Jane Austen's distinctive narrative voice, period-appropriate dialogue, and the characters' established personalities.

events.title: Aftermath: Concerns and Growing Respect
detailed_summary: Mrs. Bennet's immediate focus on Darcy's culinary preferences makes Elizabeth worry about her future interactions with him.
Elizabeth realizes that despite securing Darcy's love and her family's consent, challenges (like her mother's behavior) remain.
However, the following day proceeds better than anticipated.
Mrs. Bennet is so awestruck by her future son-in-law that she barely speaks to him except to offer polite attentions or show deference.
Elizabeth observes with pleasure that her father is actively trying to get acquainted with Darcy.
Mr. Bennet soon tells Elizabeth that his esteem for Darcy is rapidly increasing.
He concludes by stating his high admiration for all three sons-in-law, playfully suggesting Wickham might be his favorite but expecting to like Darcy just as much as Bingley.

But the morrow passed off much better than she expected; for Mrs. Bennet luckily stood in such awe of her intended son-in-law, that she ventured not to speak to him, unless it was in her power to offer him any attention, or mark her deference for his opinion.
Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing her father taking pains to get acquainted with him; and Mr. Bennet soon assured her that he was rising every hour in his esteem.

events.title: Elizabeth and Darcy Discuss the Origins of His Affection
detailed_summary: Elizabeth, feeling playful, asks Mr. Darcy to explain precisely how and when he began to fall in love with her.
Darcy admits he cannot identify the exact moment, look, or words that sparked his feelings, stating he was deeply involved before he even realized it had begun.
Elizabeth points out that he initially resisted her beauty and that her behavior towards him was often impolite, questioning if he admired her for her 'impertinence'.
Darcy corrects her, saying he admired the 'liveliness of her mind'.
Elizabeth interprets this as impertinence, suggesting Darcy was tired of the insincere deference of other women and was intrigued by her difference.
She credits his inherently good nature for not hating her and suggests he secretly despised those who flattered him.
Elizabeth claims to have saved him the trouble of explaining his feelings and deems his falling in love with her perfectly reasonable, despite acknowledging he knew no 'actual good' of her.
Darcy gently counters, asking if her devoted care for Jane during her illness at Netherfield wasn't a sign of her goodness.
Elizabeth downplays her actions for Jane but playfully accepts Darcy's 'protection' of her good qualities, promising to tease him in return.
She then shifts the questioning, asking why Darcy was so reserved and shy during his recent visits to Longbourn.
Darcy explains her own gravity and silence offered him no encouragement.
Elizabeth admits she was embarrassed, and Darcy confesses he felt the same.
She suggests he could have spoken more during dinner.
Darcy implies his deep feelings made conversation difficult, suggesting someone less emotionally invested could have chatted more easily.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Elizabeth's spirits soon rising to playfulness again, she wanted Mr. Darcy to account for his having ever fallen in love with her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “A man who had felt less might.”

events.text_segment:
Elizabeth's spirits soon rising to playfulness again, she wanted Mr. Darcy to account for his having ever fallen in love with her. “How could you begin?” said she. “I can comprehend your going on charmingly, when you had once made a beginning; but what could set you off in the first place?”
“I cannot fix on the hour, or the spot, or the look, or the words, which laid the foundation. It is too long ago. I was in the middle before I knew that I had begun.”
“My beauty you had early withstood, and as for my manners—my behaviour to you was at least always bordering on the uncivil, and I never spoke to you without rather wishing to give you pain than not. Now, be sincere; did you admire me for my impertinence?”
“For the liveliness of your mind I did.”
“You may as well call it impertinence at once. It was very little less. The fact is, that you were sick of civility, of deference, of officious attention. You were disgusted with the women who were always speaking, and looking, and thinking for your approbation alone. I roused and interested you, because I was so unlike them. Had you not been really amiable you would have hated me for it: but in spite of the pains you took to disguise yourself, your feelings were always noble and just; and in your heart you thoroughly despised the persons who so assiduously courted you. There—I have saved you the trouble of accounting for it; and really, all things considered, I begin to think it perfectly reasonable. To be sure you know no actual good of me—but nobody thinks of that when they fall in love.”
“Was there no good in your affectionate behaviour to Jane, while she was ill at Netherfield?”
“Dearest Jane! who could have done less for her? But make a virtue of it by all means. My good qualities are under your protection, and you are to exaggerate them as much as possible; and, in return, it belongs to me to find occasions for teasing and quarrelling with you as often as may be; and I shall begin directly, by asking you what made you so unwilling to come to the point at last? What made you so shy of me, when you first called, and afterwards dined here? Why, especially, when you called, did you look as if you did not care about me?”
“Because you were grave and silent, and gave me no encouragement.”
“But I was embarrassed.”
“And so was I.”
“You might have talked to me more when you came to dinner.”
“A man who had felt less might.”

events.title: Lady Catherine's Unintended Role in Darcy's Resolve
detailed_summary: Elizabeth laments Darcy having a reasonable explanation for his shyness, admitting she must accept it.
She muses on how long he might have waited to propose if she hadn't initiated the conversation by thanking him for his intervention with Lydia.
She jokingly worries about the 'moral' implications if their happiness resulted from her breaking her promise not to mention Lydia's situation.
Darcy assures her the 'moral' is intact.
He reveals that it was Lady Catherine's misguided efforts to separate them that ultimately resolved his own doubts.
He emphasizes that his current happiness and resolve were not dependent on Elizabeth's expression of gratitude, but rather spurred by the hope Lady Catherine's interference inadvertently gave him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “How unlucky that you should have a reasonable answer to give, and that I should be so reasonable as to admit it!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: My aunt’s intelligence had given me hope, and I was determined at once to know everything.”

events.text_segment:
“How unlucky that you should have a reasonable answer to give, and that I should be so reasonable as to admit it! But I wonder how long you would have gone on, if you had been left to yourself. I wonder when you would have spoken if I had not asked you! My resolution of thanking you for your kindness to Lydia had certainly great effect. Too much, I am afraid; for what becomes of the moral, if our comfort springs from a breach of promise, for I ought not to have mentioned the subject? This will never do.”
“You need not distress yourself. The moral will be perfectly fair. Lady Catherine’s unjustifiable endeavours to separate us were the means of removing all my doubts. I am not indebted for my present happiness to your eager desire of expressing your gratitude. I was not in a humour to wait for an opening of yours. My aunt’s intelligence had given me hope, and I was determined at once to know everything.”

"Lady Catherine has been of infinite use, which ought to make her happy, for she loves to be of use. But tell me, what did you come down to Netherfield for? Was it merely to ride to Longbourn and be embarrassed? or had you intended any more serious consequence?"

events.title: Darcy Reveals His Intentions and Prepares for Announcements
detailed_summary: Elizabeth acknowledges Lady Catherine's accidental helpfulness, noting her love of being useful.
She inquires about Darcy's true reason for coming down to Netherfield, beyond just visiting Longbourn.
Darcy confesses his main objective was to see Elizabeth and gauge whether he had any chance of winning her love.
He adds that his stated purpose, even to himself, was to ascertain if Jane still loved Bingley and, if so, to confess his past interference to Bingley.
Elizabeth playfully asks if Darcy possesses the courage to inform Lady Catherine about their engagement.
Darcy asserts he needs time more than courage, but affirms the necessity of telling her and asks for writing materials to do so immediately.
Elizabeth remarks that she also has a letter to write, alluding to her aunt, Mrs. Gardiner, who requires attention.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Lady Catherine has been of infinite use, which ought to make her happy, for she loves to be of use.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But I have an aunt, too, who must not be longer neglected.”

events.text_segment:
“Lady Catherine has been of infinite use, which ought to make her happy, for she loves to be of use. But tell me, what did you come down to Netherfield for? Was it merely to ride to Longbourn and be embarrassed? or had you intended any more serious consequences?”
“My real purpose was to see you, and to judge, if I could, whether I might ever hope to make you love me. My avowed one, or what I avowed to myself, was to see whether your sister was still partial to Bingley, and if she were, to make the confession to him which I have since made.”
“Shall you ever have courage to announce to Lady Catherine what is to befall her?”
“I am more likely to want time than courage, Elizabeth. But it ought to be done; and if you will give me a sheet of paper it shall be done directly.”
“And if I had not a letter to write myself, I might sit by you, and admire the evenness of your writing, as another young lady once did. But I have an aunt, too, who must not be longer neglected.”

events.title: Elizabeth's Ecstatic Letter to Mrs. Gardiner
detailed_summary: The narrator explains Elizabeth hadn't yet answered Mrs. Gardiner's letter, reluctant previously to admit how wrong she'd been about Darcy's feelings.
Now eager to share her joyous news, she feels slightly guilty her aunt and uncle have missed three days of knowing her happiness and writes immediately.
In the letter, Elizabeth apologizes for her delay, citing she was 'too cross' to write earlier.
She encourages her aunt to fully indulge her imagination about the extent of her relationship with Darcy, stating anything short of actual marriage wouldn't be an exaggeration.
She requests another letter soon, asking for even more praise of Darcy.
Elizabeth expresses gratitude for the Gardiners not going to the Lakes, calling her previous desire for that trip foolish.
She shares her delight about a plan involving ponies for exploring Pemberley's park.
She declares herself the happiest creature alive, surpassing even Jane's quiet happiness with laughter.
She conveys Darcy's regards and extends an invitation for the Gardiners to visit Pemberley at Christmas.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: From an unwillingness to confess how much her intimacy with Mr. Darcy had been overrated, Elizabeth had never yet answered Mrs. Gardiner’s long letter; but now, having that to communicate which she knew would be most welcome, she was almost ashamed to find that her uncle and aunt had already lost three days of happiness, and immediately wrote as follows:—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Yours,” etc.

events.text_segment:
From an unwillingness to confess how much her intimacy with Mr. Darcy had been overrated, Elizabeth had never yet answered Mrs. Gardiner’s long letter; but now, having that to communicate which she knew would be most welcome, she was almost ashamed to find that her uncle and aunt had already lost three days of happiness, and immediately wrote as follows:—
“I would have thanked you before, my dear aunt, as I ought to have done, for your long, kind, satisfactory detail of particulars; but, to say the truth, I was too cross to write. You supposed more than really existed. But now suppose as much as you choose; give a loose to your fancy, indulge your imagination in every possible flight which the subject will afford, and unless you believe me actually married, you cannot greatly err. You must write again very soon, and praise him a great deal more than you did in your last. I thank you again and again, for not going to the Lakes. How could I be so silly as to wish it! Your idea of the ponies is delightful. We will go round the park every day. I am the happiest creature in the world. Perhaps other people have said so before, but no one with such justice. I am happier even than Jane; she only smiles, I laugh. Mr. Darcy sends you all the love in the world that can be spared from me. You are all to come to Pemberley at Christmas. Yours,” etc.

events.title: Family Correspondence: Varied Reactions to the Engagement
detailed_summary: Darcy's letter to Lady Catherine is noted as having a different tone than Elizabeth's.
Mr. Bennet sends a characteristically concise and witty letter to Mr. Collins.
He announces Elizabeth's upcoming marriage to Mr. Darcy.
He advises Collins to offer condolences to Lady Catherine but shrewdly suggests supporting Darcy, the wealthier nephew.
Miss Bingley sends congratulations to her brother on his engagement, described as both affectionate and insincere.
She also writes to Jane, pretending delight and renewing friendship claims.
Jane perceives the insincerity but is still moved and responds kindly.
Miss Darcy's reaction upon receiving the news is genuinely joyful, mirroring her brother's happiness.
Her letter to Elizabeth overflows with delight and eagerness for a sisterly bond, filling four pages.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Darcy’s letter to Lady Catherine was in a different style, and still different from either was what Mr. Bennet sent to Mr. Collins, in return for his last.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Four sides of paper were insufficient to contain all her delight, and all her earnest desire of being loved by her sister.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Darcy’s letter to Lady Catherine was in a different style, and still different from either was what Mr. Bennet sent to Mr. Collins, in return for his last.
“Dear Sir,
“I must trouble you once more for congratulations. Elizabeth will soon be the wife of Mr. Darcy. Console Lady Catherine as well as you can. But, if I were you, I would stand by the nephew. He has more to give.
“Yours sincerely,” etc.
Miss Bingley’s congratulations to her brother on his approaching marriage were all that was affectionate and insincere. She wrote even to Jane on the occasion, to express her delight, and repeat all her former professions of regard. Jane was not deceived, but she was affected; and though feeling no reliance on her, could not help writing her a much kinder answer than she knew was deserved.
The joy which Miss Darcy expressed on receiving similar information was as sincere as her brother’s in sending it. Four sides of paper were insufficient to contain all her delight, and all her earnest desire of being loved by her sister.

The joy which Miss Darcy expressed on receiving similar information, was as sincere as her brother's in sending it. Four sides of paper were insufficient to contain all her delight, and all her earnest desire of being loved by her sister.

Before any answer could arrive from Mr. Collins, or any congratulations to Elizabeth from his wife, the Longbourn family heard that the Collinses were come themselves to Lucas Lodge. The reason of this sudden removal was soon evident. Lady Catherine had been rendered so exceedingly angry by the contents of her nephew's letter, that Charlotte, really rejoicing in the match, was anxious to get away till the storm was blown over. At such a moment, the arrival of her friend was a sincere pleasure to Elizabeth, though in the course of their meetings she must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought, when she saw Mr. Darcy exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of her husband. Mrs. Phillips's vulgarity was another, and perhaps a greater, tax on his forbearance; and though Mrs. Phillips, as well as her sister, stood in too much awe of him to speak with the familiarity which Bingley's good humour encouraged, yet, whenever she did speak, she must be vulgar. events.title: Post-Wedding Adjustments: Mrs. Bennet's Unchanged Nature and Mr. Bennet's Contentment
detailed_summary: Mrs. Bennet experienced immense happiness and pride following the advantageous marriages of Jane and Elizabeth.
Despite achieving her primary goal of seeing her daughters well-settled, Mrs. Bennet did not transform into a more sensible or amiable person, remaining prone to nervousness and silliness.
This lack of change was perhaps fortunate for Mr. Bennet, who might not have enjoyed a drastically altered domestic dynamic.
Mr. Bennet deeply missed Elizabeth's company.
His affection for Elizabeth motivated him to visit Pemberley frequently, often arriving unannounced, which brought him great pleasure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Happy for all her maternal feelings was the day on which Mrs. Bennet got rid of her two most deserving daughters.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He delighted in going to Pemberley, especially when he was least expected.

events.text_segment:
Happy for all her maternal feelings was the day on which Mrs. Bennet got rid of her two most deserving daughters. With what delighted pride she afterwards visited Mrs. Bingley, and talked of Mrs. Darcy, may be guessed. I wish I could say, for the sake of her family, that the accomplishment of her earnest desire in the establishment of so many of her children produced so happy an effect as to make her a sensible, amiable, well-informed woman for the rest of her life; though, perhaps, it was lucky for her husband, who might not have relished domestic felicity in so unusual a form, that she still was occasionally nervous and invariably silly.
Mr. Bennet missed his second daughter exceedingly; his affection for her drew him oftener from home than anything else could do. He delighted in going to Pemberley, especially when he was least expected.

Unlike Lydia, Kitty's temperament was more manageable.

events.title: Wickham and Lydia's Unchanged Characters and Financial Hopes
detailed_summary: The marriages of Jane and Elizabeth did not alter the fundamental characters of Wickham and Lydia.
Wickham accepted stoically that Elizabeth would now be fully aware of his past misconduct towards Darcy.
He still harbored some hope that Darcy might be persuaded to secure his financial future.
Lydia explicitly expressed this hope in a congratulatory letter to Elizabeth upon her marriage.
Lydia's letter wished Elizabeth happiness, comparing her potential love for Darcy to Lydia's own affection for Wickham.
She mentioned the comfort of Elizabeth's new wealth and hoped Elizabeth would consider their needs.
Lydia directly suggested Wickham would appreciate a position at court, implying they needed financial assistance (around three or four hundred pounds a year).
She tentatively added that Elizabeth shouldn't mention it to Darcy if she preferred not to.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As for Wickham and Lydia, their characters suffered no revolution from the marriage of her sisters.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Yours,” etc.

events.text_segment:
As for Wickham and Lydia, their characters suffered no revolution from the marriage of her sisters. He bore with philosophy the conviction that Elizabeth must now become acquainted with whatever of his ingratitude and falsehood had before been unknown to her; and, in spite of everything, was not wholly without hope that Darcy might yet be prevailed on to make his fortune. The congratulatory letter which Elizabeth received from Lydia on her marriage explained to her that, by his wife at least, if not by himself, such a hope was cherished. The letter was to this effect:—
“My dear Lizzy,
“I wish you joy. If you love Mr. Darcy half so well as I do my dear Wickham, you must be very happy. It is a great comfort to have you so rich; and when you have nothing else to do, I hope you will think of us. I am sure Wickham would like a place at court very much; and I do not think we shall have quite money enough to live upon without some help. Any place would do of about three or four hundred a year; but, however, do not speak to Mr. Darcy about it, if you had rather not.
“Yours,” etc.

events.title: Elizabeth's Response and the Wickhams' Continued Instability
detailed_summary: Elizabeth firmly discouraged Lydia's requests for financial intervention from Darcy in her reply.
However, Elizabeth did provide occasional financial help to the Wickhams by economizing on her personal spending.
She recognized that their income was insufficient given their extravagant habits and lack of foresight.
Whenever the Wickhams relocated, they inevitably asked Jane or Elizabeth for money to settle their debts.
Their lifestyle remained extremely unstable, characterized by constant moves seeking cheaper lodgings while consistently overspending.
Wickham's affection for Lydia faded into indifference, although hers persisted slightly longer.
Lydia maintained the social standing afforded by her marriage, despite her youth and behavior.
Darcy, unable to welcome Wickham to Pemberley, still offered professional assistance for Elizabeth's sake.
Lydia sometimes visited Pemberley alone while Wickham was away.
The Wickhams frequently overstayed their visits with the Bingleys, eventually straining even Bingley's patience to the point where he considered asking them to leave.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As it happened that Elizabeth had much rather not, she endeavoured in her answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Though Darcy could never receive him at Pemberley, yet, for Elizabeth’s sake, he assisted him further in his profession. Lydia was occasionally a visitor there, when her husband was gone to enjoy himself in London or Bath; and with the Bingleys they both of them frequently stayed so long, that even Bingley’s good-humour was overcome, and he proceeded so far as to talk of giving them a hint to be gone.

events.text_segment: As it happened that Elizabeth had much rather not, she endeavoured in her answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind. Such relief, however, as it was in her power to afford, by the practice of what might be called economy in her own private expenses, she frequently sent them. It had always been evident to her that such an income as theirs, under the direction of two persons so extravagant in their wants, and heedless of the future, must be very insufficient to their support; and whenever they changed their quarters, either Jane or herself were sure of being applied to for some little assistance towards discharging their bills. Their manner of living, even when the restoration of peace dismissed them to a home, was unsettled in the extreme. They were always moving from place to place in quest of a cheap situation, and always spending more than they ought. His affection for her soon sunk into indifference: hers lasted a little longer; and, in spite of her youth and her manners, she retained all the claims to reputation which her marriage had given her. Though Darcy could never receive him at Pemberley, yet, for Elizabeth’s sake, he assisted him further in his profession. Lydia was occasionally a visitor there, when her husband was gone to enjoy himself in London or Bath; and with the Bingleys they both of them frequently stayed so long, that even Bingley’s good-humour was overcome, and he proceeded so far as to talk of giving them a hint to be gone.

events.title: Miss Bingley's Pragmatic Acceptance of Darcy's Marriage
detailed_summary: Miss Bingley felt intense humiliation due to Darcy's marriage to Elizabeth.
Strategically deciding it was best to maintain access to Pemberley, she suppressed her negative feelings.
She increased her displays of affection towards Georgiana.
She maintained her attentive behavior towards Darcy.
She made a conscious effort to be polite and civil towards Elizabeth, making up for any past slights.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Miss Bingley was very deeply mortified by Darcy’s marriage; but as she thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley, she dropped all her resentment; was fonder than ever of Georgiana, almost as attentive to Darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility to Elizabeth.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Pemberley was now Georgiana’s home; and the attachment of the sisters was exactly what Darcy had hoped to see.

events.text_segment:
Miss Bingley was very deeply mortified by Darcy’s marriage; but as she thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley, she dropped all her resentment; was fonder than ever of Georgiana, almost as attentive to Darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility to Elizabeth.
Pemberley was now Georgiana’s home; and the attachment of the sisters was exactly what Darcy had hoped to see.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: **text_segment**: Miss Bingley was very deeply mortified by Darcy's marriage; but as she thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley, she dropped all her resentment; was fonder than ever of Georgiana, almost as attentive to Darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility to Elizabeth. Pemberley was now Georgiana's home; and the attachment of the sisters was exactly what Darcy had hoped to see. They were able to love each other even as well as they intended. Georgiana had the highest opinion in the world of Elizabeth; though at first she often listened with an astonishment bordering on alarm at her lively, sportive, manner of talking to her brother. He, who had always inspired in herself a respect which almost overcame her affection, she now saw the object of open pleasantry. Her mind received knowledge which had never before fallen in her way. By Elizabeth's instructions, she began to comprehend that a woman may take liberties with her husband which a brother will not always allow in a sister more than ten years younger than himself.

events.title: Georgiana's Flourishing Relationship with Elizabeth at Pemberley
detailed_summary: Georgiana resided permanently at Pemberley, and her bond with Elizabeth developed just as Darcy had wished.
The two sisters-in-law grew to love each other sincerely.
Georgiana held Elizabeth in the highest regard.
Initially, Georgiana was surprised, almost alarmed, by Elizabeth's playful and teasing manner when interacting with Darcy.
She observed Elizabeth treating Darcy, whom Georgiana regarded with awe-inspired respect, with open familiarity and humor.
This interaction provided Georgiana with new insights into relationships.

Through Elizabeth's example and guidance, Georgiana started to understand the different dynamics between spouses compared to those between siblings, particularly a much younger sister and her older brother.

events.title: Lady Catherine's Fury and Eventual Reconciliation
detailed_summary: Lady Catherine reacted to Darcy's marriage with extreme anger.
True to her blunt nature, her response to the news was filled with harsh insults directed at both Darcy and especially Elizabeth.
This resulted in a complete breakdown of communication between them for a period.
Eventually, Elizabeth convinced Darcy to forgive his aunt's offensive behavior and attempt reconciliation.
After some initial reluctance, Lady Catherine's anger subsided, possibly due to lingering affection for Darcy or sheer curiosity about Elizabeth's conduct as mistress of Pemberley.

She ultimately condescended to visit them at Pemberley, despite her disapproval of Elizabeth and the perceived 'pollution' caused by the presence of Elizabeth's relations from Cheapside (the Gardiners).

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Lady Catherine was extremely indignant on the marriage of her nephew; and as she gave way to all the genuine frankness of her character, in her reply to the letter which announced its arrangement, she sent him language so very abusive, especially of Elizabeth, that for some time all intercourse was at an end.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But at length, by Elizabeth’s persuasion, he was prevailed on to overlook the offence, and seek a reconciliation; and, after a little further resistance on the part of his aunt, her resentment gave way, either to her affection for him, or her curiosity to see how his wife conducted herself; and she condescended to wait on them at Pemberley, in spite of that pollution which its woods had received, not merely from the presence of such a mistress, but the visits of her uncle and aunt from the city.

events.text_segment: Lady Catherine was extremely indignant on the marriage of her nephew; and as she gave way to all the genuine frankness of her character, in her reply to the letter which announced its arrangement, she sent him language so very abusive, especially of Elizabeth, that for some time all intercourse was at an end. But at length, by Elizabeth’s persuasion, he was prevailed on to overlook the offence, and seek a reconciliation; and, after a little further resistance on the part of his aunt, her resentment gave way, either to her affection for him, or her curiosity to see how his wife conducted herself; and she condescended to wait on them at Pemberley, in spite of that pollution which its woods had received, not merely from the presence of such a mistress, but the visits of her uncle and aunt from the city.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**: Lady Catherine was extremely indignant on the marriage of her nephew; and as she gave way to all the genuine frankness of her character, in her reply to the letter which announced its arrangement, she sent him language so very abusive, especially of Elizabeth, that for some time all intercourse was at an end. But at length, by Elizabeth's persuasion, he was prevailed on to overlook the offence, and seek a reconciliation; and, after a little further resistance on the part of his aunt, her resentment gave way, either to her affection for him, or her curiosity to see how his wife conducted herself; and she condescended to wait on them at Pemberley, in spite of that pollution which its woods had received, not merely from the presence of such a mistress, but the visits of her uncle and aunt from the city.

With the Gardiners, they were always on the most intimate terms. Darcy, as well as Elizabeth, really loved them; and they were both ever sensible of the warmest gratitude towards the persons who, by bringing her into Derbyshire, had been the means of uniting them.

events.title: Enduring Gratitude and Closeness with the Gardiners
detailed_summary: The Darcys maintained a consistently close and intimate relationship with Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner.
Both Darcy and Elizabeth held genuine affection for the Gardiners.

They both felt deep and lasting gratitude towards them, recognizing that the Gardiners' invitation for Elizabeth to travel with them to Derbyshire was the pivotal event that ultimately led to Darcy and Elizabeth's union.
